From here on clear weather days, sunrise and sunsets are very beautiful. The main front steps leading to this temple have exactly 365 steps marking the number days in a year! Also one must be careful not to try to touch or offer hand outs to the monkeys as they could get quite aggressive with visitors and pilgrims!

Step it up . Water will help the step up to the top. Brilliant views all the way to the top... Small stalls along the way can break up the heat. It's well worth allowing enough time to walk through the temples and shops and take in the view.

Crowded in a feisty day, with a view. Obviously enough, to be here the day of Buddha’s birthday is not the best time to enjoy the otherwise peaceful inner courtyard of this temple, as you need to queue up even if you simply wish to turn the small prayer wheels. You can anyway enjoy a commanding view of Kathmandu, and appreciate the otherwise difficult to perceive size of the city. The temple and its ground look recently renovated, and have suffered noticeably little from the earthquake. I felt that the place hadn’t the religious flair of Bouddhanath, looked more like a strolling destinations for city dwellers wanting to escape the traffic.

Best of views. This temple, sometimes called the monkey temple, is well above Kathmandu, and provides a great platform for pictures of the city, for this reason I give it a four. On the negative side, it can be really busy with tourists, and is pretty commercial, although a couple of the shops had good artistic stone engraving that you could see taking place.

Nice place to visit. The place is higher than than the Katmandu city. So you can have a nice panoramic view of the Katmandu city. Enjoy the temples including the lively monkeys. But be ware of them as they sometimes snatches items from you.

A busy tourist spot. It was super busy! I climbed up there in the afternoon and was overwhelmed with so many tourists on the top. It is understandable since the monkey temple is listed as one of the top visit places in Kathmandu. The climb was fun but might be a bit hard for the elderly. My advice is: pick a day with clear sky to visit as you can see the whole city from above better, this can be difficult as Kathmandu is polluted and gloomy most of the times.

Nice view of Katmandu city and The sacred place. The temple which high step of stairs that let you see beautiful view of Kathmandu city. you can see the big stupa surround by monkey. and people who come to pay respect.
Amazing view of the city in the evening. Whether you are taking the steep steps to the stupa or the easier way from the other side, this place is going to offer you a great view of the vicinity

Nature. Swayambhu temple is located in the heart of kathmandu city where we can see the kathmandu city view from this temple . It was truly god gifted temple with nature . Earthquake damaged some part of temple also . The main attractive thing in Swayambhu temple for me is . . . this monkey

A picturesque view of Kathmandu Valley. If you are looking to seek tranquility in Kathmandu, a visit to Swayambhunath Temple serves the purpose. Located atop a hill, this place also gives you a postcard picture view of the Kathmandu valley.

Monkey Temple. nice morning trip. Most o the site is well preserved. One of the temples up top was destroyed by the earth quake but the main parts of the site are still intact. Go early to see more monkeys. As the day heats up there are less monkeys to be seen. Be a little careful they are not afraid of people. On two separate trips onkeys came up and yanked water bottles out of one of our group members hands.
What a splendid view!. Must visit if you go to Nepal. Head there during the afternoon/evening time. Will be fairly cool and yet warm for those who feel extra chilly.
A must see in KTM . Placed on mountain top, one has to climb good no of stairs but once you reach there is is definitely worth visiting. This is a Old Buddhist temple. Must go for experience same.

Better than i saw it form my room. i saw very beautiful scene of swayambhunath form my room, it was even adorable at the nights. so i visited! it is only the historical property with few damages by the earthquake!
MONKEYS!!!!!. Amazing architecture and beautiful temple but even better there are Monkeys that reside in the area providing entertainment as well

Great views of the Kathmandu city!. I would come here for the views. You can see the city from the top of the temple. At the entrance of the steps, you have to pay 200 rupees at the ticket counter on the left of the steps as you come up. At the top of the temple, there are many monkeys and stalls selling trinkets, souvenirs and other Nepalese/Tibetan crafts. It's a reasonable 10-15 minutes hike of steps up. You can come down from the temple the other way where you can easily catch taxi to other places. If you're planning to go Pashupathi after this temple, please note anything about 400-500 rupees is a rip off.
view point of kathmandu. Mostly known by monkey temple by foreigner. its on a small hill so from the top we can see kathmandu view from all the sides

Scenical temple. Swayambhunath temple is located in a high hill in the city so it is enjoyable to watch all this. Also very popular temple by the locals where is really crowded. There are still quite damages which had remained from the previous earthquake, so constructions still go on. But with its stupas and praying wheels it is deserved to pay a visit.

Must visit stupa in Kathmandu. Swoyambhunath stupa is on the hillock on the western side of Kathmandu overseeing Kathmandu. It is one of the most ancient temples in Kathmandu connected with start of civilisation of Kathmandu and even when Kathmandu valley was a huge lake. Some of the surrounding monasteries and a side temple were destroyed by the earthquake but temple now is open. The temple could be reached either walking all way by walk from eastern side, which is rarely used these days or alternatively drive to the western side and walk for 5-10 minutes which is mostly user route these days. On the way you would find a swimming pool for monkey. During summer, you would see monkeys doing summer slam in the pool. Visiting Kathmandu cannot be complete without visiting this world heritage site which is the Mecca of Buddhism.

One of Our Favorite Attractions!. This is a beautiful temple. The location overlooks Kathmandu and has so many things to see, including the oldest known statue of Buddha (7th Century). Monkeys are everywhere, but they are very used to the tourists and leave you alone.It is a wonderful place to see and should not be missed
Returned multiple times. One of my magic travel places. Always a joy to watch the glowing temple come to life as the sun sets over the city. I love it.
BEAUTIFUL TEMPLE BUDDHISM!!!. It is essential temple to visite once time in Kathmandu. It is a buddhism temple with many pilgrims around there. Impressive!!!
Great piece of people's faith. I was thrilled to be there and seeing the faith of the people in the monument. All were overwhelmed with joy and happiness.

Great monument and a nice view of kathmandu valley. This is on top of a small hill just outside of Kathmandu and very beautiful monument. But the place is heavily infested by hawker and craft sellers. From the top you get a nice view of the kathmandu valley and please read the history of the place - you will find more interest.

Good place to visit if you have some in Kathmandu. We had spare half a day and decided to visit this temple. It is like 45 minute walk from Thamel or 10 minutes by taxi and 200 Rupees ($2) one way. It is also called as Monkey temple. As the name suggests, there are quite a few monkey wandering around this temple. You also get a complete view of Kathmandu city. Lots of stairs to climb if you start from front side of temple but much less steps to climb from back side of the temple.
Still beautiful. It has not changeg greatly in the 40 years since I was last there. Still beautiful. Still lots of monkeys

Panoramic views of Kathmandu Valley. Swayambhunath Temple is a Buddhist Shrine with universal following in Kathmandu. Built on a hill the place affords a panoramic view of Kathmandu Valley. We were informed that all schools in the area without exception plan an excursion for their students before certificate level examinations to seek blessings of the resident deity for a good result. Apart from the shrine the place has several shops selling local curios and souvenirs. Local artists display paintings of panoramic Himalayan vistas but I found the quoted prices to be on the steeper side.
Buddhist and Hindu mix.. Can get there by public transport from Ratna Park. Bit of a climb to reach site, but worth the effort to see this mix of Hindu and Buddhist.

A place you must not miss in Kathmandu. Sawambhu is Buddhist temple. Despite this the place is attractive to all kinds of people as it is a peaceful, elevated and centrally located place in Kathmandu. One can see almost all parts of Kathmandu as it is in the tip of the hill. You can find here both Nepali and Tibetan culture. Restaurants are around, you may enjoy local as well as Tibetan recipes. There are schools teaching for Buddhism. You may interact with Buddhist Gurus and students. If you want to make your interaction with them more fruitful, would be nice you go with a little reading on Buddhism.

Buddha sees all !. Loved this place. The temple is gorgeous and there is so much culture and history to absorb. The views are beautiful but the haze does limit it to some degree. Make sure you get a guide so they can explain in detail to you about the Temple and its surroundings.

Well worth a visit. Amongst all the various Stupas we saw in Kathmandu, this was one of the best, not only for its history but also for the view you get of the city from the hill where it is located. Unfortunately whilst we were there it was raining but the view was still impressive. Thee are lots of monkeys at the top of the hill, they don't bother you but these together with a number of roaming dogs meant that there was a lot of mess as they scavenged everything they could get their hands on.

Swayambhunath. I couldn't come to Kathmandu and not spend a few hours at Swayambhunath. This place could be considered quite touristy but it's still an amazing, spiritual and deeply atmospheric place. Given the height of this temple there should be good views of Kathmandu but whenever I've been here it's normally quite hazy. There is a quite a steep walk from street level to the top but on the way you come across lots of monkeys playing amongst the trees and monuments on the way.There are so many great photo opportunities here too.I was here in 1999 and again in 2015 (just before the earthquake) and it hadn't changed a bit.

Very atmospheric and evocative place. Beautiful view of Kathmandu valley. One of the best locations in Kathmandu - or should I say the best. Though Durbar square is beautiful and so is Pashupatinath, Swayambhunath easily walks away with top honours. The climb up the dizzying flight of stairs reveals a birds eye view of Kathmandu. The temple complex itself is amazing, containing a microcosm of Kathmandu. The architecture and sculpture is amazing. Unlike Pashupatinath you can take pictures everywhere and marvel at the wonderful wood and brass carvings. Easily possible to spend an entire day enjoying the views and the atmosphere. Dont miss at any cost

Monkey Temple. swayambhunath Temple called monkey temple also that is so nice temple we can see kathmandu Valley from there and so many monkeys everywhere thatswhy called monkey temple i like that because from there we can see all kathmandu Valley.
A living temple. A great place to visit. Friendly people, nice gardens, great views of Kathmandu, wild monkeys. An earthquake damage still visible.

Excellent views of Kathmandu from the top. It's worth heading up to the top as it's one of the highest points in Kathmandu so offers unspoilt views out over the city. One of the iconic sites everyone must visit on a trip to Kathmandu. I have a mild form of Cerebral Palsy and can be a bit unsteady on stairs without handrails so took the West entrance rather than 310 steep steps of the East entrance, and it was definitely manageable for me - though someone with more severe mobility problems may struggle. Wheelchair users would find it impossible.

A Must Visit Place in Kathmandu!. I was not expecting to see much when planning my visit to Kathmandu as I heard that this is the worst time to visit Nepal because of the weather and also there is not much left to see in the capital city after the earthquake. However, I was quite surprised to see what the place still had to offer. I didn't see any visible sign of the earthquake and it was quite what I expected after seeing all the pictures. If you are planning to visit some of the temples in Nepal, do keep this one on your list for sure.

Up on a hill. Beautiful Temple atop a hill, involving climbing lots of steps. From here one gets a panoramic view of Kathmandu valley. The temple reaches up to the sky with its golden crown that can be spotted even from the bottom of the valley.
Lovely temple, worth the climb . You need to climb over 300 steps to reach the temple but certainly worth it. The view of the valley from the temple is also great. A must do if you are in Kathmandu.

Wow. This was first stop on a private tour. The tour guide took me around discussed the history and showed me an art school as well. Limited damage of this temple makes it an excellent place for great photos.

great view and lots of photography. We just arrived from Sydney, it was a bit overwhelming the incense smell, people from many destinations, monkeys stealing food from a family picnic. Lucky we didnt have to walk 365 stairs. There is a carpark at the top. Not much damage from the earthquake.

Beautiful. Swayabbhunath temple is really pretty. It's quite a workout to reach up there. The steep stairs is very scary to me so i always take the other path. But it is very beautiful and there are a lot of monkeys hence the name "Monkey Temple". They are really cute. Little tiny baby monkeys will melt your heart. I'm currently staying nearby the temple so i go there every morning for a walk. I will never get sick of the scenery.

Represent of Nepal. Swayambhunath Temple represent of all Nepal. I recommended for photographer or who's looking for good relief and culture.And from the highest you can see the urban life of khatmandu valley.
Amazing !. Lovely place to visit ! Monekys everywhere, and the Monastic is simply amazing ! You will enjoy the view from the top and the 365 stairs !

Top 5 in Kathmandu. So close to Thamel the "Monkey Temple" is a must see.Largely intact post the EQ it is within walking distance from Thamel or a short taxi ride, all the taxi drivers know we're it is and if you chose this option you should pay about half the asking price.The Stupa is in good condition and gives you that great photo of the "all seeing eyes" especially as Bodhnath looks likely to be under scaffolding for most if not all of 2016.The monkey risk is real they will leave you alone as long as you have no food, that said you also need to watch your water bottles and be aware of your back packs.The taxis from the top ask for more so when you are finished walk back down the stair to the main road where they are more reasonable.

Wisdom Eyes of Buddha. Right in the main shopping district, you might stumble onto this square. Take a moment and enter the temple and view some Thanka art. The seeing eyes, wisdom eyes of Buddha will capture your attention as you enter.
A must see!. We saw monkey temple twice during our visit to Nepal. Plenty of monkeys (watch your food around them!), and a beautiful scenic view of Kathmandu.

Fascinating. An opportunity to see a mix of Hindu and Buddhist religion together. Well worth a visit although you won't think so until you've recovered from climbing the steps - and I'm not exaggerating!

A very steep climb. Be prepared for the many ,many steps upto the temple.
If you give to one of the temple beggers, you will be approached by many mote
SPECIAL!. Very little earthquake damage. Visit late afternoon/early evening and capture some unforgettable photographs.

Splendid place with the combination of Hindu and Buddhist.. it is really really a nice place to be. I found it is also called as monkey temple as here we have seen many monkeys. This place includes the temple of Goddess Harati who is equally worshiped by Hindu and Buddhist.What a harmony... from here you can see a nice view of Kathmandu Valley too. Highly recommended to visit this place.

Worth the hike - but watch out!. It's possible to walk to Swayambhunath from Thamel, and worth it to see more of Kathmandu than the tourist traps! The "monkey temple" deserves its English nickname- starting at the base, there are monkeys everywhere. It is best not to bring any food or drinks- these bold monkeys will attack if you have something they want. One friend wasn't gripping his soda bottle tightly enough, and a monkey pulled it out of his hands and bit through the plastic to get a drink. My husband had a monkey climbing up his legs and grabbing him trying to steal a water bottle. Monkeys aside, also beware of the many touts crawling all over the base and steps, who will try trick you into paying for a tour. If you can avoid these two hazards, it's worth the walk up the hundred of steps to see the beautiful stupa. There is earthquake damage, but also a lot of repair work being done. If a yellow haze of pollution wasn't permanently hanging over Kathmandu, there would probably be nice views over the city. This site costs about Rs.800 LESS than walking through Durbar Square and is far more beautiful and interesting.

Loved it. A very enjoyable morning walking around and taking in the views! Fantastic place. I also purchased some local art at very affordable prices- cheaper than Thamel! A nice bonus to end a lovely day

Beautiful, with a wide view and a nice breeze. You can eather start at the point where a Taxi drops you and you just walk up some steps, or you take the "advanced-travellers-side" where you will be dropped off down at the foot of many, many steps.I still prefer this side, because you walk past Monkeys, big Buddha Statues and have a more holy and spiritual feeling when you reach the peak directly at the big Stupa and feel the breeze on your sweaty body.You have to pay an entrance fee of 200 rp, but it is totally worth it.You can walk clockwise around the Stupa, buy some necklaces, walk further down to the bond where another Buddha stands inside a pond, and you can throw some coins on it to get good luck and Karma. The area is wide spread, you can enjoy the beautiful view over Kathmandu and surely spend more then one and a half hours there!I've been there 2 times and I still think it's a lovely place to visit even more than once.

Earthquake rebuild. This was badly effected by the earthquake.After walking all those stairs you are confronted with major destruction ...like most sacred sites it looks like a team of volunteers are doing most of the work.However it is still worth making the effort to get their / climb the steps and enjoy the view and religious significance

Incredible experience with monkeys. This temple knows as Monkey temple too, you are in direct contact with crazy monkyes, part of them were nasty, but anyway definitely this is one of the TOP attractions of Kathmandu.

Loved it!. Went here the day after I arrived in Kathmandu. We walked from Thamel and were really immersed in all the sights, sounds, and smells quickly! Be prepared to walk up alot of steps, it was quite hot the day we went so make sure you have water with you. Take your time once you reach the top and really soak it all in. The views are amazing and the monkeys love photobombing lol! A must see while here!

A good place to visit in the morning. Visited the Swayambhunath temple mid May.Early in the morning is better as it is not too busy or hot.I spent about 1 hour in the temple. Plenty of taxis.I was about 35 minutes walk from the temple so I took a taxi there about 350 and walked back.

Swayambhunath Temple. Booked the trip with a local driver and visited the Swaysmbhunath Temple. Great trip got to see the culture of Nepal and learn local tourism.Best to gets guide who can fast track you through the queues otherwise you'll be there for a while.

A must visit. A must visit when in Kathmandu . There is a climb of a lot of steps but once you reach the top the climb becomes worth it. It is really ancient and the view of Kathmandu from the top is breathtaking

Great view, not so great people. the locals have taken full advantage of this temple being a tourist spot and try to get you to part with your money at EVERY opportunity. I was cursed at aggressively for politely declining a tour and teaching of their rituals at the top by a "guide".The monkeys can be quite entertaining too.

special, but still very much damanged. The temple is beautiful and intensively used by Nepali and Tibetan worshippers. Views are beautiful if the sky is clear. The stairs can be taken by anyone in good health. But if not, one can come close by taxi. The commercial aspect is very much present and that is a mixed blessing. But the real downside is the fact that the buildings where monks chant and pray were destroyed by the 2015 earthquake and reconstruction has not even started...

Beautiful heritage with a beautiful view of the valley. The Swayambhu Stupa shows the heritage of this country in a very beautiful way. The location also gives one of the most beautiful views of the Kathmandu Valley.

Worth a stop. Has been damaged by earthquake over a year ago and is in process of restoration. Several ways to get up including stairs and another that gets you closer to top then you walk. Lots of monkeys here. Good views. Hindu offerings at top as well.
Nice Group of Temples Overlooking Kathmandu Valley. Visited Swayambhunath in May. The weather and views of Kathmandu were nice. Highly recommend when visiting Kathmandu.

Day trip. Visited by myself during my stay in Kathmandu. Walked to temple from Thamel region. Was easy enough to find and walking route to temple takes you through some interesting streets and past some good view points. Temple is currently being repaired but even more reason to view it and support its renovation. Worth the steps and nice view of the city from the top. Nice to just rest at top and take in scenery and architecture/designs. There is a cafe that, although appears not fully functioning due to damage, still serves cold drinks so nice to enjoy a break. Beautiful location, worth a visit.

Entertaining and interesting. This was my second visit to Monkey Temple and it did not disappoint. My friend insisted on walking there. I say take a tuk tuk or taxi. The walk there is pure chaos, but the monkeys are entertaining and this temple is very photogenic, which I haven't found most monuments in Kathmandu to be. There was some earthquake damage, but it looks like repairs have started. Ignore the supposed guides at the bottom of the stairs and don't pet the dogs no matter how cute. Fee is only 200 rupees for foreigners. Well worth a visit.

Swayambhu, meaning "Self-Created". Swayambhunath is also known as the Monkey Temple as there are holy monkeys living in the north-west parts of the temple. They are holy because Manjushri, the bodhisattva of wisdom and learning was raising the hill which the Swayambhunath Temple stands on. He was supposed to leave his hair short but he made it grow long and head lice grew. It is said that the head lice transformed into these monkeys.
I love this place. Good place for shopping, haggling.Great place to people watch and generally enjoy at your own place. Get off the beaten track in Thamel as every st offers something different.
Valley gaze. One of the best spot to gaze over Kathmandu valley.The evening time its more nice to have a view over valley with cool air
Best attraction in Kathmandu 🙈. A beautiful temple, packed with monkeys with nice panorama of the city Touristically speaking, for me, it can't get much better than that. Definitely recommended.

perfectly made. to reach this beautiful temple. we climbed 365 steps..i was quite tiring, me and my 2 other friend need make few stops whiling going up the steps:) and we didnt have water with us( kindly please bring at lease a bottle of water to hydrate yourself). but as we reached up, we forgot about tiredness,,, because the temple is really beautiful plus we went there during evening, the sun shined on the temple even made it alive. and the statues are made out of beautiful stones, perfectly curved.and if u are lucky enough,, u could see monkeys running around. so be careful with your stuffs:) the view from the temple is really beautiful, we could see almost the whole kathmandu city if its not hazzy.there are few mini shops up there that sells sourvinies too and they are antique and beautful. im truely amaized with the curvings which was perfectly done really long ago and still perfectly strong till now. a great place to visit in kathmandu city. i truely love nepal.

Fascinating temple. Large grounds with a 200rp entrance fee for foreigners. Definitely worth a visit while you're in Kathmandu. Easy walk from Thamel and the 365 stairs up to the top help burn off all the curries!

A Beautiful Heritage. A nice place to visit when you are in the Kathmandu Valley. You get nice view of the entire city. One can shop here for a lot of junk jewellry, stamps coins and and many more items. The interiors of the temple is beautifully carved.

Beautiful and peaceful place in Kathmandu!. If you have got some time then give it a visit as this place is amazing and will make your holiday more than beautiful. You can have a beautiful views of the whole Kathmandu valley from the top of this temple. If you have a tour guide then he will tell you many information that you won't get on your own.Truly an experience!

Perfect view from above !. The temple or stupa is at a good height. You have to walk 365 steps or there is another way for cars also. You can find many tourists coming there. There are lots of Monkeys in the whole premises. There is a place where you can have a view of the valley with binoculars.
Tawer . Looks view tawer in Kathmandu you may able to see all belly from their nice small budish Muslim same thing good like artists
Excellent view of Kathmandu skyline. Nothing much to see here except for monkeys and the famous stupa, but the view of Kathmandu's "skyline" from the top is worth the climb.

ONE OF THE BEST SITE IN KATHMANDU. In Kathmandu there is nothing much which tourist can see or like except the damaged buildings broken roads devastated city by earth quake. The negligence of Government, may be they don't want to repair anything the most famous river of Nepal resembles to some sever drain full of filth. But exception if any are just few places and this one is the one. This Buddha Temple dated back many hundreds or thousands years situated at a hill top is a beautiful place and is worth seeing. All the travelers visiting Kathmandu must visit this site. They say this place is also home of over 3000 monkeys and locals call it Monkey Temple. Some beautiful old things statues are situated there. Must not miss visiting this site.

View of Kathmandu. This temple provides a very good view of the kathmandu city. in order to reach here, you'll have to walk a lot since it is almost at the end of the city, especially if you are coming from thamel
Interesting place. Known as Monkey templeLots of monkeys and interesting place to see in KMTBe aware of 365 stairs to climb but worth visiting

Everyone Should Visit the Monkey Temple. This is a great temple and is a great place to visit while Boudhanath Stupa is being reconstructed. The monkeys are awesome and the tanka shop, together with the whole artist's coop, is a great place to buy gifts. It took us about an hour to see the sight.

Love it. How i love the arcitechture of all buildings. If you're going to kathmandu for trekking, don't forget to do city tour (you can ask your hotel for the accomodation) to this temple. So beautiful!
Monkey temple. This is what is known as the monkey temple. Lots of interest, views from the hill top, temples, photogenic, shops, great atmosphere with the Buddhist chants being played

A highlight of Kathmandu. I really enjoyed visiting Swayambhunath - aka Monkey Temple (aptly named due to the high number of monkeys dotted about the place). The views of the city sprawl from the top of the Temple are fantastic and there is a really interesting mix of Buddhist and Hindu sites on display. As other reviewers have noted, if you don't feel like the long walk up the many steps, you can get quite close to the top via a road. I can see why others mention that it feels a little too commercial with street vendors, but I just enjoyed wandering around looking at the variety of architectural styles. The monkeys were not a pest.

Nice but not spiritual. All reviews are filtered through the cultural sense of he reviewer so my take on this place is biased but the trash, and souvenir stands right against the temples takes away from the experience for me. It is worth visiting and I found the areas away from the main tower to be more peaceful. Definitely approach up the long staircase and not the car park.

Great view on Kathmandu!. The main reason you I visit this place was a great view on Kathmandu! But also it is a peaceful Buddhist place with a lot of monkeys and unfortunately tourists when I was there. But still everyone who travel to Kathmandu have to visit Monkey Temple!

Nice Temple, Monkeys don't attack you like other countries. We are always a little hesitant about visiting places with monkeys and lots of tourists. More often than not the monkeys realise that they can get away with stealing whatever they like from you and unless you're willing to fight a monkey the monkey usually wins.This wasn't the case here. The monkeys are all really placid and the temple is quite beautiful. It was hazy weather when we were here so we couldn't see very much from the top but it was still a nice walk up the steps with some interesting market stalls at the top. We came here around mid-day and it was fine but I think for the best experience you would be better coming for Sunrise or Sunset.

Nice but building work. It was nice to visit, but at the time we were there they did some building. Because of that we could not look at all things. But what we saw was beautiful. Especially the monkeys everywhere.Watch out!! There are some men in special dresses. They want money for a picture!! ;-)

365 steps to the top of Kathmandu!. At the bottom you have people touting to be your guide. I preferred not to have one. So I walked up, along the steps are vendors selling all sorts of memorabilia, there are more stores at the top so I wouldn't buy anything on the way up. About 10 stairs from the top is the booth to pay the entrance fee. This costs about 200 rupees. At the top there are amazing views across Kathmandu, a lot of monkeys, people praying and prayer wheels. There are more guides at the top vying for your business and if you are interested in the history of the place it would be worth getting one. If you go on your own or without a guide you are more likely to be bothered a lot more by people trying to sell you stuff. If you have a guide then once you have one you will be bothered a lot less. The place is definitely well worth a visit. I spent about 30 mins at the top without a guide and without buying anything, but you could spend a couple of hours up there with one and perusing the stores. This is a must visit location if you have a couple of days in Kathmandu!

Pretty touristy. More shops than temple!. I felt a bit let down by this to be honest. It's a long slog to get up the steps. The 200 Rps entrance fee is modest and OK. But once you conquer the steps it seems to be more about selling prayer flags, masks and t-shirts rather than about the temple and all that it stands for. I would have preferred to spend more time in Pathan.

Well worth the Visit, with many facets to appreciate.. Monkey temple as its known has many reasons to visit. For those tempted to go on a trek, the stairs up to it will test your breathing, but the reality is that there is quite a bit happening around the lower steps to hold your attention, with people praying, or spinning the prayer wheels. At the top the configuration and aesthetic appeal of the main structure is certainly entrancing. But more than this it is the reverence and homage paid by most of the visitors that really makes it. It is not just a place for tourists, although by the amount of tourist goods being sold around it, you could be mistaken. One note however, we went in April just before the monsoon and the pollution in the air was truely unbelievable making what should have been amazing views, virtually impossible. Going in Sept -Oct when air hasbeen "cleaned" would provide a better vista.
height temple. a bit walk on height arrives the Swayambhunath surrounding many small temple,from here can view kathmandu valley.

Must See. İf you dont want to climb 365 stairs there is an alternatife! try the car road around the hill from the south leading to the southwest entrance and go down the steps.Sunset time is very beautifull.You will be looking at a huge Katmandu scene from there. Even if the temple is damaged after the earthquake it is still one of the best attractions in Nepal.

As Great as they Say. This was another of my must see places in my life since I was a child. It was a dream come true getting here and was one of my first solo trips. Every time I look back at the pictures I am still amazed at the beauty and the culture.
amazing place. This is best experience i have ever got in my life going with this guys make my tripe worth it truly amazing!!!
Amazing Place. Visited before and after the earthquake and I was surprised that the damage is not worse, although structurally it may be. It is still an absolute must see visit.

Peace is the theme. I have been to this place number of times and each time I go, I like it more. This April when we were in Kathmandu, we went to observe the damage caused by earthquake in 2015 April. I highly recommend this place for people who visit Kathmandu.

Must see in Kathmandu. Worth the visit and entrance fee (200 rupees, ~$2.50). Ensure your driver takes you to the top entrance to save you walking up all the steps.There are tons of monkeys here and it is easy to get pictures with them. Our guide dubbed it the "Monkey Temple"You can buy coins for cheap and toss them into the fountain for good luck. Worth doing for the local touch!
Lovely temple. It is a very beautiful temple. The main temple wasn't damaged by the earth quake but the surrounding area there is some damage. Nevertheless a must visit in Khatmandu

Monkeys and steep stairs. While strenuous activity in Kathmandu always has the drawback of making you breathe in more of the polluted air, getting some exercise climbing the steep stairs is a nice prelude to hanging out with monkeys at the top. Spectacular views of Kathmandu (when there's not too much smogs) and plenty to see. Food is available everywhere.

Great temple on the top of Kathmandu city. Going up to the temple maybe a bit tiring due to many stairs to go up. But once you are on the top, you'll get a great view of Kathmandu city. The ornaments and many shops in the temple above may be a great attraction, in addition to some regular rituals of some visitors to pray in the temple. You'll find also monkeys around the stairs below.

My favorite temple in Kathmandu. I spent few hours visiting this temple and enjoyed the little shops and the 365 stairs. It's a must see when in Nepal. I prefer it to Buddhanath. The monkeys along the stairs and around the temple were so entertaining.

A holy place with lots of positive energy. We attended a work shop of sound healing there. There are apox. 400 stairs to climb. Last 70 stairs are very stiff. There is another easier way to get there but we preferred the short cut. The campus is very huge from ground level to the top.Tip: start your trip early in the morning
The monkey temple. Nice walk to the monkey temple. Watch out fot the monkeys... They steal your water bottles, give you the finger and 'll come after you in your sleep...
View tower. You can see the kathmandu valley from here. One of the nice buddhist stupa in Asia. You can many monkeys so it is called monkey temple.
A must see. The "monkey" temple is best viewed in the morning when the view of Kathmandu is clear. Try to go before 10 am when there are less tourists.

My daily dose of adrenaline rush!!!. Also know as monkey temple, this place really is full of monkeys that u better watch out for. I find peace every time I visit this place. As a local tourist its a good place to go get your adrenaline rush in the mornings. The view of the concrete jungle (Kathmandu) from the top is somewhat mesmerizing.

Beautiful place stimulating all the senses, also a place of Peace and Stillness. It was a real pleasure to visit this Temple. Walking up the stairs was a nice way to start the pilgrimage. As I reached the summit all of my senses were welcomed by the physical beauty of the Temple, the smell of incense, the sound of music playing - 'Om Mani Padme Hum', and a gentle breeze that flapped the many lines of prayer flags waving through the air. It was an experience to behold, it was overwhelming for the first several minutes but once I got into the flow of spinning the many prayer wheels and viewing the beautiful Buddhas I was in a nice space of peace.

Go to Monkey temple. This is one of the landmarks of Kathmandu. Spend half-a day there just roaming around. The scenery is nice. The monkeys are plenty, but not seems to be aggressive.Serene place to relax.

Monkey business!. Maybe I'm biased as this was the first site I saw in Nepal, but I found this to be a magical place. Perched atop one of the hills in Kathmandu you are met with a fresh breeze as you ascend to the temple. The history and architecture along the way are fascinating but of course the real attraction is the monkeys, roaming around by the dozen. The temple is a vibrant mix of tourists, vendors, worshippers and the ubiquitous monkeys. Stroll around (in a clockwise direction of course) and drink in the atmosphere.

Watch Out for the Monkeys. The monkeys here are used to people walking up to them. They are not scared of you, you should be scared of them. The site and historic buildings have been kept well. This was before the earthquake. Haven't been back since so not sure if there are any damages.

Very interesting . Very interesting place to visit, but like many places in the area parts of it have been somewhat damaged by the earthquake. There are two entrances, one has a lot more stairs up than the other. There are plenty of monkeys around and many local worshippers if you go on a Saturday.

Beautiful hilltop temple - spiritual place for meditation. People call it monkey temple , to enjoy to fullest extent you have to climb the hill top , if possible or at-least dont use car to climb down. Its great experience on hill top temple, those who have spiritual orientation , can be real great place.

Beware of Monkeys. . I bought 50nrp penuts and planned to share with the monkeys but 2 of them just grap from my hands we had a laugh. Some part of this temple was damaged due to 2015 earthquake still worth the hiking up. I took rishaw from city to here promised 200 but driver begging for 300 so gave him 300. Suggest to take taxi here not rishaw as taxi drop off closer to the entrance. Entrance fee 200. Met prime minister KP Oli seems he was giving a speech for memorial day of 2015 earthquake. Taxi back town 200 nrp.

Monkey temple always an astonishing place, all the people, monkeys, burning lights,stupas, shops. A touristy must. Helpful on the old legs not having to climb all the stairs as inthe past, thanks to road access. Don't have food on you or the monkeys will hassle you.

Enjoy the height. Situation in lovely area before talking the long walk up. If taken slowly not a real problem.If you take a taxi there you can avoid many of the stairs up. The narrow walk ways near the top are littered with souvenir stalls which detracts form the religious aspect somehow, Duly note their are hundreds of less than friendly monkeys fighting with the abundance of dogs so be careful.Worth a great picture of the "eyes" and views over Kathmandu

Unfortunately destroyed by the quake. I knew it was destroyed but I paid and entered anyway hoping that the money will be used towards rebuilding the great monument. Would love to visit again when they are done rebuilding it!

A monkey took my drink. Be careful of the monkeys! This was really cool to see at sunset, should cost 250-300r from Thamel each way in a cab. The site itself costs 200r, but there isn't really a check point, the ticket box is almost at the top of the east stairs.

Must See when you are visting Kathmandu. Entry fee is small. But the experience is huge. I got a taxi to take me up the Hill. There was a lot of young people, modern Nepal youth. Great photo areas. Also has good area's to sit and absorb the atmosphere. The monkeys I saw seemed to be focused on finding treats.

Its a must go place. This is a place which is filled with history, the kind of statues that has is extraordinary. If not for Lumbini this is the place to go, it is very calm, lovely people around, amazing view of the entire nepal valley can be seen from there.Regards,Amith

Nice Temple. Nice temple to visit. I think its worth the 200 Rps entrance fee.How to go from Thamel: taxi for 100-150 or Walk 3km west to Swayambhunath temple (the stupa now got cracks so be careful).Avoid ticket: show up early before the ticket gate is open (i think at 9am). [Some sources say you can visit the monastery at the back of the Swayambhunath complex - wrong, or at least the route is not easy to find. There are 2 entrances both have ticket booths.]Be careful not to show plastic bag or food here: monkey bites may be infected with rabies. Also there is a steep staircase climb to wear flats
Nice. Beautiful view of Kathmandu from the top of the hill. Its possible to go there by foot from Thamel. Looots of stairs to climb.But its worth it.

A good exercise while climbing 300 odd steps.... A good place to visit... you can see entire Kathmandu from the top... You have to climb 300 odd steps but its rewarding...when you will be top you will get panoramic view of entire Kathmandu Valey

Sacred Destination of Kathmandu. When this sanctuary was established around 2,000 years prior, Kathmandu Valley was loaded with an awesome lake. As indicated by Buddhist legend, a solitary flawless lotus developed in the focal point of the lake. At the point when the bodhisattva Manjusri depleted the lake with a slice of his sword, the lotus bloom settled on top of the slope and mysteriously changed into the stupa. Hence it is known as the Self-Created (swayambhu) Stupa. The most punctual composed record of the Swayambunath Stupa's presence is a fifth century stone engraving, yet researchers accept there was likely a hallowed place here as ahead of schedule as the first century. Indeed, even before that, it is likely that animist customs occurred on this slope. Swayambunath is one of Nepal's most seasoned Buddhist sanctuaries and it has an antiquated environment, particularly when one methodologies by walking with the pioneers.

Worth the visit.. This covers quite a large area, and is also known as 'The Monkey Temple', due to many monkey's living there. It is well worth a visit, and spending some time there, there is a bit of a hill, but worth it to see the temples and the views.

Beautiful ancient stupa. This stupa on the hill is one of the oldest in Kathmandu. It's a peaceful and reflective place that I quite enjoyed. You can find some nice city views as well as reasonably price souvenirs. Also there's not much damage from the earthquake.
Great place to get a sense of Nepali Buddhism. We spent about 2 hours at this site, there is a considerable amount of details to observe and watch the locals praying.

Damage after a year by earthquake is still there. Not only from the top of hill but also behind the temple is so peaceful and relaxing.
Do not miss it.

Come on a clear day if you can!. We got a taxi from Thamel (250 rs) and climbed the 400 or so steps. The stupa is undamaged although some of the surrounding buildings are damaged. There was repair work going on to some of them. It was a clear day so we had great views of Kathmandu. The monkeys are cute and don't bother you. A lovely place to visit.
Interesting, but just once. It was first place what i was visiting in KTH. If you are are there don't miss it, but if i'll be back to Nepal i won't go there again.
My favorite tourist attraction. This is a must see for good Karma! You need at least an hour (there are a lot of stairs). Worth the small entry fee.

Amazing, relaxed place. Sadly some of it was damaged in the earthquake, but still a great place to visit. Despite being quite busy the place has a relaxed feel. 250 rupees to enter, not sure if this applies if you go up the stairs?? They don't really check too much on the gates, so you may be able to just walk past. Loads of monkeys, not too tame and not too cheeky. At the top is loads of different interesting things and great views of the Kathmandu valley. You will take a lot of photos. A must see!!!
Fascinating place. Fascinating place, go there un the early morning to enjoy these unique place. Dont miss One of the nicest places in nepal.

Amazing. This place is a must go place when visiting kathmandu. Its also known as monkey temple. Well entrance fee for foreigners is Nep250 rupees which is not expensive at all. This place offers quite nice view of city and their are many temples within it. Due to earthquake happend recently, many parts of Temple is damaged and they are re constructing it (some parts only).

Undamaged and worth the stairs!. I was so happy to see this beautiful stupa undamaged. Beware there are a lot of stairs to get there but it is worth it! Enjoy the monkeys on your way up. At one point the fence on the side of the stairs opens (probably three quarters to the top) on the right into a foresty area and there are SO many monkeys in there!! Worth a peek. Once at the top there is a lovely view of the city and a couple of small temples with the stupa. There used to be cafes there but have sadly closed. Back atthe bottom if you are facing the stairs going upward turn right.. There are a bunch of temples with HUGE prayer wheels you can spin and interesting looking stupas along the way you will see them if you walk this way for a couple minutes. Unfortunately boudhanath was virtually destroyed and I enjoyed this much more

Very cute monkeys. The monkeys were the best part of our visit to this temple. They are everywhere and so cute. I was a little overwhelmed by the vendors trying very hard to sell us their goods at every turn. In my view it took away from the spirituality of this landmark.

must see in Kathmandu, Swayambhunath Temple. Swayambhunath is everything you would expect to experience in exotic Nepal ... monks, monkeys, and historical ancient architecture and cultural time-traveling in Southeast Asia.It is currently under restoration, due to extensive damage from the 2015 earthquakes in April and May. Despite the areas that are being rebuilt, it remains an experience not to be missed.

Budham sharnam Gchami. Swayambhunath is an ancient religious architecture atop a hill in the Kathmandu Valley, west of Kathmandu city.But the earthquake changed the scene u will find crack every where. Expect Nepali Outsider need buy visiting ticket.

Great views of the city!. It's within walking distance from Thamel, but almost all uphill on the way there!Great views from the top, but would have been even better on a clear day (if that ever happens).

Interesting visit. Worth a visit. It is very atmospheric. The walk up to the top is very steep. If you don't like monkeys then this is not the place for you as they are monkeys everywhere. But great views of Kathmandu...on a clear day...

Monkeys + Buddha + Amazing View at the Capital = a Must See. This temple is something you should now miss if in Kathmandu. Not just because of cute monkeys all over the place, but also for the souvenirs, jewellery, scenery, breathtaking view at the city, small temples every here and there, smiling locals selling you their handicrafts, fresh air, look at the Himalayas...

The Peace Eyes. The swayambhunath temple which is also locally known as the monkey temple is the one of the most attractive tourist destion in kathmandu. once if you visit this place you would love to go there more and more. The temple is 385 stairs up in the hill. also the surrounding area of temple is very peaceful and beautiful to visit. you can see many stupas and lamas in this place. it is also listed by the unesco as the world heritage sites. You have to visit once you are in Nepal. The peace eyes is really beautiful. And it has not much damage from earthquake so its still beautiful as it used to be.Strongly recommended.

Standing Still........ Its exactly one year since massive devastating earthquake hit Nepal. As a local resident of the valley I am reviewing the temple to give current knowledge to the readers after one year completion of the earthquake. Many buildings including monuments were damaged/destroyed in kathmandu valley and its surroundings. Swayambhunath Temple though stand still however few portions of the area were totally damaged. Out of 4 Chaitas that surrounds the main temple, one is also damaged totally pic for which is also attached. Northern side temple is also damaged and hence keep their Statue of Buddha outside temporarily. Nevertheless, the place is still recommended to visit as you can see the aftermath effects of earthquake and yet can see the main Temple which still standing at the center of the area.

Beautiful. The temple has only small amounts of damage from last year's earthquake and is still as impressive as ever. The stairs up the front are an experience in themselves and the view from the top over the city amazing. The site takes around an hour to walk around slowly and enjoy the sights. The monkeys are cool and add to the atmosphere but don't get too close to the ones with young or they will lash at you with claws and teeth.

Buddha eyes at Swayambhunath Temple in Kathmandu. Also known as monkey temple, the temple is right in the heart of the city, approximately 2.5-3 kms from Thamel. The temple is approachable through road from its west side. Situated on the top of a hill, Buddha eyes with a question mark seem to be watching Kathmandu from up there. I went to this place in the afternoon of the mid of April and the weather was pleasant with a nice cool breeze blowing in the evening. One needs to be careful with the monkeys. With the Stupas, Buddha eyes, prayer wheels and prayer flags all around this place, it looks quite spiritually majestic on the top of the hill.
Great views and an impressive temple. Nice view, worth the steps and the 200 rupees entry fee, not too many beggars or hawkers, mostly it's the monkeys to watch out for if you have any food.

Nice afternoon visit. We walked up the many many many steps to the top of the stupa. It's half the fun as you feel a sense of achievement at the top. I recommend taking g some water for the journey but keep your belongings well secured as we saw some monkeys stealing from people who were less careful. The stupa was beautiful and the views of kathmandu are incredible. A visit to this city isn't complete without seeing this place. There's also a little shop to the left back corner that has refrigerated water for 40rp which was a blessing!!

Must visit while in Kathmandu!!! . The views are spectacular ! Go super early if you really want to get a shot (not guaranteed w haze) of the Himalayas.. say 6 am or even 5.If you go on a Local holiday, which there are a lot, expect tons of people--which isn't necessarily a minus if you like to people watch, see local color or traditions.... :-) But if you want a quiet prayer and meditation in this sacred place and a crack at seeing the mountains --go as early as you possibly can!
Day Trip. Interesting area to bust. Very sad to see the devastation caused by the earthquake in 2015 but reassuring to see the reconstruction process taking place

View is spectacular. There were quite some steps to reach the temple but we managed it with taking some breaks and taking some pictures with the sunset.(Would not recommend on a hot day) Few benches are lined up along the stairs. The view is really amazing. On the top the temple is very beautiful. Beautiful idols. a good place for some photography.

what is up with all the vendors. Nepal....wake up! This is a temple. I visited 15 years ago and loved, now its overrun with people selling beads and trinkets. There is a place for this, but not in the actual temple. It seems that Nepal doesn't really care about the tourist experience and just lets people overrun the place.

Lots of Monkey around. This temple got its name because of all the monkey around, and indeed there are lots of them. We had a guide with us and he taught us lots of Hindu mythologies. With that in mind, we have a better understanding of all the structure of the temple. There are also quite a bit of souvenir stores and the guide tried to lead us to certain one and try to sell us something. Just look around in town, there are lots of merchandise with better price.

A great place to visit, go the hard way, up the huge flight of steps!. A great place to visit, go the hard way, up the huge flight of steps! Sadly the eating places have become very poor these days, but the views are great and the architecture and statuary breath taking
Astonishing. This temple is a very good stupa. A lot of monkeys and that are playful. Avoid bringing food to temple as it makes the monkeys very aggressive.

Lots of steps.. I caught a taxi there from Durbar Square for 300NPR.If you are not up for the 365 steps, quite steep, go around to the back. If you are facing the steps, go to the left, the taxi will take you. Around the back is the picture that youmsee with all the flags. Also a wishing pond and a few stalls. Lots of monkeys, if you have food, be careful. Then you can go up about 100 steps to the top. I was quite disappointed at the top as I had already seen many stupas, but if you haven't then you may feel different. I then took the 365 stairs down, which was ok. Taxis at the bottom, remember negotiate price and if you don't feel right about the drover, walk away, always another one.

Mobbed by monkeys!. Actually the monkeys are quite wary of humans. Probably been kicked a few times in the past. Some tourists seem to think it good to give them bottles to drink from. The view of Kathmandu from the top is good on a clear day. The temple hasn't suffered too much from earthquake damage. It is interesting to break away awhile and wander around by yourself and look at the various hidden treasures around.
Nice trip. Very good trip... you can see entire Kathmandu from the top... Good local antiques you can buy... Tibetan arts and Jewels... etc...

Worth a visit. There is an easy climb to the temple and it is worthwhile in that there are numerous interesting things and people to see. Should it be a clear day, the views would likely be good. Don't miss the ' hermit' perched along the stairs waiting to charge a fee to take his picture.
Absolutely needed to visit. A nice place to visit. It was very afecte by the earthquake of last year but not all was fallen and today you can see a great place.

A must visit while in Kathmandu. Swayambhu is one of the temples you must visit in Kathmandu. Situated on a hill in the outskirts of town you get wonderful view of the city. This shrine has both hindu and buddist worshippers peacefully side by side, as they have been for sanctuaries.The temple is also known as the Monkey Temple, but be safe and keep some distance from the animals.

Very interesting place . Only the brave at hear should take the pilgrims steps! It's a long way up and with the air pollution and the elevation it was hard for me to breathe going up the steps and it's common to see tourists and locals alike taking a break on the way up. The stairs themselves are lined with many small vendors selling stone carvings, beadwork, and signing bowls. Its always very crowded at the top and the smell of butter lamps hangs very heavy in the air. The stuppas itself remains intact after the earthquake and is one of the most magnificent ones I've seen in Nepal. The views from here would be very nice if you could see through the haze. All in all very nice, and worth a visit. But if you don't feel up to climbing the stairs don't risk it (it's a steep fall down) go to the other entrance.

A great place to visit!. I was impressed with the amount of time you could spend walking around this area. My favourite site seeing day in Nepal so far! As always the locals were so friendly and you could easily spend up to 3-5 hours there.

The monkey temple. Spend your early morning or chilled evenings at Swayambhunath, give it all for the amazing view of Kathmandu, the religious value and the ever energetic monkey climbing here and there. Swayambhunath a great place for relaxation, working out and photography.

Good atmosphere. Went here a couple of times & really enjoyed the view and the atmosphere. If you don't take the main entry you don't have to pay the 200 Rp for the entry. You can easiely walk from Thamel

Highly recommended monkey temple. I never feel templed out so this monument was an easy place for me to visit for a day. It's a short 20-30 minute walk from Thamel, and then 200 rupes to get in. At the base of it are local guides looking for work, so if you want to get into the history of the temple you can hire one easily I'm just not sure the cost. It's interesting to visit without a guide though. There are monkeys everywhere and it has an awesome view of the Katmandu area. Definitely one of the few things to do while you're visiting the city so don't miss it.

Nice palace . In top view off Kathmandu city good views is seen there Swayambhunath is one of the world heritage buddha sttupa in Kathmandu here is one museums off some heritage antiques .. visit here if you come Kathmandu. .
Good spot for a valley view.. Though the earthquake has minimal affect at this area,you can visit here anytime and observe the kathmandu valley view.

Awesome view and fun walk. Really cool place to visit. Worth it, takes about 30 minutes to walk up to the top but there's a back way if you want to drive from the taxi. I suggest walking. Cool view of the city when there's no pollution.
Holy place. Holy place which must visit, from there can see the beautiful view of kathmandu and feel holy. I loved the place.
Amazing place.. All complex is very peaceful and green. You have to take lots of stairs but it's really worth it. Great view. Many mokeys all around. Beutiful praying wheels. Magic in the air.
True Nepali Temple. very well preserve temple and near to main Thamel center. The buildings are well maintain and many interesting ceremony can be observe.
Excellent. Very spritual place. I will visit again,, I will go back to see if the the temple have been restored.
365 steps. Nice place, you cannot lose this. You can go walking, it is 20 to 30 minutes walking from central Thamel, there you have 365 steps, but the view is great.
Nice to been here but not much more. When going to Kathmandu you have to visit it, but we only spent like 30 minutes here. Just walked around checking the temple and people making offers to the gods.
Nice to been here but not much more. When going to Kathmandu you have to visit it, but we only spent like 30 minutes here. Just walked around checking the temple and people making offers to the gods.
Amazing Temples up on Monkey Mountain. A great day out sight seeing over Monkey Mountain. You can get a Taxi or a Rickshaw. Just the other side of Kathmandu.

Monkey temple. A long walk to the top of the temple... on the way you come across different souvenirs you can buy such as singing bowls and accessories. Bargaining is a must here! The best experience out of all is to visit the art stores at the top and learn more about the "thankas".

the best turist attraction in Kathmandu. Probably the most interesting place to visit in Kathmandu. Make sure you go during sunset. It is an amazing view on the hill. And beware of monkeys, don't get too close.

shopping. You can spend a long time walking around, looking at art and crafts
of different kind. Singing bowls, carvings, paintings and bracelets of all kinds.
Great views of the city! . We enjoyed seeing the monkeys as well as the temple. The views are fantastic and worth the hike up. Definitely recommend.

Worth the trek. Its uphill and loads of stairs but worth the trek. You get a splendid view of Kathmandu valley from up there and the mountains on a clear day. Lots of monkeys there! But they wont do anything unless felt attacked.
Must see. This wonderful stupa, on top of the hill gives wonderful views of Kathmandu- just try to go on a clear day! Monkeys are everywhere - they are all docile, just do not get out food!!
Lovely old Temples and views. Even with the earthquake you can still see all the grounds of the temple. A lot of the structures have poles as support but never felt unsafe.

You don't have to take the stairs, but you should. Swayambhunath is breathtaking- monkeys everywhere and stunning views of Kathmandu. Worth the trek. I would take a cab if coming from Thamel- we got pretty lost trying to walk there. You have the option of driving to the top and walking in from the backside, but we took the stairs- worth it!

Damaged and overrun. I have visited this temple complex a number of times but this time I was really struck by what an overrun tourist magnet it is. It seems that almost every inch is covered by stalls selling trinkets, baubles and paintings. Squeezed between the merchandising are places for the Pius to worship. There's the occasional ringing of a bell, a bit of chanting but apart from it might as well have been a fair ground attraction. To top it all my favorite restaurant with a roof top view lies in ruins (earthquake damage).  Saying all this. If it's your first visit to Kathmandu it's worth dropping by. On a clear day the view is excellent - the climb up the approach stairs and all the monkeys are an experience in themselves and it's cheap to get in. Just don't expect too much of a religious experience.

Great early morning visit.. See the views from up here early, before the smog or clouds obstruct the views. It is harder to get clear days for viewing as KTM has so much smog, but worth planning on a clear day.The site was damaged in the 2015 earthquake but the main stupa is in tact. Unfortunately the great monastery was catastrophically damaged and is not gone, sad but it will be rebuilt in time.Always a good place to catch the early morning exercises the locals go up to do.Plenty of monkey bussiness up here.The large chora is worth a walk around, it is at least a couple of kilometers around and thousands of prayer wheels to spin :)Still one of the top sights in KTM, post earthquake.
The famous Monkey Temple. A must visit for the best view of Kathmandu valley. Sunsets are just to die for. Best for morning walk too.
Monkey Temple. Great way to spend an afternoon. The monkeys really make the place and are not aggressive. The walk to the top is well worth it, so keep going!
Monkey temple. Great views, superbly preserved shrines and lots of monkeys. this is a "must see" temple in Kathmandu.
Walk to visit. Busy and touristy. Worth going to see as a tourist site. It is about 5 km from Thamel. Go by Taxi 400Rs. There is slot of earthquake damage but worth seeing
Very unusual. The temple seems to be in very poor condition and didn't feel so holy for a non-hindu... The public cremation are an unusual show but was an interesting insight into the culture...

Great stop in your trip. This is worth a visit. There are monkeys all over the temple, they seem fine but watch out if you have food. The top is beautiful (there were not prayer flags when we visited). Plenty of shops and activities going on. We didn't stay long but you could spend a short amount or a long amount of time here.

Do it right, go up the 365 steps!. This is a must see place. To do it right get dropped off at the bottom of the 365 (steep) steps and earn yourself the stunning views over Kathmandu. For those that cannot climb the steps, your taxi driver can drive you close to the top where you'll have to climb some 20 or so steps up to the temples.There is a charge for visitors to enter Swayambhu - some 200 rupees from recollection. Well worth it. The views over Kathmandu and the valley are breathtaking, and the Bhuddist temples aren't bad either. Plus, you get monkeys as well. Just keep your food hidden because they can be ruthlessly aggressive in relieving you of it.

Great visit. I enjoyed this a lot. It only cost 200rupes and the view is great (on a nice day). The shops at the top are good too, lots of beautiful paintings and watercolours. Lots of monkeys as to be expected, they were throwing strawberries at as! Worth doing!
Worth a visit! . Some trek up the steps but the pagoda provides a stunning panoramic view of Kathmandu city. There are plenty of souvenir shops and restaurants at the top too. Very interesting.
The best view point and peaceful place p in Kathmandu. The best place to see Kathmandu valley and very peaceful place in busy Kathmandu. You will 100% love this place!
Day trip. Amazing place. Never expected to witness a Hindu funeral. The sights were very strange for a western tourist. A real eye opener.

Really great view of kathmandu valley . We biked here(bike rental 100 rupee/ hour) traffic was intense, but the temple made up for the sweat and tears. Lots of monkeys on our way up the long staircase. If you are from one of the neighboring countries you can pay 50 rupees to get in (our friend is Bangladesh) but we had to pay a bit more 200 each I believe. The temple had beautiful prayer wheels and rows of candles. Again best thing was definitely the awesome view.

Beautiful temple overlooking Kathmandu. After climbing 365 steps to get to the top, you get an amazing view of the city. This temple was luckily not damaged by die earthquake, although some buildings surrounding the temple were quite badly damaged. There are many shops that sell beautiful paintings, crafts etc. around the temple.

Instantly recognizable symbol of Nepal. Sitting on top of a hill, the famous "Monkey Temple" is one of the most popular tourist attractions in Nepal. A large tribe of monkeys guard the hill and amuse visitors with their tricks. It's a must see.

Great place!. We visited in early March and greatly enjoyed! It is a very important place, with rich history and a focal point for Hinduism and Buddhist traditions. Also connected to the legand around Kathmandu's establishing. It is a nice walk up, if you're lucky with nice views to the city. What I very much enjoyed there was simply finding a nice spot to sit and watch all that is happening around. It is sometimes the best way to absord the atmosphere of a place and definitely worked for me in this case too, with om mani padme hum running at the background from a near-by shop. Definitely a must visit place in Kathmandu, in my opinion. We walked up through the foresty path and walked down the steep stairs, which is a nice change to the general route. The foresty path can be entered from the side of the stupa and is a nice walk up, with tons of monkeys running around. Shortly before the stupa, there's another square with a number of nice things to see and do around. From there, you can ascend to the stupa and after seeing around it, descend from the stairs.

Awesome temple. This was our favorite temple in Kathmandu. We rode bikes here and enjoyed the steep incline up to the top. The climb is a bit intense and may take your breath away. The monkeys are pretty rad and run around quite a bit.

Fantastic Views. Terrific views and an interesting picture of the Buddhist faith. Be careful of the monkeys as they can be a bit erratic. It worth going down the back path to the fountain and throwing coins for good luck.
Holy place. Very nice place to visit.The structure are amazing. It was good weather to visit during March spring time.

The holy palce . Agin in year 2 time
It's feel good from heart when you visit here, stunning views of city and more then the temple beautiful and holy place for religion pepole who can visit and pray..

The last year terrible earthquake has not damage the syambhu tower. The main stupa looks not damage by last year disaster earthquake. Where around building was terrible damaged. it seems that the super power does exits in the Buddhist Stupa at Syambhunath(Monkey Temple)

Busy local temple but the view of the haze stops it being amazing!. The prospect of visiting a busy Buddhist temple with breathtaking views made this a 'Must See' on my Kathmandu itinerary.Unfortunately the view is badly impacted by the haze around at the time (late Feb) and your view is hardly spectacular.That aside the temple itself offers quite a sight, with its large stupa and associated shrines. Large crowds of locals rise the many steps early morning to pay respect and worship and is a critical part of everyday life and was very interesting to witness first hand.As with most of the major sights, some of the buildings are badly damaged from the earthquake and a few touts are about offering guide services and the like.Finally a word of warning, make sure you are prepared to climb the steps and work out a bit of sweat as it is hard enough work.

Always standing on the hill top. Swayambhunath Stupa is worshiped by both hindus and buddhists pilgrimage. no matter of religion everyone reach there right next day of their arrival in Nepal. It is such a beautiful place to visit.
beautiful view. It is a lovely temple, but something even more special is the view you have over Kathmandu. The temple itself is wonderfull as wel, really! And all the monkeys are just so cute!

Must See. One of the many Temples to visit in Katmandu. This place is worth the visit. You can hike up the stairs or take a cab to the top. It is a little commercialized so expect to be approached by people selling stuff.

Breathtaking view. Great place to walk through stairs to the top & look at the stunning view of Kathmandu Valley. Historical place wt great architecture... You can also entertain the birds & monkeys by feeding them. Just be careful with Monkey though as they are too cheeky :P

A place not just for monkeys. Like the Boudha Stupa Swayambhunath was also effected by earthquake, but seems a bit more lucky than the brother stupa! The roads around the Temple have been my home for 7 months and I climbed that beautiful place several times. Don't miss to visit on Nepali holidays or late in the evening!
Amazing!!. Totally worth it! Impressive cultural art and it's a really nice 'reward' after climbing the high stairs. You have a nice view over Kathmandu city aswell

Solo Trekker . Had a really good time at the Monkey Temple. Plenty to see and do here. They run a few classes on the traditional painting techniques etc.Monkeys everywhere and some scenic views from the roof tops if you know the local haunts and if not the view from the base of the temple is pretty good. Again a lot of people selling stuff but just smile and wave.

visiting the monkeys and monks!. This temple was absolutely beautiful and would be easy to spend a day here getting lost. Easy walk from Thamel with a map of course but watch out for those killer stairs!!! We were forced into having a guide but he wasn't pushy and spent a long time explaining the history so we felt that money was well worth it. The monkeys and people interacting was such a beautiful site. Would recommend and make sure you walk all the way through as it gets quieter the deeper you explore

Amazing stupa - just be prepared for the climb!. I loved this stupa so much I walked up to it from Thamel daily the last time I was in KTM. It's an easy walk during the day, except for the steps to reach the stupa itself, which are perfectly doable if you're moderately fit. Beuatiful stupa, with great views across Kathmandu.

Peaceful and beautiful . The monkey temple is a must visit site for all tourists visiting Nepal. A good 15 minutes walk from Thamel. The walk is worth it cause you will see the local way of life and experience it better. The temple itself is serene and beautiful, with a lot of energy. Watch out for the monkeys.

A Must Visit!!! . Walking up the stairs of this magical place, encountering monkeys and monks, this is a must visit for all seeking spiritual blessing! It's historical! It's ancient! It's has one of the best views of Kathmandu Valley!! It's is surrounded by temples built during the times of the great Malla Dynasty... It's an open destination for all lovers of peace and happiness.

Swayambunath Stupa. A golden spire crowning a conical wooded hill, Swayambhunath Stupa is the most ancient and enigmatic of all the holy shrines in Kathmandu valley. Its lofty white dome and glittering golden spire are visible for many miles and from all sides of the valley. Historical records found on a stone inscription give evidence that the stupa was already an important Buddhist pilgrimage destination by the 5th century AD. Its origins however, date to a much earlier time, long before the arrival of Buddhism into the valley. This is one of the world’s most glorious Buddhist Stupa. Painted on the four sides of the spire bases are the all seeing eyes of Lord Buddha. Swayambhu has two small Tibetan Gumbas with typical colorful shrines open to all visitors.

I wondered to know what's inside a Buddhist Stupa.... The temple (specifically 'Stupa') with two eyes of lord Buddha, believed to be able to distinguish justice and injustice. Yes, beautiful & perfect location for a day out, Swayamboonath... Entering from the main gate, near to the Golden, large & tall statue of Lord Buddha in yoga mudra, you r free to blow a couple of 'Shankha' (snail) for eternal & world peace. Proceed uphill clockwise rotating innumerable 'Mane', the rotating holy cylinders embossed with 'Mantra', the holy words. Each Mane would give u a holy feel and deep eternal peace. The higher u go, the more u feel peaceful. Added advantage is that u can see almost whole valley from the top, going is not difficult. You can rest anywhere u feel comfortable. Yes, inside the temple at the top, there is a big Mane being rotated by couple of people! Strange but unique, I hope!

Great temple to visit !!. i have been to swayambhunath several times and it is one of the great world heritage site too. it is the symbol of peace and love. so i recommend to visit this temple where you can discover amazing things for your heart and soul.
Beautiful temple worth a visit :-). A very beautiful temple found near thamel. Worth walking afterwards to thamel in the city and see where people live as well as monkeys all along.

Sad to see. I first saw Swayambhu in December, 1967. Went many times up to 1974, then once in 1991, and now. The complex was devastated by the April earthquake. Many structures now supported by strut beams, and piles of rubble everywhere. Before it was free, now non locals have to pay, Rs 400 I think I remember. One bright spot: there was a huge gathering of Tibetan pilgrims attending an annual puja conducted by a high lama. Lots of fun to watch. We came down the front 360 steps, and I got jumped by one of those nasty rhesus monkeys who was trying to steal my water bottle. Be forewarned: DO NOT WALK AROUND WITH ANYTHING EDIBLE. You will be jumped by a monkey!

Great temple in the east side of Kathmandu . The temple was beautiful. Nice to come in the morning. Less tourist. Quite impressive structure and the regular tourist shoes at the top.I would recommend walking by foot and not take taxies or buses everywhere as you can expiriance the city much better.

See kathmandu valley with eyes of buddha. Either with stairs or a steep ascent from bottom, it is worth visiting. Whether you are a buddhist pilgrim or a peace traveller, you will find this very exquisite. Anyone can clearly see kathmandu valley and roam around for handicrafts and many more.

Nice temple in the same area of Bodhnath Stupa .. Swayambhunath is a mahadev temple just build near the bodhnath stupa . The area is having monkeys who if not alert snatch food items or mobile from visitors.But an interesting place to visit . A must see in Kathmandu . It is a visiting place than a worship place . It has a superb view of Kathmandu city .

Bouddhist pilgrimage site on a small terrace over looking Kathmandu valley. Believed to be the first piece of the land to be seen when the water of Kathmandu valley, once a lake, has flown southwards. Very important in religious, cultural and historical aspect of the Kathmandu Valley. This is the place where one can start comprehending the history of Kathmandu valley and learn some amount of Mahayana Buddhism. This site on a small hill accessed by 365 steps (much less if used another access) is a nice place to see whole Kathmandu valley just as one can see Paris from Montmartre besides, a panorama of Himalayan mountain peaks can be seen to the north on a clear day.

A Place of Intense Wonder. As other reviewers have described Swayambu was hit by the earthquakes but it is more than worth the visit. There are two ways up, if you take the left stairs, once out of the carpark, get to the top walk past a Bhudda on your left and up a short flight of steps on the right at the top is Buddha Thanka Treasure. An honest place to buy paintings. There are many other stalls selling innumerable statues. It was worth remembering that almost everything made in Nepal is handmade, from the most simple memento to the more elaborate pieces. And you haven't even reached the gem of the main stupa yet or the host of shrines crammed on top of the scared hill. Read up a little before you visit. It will make experience your even richer.

Enchanting. when we visited this temple it was almost getting dark.( Winter time about 4 pm ). we had to pay a small entrance fee of about 1 UD$.
