The entrance of the temple was lined with beggars mostly women or children. we had prepared for this encounter and gave small amounts to most of them. we felt good about it. the way up to the temple is lined with small time vendors selling all kind of nick knacks . mostly prayer beads.most of the buildings which surround the main temple were also destroyed by the 2014 earthquake and have not yet been rebuilt.here i must say beware of the always hungry quite aggressive monkeys.Do not eat and walk around the will just grab it from you and you might get hurt.the view over Kathmandu is fantastic especially around 6 pm when you get the last rays of the evening sun, something for someone who likes photography.the most easiest way to get here is by taxi ,the fare from the city center is about 5 US$ or less. there is also bus service( which would be quite interesting to take ) but the buses are always over crowded

Devastated by not destroyed by earthquake, a must see!. A must see in Kathmandu! The Swayambhunath Temple otherwise known as the monkey temple offers a spectacular view of Kathmandu. The architecture and religious artifacts are breathtaking. Monkeys wander freely throughout the temple. The April 2015 earthquake damage is obvious and had a major impact on the temple and adjacent buildings but the best still stands and work has already begun to rebuild. Authentic and untouched. Watch the worshippers as they make the rounds from temple to temple. Be part of the tradition and go see this must see place. Note, you need to be in shape to get to the top of the stairs.

Swayambhunath Temple, Monkey Temple. Great fun due to all of the monkeys. The temple and surrounding structures are most interesting but the monkeys steal the show. Be sure to see the peace pond where you can toss coins trying to get them in the receptacle.

Love Being Here. One of the my favorite place in Kathmandu. Being here and looking around the valley view is superb. Its about 12-15 min drive from thamel and and about 35-45 min walking.Lots of monkey and lots of things to do being around here.

Must VisitTemple with Great Views!. We arrived at the lower end of the hill climbing up the 500+ stairs to reach the top - this is also the side opposite the giant sculptures and we went down the other side to see these. We went at sunset and saw the monks praying around the temple - just make sure you walk around clockwise. Even after the earthquakes the views over Kathmandu were amazing!

Worth a visit to see the monkeys.. Went here the guide I was with bought some cheap biscuits which we used to feed the local monkey population which were very well behaved and fun. Climbed up a few stairs on the route we took not the 365 steps from the other end. Saw the painters painting the hand painted budhist paintings had an interesting talk one on one about budhism and it's history with the people in the temple. Saw some of the local eagle population flying down from the trees. The place had a good vibe it felt pleasant there. It was worth a visit take time to see the rescued statues in the hall at the top.

My favorite temple in Kathmandu - Monkey Temple. This is my favorite temple in Kathmandu for four reasons. Reason 1 - the view. It's on the hillside so you get a nice view of the valley. I've gone during sunset and it was nice, and the night view with all the lights is nice too. One cool thing was I got to see when a group/area went into load shedding and see that entire area black out while another area lit up. During the day it is also nice to see the surrounding hills and buildings. If you're lucky (maybe 3 days or so a month) it's clear enough that you can see the Himalayas to the east. But usually it's too smoggy, foggy, dirty, hazy. Reason 2 - the monkeys. They're so funny and cute. I don't feed them, but they are nice when you leave them alone and you can get good pictures of them perched everywhere. Reason 3 - the shopping. Most places around Kathmandu don't have these kinds of little stands selling trinkets and souvenirs. These sellers are very reasonably priced and there is a good variety. Almost every stand I visited had different designs in jewelry, unlike Thamel or Durbar Square where everyone has the same stuff. Reason 4 - All the different structures at the base and the top of the stupa. At the base there is the fountain with the gold stature and miniature stupas with the gold top and eyes. There is also the large temple bell and gate. Then at the top there are the lookout towers (unfortunately one crumbled during the earthquake) and the main large stupa. The gold top and eyes are still intact and when the sun hits it, it is amazing. They are known as the "eyes of Nepal" and for good reason. The surrounding older buildings with the original wood carved windows and brick walls are also a nice contrast to the newer concrete buildings that surround the Boudhanath Stupa. This place is well worth the 200 rupees to visit.

A must in Kathmandu. This is a site you really must visit in Kathmandu. I walked from my hotel in Thamel and it took around 45 minutes to an hour at a leisurely pace. If you're not sure, just ask for directions on the way, people are quite happy to help. The stairs are a steep climb but well worth it at the top with great views over the valley and a fascinating temple to explore. Theres a charge at the top of the stairs, only a pound or two. Watch out for people who will start talking a tour at you without any warning then ask for money to go away and be wary with asking for strangers for directions here, it can result in a 'i help you, you help me' situation. All in all, great place to visit, plus theres loads of monkeys knocking it about!

Great Views and Fun Experience. I would definitely recommend making a trip out to this temple. It is huge, and there is so much more to see than just the stupa at the top. There are lots of little shops along the trek up to the stupa. And of course, there are a ton of Monkeys. I was worried they would be bothersome but they weren't at all. I walked past so many and they didn't try to steal anything out of my hand or jump on me, but I also wasn't trying to get their attention either. I visited this site in Feb. during the low tourist season but this place was jam packed. Come early if you don't like huge crowds, and be prepared to walk. You can have a driver take you further up so you don't have to walk up the stairs. They do have bathrooms near the entrance (the "attendants" will expect you to leave a tip). The views at the top are amazing, but we didn't get to see much due to the bad pollution that day. There is an entrance fee, so bring cash.
must visit. must visit , one of UNESCO spot to visit in nepal , although damaged by recent earthquake partially .
Monkey temple . This history sight is one of the awesome places I visited thus far in Nepal. A site i will never forget in my life. Spending time with awesome people.

Shorter climb from tourist car park. Our taxi driver took us to the pilgrim stairs first, but we asked him to go to the tourist car park which is nearer to the top of the hill. Taxis at the car park when we left were wanting $10US back to our hotel in Lazimpat. We used the steps on the side which leads to the road farther down the hill where we found a taxi for 300rupees (US $3). We liked patronizing the honest taxi drivers and found the majority easy to agree on fares. The nice receptionist at our hotel told us approximate taxi rates for our destination each day.

Worth seeing. This is a major site, and it's worth seeing. If it's a rare day that's clear enough to see the high mountains, that would be an extra bonus. The atmosphere of pilgrimage makes this especially interesting. (Many shops and people trying to get you to buy, but that's inevitable at any major site in Kathmandu.)

Beautiful temple!. Hanging out with the monkeys at the entrance was fun, but taking a trip to the top and seeing the temple was enlightening! Very peaceful with many prayer wheels to spin. There are lots of vendors at the top, so be prepared to see various souvenirs on display. On a clear day, you can see beautiful Kathmandu from the top!

Check the sky and go for sunrise or sunset!. Good point to see the huge city at your feet. Besides the temple is nice and the stairs going up there just amazing. Going early in the morning at 5:30am allows you to see many pilgrims doing puja and givings. At night is also good!!!

Awesome views and monkeys!. Definitely worth the 200 rp entry fee and walk up the steep steps. It was fun to see the monkeys and dogs running around. Around the temples at the top are a bunch of shops selling all the normal touristy stuff. And the views over Kathmandu are pretty awesome- wonder if the smog will ever clear! There's definitely still earthquake damage on the back side so be ready to be impressed. Definitely go!
Culture. Nice place fir viewing kathmandu valley!! If you want to visit kathmandu valley you should definitely visit here!!! A great place for refreshment

Wonderfully enlightening and fascinating . Another amazing Buddhist temple, and there is so much more here than just the stupa (which is incredible in itself). Lots of handcrafted wares being sold and a step back in history with the many things to see.

Big complex on top of the hill. You need to climb some steps to get to the top but than you will be reworded with beautiful complex of temples and shrines. It's called the monkey temple however we haven't seen that many monkeys there :) Even after the earthquake you can still see the beauty of that place
View point.. The monkey temple,you can see the view of Kathmandu.The nice place that you can feel about Bhudist and Hindu culture.

Best Attraction in Kathmandu. Best attraction in Kathmandu in my opinion, Way better than the durbar square, and the guides selling their tours were far less annoying up here.Possibley a little tricky to find, I missed the main entrance which is quite spectacular, up the long flight of steps, and came in round a back way, Where I also seemed to miss the Ticket selling gate which kinda saved me 1000 Roupees, sorry! I just kind of wandered in and didn't realise you had to pay untill I saw the tickets on the way out! I found it fairly interesting, and you get some great Views over the city. change some money for coins and you can have a go at chucking it into the pond with a budda statue in the middle, I think you got good luck if you landed it at the buddas feet. I missed which totally explained the bad luck I received the next day when my flight to lukla got cancelled and I had to wait 9 hours in the airport to find out! Should have thrown more pennies ;)There really are loads of monkeys, I'd be a little wary of them though one of my mates got bit by a monkey in Thailand and had to have rabies shots!Go here over Durbar square ;)

must see the 'monkey temple'. There is minimal damage to this temple complex from the 2015 earthquake. it's a great place to visit if you need a break from the honking streets of nepal, very peaceful. but probably you shouldn't visit if you don't like monkeys, because they are everywhere.

Holy temple. A holy place for Hindus as well as Buddhists, Swayambhunath Stupa/temple was built before 5th century AD. The temple is mesmerizing. It is situated on a hill and this beautiful temple is visible from miles away. I suggest to visit it in the evening before the sunset. You can see Kathmandu city from up above. There are 300 + steps to the hill if you prefer to walk up or you can take your bike/car up the hill too. This place is very peaceful. A must visit if you are in Kathmandu.

Temple at the top of a hill. Swayambhunath is one of the temples in Kathmandu. It's located atop the hill in Kathmandu valley. Be ready to walk up hundreds of stairs. But if you come by car like I did, you driver will probably bring the car higher so you won't be too tired. Besides the temple, I like the look of their brick buildings. Monkeys were here so watch your belongings.

Temple with Monkeys.. This is a hindu temple based in Kathmandu. It has many steps hence be aware of that. It has many monkeys to welcome you and one must beware of them.Unfortunately the main temple was shut hence we could not go in. But from the outside the building is beautiful and monumental. A must visit.
A nice temple. This is a nice temple, it is at some height, sad to see the damage caused by earth quake, but main corridor in intact.

Take a guide to get the most out of the "monkey temple". Another fascinating glimpse into Buddhist culture. We had an independent guide with driver and although this was a cost, if you can afford it, it was worth it for the interesting narrative he provided, as well as making the whole day go smoothly. We went in the morning when everything was just getting underway so the place was a hive of activity. The monkeys though were calm and we didn't feel threatened that they may jump on us. There were also lots of street dogs, but again, peaceful. The central steps are very steep.but others less so. It is one of the must-see places in Kathmandu and well worth the time and money.

Stunning. After climbing up the steep steps you are rewarded with a fantastic view of the city all around. The temple survived the earthquake, although the surrounding buildings show evidence of the damage. Colourful prayer flags and monkeys all around make for sme beautiful photographs!
Interesting with city views. An amazing gold stupa after quit a few sets of steps overlooking the city. Try to choose a clear day and you might get a view of the mountains.

Wonderful. Beautiful architecture and happy people envelope you as you walk through the temple, mischievous monkeys play a role in the experience too. Easy enough to reach by walking depending on where you are staying and with an entry of 1000Rps not a bad price either. Highly suggest this experience to anyone willing to pay and see the beauty of this place.
Damaged a bit by the earthquake, but as a Stupa still going strong!. A must see when visiting KTM, this Stupa is as grand as ever, even after surviving several earthquakes during this decade.

Go before sunrise for the view and locals exercising . Zigzagged through Kathmandu before sunrise to come here with a local friend, it was totally worth it at this time with only locals going about their day running up and down and even the army using the steep hill as a work out, watch out for the hundreds of steps up !! Enjoy milk tea at the top.
Unique blend of religions. Lovely place . Has great religions and natural value. Good view of the valley from the top.Not difficult to climb from where the car drops you.

Worth a Visit to see the monkey's and the views over Kathmandu. The temple is buzzing with tourists and stalls. I also visited the art gallery to find out about mandalas whilst I was here which was very interesting.My friend had a bottle of coke that he brought and the monkey's nabbed it off him, bit into it and all enjoyed licking it up! So, my top tip would be to make sure you take nothing but water up to the temple. There are also quiet a few steps!

Good half day visit in Kathmandu. Good place to visit by 30 minute walk from Thamel enjoying the street scape on the way then a step climb to the hill top complex It is a hive of activity and provides good views as well as interest itself. Reasonable entrance fee.

Fantastic!. This place. It's fantastic. First off, the monkeys are so much fun to watch, and they get super close to you which can be slightly frightening at times. Secondly, the architecture & design details are very beautiful & interesting, and there's a sense of wonder - although have to say there were a ton of pigeons at the top which I didn't like, but just get past that. Thirdly, the view from the top alone is worth the admission. It's at one of if not the highest point in the city and you can see the entire Kathmandu valley spread out below you. Breathtaking.
Interesting. Interesting with its history, statues, prayer wheels, monkeys are everywhere but harmless. Little shops for souvenirs shopping.

Enjoy the scenery of Kathmandu. enjoying the colorful flags, rotating bells, and the architecture of the mini Stupa. Shops offer varieties of handcrafts and souvenirs. The public rest room here are not hygiene. Need improvement. The trips can takes less than 45 minutes to discover all. For Buddhist can do prayer here.

A must visit site. One of the world's heritage site is still standing high despite the April's earthquake. It is a holy place and should be treated as such.The hike up the stairs can be challenging, but definitely worth it. The panoramic view of the Kathmandu valley is spectacular, but make sure to go there when the fog is gone.Don't forget to visit the 3 huge golden Buddhas. They are relatively new attractions and many people might not even know they are there. The Buddhas are located near the Ring road, a short walking distance from Swayambhunath Temple.
Swayanbhubath - Worth to vistit world heritage site. Swayambhunath is one of the world heritage site. One can see the beautiful Kathmandu valley from the top of this stupa.
Holy place. This is one of the largest stupa I have seen in Nepal. It is a holy place where Buddhists as well as Hindus visit.

Good experience !!. I would say to go when the fog clears so that you can get a real good view over Kathmandu and a must watch and photograph a Sunset from this point. Rich heritage and culture of Nepal can be seen and experienced here.

The holy place for peace lovers and budhhist who are sacred heart .. It is nearby Thamel and along the ring road at KATHMANDU. The Stupa is very ancient time and the Lord Budhha also is regarded as a shrine place from all Buddhist from all over the world.

Perfect view point . Possible to see nice views of kathmandu valley and mountains range. Buddhist temple is in the top of the hill. Another name is monkey temple. Can see many monkey on the way. So nice to be there. Be there if you get some time. It is in walking distance from Thamel also.
Captivating. I recommend going in the morning, earlier than the masses. This place is just fascinating. Take your time to just sit and watch.

Monkey temple. a buddist pagod lies in the top of hill is nice to visit during your kathmandu visit.from where you can see good panoramic view of kathmandu city.where you can see lots of monkeys and can feed them too which will be really fun.

Short hike up the hill watch out for monkeys !. Beautiful structure and a must do afternoon stroll up the hill with just rewards. Sunset a nice experience but can become very crowded so consider an early morning before tour groups rise out of their plush hotel comforts.

Religious & Scenic. Nepal People have a lot of respect for this temple.
One wont regret being there if u visit early in the Morning. Its Windy cold up there, Awesome view of the city, Morning Sunrise, Peace of Mind and many added features.
Definitely it has to be there in the Places to visit List.

Budhist monastery. This place is budhist historical place. From here you can see Sun rise and Sun set. And lots of monkey are here if you are carrying plastic bag on your hand monkey will take happily. I suggest not to take in your hand and you have to pay for entrance.

Sightseeing . Amazing time seeing traditional Hindu and Buddhist destination with great views.
Original architecture. Quite busy place.
You can buy nice original Nepali gift there.
monkeys galore. Our kids loved watching the monkey families. The earthquake damage has resulted in much work going on but it is an impressive place to visit and regard tbe significance .
Great views. the climb to the top of the hill is worth it for the great views. My kids just loved all of the monkeys.

Amazing views. We went here in Feb 2016. I would highly recommend walking up the steps, there are many but it is so worth it seeing the monkeys along the way and the amazing views. I would say to go when the fog clears so that you can get a real good view over Kathmandu!
Temple on the top of the hill. Nice view of Kathmandu Valley from the top of the temple. 100 steps to climb to the temple. Many shops selling souvenirs as memento

One of the most peaceful places in Kathmandu. This place is a great escape from the hectic life in Kathmandu. When living in Nepal I went here regularly. Both for the calm nature of the place but also for the magnificent history of the place and the view.
Best view. i went in the evening to get sun set view and feel the calmness after the crowd left the hill. this hill is very ancient.

Hindu temple with amazing view to Kathmandu Valley. Impressing Hindu temple in a short distance from KTM Thamel center. If you dont like stairs, better access from the back entrance as the main entrance has 600 plus stairs!Very interesting temple, but somewhat destroyed by the 2015 earthquake. An awful lot of wild monkeys and wild dogs, of who some seems to be rather aggressive so better take your precautions. Special toilets for tourists for free and the standard is acceptable.
A most spiritual place. A wonderful insight into the Hindu/Buddhist culture.Make sure you visit Buddha Thanka Treasure and learn about the art of painting the beautiful Mandala.

The most blessed place in the world. Nothing to add, it's the most blessed place in the world. If you've see Swayambhu once, it becomes a part of you and will never leave you. Amazing experience, must-visit place number one.

Still standing after earthquake. I have been to this temple before and after the quake. It is on the must dos in Kathmandu and easy to walk to from Thamel. It takes approx 30 mins and if you ask people to the "monkey temple"they will point.Lots of beggars at the base and monkeys on the stairs make it a slight tourist hazard. the 365 steps to the top are cathartic and represent the days of the year.

Watch your valuables!. Monkeys everywhere! Great place to visit, at the top of the hill, there are stupas, temples and stalls and a fantastic view of Kathmandu.NR200 entry which is very reasonable but watch your valuables and loose items, the monkeys might want them more than you!
Interesting place to visit.. Nice place to visit. It is Buddhist worship place. good surrounding and being at hill top can have a very beautiful view of the city.
Cool place. Æ really cool place to visit just a few min from Thamel with taxi. Great view of the city, nice atmosphere and really fun with the monkeys! A beautiful temple

20% beautiful temple and 80% market place with annoying salesmen.. The temple in itself is incredibly beautiful, unfortunately the temple is totally surrounded with extremely annoying and pushy salesmen selling overpriced unoriginal stuff.
Nice place . Very nice place good views of kathmandu sad to see the earthquake damage lots of vendors make it look like a flea market

Monkeys were the best feature!. We went here early in the morning, and it was a great time to go as there were few visitors, and the touts had yet to set up. We also took a taxi to the side entrance, which saved having to climb the hundreds of steps that are at the front - highly recommended! But this wasn't our favourite temple - there wasn't a huge amount to see, and probably an hour is the most I could see spending there.

Peaceful atmosphere . The steps leading to the main temple was breathtaking. But it was spoilt by the scene of women beggers carrying small babies begging for money. I'm not sure if it's a syndicate or not. Anyway, the main temple was ok, but to me the main attraction are the stairs heading down to the other side which are more peaceful and pleasent. Many photo taking opportunities here. Perfect place to meditate also.
Peaceful Place. Very peaceful place.You can have a good view of the city from the temple.The staircase are straight which makes you feel like you are actually trekking.
beautiful. Best place to visit in evening. Place where we can enjoy the view of natural beauty. Awesome view of whole kathmandu city lightening do not miss it!!!

"Divine Blessings". This place gives peaceful experience right from my first visit, famously known as monkey temple, it fulfills your wishes. It houses some of the statues of Lord Buddha. Structure is now damaged due to last years earth quake.

Splendid. This is a beautiful place and among-st the recommended places of visit if you are in Kathmandu. I loved the Harati Devi temple and the beautiful Single stone Buddha Statue ! Incredible indeed !

Serene, calming, spiritual enrichment experience . One of the two most iconic monuments in Nepal. Swayambunath temple is situated at higher ground, which makes it with an extra higher ground breathtaking views of Swayambunath valley. Do spend sometimes to connect to the calming energy around you here, you are assured refreshed, recharged and reenergized wholesomely.
Worth the walk up but? . It's a shame that it's not cleaner and less stalls as it ruins the atmosphere. Monkeys are fun to watch.

Swayambhu - Monkey Temple. This is yet another World Heritage site of Kathmandu valley and worth visiting while in Kathmandu. This is at a small hill. You can either walk and make your way to the top after dealing with 365 stairs or you can drive almost to the top. The stupa of Swayambhu is magnificent. There are also other Hindu temples around the stupa. Here you see how Hinduism and Budhism are interrelated. Mostly, local people make their praying to both Hind deities and Budha. You must be careful of the monkeys, if you are carrying any fruit or food on your hands. Some part of the surrounding building is in repair due to april 2015 earthquake. But it is quite safe to visit this site.

find some Peace at top of city. the environment is great, the three statues at front is the most favorite part, after a short wall uphill you will find the worshipers and visitors, the view from top is very nice, it's kind of having a birds eye view.
Monkey temple. Yep, a very historic Buddhist site. Commercialised and crowded but still awesome. Monkeys are a bit feral.
Monkey Temple. Great visit but you must love the stairs. :) Its worth spending time to visit the temple and witness the monkeys everywhere.

It just blew my mind. . People say Buddha visited this place thousands years ago. i grew up in a devoted Buddhist family, even though I am shy to say I'm a devoted Buddhist myself, I love the feeling of being so close to God, i feel peaceful. I met a couple of tourists who are from China, they told me that Nepal is the place which is very close to haven and God. I think that's why i didn't feel unsafe for some reasons. And the Nepalese are all look very genuine people and kind. Seems like they will never had ulterior motive. I would love to come back again, Swayambhunath, i love it. And mind you, a lot of steps to climb! Good exercise for me, again I love it

Historical place with lots of monkeys...... Everybody who knows about Nepal would definitely be knowing about swayambhu.the tourism in that place has been drastically changed as i have been visiting in that place from around 15 years and the changes are recommendable. The tourist are given top priority and the place is also very much clean in compare to other places.despite the earthquake the site has been properly managed and rebuilding has done and gone smoothly.

Well worth the stairs!. It really is simply breathtaking to see such a structure, though it's quite a climb to make it at the top trust me you'll thank yourself for the exercise when you get there! There are numerous local stores around the top one of which that sticks in my memory is an original art store where you can pick up some authentic Nepalese artwork
Visited in 2014 . Great mixture of Hindu and Buddhist harmony symbolic of Nepal. The walk up the stairs are a bit of a pain but the view is worth it. The monkeys are a problem.
Monkey temple. very interesting history and masses of monkeys even worth the steps to get to the temple as tradition says you do not walk back down the same way
wonderful. I went to day trip from rosha the hospitality was every good and the place where we live was also good .All places were good and the people where we lived was also very good .

Fascinating religious site. A great walk up the steps, great view of the view, and beautiful stupa and side buildings makes it a worthwhile visit. I saw it before the 2015 earthquake and afterwards. Despite the damage, be sure to see it. Also, be sure to the campus behind the stupa.
Monkey Temple. On ninth January 2016 Me, my sister and her children went swayambhunath temple, when we went there we saw one of the nice place in Nepal.

Monkey Temple. Good stairway which gets steeper and steeper, many stop to take a breath. Nice temple with a good view of the city. Lots of people begging on the stairs up to the temple, and monkeys of course, might try to steal your water bottle!

loved the morning visit. its located on top of a small hill with beautiful valley view. Its also known as the monkey temple. There are two ways to get there, drive to the top of the hill or walk it from the base and climb and steep stairs to the top. Its a nice place to spend a morning, lots of locals visit for religious purposes and the air is filled with incense perfume. There are little shops and cafes selling souvenirs, paintings stoneworks etc. Photographers will have a field day.
Monkey temple. Went there before the earthquake. You can see the beautiful Kathmandu valley from here. One of the must visit temple.

My favourite and most arresting visit in Kathmandu. High on a hilltop above Kathmandu rises this tranquil and peaceful temple. You feel a change come over you as you ascend the stairs to the top to find a little world up there. The monkeys alone are worth the visit - don't get too close though - they will make a grab for anything shiny or loose.
Interesting History. A definite must see but watch out for the monkeys! You can see all of Kathmandu from the high point.

Swayambhunath is known best as the monkey temple..... This is one of the landmarks of Kathmandu. It takes about 20 to 30 minutes to climb up the temple. The climb is steep towards the end. There is statue of Buddha inside a water body where people throw coins aiming at the feet of Buddha. There are many monkeys on the way and at the top. Hence the nickname of the temple - monkey temple!

Humanity through history. Amazing heritage of Nepal. I visited the temple in early Jan 2016. Signs of devastation and ruins from the April 2015 earthquake are still strong. Sad to see so little and meaningful restoration is being done. On the other hand, the spirit of the people living in the vicinity is a burning flame. A wonderful contrast.

Beautiful views. Loved how close up you can get to the ornate gold structure and surrounding prayer areas. Beautiful views of Kathmandu as well. Really serene, lovely area. Definitely worth the effort to get there.
Amazing spot. The stairs aren't that bad. The view is definitely worth it. Quite earthquake damaged too. Go over the back to the pools too. Heaps of flats etc as well
What a beautiful view. The view is beautiful from the top and the monkeys are a cute novelty. So much to see and well worth the effort.

Nice Place to Visit and Do Meditation!!. Its Nice place to Visit when you come to Kathmandu as you can feel Great and the View from here is so nice to Whole Kathmandu ..Its an ancient religious architecture atop a hill in the Kathmandu Valley .The stupa has Buddha's eyes and eyebrows painted on. Between them, the number one (in Devanagari script) is painted in the fashion of a nose. There are also shops, restaurants and hostels. The site has two access points: a long stairway with 365 steps, leading directly to the main platform of the temple, which is from the top of the hill to the east; and a car road around the hill from the south leading to the southwest entrance.
excellent. this place is located in the top of the hill so the view u will see is all ktm from this place .it is a silent place which everyone will love to spend time .
A must see in Kathmandu. A spectacular historic site. We spent 3-4 hours here and wish we had more time. Even after the earthquake it is still a remarkable place. Beware the monkeys!
Monkey temple . One of the most popular and historical place of Kathmandu. It is popular as a monkey temple.major place to visit while you are in Kathmandu.

Fantastic views and vibe!. Well worth the trip here to see the views of kathmandu in the valley of the mountains. The stairs up to the temple are very steep, and hundreds of monkeys play on the steps. You can take a taxi to the "back entrance" to avoid the climb and the creatures if you need :) approx 200 rupees for foreigners to enter.

Monkey Temple will not disappoint!!!. For the most breath taking view in Kathmandu the Monkey Temple is your best bet!!! And the hundreds of wild monkeys are amazing!! (Be careful though as one monkey tried to steal my coke a cola right out of my hand! They can be slightly intimidating at first but you soon realize they are more afraid of you than you are of them. That being said do not try to feed or pet them as they are still wild animals.) When I say hundreds I mean it! They will be everywhere, lots of babies and mothers too :) the best time to visit is at sun set because large bowls of food are put out for the monkeys at the top of the temple. the entry fee for tourists is a mere 200 rupees. Bring extra if you would like to purchase Prayer flags and other neat gifts.

So many monkeys!. This delightful temple sits at the top of several hundred stairs and is home to a wonderful troop of rhesus macaques. With incredible views over Kathmandu, wonderful wildlife, and a beautiful array of architecture this is a great place to spend an afternoon. We went late in the day but heard that sunrise from here is stunning. Plus the monkeys are chased out of the temple first thing, which is a sight to see.

historic place. swyambhu nath also known as the monkey temple is one of the most historic and heritage of nepal. the environment around is so beautiful and peace. the main temple is in between the thick jungle with lots of monkey. almost thousands of local and tourist visits there everyday. very popular for both hindu and buddhist followers. a must visit .

Peace at top.. Swyambhu nath stupa is one of the oldest stupa in the world . It is located north west of kathmandu valley on small hill with 365 steps lead you to the top that indicates 365 days of the year. Magnificent views of kathmandu valley on beautiful day make you more exciting and popularly know as monkey temple . Once you reach the top feeling will be peace in mind and you will be blessed for whole year only after you climbed 365 steps.

best sightseeing ever... Kathmandu city have millions of population and there is no any other place to go and be fresh but while you been in swayambhunath or monkey temple you will fell just amazing ,It was perfect time.

Temple on Hill. You have to climb so many steps to visit the temple as it is on the top of the Kathmandu City.After one point you have to leave you car and climb steps to reach temple where you can see entire Kathmandu City.

"The Monkey Temple" - as locals call it. The Monkey Temple has not so many monkeys but maybe it was called that because of the presence of a few human friendly monkeys there who are accustomed to tourists offering them food to eat. The temple has many small structures/tombs separated from each other, though in the same vast courtyard. Most structure represent traditional Nepalese architecture and bear fine cravings on stone. You will find many of the tombs and doors of many structures made of gold. Well, in ancient days it was real gold but it is reduced to gold plating now. You can see almost whole of Kathmandu from the top. It's a beautiful view.There are many tourist shops that sell attractive local souvenirs from Nepal – paintings, singing bowls, healing bowls, chants, and several brass items representing various mythological gods. You will find a lot of Buddha statues available in many materials – stone, wood, brass, etc. I was fascinated by the big brass bowls (actually they are not just made of brass – they are a mixture of brass and copper). There are two kinds – hand made and machine made. You can clearly make out the difference. The machine made ones are close to perfection in the physical form. The handmade ones don’t have such fine finishing but the difference lies between the powers contained in both. The machine made ones don’t produce so much of resonating singing sound as the handmade ones do. I am told the bowls have many uses – first and foremost of them being healing. Migraines, back-pains, blood pressure, etc. are common diseases that can be cured by using the bows in different ways. The technique lies in producing the sound vibrations and massaging the painful area with the vibrating bowl. If you pour some water in the bowl and produce the sound with the drumstick, the water starts to jump inside the bowl in a very mystic way and those drops carry huge amount of healing power for eyes and face. Well, I bought one bowl and am very excited about it. You can typically bargain up to 30-40% depending upon your need to buy, the shopkeeper’s need to sell and your negotiation skills.

A must see if you're in Kathmandu... The area around this pagoda is electric. Knowing that you're spinning the same prayer wheels as Everest climbers is humbling, especially since not all survived the journey back. You will see women in traditional colorful clothing walking around the shops surrounding the pagoda.

Amazing View of Kathmandu. Kathmandu city have millions of population and there is no any other place to go and be fresh but while you been in swayambhunath or monkey temple you will fell just amazing ,It was perfect time.
Nice temple. The temple is more full of sellers than religous content, but still worth a look. The lower section near the ring road is quite good and more religous.

Yikes! Too many monkeys and pigeons and dogs! Great views on a clear day.. This temple to me was the perfect dilemma (mish-mash) of the Hindu and Buddhist faiths that coexist in Nepal. The Nepalis have managed to somehow merge both these influences in this one temple. At first glance, I did not know if I was visiting a Hindu temple or a Buddhist one! The peace eyes at the entrance of the steps to the temple are quite mesmerizing. But the same set of eyes again greet you at the top of the stairs (where the actual temple is). The stairs are not too difficult to climb. There is an entrance fee (less for SAARC citizens and slightly more for non-SAARC ones).There are plenty of hawkers selling knick-knacks and souvenirs on the stairs to the temple. Lots and lots of monkeys in the main temple area. Too many pigeons for my liking and a couple of dogs thrown in too! The prayers wheels encircle the stupa and it is really calming to turn them. We did see many brave-hearts climbing up from the other set of stairs (too many and too tiring!), which looked very steep, to the temple. Avoid those and just ask your car/taxi to drop you to the main temple area, from where it is just a few steps up. The views of the valley are the best from here. The whole of Kathmandu at the bottom, with prayer flags fluttering in the foreground! Make sure you pray for clear skies though!

Beware of the fees at the top.. I hate it when the Nepali system of paying is so unclear, or even forced upon you. The sights are interesting especially the culture of Nepal. It's only good to see it once.

Wonderful place, reflects local troubles. The temple is amazing, on a high wooded hill overlooking the city, with monkeys everywhere. Definitely worth a visit. Should be five stars, but upkeep is questionable (trash everywhere except main path, many vendors interrupting visit) and views are obscured by the pervasive haze/smog over the city.

Cool experience, amazing views. I love heights, so visiting this place was amazing for me. The history, the temple, the area... are fantastic. Monkey sightings were amazing as well. Saw about 100 of them.
Monkey temple. Only if you like monkeys setting around. Nontheless the Tempel and the Viele are stunning. Get a lokal Guide at the entrance to explizit a bit about the place

Nice view of kathmandu valley . Known as the monkey temple perched up on a hill. Lots of stairs. There are 2 entrance to the temple. Avoid the steep stairs entrance if you have knee problems after your trekking trip.
3rd visit. What I love about nepal is the sights never get old or boring. Always spectacular and beautiful. A must visit when in kathmandu.

Go here too. Mukava paikka vierailla. Minulla oli onnea saada paikallinen munkki oppaaksi, joten samalla kuulin myös paikallisista elämäntavoista ja munkkien elämästä lyhyen saelostyuksen.
Nice plase to see. I had guided By local monck so it was interesting visit

Came for Sunset. Not much earthquake damage of the stupa from what we can tell.
Entrance is 200 rupees. From the car park, you walk some steps to the top where the Stupa is. We spent about 30 minutes here.
The sunset was also average. Nothing really special.

second visit. My first visit to this beautiful temple was several years ago prior to the damage caused by the earthquake. It remains a beautiful place to visit and it filled me with sadness to see the extent of the damage but work is being done to restore these temples to their former glory

Naughty Monkeys and Overpriced Buddhas. The trouble with Kathmandu is that it is a very spiritually-focused place, especially for the Western tourist. One visits Kathmandu expecting some kind of revelation. What the city does reveal is that the abject poverty that leaks from the city has also fashioned a way of survival for the people who call the city home. Meaning: at many of the religious sites, including this one, the trip is partially spiritual reflection and capitalist intervention. The hundreds of steps up to this stupa can take your breath away. At almost the very top, a man will ask you to pay the admission fee (a NPR 200 for foreigners, 50 NPR for locals). Not a bad idea. It goes to paying for the heritage preservation. Then at the top, you are greated by a gorgeous looking stupa that is no longer made of gold (but used to be). And many dozens of naughty little monkeys who make a game of stealing chapati and crisps from the hands of children, some of whom are brought by their parents to have a family picnic at the top of the hill.The monkeys can be quite entertaining, but I couldn't help but think that they brought a sense of poor hygeine to the place.Then there are the familes coming to the small temples around the stupa for blessings and puja. Very interesting to watch, as they are laced with flowers and given doti of vermillion and red on their foreheads. And lastly I remember the vendors asking if I wanted to buy a Buddha statue. I did. But the price they asked for even the smallest copper / bronze statues (US$45) made me choke with derision and surprise. Nepal has faced a lot in the wake of the two powerful earthquakes, and it is to be expected that people want to improve their lives. I just wish there was a better way other than selling artifacts that are really not genuine artifacts. But is there a better way?Please visit.
nice place. like it very much with tbus place.driver from my hotel took this place with other two guest from oman and it was really worth to visit.I just had two days in kathmandu it was not enoughf.

Fun place to watch monkeys play. It's a bit of a hike up to Swayambhunath Temple, but I liked to sit under the trees and prayer flags to watch the monkeys play. This was probably the best part for me. At the temple itself, there are many vendors and people, there is a view of the city but it was quite hazy, and it felt a bit hectic.

Lovely view from Atop.. beware of the monkeys!! But a beautiful view of the Nepal city and a must watch n photograph a Sunset from this point. Rich heritage and culture of Nepal can be seen and experienced here.
Long stairs but worth it!. 2nd after Boudhanath temple, Swayambunath is also one of the holiest place for Buddhist pilgrims. It has 365 stairs to reach the temple. Nice view of Kathmandu city..

Stunning, but beware the monkeys!. It's a trek up the steps (bring water!) and 200 rupees for foreigners but is well worth it. Absolutely stunning and great vistas of the city. The monkeys are an annoyance though- be wary of them.

Enchanted place. i feel really peaceful and saw whole kathmandu city from the top.
wow!! its amazing and wonderful and too any little temples around the swayambhu area.

Amazing views . Hell of a walk to get up there and a cheap entrance fee (which can be avoided via certain entries) but a well worth it. Amazing views of the valley, the stupa is nice and quite big and the monkeys are a bag of entertainment that cause just the right amount of chaos!!

Very memorable, culturally significant. The walk up to the temple is a bit far, but not unbearable. The eye of the temple is striking, and there are many religious structures at the site (turning prayers, etc), and the view of the city is great. Going down the hills, there were a lot of monkeys around the area. It was definitely one of the highlights of the trip.
Great place to view kathmandu. Swayambhunath is nice temple and view tower for kathmandu city, evening is good time to explore .lots of monkey and also called monkey temple.
moksh. I ve Been this place many times from my childhood... And always been peaceful place to me than anywhere in valley... Have to climb 265 stairs or more and have wonderful view of kathmandu..

Monkeying around for hilltop views of Kathmandu. Two of us visited Swayambhunath Temple on our last afternoon in Nepal. Admission is 200 NRs per person. We had an unpleasant encounter with the ticket agent who ended up getting 500 NRs for two of us and then accused us of not paying and refused to give us tickets. Fortunately, you do not need the paper tickets (no one at the temple grounds asked to inspect that we had paid admission). After that unpleasantness, everything else about the visit to Swayambhunath Temple was nice. I knew there were monkeys around but I was still surprised at the number of them. It's particularly intimidating when they move --very fast--as a group. There were also lots of pigeons and a few dogs and puppy. The views of Kathmandu from the temple are spectacular. I was sad to see many structures still suffering from earthquake damage. I know there are ways to evade paying the admission fee (probably why the ticket agent was grumpy and accusatory), but please pay it. Hopefully it will help with paying towards repairing the earthquake damage.
Worthwhile visit. This was a super place to go and tour. Lots of monkeys surrounding this mecca of a cultural temple. Enjoy!

another great place in kathmandu. when the driver asked us if we didnt mind a little walk to the temple we said great help digest the breakfast just finished in Yak and Yeti, nearing 50 and sedentary lifestyles took their toll climbing up to Swayambhunath Temple.365 steep steeps get steeper as we approach the top and we stumbles up to the top breathless and the massive Vajra (thunderbolt scepter) took our breath away.beautiful architecture and temples stupas around 1500 years old, the mystic eyes painted on the stupa and a fantastic view of the city.thank you kathmandu for all the splendour.

Very Auspicious site!. Lovely place to go if visiting nepal. Takes about 40 minutes to circumambulate around the temple once. Careful of the monkeys though. I would not bring food to this site at all!!! There are alot of monkeys and they just walk around very close to you so please please do not bring food as they will grab it from you or you may get bitten. Otherwise it is a lovely place. I would early in them morning around 8-8:30am before any crowds.

Brilliant hilltop position overlooking Kathmandu.. We did this at the start of a busy day's sightseeing and were not disappointed. I loved the monkeys and thought they added something - my wife was not so keen. We both enjoyed the tour and the earthquake damage did not detract from the experience - if anything it adds something.

Peace and Serenity.. If you wish to get out of the hustle and bustle from Kathmandu this is the place I would recommend in search of peace and serenity. When you get here you can see the fair and beautiful view of Kathmandu city, it looks amazing especially in the night.

Pick of the stupas in Kathmandu . Up front - I am not a fan on monkeys. They are just too smart and unpredictable for me to be comfortable around them. However, don't be put off by their presence here - they are mainly fairly placid and didn't come anywhere near me. The temple complex itself is very beautiful and serene. There are also good views down into the city and some interesting craft stalls. This was one of the best things I saw in Kathmandu so I'd strongly suggest you put it on your itinerary.

Well worth the steps. This temple is a must-visit if one is in Kathmandu and I highly recommend walking up the stairs - the monkeys are cute, the view of the city improves as you climb, and there is a sense of having reached a significant place as you top out on the stairs and contemplate the temple.
Have to go!. This is for sure one of the most emblematic temples that you can see in Nepal. For me was an incredible experience and I was impressed on the beauty of the place!
Try walking on the right. Was told by a local after I have visited that you could walk up the temple via the stairs on the right to avoid the admission fee.
Nice place. It is the place which is peaceful, right in middle of the town and on the top of the hill. You can enjoy the view of Kathmandu, you will see how the Kathmandu.

A Highlight of Kathmandu. I walked to here, which was nice, as you can climb the steps from the East and get a real feel for the experience. Friends were dropped off in the West parking lot, not as authentic. I love the many temples here and even the souvenir stores are amazing up on the plaza on top. Great views too. I think that since the earthquake this may be one of the best sites in town.
Beautiful temple. A must see for Katmandu travelers. It has really nice views of the valley. The temple is very old and I enjoyed visit g the temple.

Nice view, with entrance fee and lot of monkeys. As a tourist, this is a must. Great view over the city, but my recommendation is to go there early morning or afternoon because of the sunrise/sunset scenery. Also depends on the actual weather and smog (during my visit it was very smoggy/foggy). This site was affected by earthquake a lot, however in December 2015 was fully accessible with no restrictions and it's partially renowed.Be prepared for local residents - monkeys. They are literally everywhere. I was a bit scared first, bud they are domesticated and "respectful", so no need to worry about your personal items (if it's not food sticking out from your bag). There is also a small entrance fee - 200 rupees, a way less than in Durbar Square or Pashupatinath (1000 npr each).

amazing place. Quite amazing place a lots of steep steps to access and is actually quite small when you get up there.and many many monkey they make you felling happiness when you watching their activity in the ground of temple and jungle.. and over there evening time sunset view...owwww amazing you never forget that time ...
awasome holy place. we went to swayambhunath stupa and its call monkey temple too. and we saw whole kathmandu from top of the stupa. wow!!

Sunrise! In December - it was cloudy . Used to climb up here many times on previous visits but shocked how hard it was again this time.Make sure you take water, there will be places up at the top but you may need a half way stop! It's easy to walk there from Thamel, but check out a map beforehand. If unsure take a taxi! If heading for sunrise, it can be very dark, so walking the streets take a touch.Swayambhunath is a local place to go to exercise in the morning, so be prepared to share your view with the odd press up and monkey in front of you.Best tip - Get there before 6:30am and you don't have to pay the 200 rupees.After the earthquake it's clear what damage was caused and it's awful to see so many buildings destroyed! Be careful when walking around as there are a number of "danger zones" Good news if you go past the stupa and turn right down a side path, there are public toilets. Which is a nice change to other places on Kathmandu.Strongly recommend a visit but if you are not prepared to do the climb you can always take the back road and get a taxi!

My second Nirvana!!!!. After visiting Boudhanath, this was my must to be visited place. even after the earthquake the place still stands strong and gives the amazing view of KTM city. You will love the monkey summon here :D

City of Temples. Swayambunath is also another stupa in the city of temples. In the country where Buddha was born and where happy and poor people live these stupas have seen this all for the centuries. It seems like those have shouldered all the thoughts of people as they also look sad. The building and the murals surrounding the temple is also nice to see if you are a travellers. And in you are interested in archeology better you read before you get here as these murals of stones and timer surely have a bigger story to tell to the people who are interested.

Amazing. My 2nd trip there. Before the earthquake n after the earthquake. I was lucky enough to have captured both the photo during n after the earthquake of this Swayambhunath stupa. I just cant imagine how the earthquake happen. The attire structure and small shops around it rubbled within seconds. It was such a beautiful ancient architecture atop a hill. A place must visit on planet earth.
Serene. This is a must-see for anyone visiting Kathmandu; to get a deep insight into their culture. If anything, the view of the valley from atop the temple is magnificent.

Lovely Temple, great views. A really fun place to visit as there are monkeys everywhere (be careful of you bag/loose items, they will try to take things). Have to climb a lot of stairs but when you get to the top the views are fantastic and well worth the climb.

Worth walking from thamel. I walked to the temple from Thamel which was a nice 40 minute walk out of the polluted and touristy Thamel through back streets and passed houses and the real Kathmandu. I got quite lost getting there but once out of Thamel you can see the temple in the hill so it doesn't matter if you get lost. The temple has lots of steep steps to access and is actually quite small when you get up there, a few stalls selling items and a queue of devotees waiting to be blessed. It's amazing the main bit of the temple wasn't badly destroyed in the earthquake though surrounding buildings are being repaired. Worth the 200 rupees entrance fee

Better to go up from the back side! :). Quite "sprawling & spacious" grounds on not one, but TWO levels (don't have to go too many steps from the middle level to the top though) are what await you at this temple on top of the hill by the same name, and the best advice I can give when it comes to this temple is to go up from the back side with "easier" steps leading to the middle level where I suggest you spend half an hour to an hour, starting from the two white stupas and the little pond with a standing Buddha in the middle to the back area where there's a rectangular-shaped structure with small dharma wheels around it and a two-story red temple with lion statues at its gate, before going up to the top where the main stupa is. There are also great views of the city below from near the red temple (mentioned above), but the views may be somewhat obscured by trees there, and yes do keep an eye on the monkeys and don't go too close to them (I encountered quite aggressive ones!).And the way I did after the middle level (after coming back to the front side of the middle level from the red temple at the back) to get to the top is taking the steps on the left side which took me: firstly to the back area of the top with a big golden-and-red Buddha and two-or-three-story brick buildings on three sides selling miscellaneous religious items like strings of beads, statuettes and masks; secondly to the more spacious courtyard-like area surrounded on all four sides by similar brick buildings selling similar items as at the back area; and finally to the main stupa at the open area on the left after passing through these miniature tower-shaped & cone-shaped structures on the part of the temple grounds near the Stupa (those structures are actually scattered all over the temple grounds on both levels, but there's a big cluster of them near the Stupa). Also be sure to take in the absolutely "spectacular" view of the city below and the surrounding mountains of the Kathmandu Valley from the lookout area just past the Stupa where you might also see some people burning things in small cups or something for maybe some religious reason. The front side which is the side most tourists use (and where the main parking area is) will bypass the middle level and take you straight up to the top (you could go down to the middle level from the top though, kind of opposite to the way I did with the middle level first coming up the hill from the back), but it will be a "much more" arduous way compared to going up from the back side to the middle level first. The only things worthwhile to use the steps on the front side are these two pretty identical sets of three golden-and-red Buddhas along the way up (the first set pretty close to the bottom of the hill, the second one a bit higher up), but you could check out those Buddhas on the front-side steps AFTER coming down the hill from the back side (the same way as going up) and walking around or getting your cab to drive around to the front.From Thamel, it's just about a half-hour walk west to get here (have to walk around about another 15 minutes though to get to the steps on the back side), so a cab is just optional which will only be like a ten-minute ride (ask the driver to take you to the back if you want to go up the way I did). I didn't walk here though, actually did a combo tour that day (arranged at my hotel) starting from Thamel to Bodhnath first, then to Buddhanilkantha and finally to this one before returning to Thamel costing 3,000 Nepalese rupees (about US$30), which was a good deal since there seemed no other option to get to those two other places (Bodhnath & Buddhanilkantha) quite distant from the heart of the city (where Thamel is).

the ancient Swayambunath Stupa (known to tourists as the Monkey Temple) is Kathmandu's most important Buddhist shrine.. At the bottom of the eastern stairway is a brightly painted gate containing a huge Tibetan prayer wheel nearly 12 feet tall. It takes two people to turn it and a bell sounds during each revolution. Around the gate are dozens more smaller wheels. Devotees spin prayer wheels to release prayers and mantras to heaven - visitors are welcomed to do so as well.and as many other things

Beautiful high temple and cool monkeys!. We went on a private day tour with Kishore from Ace the Himalaya. He met us at our hotel in Thamel and walked us to the Monkey Temple. It was great to see the city that way. Once we got to the temple, he walked us up the LONG LONG staircase and then explained the history and significance of the temple. He showed us the impact of the earthquake and explained the efforts of the restoration. It was great having him with us-- he knew just how close to get to the monkeys, he taught us much about the religion and helped us make offerings and buy candles. Having him as a guide added to our experience immensely.

Many great homemade crafts on sale in the surrounding compound in spite of the earthquake damage.. Please visit in spite of the earthquake - a great world destination that is rebuilding itself. Pass on the wordl!!!

Spectacular views on top of the temple. Some known this as Monkey Temple. I was there when the earthquake was happened but I was so lucky that I was on my way down the hill when it's happened. I hope that they have repaired its to much as possible by now.You will have to climb up quite a bit to reach the top and you will find monkey all around. Once you reach the top, you will find a 360 degree magnificent view of the city. There are souvenir shop around the there. Normally people will walk around the stupa in a clockwise direction and spinning the prayer wheel. I imagined if it's less crowded, it can be a very peaceful moment.You will find lots of souvenir shop around there as well.

Don't stare at the monkeys. A good place to start seeing the sights of KTM.There are many stairs to climb but the view at the top and the opportunity to buy the local begging kids ice cream is worth it!

A Must See. There's no question - this is simply one of the things that you *must* see if you're in Kathmandu.It's a bit dirty (a lot is in Kathmandu) and there are too many vendors selling tourist tchotchke, but look past that. It's a beautiful complex worth seeing. And of course, it's called the "Monkey Temple" for a reason - they are everywhere! Fun to watch. Just don't get too close or look them in the eye. ;)

Swayambhunath temple after earthquake. Although the area has been affected by the earthquake, with lost temples and a monastery, the site is still well worth visiting. The 365 steps up the hill can seem daunting but worth the effort, there is slightly easier access from car park behind the complex. The monkeys tend to ignore you and go about their own business. Guides are available to take you around if required, worth the small cost. Repair work is underway on the complex and the cafe was not fully open.
Monkey Temple. Really fun to see all the monkeys. The view of the city can't be beat. Definitely worth checking out while you are there.

WORTH EVERY STEP!!!. There are many many steps to climb to the top of this temple but it was by far one of my favorites in Kathmandu. The temple was not damaged from what I could see and it was alive with worshipers, tourists, monkeys, dogs, and venders. Follow the example of the worshipers and read the signs to behave appropriately. It is a holy site. One of the vendors introduced us to the singing bowls and did a meditative ritual. We found the experience wonderful enough to buy the bowl...lol.

Stunning. This is a very beautiful temple perched on the the top of a hill. The lazy half-closed eyes are famous to Buddhists the world over. It was very lucky to escape with very little damage during the recent earthquake. I would have given this an 'excellent', but for the idiot ticket seller screaming at me to pay whilst I was still fifteen steps from the entrance and the badgering touts and sellers, took the gleam off a wonderful spot.Panoramic views are stunning.

Beautiful and Serene. You'ill have to climb up multiple steps to reach the temple complex, which has a stupa, a library/museum. There as shops all across you way up the stairs. After reaching the complex, you get to see the valley below - awesome view.

Monkey Temple , very unique. This is a Hill Top temple, known as Monkey Temple too. Enjoyed the Monkeys taking bath / swim in the special pool created for them. A top you climb steps to have darshan of Buddha Stupa. Here too some structure damaged due to the earthquake. The Kathmandu City panoramic view from the top is very beautiful.
Lovely place. This temple and it's surrounding areas are a great place to visit! There is just a really nice atmosphere and a nice view over the smog-covered Kathmandu.

Worthwhile. We visited for a few hours, watching the packs of monkeys suddenly running past - it's an experience worth doing and you're garaunteed to see monkeys!Don't take plastic bags or food because monkeys steal!The downside is that it's overrun by salespeople. It's like a mini market; they have nice stone etchings and singing bowls but other than that it's the same old stuff.Great for passing a few hours. Note you'll have to climb a lot of steps to get up there.And not all monkeys keep it PG.
A must see site. despite the earthquake damage to the stupa this is still an incredibly inspiring site and a great place for tourists to enjoy the handicrafts and art of Nepel.

Holy n ancient place set on a hill top. An absolutely beautiful building. However, it's heart-wrenching to see the poor begging for food at the steps while the people in the temple are throwing food at their God's. Overall it gave a good insight into the the Nepali spiritual life.
Went there for a few hours. Nice site seeing.Many monkeys..It's nice to visit, but to many people who pushing you to buy something. All the beauty is taken away by all the souvenir sellers :-(

Any time of day awesome!. I loved sunrise when people come to pray. But its beautiful with beautiful views anytime of day - I highly recommend it!!! A must if going to Kathmandu - you can really see the city from up there!

Climb those stairs!. We were given the choice to climb the stairs or to take the van up to a higher point. The stairs were steep but so worth it to people and monkey-watch as you make your way to the top. The history of Monkey Temple is fascinating..we had a wonderful guide from Distinctive Nepal tours....and it was just plain fun to see all the monkeys.

Nice Monument!!. For peace of mind and a good view of the Kathmandu city, this monument is among the top places to visit. The stupa is a sacred place for the Buddhists and offers a good 360 degree view of the capital city of Nepal. Must visit!!

Beautiful as always!. Swayambu, I grew up with a view of the top of this temple in the background. It is as I remember, if not better. However this was in April, I wonder what the recent events have done to it. The view of the city is good from the temple. Its worth visiting.
Beautiful and entertaining. Must go if you're in Kathmandu. Monkeys are awesome! It's truly wonderful and refreshing. Just go :)

My favorite temple to visit. Among Boudha, Pashupatinath and Swayambhunath temples, Swayambhunath is by far my favorite. Climbing and seeing the blue, white, red, green and white flags gives it a special charm. Besides there are hidden tiny special secrets all around the temple. For me the must to visit in Kathmandu

A haven of peace. "May peace prevail on earth" The Swayambhunath Monkey Temple is a truly haven of peace although
Monkeys in a bit scratchy with each other.

worth every step on the way to the top!. For me, walking to this historical site from Thamel was the best than taking a vehicle. The 365 steps (denoting the days of a year) get quite strenuous towards the end but the climbing is all worth for the amazing views that this place offers of the Kathmandu valley. History buffs will love this place because it has so much to say!

A must visit in Kathmandu. Visited the temple in the year 2010. Absolutely amazing experience. Didn't realise the steepness of the temple stairs due to excitement. Can be seen some very rare piece of art and sculptures. Took lots of pictures of the temple itself. Most part of the Kathmandu valley can be seen from here. The scenery is beautiful.Also lighted candles in the temple. I wonder, how the recent earthquake have affected this beautiful temple.

Watch out for the Monkeys. Its a nice climb and good exercise all the way to the top, I have been up thre 3 time and its always beautiful. The monkeys used to be able to gt 100% of their food from the jungle around the money temple, but the expanding city and human population has encroached their jungle and food source. the monkeys now get more than 12 of their food from people who feed them, and they are old enough to come after you if you bring any food or drinks out that they can see. I bought a juice box from a woman sitting selling drinks and a whole pack of monkeys cam after me and stole my juice box! they also started to stalk a friend of mine who was carrying a piece of coconut!

Monkey temple. I was been there with one of my close friend and had real fun out there. There was lot of monkey down there and they were snatching things up from the tourist.There got nice views from the top of the Temple. You can see the whole city view from there. Should Visit if you're in Kathmandu. I went there by walk from Thamel and it was fun walking from local street. Should try.

Best view of Kathmandu!. Climbing all the stairs is definitely exhausting, but you will be well rewarded when you take this path up (and not the easier paved road to the left). There will be plenty of monkeys on your way up, and there is something special with watching the view appear as you climb. The view on top is breathtaking!
If you go to Kathmandu, you go to Swayambhunath. Swayambhunath is an integral part of Kathmandu. Not seeing it is like staying in your Hotel room and not seeing anything

Beautiful temple with great views of the city. I really enjoyed visiting this temple- although affected by the earthquake, it still maintained it's wonderful aura and was a joy to visit. There are great views of the city from the top and there is an ancient feel to the place, which is worth experiencing. There are also lots of monkeys around the temple, which were not aggressive, compared to other places that I've visited.

Great views. The views from the top alone are well worth the walk up the stairs and entry fee. The temples, souvenir stalls and monkeys will keep you occupied for ages. Just be careful, if you're carrying a bag in your hands the monkeys WILL attempt to snatch it, otherwise they won't bother you.

Certainly a worthwhile visit. This is a World Heritage site and with good reason. It is situated on a high hill in the city, and you can climb the steps or a car can drive up the back way, leaving a small walk to the temple. It is a significant site both religiously and historically. There are many monkeys, so carrying food or drink is unprofitable unless you want to get to know a monkey up close and personal. Vendors are typically enthusiastic without going overboard. Buildings are closed because of damage from the earthquake, but the historically and architecturally important stupa is intact. Also a great place to see black kites (the bird) very close.
Must see - the monkey temple. This is a Buddhist temple and a World Heritage site. The site is a muddle of Buddhist and Hindu iconography.

Visit at night. Spectacular Views. we visited the place at night. you can get a full view of the katmandu valley below. Beware of the monkeys around. There are a lot. You can either go by car or trek up the stairs. Be careful if climbing up the stairs. some of them are quite steep.
very fresh environment. I visited swayambhunath 15 days before earthquake in 2015. you have to climb steps. great view of the Kathmandu. Good place to visit....
Monkeys everywhere. Fantastic views across the Kathmandu valley. So many monkeys - don't eat any snacks! Not too much earthquake damage - enjoy the walk up the steps!
Highlight. Don't miss this wonderful site. Earthquake effects evident but Nepal will rebuild Very special part of Nepal
Monkey Temple. The temple is a great place to see stupa's, monkeys and get some exercise. It has great views of Kathmandu Valley

Interesting place. Great views of the city, interesting architecture, monkeys everywhere and even a good number of souvenir shops. Long staircase to go up unless you drive to the back and after 111 steps you are at the top :)

It's worth the trek.. It's a nice short getaway from Thamel. You'll get a nice view of Kathmandu from this temple. See swarms of monkey on the way up. It's a 20 minute walk to the stairway from Thamel, about 300+ steps up. The walk from Thamel isn't eventful, but you'll get to see the locals. 200 rupees entrance fee.
Damaged but still worthwhile. Like the Bhoda stupa, the monkey temple was also damaged by the earthquake but it will eventually be repaired again. It is still worth visiting in spite of the damage.

Tradition & Religion. On top of a mountain from where you can see Kathmandu from a birds eye view, Swayambhunath or the Temple of Monkeys is a fabulous place to visit while in Kathmandu. It is probably bigger than what you expect, full of life everywhere! The monkeys are adorable, make sure you visit the swimming pool where they like to jump, swim and play (it is a bit hidden, but ask for it!).

Stunning views over Kathmandu. Swayambhunath Temple, also known as the Monkey Temple, because of the hundreds of monkeys freely moving around the temple. Great 360 degrees views over Kathmandu looking towards the mountains. Atmospheric. Bit of a climb up lots of steps but well worth it, it has to be included in your itinerary for Kathmandu.

A religious site with a view. Despite being a significant religious site, most of the visitors (whilst I was there anyway) seemed to be more interested in the commanding views of greater Kathmandu. The seemingly peaceful relationship between dogs, monkeys and birdlife reflect the co-habitation of Buddhist and Hindu faiths. Earthquake damage detracts from its beauty as do the merchandisers but efforts are being made to rectify at least one of these.

Even with earthquake damage...Amazing. Spectacular views and lots of merchants and monkeys to keep you entertained along the way. The long walk up steep steps is not for the faint of heart but definitely worthwhile in terms of the secular views. Mediation music playing in the background makes this even more tranquil of a visit.
Interesting temple. Gorgeous view of Kathmandu from the top and very interesting history. Monkeys were a little unnerving, especially when they fight each other right near you.

Worth to visit as part of kathmandu visit. This temple was sustained some damage from the earthquake but for the most part it is intact. The temple is mobbed by monkeys which is the reason for its name "the monkey temple." It is probably not the cleanest place but it is still interesting and beautiful with many carving stones, rotating worship bells which are moved by the pilgrims when pass by. It is the best place to take a paranomic view of kathmandu valley.There is a school of mandala painting which is very interesting and informative. You can buy some authentic mandala paintings here.
Head of kathmandu Valley. It's lies height of western part of Kathmandu valley.it is a small hills.we can see Kathmandu valley from Swayambhunath temple. we are know also monkey temple.

Amazing Temple on top of a hill surrounded by Monkeys. This temple was amazing, and there were many monkey's to greet us on the hike up the steps. It's also called "monkey temple" and many holy men hang out on the steps below. It gives a good view of Kathmandu and the temple itself is old and stunning. Worth the visit, not sure how badly damaged it was in the April earthquake, we were there the day before the earthquake and luckily flew out the next day before it happened.
Monkey Temple. 2 ways up steep steps or from park - a great location especially later in the day when light goes low and warm

Must See Attraction. This stupa is still intact, thank god. Some of the buildings around it are damaged, but nothing that gets in the way of the vibe here. Great view of the city, great area. Make sure that when you do the long walk up that you're not eating any food. My friend was eating some bread and a monkey lunged at him and stole it. It could be dangerous if the monkey scratches you as it did with my friend. Great attraction.

Do not miss this!! Its beautiful. Swayambhunath temple was not included in our day trip in Kathmandu so my mom and I decided to venture out on our own. It was the best decision ever! We climbed up to the top and got amazing views of Kathmandu and of course, got to see the Swayambhunath Temple's stupa. It was peaceful and very nice. Highly recommended... they call it the temple of the monkeys b/c there are lots of monkeys you will find on the way to the top. Make sure you have comfortable shoes as there are lots of steps to climb up!

Nice temple complex with monkeys. We visited this during our Nepal trip in December 2010. Swayambhunath is an ancient religious architecture atop a hill in the Kathmandu Valley and one of the most sacred among Buddhist pilgrimage sites.We saw lot of monkeys roaming around and nice handicraft shops in the temple complex.The Swayambhunath complex consists of a stupa, a variety of shrines and temples, a Tibetan monastery, museum and library. The stupa has Buddha's eyes and eyebrows painted on it and between them, the number one (in Devanagari script) is painted in the fashion of a nose.

Dirty Monkeys, Dirty Area. I was underwhelmed the day I visited. The views of Kathmandu were obscured by smog, the monkeys were nasty, and the site itself was unkempt and just had the feel of a bazaar with booths selling trinkets and many, many beggars

Hidden Gem in Kathmandu. Earthquake damage is being actively repaired. Still lovely to walk around. The monastery is small but a welcoming space. Lots of shops around to buy pretty much anything you want.

Interesting Visit. I really enjoyed my visit. Great views of Kathmandu, interesting learning about the temple, and the monkeys were a real highlight. There is a pool of water that they throw themselves into time after time having a great time. Lots of fun to watch. There are many stairs to climb and it can be very hot so bring water and an umbrella for shade.

A temple uphill with monkeys. You can either choose to climb uphill or get a ride all the way to the door step of the temple. There wasn't as many monkeys as I had expected. It's still worth a visit as you can get a birds eye view of Kathmandu valley from the top of the temple!

Monkey temple, Panoramic view of KTM. This too is an obligatory stop for every tourist in Kathmandu. The walk up to the top or the drive up to the top gives you a lovely overview of the city of Kathmandu.
Stunning view. It's a must to visit this holy place. Wonderful and peaceful.Loads of hungry monkeys around, please feed them.Stunning view for Kathmandu in clear weather.

Beautiful temple with city-view. Popularly known as 'monkey temple', I think. Didn't see many monkeys, but the temple structures were beautiful, despite some damage from earthquake. Beautiful city view because it's quite a climb up: you can ask to be dropped at entrance at top, then walk down to street after touring the temple, if roundtrip walking is too much. About 45min walk from Thamel, where many nice garden restaurants are available to cool down in with a beer.
Great view of Kathmandu Valley. We visit this place afternoon before earth quack. The View of Kathmandu city & valley from this temple was so amazing!

Lovely Temple. Very spiritual place; a truly enjoyable visit.
Be aware of steps to walk to the top of the hill and also be careful of monkeys stealing food!

Monkey paradise. Beautiful views of the city from here . Good walk up and down to the temple so suggest sensible footwear.
Magnificent Stupa temple
Monkey temple. Amazing views from this temple. It is a definitely sightseeing n.1. Beautiful sunset and sunrise from this place.

We like Monkeys!. Which is just as well as there were hundreds of them!
Entertainment itself watching them play and groom each other.
Some earthquake damage but mostly intact. Amazing views of the city
