Fun but surreal time filler . We visited the temple as we had a day to kill having travelled from Lukla waiting for a flight to London. This proved very entertaining and a nice taste of Kathmandu. The monkeys are very cute and full of character and seeing these animals up close rather than in a cage is a real bonus. The temple itself is an interesting and curious mix of religious site and tourist destination but the mix somehow works. The stall vendors will give you the hard sell but they do it with charm so it's not a problem. Haggle with them!

100 BC Buddhist Stupa. One of the oldest pilgrimage landmark in Kathmandu that dates back to thousand years...this holy place is very famous among buddhist communities of the world and should be visited once in a life time

A must see!. A trip to Kathmandu would not be complete with a visit to the Monkey Temple!! You must climb the stairs to the top! You can step to the side and catch your breath if needed. Worth the climb once you see the monkeys everywhere. You can feed them and watch them play! Will make you feel like a kid feeding Monkeys!

Such a shame. My wife and I visited Kathmandu as part of our 25th Anniversary Asia tour this October, such a shame to see such an iconic landmark in the city so devistated by the recent earthquake, but , the locals have committed to rebuild, we visited the temple just to see its condition. No access was allowed inside due to structural damage although the surrounding shops were open. The tower had been removed and was being stored and repaired. Please visit this iconic landmark and as we did leave a donation at the tented donation desk, you will receive a receipt and monies raised will bring this Stupa back to its forma glory

Cool place to visit when in Kathmandu. This temple is also called the Monkey Temple. It is perched high on a hill in Kathmandu with spectacular views to the city and surrounds below. There are many different things to experience there including a Thanka art school where you can learn about this intricate style of religious art. Be careful of the cheeky monkeys that will try and steal any treats such as fresh coconut you might buy while visiting the temple.

Nice view of city in the evening.. If you plan to reduce weight or born some calories, you can go for evening walk/hike to swysmbhunath stupa located few km from famous tourist hub thamel. You can see beautiful view of kathmandu city in the evening. I keep visiting this place every time i make visit to kathmandu. This october i have taken my younger sister for sight seeing. She was amazed to see the view from the top. Its always good to feel the cool breeze from the top.
Beautiful views & monkeys provide entertainment. Definitely worth a visit. The stupa is one of the most ancient and enigmatic holy shrines. Hindus and Buddhists worship here.

Watch out for the Monkeys. This place is also known as the 'Monkey Temple' and you will see when you arrive.....they are everywhere. Once again a very holy place in Kathmandu which is busy all day every day.
Great view over the city. Climb up the hill via the steep 365 steps with the stupa right in front of you. Once up, turn around and you'll be amazed by the stunning view over the city. :)

Atmosphere plus. This is still worth a visit, in spite of earthquake damage. Little shops around the stupa are keen for business. I visited on a festival day, when pigeons, dogs and monkeys enjoyed rice and other offerings. Wonderful small shrines surround the central one. Great for photography. The tea shop has closed, unfortunately.
So nice!. Don't only walk up the stairs to the stupa. Also walk to the right in front of the entrance and see the the other sculptures and "begging-wheel". Fantastic view over the city from the top.
Nice view of kathmandu. Just alot of steps to get there. If the view is good enough the sun set is quite nice from up there. Don't tease the monkeys or they will become aggressive
A moving experience viewing an anchient temple. The recent earthquake harmed many of the temples. Please visit anyway the people need your support and you will see an amazing culture and people.
30th Anniversary Trip. It was an amazing culture experience that helped see the another part of the people of Nepal. This was the type people in a crowd that makes Lora happy.

Worth the climb . Worth the climb at sunset for great views over Kathmandu. If your into photography I would say it's definitely a worthwhile excursion. Also lots of monkeys about so we enjoyed taking photos of them climbing all over the temple:)

Gud to Visit. For Travellers it a MUST to visit point in Kathmandu.
The Ancient Temple with Monkeys is a worth visiting that you would really love.

Stunning views. A wonderful temple complex located on the top of a hill, offering stunning views over the Kathmandu valley. Be aware of the monkeys and don't even think of bringing food and/or shopping bags to the premises. The monkeys are on the constant look out of stealing everything that looks interesting to them!
Ancient Stupa. Ancient temple at the highest point of Kathmandu valley. from here on a clear day one can observe whole valley. be careful of monkey, no food on your hand monkey will take it.
The famous monkey temple. I love this temple. In the area around there are many many monkeys. It has a nice athmosphere and is a part of every guided tour in Kathmandu. Some shops are also there.

worth a visit. This is an interesting location and is worth a visit for the views of Kathmandu alone - probably the best their is from the ground.
There are lots of monkeys around and they are rascals, pinching things from people. The temples are lovely and the pics from here are great for the album.

Worth a trip but not a relaxing experience . Fantastic views of Kathmandu and glad we did it. We walked from Shanker hotel Lazimpat. Really enjoyed the walk, lots to see in the streets along the way. I personally felt quite anxious with all the monkeys around the temple and they were fighting as we walked up the stairs. Wanted to enjoy the view but felt a bit on edge as sellers pestering you and street children begging on the way up. We were offered to hold a baby on the way up. Glad we did it but personally did not find it a relaxing experience in which you could appreciate the significance and setting.
1000 steps up. Good training for your upcoming trek 2000 stepsLots of monkeys , great veiws of Kathmandu, lots of earthquake damage

Peaceful and serene. I went there in the late afternoon and stayed to watch the sunset. It is a beautiful temple, unfortunately you can see the cracks and damages on the stupas from the recent earthquake. Take time to turn the dharma wheels that string the entire exterior perimeter of the temple.

Peaceful place and even athiests would feel that they had a pilgrimage after climbing up the steps. I wanted to walk through the city to get here, and found the steps at the bottom of the hill. I heard that a lot of people walk around the side to alternative steps, but please do not. You walk up many steps to different levels where myriad shrines are dotted around the place and after the first climb of steps you'll find that the noise and chaos of Kathmandu has some how disappeared. You will need to walk several flights of steps before you get to the top so take a bottle of water on those hot days; you'll need it.The temple complex at the top was very sadly damaged due to the earthquake, but damage aside I wanted to go, and felt that this holy place still kept its atmosphere. the views from the top are incredible. The temple complex is bigger than it initially seems to give yourself time to talk around - I spent half a day up there, just strolling and find a shaded spot here and there to sit and soak up this place. If only in its small measure does my payment contribute to the restoration of this place then I am please to pay. I donated too because the world would be diminished if Nepal's places of wonder were not restored back to their pre-earthquake condition.
Oasis of Peace. Loved the peace of this place and watching the monks walk around. A must see place during your stay in Kathmandu

Some parts are effect from earthquake - but need to see. Go , for helping the effected area by buying ticket
Nice coffee and restaurants avaialbe around the temple

shame on nepal. it's very nice and beautiful place, but it's very dirty unfortunately,
you can see the whole city from up there. it worth to visit but take care of monkeys, they will take anything you put on the ground.
Beautiful. Well the walk up the hill to view this monument. Its a pity tat there is some earthquake damage although the main structure seems intact

The 365 steps to the top is a must do!. I loved the 365 steps! Passing giant statues on the way and people playing those strange little violin type things. Driving up is cheating and will take away some of the magic!There are definitely lots of monkeys around but they aren't the problem - the people with those stupid selfie sticks are. Try go at a time where it may be quiter, otherwise wear a helmet.
Amazing temple. One of the must visit temples in Kathmandu. Very good views as well. Do not miss this visit while in Kathmandu

Very interesting place. We did hike there from Thamel as during fuel crises taxi drivers charge some crazy money for driving just a couple of km! Great place, we get there at the evening and both Kathmandu and hills looked great. Monkeys around poking and getting snacks from the temple keepers. You can see some scares after earthquake but generally the place did not suffered much. Hiking the loooong stairs was fun. At the evening there were young Nepali jogging up the stairs. Very impressive! :)

Amazing place, easy to observe local religious traditions.. Locals call it the monkey temple. It's only 25 min walk away from thamel. After climbing about 400 steps you get beautiful view to kathmandu valley. They charge 200 nrp from tourists, but it's wel worth the price. And the monkeys, there are hundreds of them. Take good care of your belongings because every now and then the monkeys tries to steal them.
Interesting view. Interesting view of Kathmandu. Some parts are still in damaged condition after the earthquake so be careful. But this monkey temple is really worth a visit.
Swayambhunath Temple. Well worth the long walk up as there are great views of KTM here. Lots of monkeys and stray dogs wandering around.

Hill top stupa, standing tall even after the mighty earthquake. I had been here on 2010. When I learnt about a major quake in Kathmandu in April 2015, I was worried about this ancient monument. So, I was very curious to visit this place again when I went here in September 2015. Glad to see that the main structure is standing tall, in tact, with negligible damage. Some surrounding temple buildings did suffer a lot and are in different stages of renovation.One has to walk between 20 and 40 minutes in two directions to reach the main stupa. It is quite a steep ascent and elderly people find it not very easy to reach the top. The road to top has many monkeys snatching food articles from the hands of the tourists. There are many hawkers lining both sides of the roads to sell small mementos and typical touristic things.Once on top, one can really have a "bird's eye view" of the whole Kathmandu city. Small temples around showcase coexistence of two religions - Hinduism and Buddhism side by side, peacefully. It is a beautiful spot for photography. Buddha's eyes painted here are symbol of Nepal tourism and easily identifiable everywhere. This is a scenic spot worth a couple of hours at least. If you have enough time to spare, it is worth even half a day. But do remember, it is tiring at the end of the day.

Great view over Kathmandu. My favorite spot in Kathmandu. You can easily walk from Thamel. Once you reach it, there are steep steps up to the temple. You can take another entrance from left or right side - just ask the locals. The netry fee is 200Rs. The view is just perfect!

Sacred and Enchanting (Monkeys, Dogs, Goats, too!). Without getting too lost in the narrow, curving streets, I walked from my hotel in Thamel, Kathmandu to the Swayambhuanath Temple and up the 365 unevenly cut rock steps and into the gazing stares of Buddha's Eyes. The panoramic views from the top are awe inspiring. On a clear day, most of the Kathmandu City Valley is visible, as are the highest white mountains in the far distance. Every animal is allowed to be at the temple, so hundreds of monkeys play and climb on every building and tree. (Swayambhunath is also called "Monkey Temple") I saw several dogs sleeping in the shaded areas, and even a family of goats standing near one stupa. Very early in the morning, the temple is quite, calm and restful. The later in the day, more and more tourists, pilgrims, vendors and loudness move into the area and Swayambhunath becomes a crowded & noisy "attraction" rather than a much revered sacred place of worship and meditation. The earthquake in April 2015 damaged one of the tall stupas and it fell completely down. There used to be a restaurant in an upper part, which was also damaged and closed as of October 02, 2015, anyway. Early in the morning this ancient temple is absolutely breath-taking and serene. It's most definitely worth the climb up the steps!!

After the earthquake .... Last visit in October 2014 I was curious to re-visit the Swayambunath temple in October this year.Actually and all in all the temple area looks better than expected. A number of buildings have been destroyed and works are ongoing. People there try to do their best to welcome tourists here and there are as many souvenir stores as before.

Lovely view from the top. I was here before the earthquake of 2015.We took a taxi from Thamel and climbed the stairs to the top while avoiding the monkeys.We have been warned by our guide that they could be dangerous.Love the temple and the view from the top.Beautiful.

Ancient heritage. Good to see after the huge earthquake in April 2015.. I recommend to visit this heritage which is the symbol of peace for all Buddhists and Hindus. Similar structures are found in many other countries, but this is quite unique.

Easily accessible and good views of Kathmandu. Suggest taking the longer steps to the temple to better enjoy the ambience and go earlier in the day when religious attendances are up and the heat is down.

Steep walk up the 365 steps but the views were amazing!. The culture of Kathmandu was wonderfully present at the Monkey Temple! The earthquake damage is being restored, and the prayer flags waving in the sky were beautiful. This is one site to see!

Damaged but still wonderful. Even when it was severely damaged during April's earthquake, Swayambu is still one of the reasons you would love Kathmandu. The temple itself is magnificent and full of symbolism. In a clear day, the views are amazing. And of course, there are hundreds of monkeys....but believe me, this is more than a "monkey temple" as many others around south Asia.

Lovely temple beautiful views. Great views from here. This is a lovely temple, often called the monkey temple because the monkeys (and all animals) are treated with respect and overrun this temple. I would advise great care of your belongings as the monkeys will snatch things out of your hand e.g. bottles of water. There are also many stray dogs around .

Great Sunset. A big flight of stairs up to the temple is well worth it. If you go in the evening, the guard leaves and you can get in for free, and also see many of the locals who use the stairs as a fitness training ground. Plus there is usually a spectacular sunset to the West, and a view of all of Kathmandu to the East. A great place.
Monkey Temple. Only 10 minutes drive from Thamel by taxi, you can be dropped at the top or walk up the steps from the bottom, there are a lot and they are steep, but worth it for the view.

Beautiful stupa. Perched on a hilltop, Swayambhunath is a beautiful stupa, well worth the 365 steep steps up. The view from the top is priceless. Watch out for the monkeys (Swayambu is sometimes called monkey temple) and the numerous merchants hawking their wares. I'm not sure which were more scary.
Do make some butter light offerings at NPR5 per light.

Majestic Heritage, Beuatiful View!. One of my favourite spots in Kathmandu. You have an amazing view over the city from the hilltop and the majestic Stupa is particularly beautiful on a bright sunny day! The surrounding temples, statues, small gardens and little shops make it a lovely location where you can easily spend a couple of hours! Beware of the not so shy monkeys who are always on the lookout for food! Your are best arriving from the side entry and then taking the main entrance with steep steps on your way down!
The views over Kathmandu. 365 steps the hard way or up the slope. The monkeys and views are worth seeing. I did have a guide which made the visit all the more interesting.

Unique Place - Truly watching over the city. Never mind the number of stairs you have to climb to reach to the top, never mind too the numerous monkeys trying to snatch your camera or water bottle; just reach to the top if you are able to and see for yourself - you can truly see the whole city just like the eyes of God Swyambhu who has been watching over the city and protecting it for ages. The place has its own charm - the stone lingams, the golden shrine, numerous curio like shops selling innumerable stuff.. just take it in! Unlike most of the other Hindu shrines where people try to loot you in the name of God, here nobody will do that - no pushing, no forceful offering. I loved the place, you will too.
good valley view place. You will see nice view from here after 3o clock good time it is related place for Buddhist and Hindu religious also known as in world heritage site nice for day tour

By Gum! - get tha' sen a lift. Taken to the bottom by rickshaw and then we climbed, and climbed and climbed.But the views from the top are stunning and a whole new world greets you.Don't forget to "go down" the other side to see the rest of this superb site and to experience a different route down.Being lazy so will upload some photos and let them speak in stead of me. But you can still like my effort as I crave recognition.Ta
Fabulous Views. The hike to the temple is well worth it. The views are fabulous and although the temple has suffered some damage the ambiance still remains. Watch the monkeys!

amazing temple. the temple is amazing. the view over kathmandu is great and the temple is an amazing journey into nepalese spirituality, culture and art. beware of the monkeys! unfortunately the earthquake caused some damages

Monkey business. A must visit site if you are in Nepal. Walk from Thamel, its easy to find and not that far, just bring a map or ask a local. The long and daunting steps are a must do, it's part of the experience, you can enter from the rear, much easier, but you'll be cheating! Just before the top of the staircase is a ticket office, 200npr. Once in the temple courtyard, you'll realise it was worth the trip, great views of the city, beautiful stupa and some wonderful shrines and temples. The earthquake damage is not as severe as some sights and there are some great photo spots. Food and drink is available at the top as well. On the far side are a number of pools that the monkey population use for cooling off, you can spend ages here watching their antics. Watch you bags and don't eat in front of the monkeys or you'll get some unwanted attention!
The unmistakeable MONKEY TEMPLE. Unfortunately damaged by the earthquakes but still a lovely place to wander around. Loads of monkeys, good views of the Kathmandu valley. A must see place

Heritage point, a must do. A must do, this is a big part of the locals' lives. Although likely to be crowded through the day, it is lovely to just walk about the place and observe the locals offer their prayers and light lamps.

Steep climb, but good views. The climb up is a bit steep, but you can pause whenever you like. Once on top you pay the tickets and enter the platform. I was told that a lot is destroyed in the quake, but there is much to see nonetheless.

At one of the most sacred Buddhist Temples of Nepal!. The golden "Swayambhunath Stupa", most commonly known as the "Monkey Temple", is the oldest and probably one of the most revered holy shrines in all Kathmandu. Its construction dates as far back as the 5th Century. It is a must see in your visit to Nepal's capital city. Strong legs and comfortable shoes are strongly needed, as a long stairway, with 365 steps, leads to the sacred stupa. Keep your good spirits and enjoy a breathtaking view of Kathmandu and its valley. "Holy" monkeys are everywhere! Keep your eyes wide opened, your belongings safely secured and watch carefully your steps. Monkeys are not at all reliable! And never never feed them! Souvenir shops are everywhere! I visited Kathmandu on February 2015, nearly two and a half months before the terrible earthquake that devastated Nepal on April 25, 2015. The "Swayambhunath" complex has been severely damaged by the earthquake, but the main stupa survived and the remaining structures are safe and opened to public. Visiting Nepal is a form of supporting this country's efforts towards reconstruction. Don't give up your plans! Enjoy!
Swayambhunath Temple in Kathmandu. A must visit location in Kathmandu ! Just slighly damaged after the recent earth quake, they are under repairing now, shall be OK very soon.

Before earthquake in 2015 it was OK. I was there 2 weeks before earthquake in the year 2015. It was after the sunset, it was dark. No too many vistors. Lot of monkeys everywhere! It was amazing place. Worth to see it. Do not know how it looks now!

The terrific Monkey Temple of kathmandu. After a lot of stairs you find yourself overlooking Kathmandu with the Swayambhunath Temple. monkeys inhabit the surrounds and can sometimes be a bit cheeky - we had one steal a bag of bananas - our fault!Also the temple is accompanied by some quite good gift shops.A lot of fun and a must-see in Kathmandu.

I love this temple. The scenery is awsome!! you can see Kathmandu from here. It's quiet and peacefull. Be careful with monkey, keep you things inside bag (ex: water bottle, umbrela etc). Prepare stamina, bcos you need take stair to get the awsome view.

One of the best historic sites remaining in Kathmandu since the earthquakes.. This temple is still in very good repair compared to many sites in Kathmandu. It is a beautiful view overlooking the city. Well worth the ride out and the climb up to the temple.

Must See! . This ancient site is a must see! Bring water and comfortable shoes for the hundreds of steps you will take on your journey to the golden Stupa. The fascinating history behind the construction and meaning of this great temple is worth reading about before your visit. There is so much to see! Don't be afraid of the monkeys. They are harmless if not provoked and are very comfortable walking beside you. Remember; however, that they are wild and should never be pet or approached. I found the smells to be quite intense - at times a strong mixture of monkey waste and incense. It might be wise for sensitive travelers to be prepared with a mask. All in all, I would highly recommend this stop on your visit to Kathmandu!
Important Buddhist temple. This place has a lot of religious significance. You can buy and go up and light candles. Food also available.

Very busy, quite dirty -- but a wonderful experience!. Monkeys everywhere, families...rice afoot and food offerings all over. But still, an interesting place to visit. As you enter, go up to your left -- lots of Tibetan prayer flags sending prayers on the wind (and quieter in this place!). Then, go up to the right for a more riotous experience. Focus on the micro-experience, and try to look past the mess, and you will have an incredible experience.

Monkey Temple - Swayabhunath. One of most important sightseeing in Kathmandu. First of all you will have beautiful view of Kathmandu valley, second, there really a lot of sacred temples and you even can find there special temple for wishes. Third, if you like nature and animals there a lot of monkeys around, and this place people mostly calling like Monkey Temple. You can also find there many stupas, lovely pictures and thousand souvenirs. Every month during the full moon. a lot of prayers are coming at the evening time, and you can see puja and even participate in that deal.

A intresting temple out of katmandu . There are two ways to see this temple. One of them led to point 1 kilometer far of temple but the second way via taxi you can go just in front of steps. You can clarify final destination before with drivers. The popular name of this temple is Monkey temple.There are many monkeys around of it and this is the main reason of its name. Becarful about feeding the monkeys; because of too many monkeys and if you decide to feeding, they accumulate with aggressive behavior around you.

The best sunset in kathmandu. Get there around 5-5:30 because you'll need to climb a few stairs. If you get there early, have a tea at one of the terraces around the temple. Watch the sunset and go back again to light all the candles along with the monks.

Most prominent attraction in the valley. Although many of the smaller shrines that surround Swayambhunath were damaged in the earthquake, the main Buddhist shrine here is still in tact, towering over the valley. This sacred hill in the middle of the valley was once an island when the valley was a lake. It is revered by Hindus and Buddhists, and worth a visit, but the tourist fee is a bit discouraging.

Awesome view. Also known as the Monkey Temple and is one of the oldest religious sites in Nepal. Awesome view of Kathmandu and I suggest you visit an hour or 2 before sunset. Monkeys are crazy but some amazing photo opportunities. A definite place to visit.

Our visits to Swayambunath Temple. Usually called Monkey Temple as you can see many monkeys around the temple. But it is Swayambhunath temple. Swayambhu means forming on its own. Temple is in a nicely elevated place in a hill and you have good view of Kathmandu. The temple has access by road and also those who want to exercise can use the steps to go up and come down. But, watch out for the Monkeys, which are quite okay if you walk with your empty hands. If you have bag the monkey will snatch thinking you have food. No harm, but little scary.

Monkeys and Street Vendors... EVERYWHERE. Our guide took us here ad got our tickets. When you first walk in, you are greeted by beggars and street vendors. These people are persistent. Don't waste your time with them. There are better souvenirs at the top. It a truly amazing site to see all the prayer flags blowing in the wind and the monkeys playing. Watching them jump off the ledge into a pool was entertaining. From there you climb 100+ stairs to the temple. The other side has 365 steps. There is a lot of walking that can be done here. The Stupa is breath-taking. We walked around following the prayer wheels, and saw some great views of the city. Bring your selfie stick, or plan on actually asking another human to help with the picture. Worth the admission fee.

Swayambhu - The eyes are watching always,. If you want to get out of the busy Kathmandu life and find peace, there is no other place better than the peaceful area of Swayambhu. Watch the 360 view of Kathmandu valley surrounded by the hills. In the afternoon, enjoy the cool breeze that crosses through and check out the sunset. Your mind will be blown. Pass time with the lovely and friendly shop owners at the square. They are helpful and nice. Also monkeys are everywhere to entertain you! Beware of their activities, as sometimes they snatch staff.
Temple in the high. Temple in the sky, its high a we hv to clim the stairs up, U may buy a souvenir and see the mountain view from above

Worth seeing -- restoring after the earthquake. Gardens are very nice and clean, the monkeys were playful, and the temple itself is fine. One smaller tall Hindu-type shrine collapsed but the other survived. Some braces on old brick buildings (as everywhere in the valley). Show support, and visit.

Fun and educational. Beautiful place with lots of cheeky monkeys! Beware, they steal ice cream from kids! A nice long climb up the steep steps but the view is amazing from the top. And the grounds on the top are lovely. Some works taking place like in most places after the earthquake. It wasn't expensive either. It's a nice walk from town to get there, a bit far, but you get to see all different neighbourhoods and some relics on the way.

Picture perfect. This was the highlight of our day touring Kathmandu. A number of angles provided stunning views over the Valley. It was interesting to see the monuments at the top, even though there has been significant earthquake damage to some parts. The monkeys provide another point of difference to other temples and have free reign of the place.

Magnificent. This is one of the best places in the city and probably one of the best places on the planet. The most noticeable thing is the huge population of monkeys that lives in the area. Watch out for your food, they're going to steal it!

Loved it! . The statues are great and the monkeys own the place! They have their own swimming pool!! Despite the touristy stuff you do feel quite a respect given to the prayer and statues you do find worshipers praying. But be prepared for the zillion steps you will be rewarded with a great view of Kathmandu

Monkeys. We walked from Thamel took us about 40 mins. Pleasant stroll, nice to fet out of the tourist area, felt very safe, just be careful crossing the roads. Many steps up to the temple but amazing view of the city. Lots of monkeys, no trouble but I wouldnt get too close. One of the stall holders (not pushy at all) asked if we would like to know a bit of history and have a tour, for 500 rupees there was 4 of us. He was very informative gave us a tour of the whole stupa and he let us know what we could and couldnt take photos of and told us about the different gods and festivals there. Would recommend to get someone to show you around.

Morning walk to see Himalaya. very ancient temple which look like Tibetan Buddhist temple. at the top of the hill, you can view the city of Kathmandu, and Himalaya if you are lucky. recommend go in morning. many Buddhist item can be purchase at the hill temple.
Beautiful Temple. This incredible temple has suffered damage but is so beautiful. Very popular with locals. Even the steps up there are exciting!

Must see sight within short walk from Tamel. You can easily walk there from Tamel (about 30 minutes) - great opportunity to see real Kathmandu life. The price is 200 NR (Sep 2015) and definitely worth it - great view of Kathmandu valley and lot of monkeys to play with. I would recommend to go there on weekdays - not as crowded as on weekend. There are also many monasteries around to have a look

Looking good after earthquake . ...considering the damage done. Plenty of interest, monkeys, stalls, flags and colour.
Beware the damaged brick buildings still in use.

Little heaven in the kingdom of Nepal. A must visit place while you in Kathmandu. I would recommend everyone to visit the stupa during the morning hours. The view from the top is just breathtaking. You have two main entrances to Swayambhu. I took the stairway the harder way. 365 total stairs, it was tiresome but worth it. Once you get to the top you just tend to forget your pain and cramps. It's like a heaven on earth. I would definitely recommend this place to every fellow traveler. And yes, you gonna encounter lot of monkeys on your way to the stupa. A friendly advice for the fellow travelers, just do not bother the monkeys.

An old historic site & a favorite sight to see.. This is a favorite sight to see....you can walk up many, many stairs or drive up the roadway...,many shops are nearby the Temple...I ate on the roof top of one of the restaurants...beautiful view of Kathmandu for the Temple...old historic site... so sad so much of it was destroyed in the Earthquake...

Where we met the gods(Monkey Temple). Best time to visit this beautiful shrime can be early in the morning or during the sunset. Usually is crowded with pilgrims and health enthusiasts. You can get view of the whole kathmandu Valley and also the hills surrounding it. The stupa is a beauty itself with other temples arounds it.Be aware that you may get bothered by the mischievous monkeys.

Worth a visit.. The view and monkeys make up for the temple.Entrance tourists 200rs, SAARC countries 50rs.Don't be afraid of the monkeys, they might jump on your bag or around your leg if you are carrying food or water visibly. You can always shoosh them away (raise your hands to make yourself big).There are locals exercising by running up and down the stairs.

Ok place, great city views.. Be prepared for a steep climb. not advisable for people who are unsteady. steps are worse coming down...quite dangerous. great view from the top.... we found it free to enter, others had to pay 200rs but we didnt see a ticket booth! Easy and fun walk from thamel...follow your google maps, towns along the way are fascinating.... Lots of activity around the area.....worth a visit
Sacred with a great view. a must for all travellers, a little banged up from the earthquake, but repairs are on going. Offer some prayer flags and walk around the park like settings

a little of Tibet in the middle of Kathmandu. One of the most sacred Tibetan Holy places i have visited.If your lucky it's not too crowdy early mornings, Depending on the time of the years lots of Tibetan Pilgrims can be seen. Forget the commercial aspect (all the shops surrounding the Stupa selling fake and "real" Tibetan antiques!) Just look at the greatness of the Stupa!

Highlight of our Kathmandu trip. The temple and grounds are beautiful, clean and refreshing escape. Very little earth quake damage to effect the experience of seeing this world heritage site. There is even a monkey pool! The views of the city are breathtaking.

lots of monkeys. visited just before the earthquake this year a beautiful temple with lots to see - lots of shops and lots of monkeys so dont walk around with food in your hand or you will get lots of attention. Throw a coin a the bell in the wishing well by the lower entrance or if you are feeling fit climb the huge staircase to the temple.
Monkey business :). Magnificent structure, being repared at the moment after the april and may earthquakes, it's still imperative to visit the temple and it's monkeys! :)

World Heritage Site ; Stunning !!! ❤ 💘 ❤. One of the most Stunningly Beautiful places in Kathmandu , I went there on 25th August and with its Beauty it attracted me to come back on 2nd September before boarding my flight to Chennai via Delhi, The world heritage site is full of protected monuments, in fact the total Swayambunath area is protected area.We can see lots and lots of wonderful sculptures combined with stupa, temples and the panaromic views adds to the beauty of this glorious place.Must visit for all age groups when you are in Kathmandu, 2hours is enough to visit this fabulous location.Thanks a lot for everything,Loving you so much,Peacefully yours.S M Bega Raaj.Happy travelling... ❤ ...
Great city view!. I nice walk from Thamel, with a great view of Kathmandu. Unfortunately some renovation was going on, but still worth the visit.
Wonderful to visit -- dogs, monkeys, people, history. Interesting for history, views, people (and monkey and dog) watching. I went around 6pm for early sunset -- very nice.
Must visit. Go for mental peace and calmness. View of valley is awesome. Very crowded but worth a visit. Lots of antique shop and old building structure is interesting

Monkeys still in business. It was with some trepidation I visited last month, in August, just a couple of months after two nasty earthquakes that had rocked the country and had reportedly damaged many of the older historic sites.However, though there were signs of rubble and damage; and one temple was in a bad way, collapsed at one end, I was surprised to find that it was no way as bad as I'd dreaded and certainly had lost none of its appeal.Workers are busy restoring the beautiful old shrines, stupas and temples in this hilltop complex that looks over the city. Famously nick-named the 'Monkey Temple,' these savvy apes have returned, entertaining visitors when I was there, by diving into an ornamental pool to cool off.
Densely packed Stupa area with views. The monkeys are still shy so no problem. Best approach is long stairway at East-Southeast corner, ticket office at top (250).

A must visit for any western Buddist. A spectacular building. Lots of intricate carvings. A hive of activity. Wonderful experience to turn the prayer wheels. Go to Kathmandu. Support the Nepalese people. They are are a beautiful people. Namaste
Amazing. You cannot go to Kathmandu and not take a walk to Swayambunath! Beautiful and spiritual place with an amazing view of the valley

amazing temple, amazing people. Just love it! although u have to brave hundreds flight of stairs in order to reach the top, I'll assure you that it will be all worth it by the time you reach the top & you'll be rewarded with a spectacular view of the city & the amazing temple up there

It was lovely to walk around and spin the wheels. look forward to doing it again.. Very sad to see the destruction but hopefully they will restore keeping the history for future. The expanse of the place and the faith of the visitors is a pleasant takeaway.

An icon of Kathamandu. As you walk on the main road and turn into the square the temple strikes you with its white covered dome. The sunshine reflecting on the golden plinth. The temple is best observed from the side balcony adjacent to the main entrance to the temple. The square is large and has lots of shops selling coats and exchange booths. Worth a visit as it is an icon of kathamandu.

Beautiful place with lots of monkeys . The temple itself isn't overwhelming. Why you should here is because the Swayambunath temple ensemble with monkeys roaming freely, monks praying, stupas everywhere and all along a great hilltop view of Kathmandu is why this is where you should go to if you're in Nepal.

Ancient Buddha Stupa. Great place for foreigners to visit and to learn some buddhism. Many visitors, locals too and big no. of monkeys. Don't try to feed them!! The temple holds a great history to itself.
Must Visit. Minor affected by earthquake. Repair work had been initiated. Can see a view of Kathmandu from There.and yah dont mind to take lot of stairs. You may find lots of human friendly monkeys.

A place you must visit. absolutely stunning! beautiful setting with views across Kathmandu Valley.The temple sits high on a hill above the town and can either be reached by a long flight of steps or by road. It is a large complex with the main temple, some shops etc

Great way to get a little hike in, while in Kathmandu!. The monkey Temple is always a joy. Be careful of the monkeys as they will steal any food you might have, right out of your hand. Enjoy the climb and one of the best views of he Kathmandu Valley from anywhere.

Nice Temple, Nicer Views!. Swayambhunath is a beautiful temple. There are steep steps that lead up to the temple, past various statues and many prayer flags. The views from the top are brilliant, you get a 360 degree view of all of Kathmandu. The temple is also home to many monkeys, which make for great photographs. We visited in August, after the earthquake, and there was no visible damage to the stupa itself, however, some of the surrounding buildings were damaged. Reconstruction work seems to be underway already.A taxi to the temple from Thamel costs about 250Rs

Called Monkey Temple. This temple in height location with great view to Nepal, easy to and safe place for tourist, many and Many of monkeys around all the place,you have to be carful as they might be unfriendly. One of the good location you have to see in Nepal once you visit .
Don't miss this. Gorgeous temple. Climb to the top is a bit steep, but the views are great. Was a much better experience than Pashupatinath.

Amazing view. Amazing view from the stupa. Beware!! you might be making new friends. This might be a handy tip, just don't bother the monkeys. You Will encounter them a lot. But worth visiting this place.

Worth it.. The walk up the stairs is killing but think about the view and it will be worth it! There are few monkeys around the stairs but none once you reach the top. I was terrified but I am glad I ignored the monkeys.

Beautiful temple. The stupa of swayambhunath is very impressing and beautiful. Only little of it has been destroyed by the earthquake and it is defenitely worth visiting. Also the many monkeys are quite fun to look at. One can walk there quite easily from thamel, it takes about half an hour. And if you are too tired to walk back after climbing the steep stairs to the temple you can take a taxi back to thamel for about 200 nr.

Disturbed but still incredible. Swayambhunath temple is truly worth a visit even with the destruction from the earthquake. The monkeys don't seem to have noticed the difference and the steps haven't got any less. there is a lot of re building going on and some of the cafes have gone. It is safe to be there and the view over KTM is magnificent. People spend hours watching the monkeys play in their pool, the monkeys appear to have competitions, who can jump from the highest point and push each other around. Fascinating.

The view!. The temple is an old structure located on a hillock over looking the city of Kathmandu.You need to climb quite a few steep stairs to reach this place. More than the temple, i enjoyed the beautiful and uninterrupted views of the city.

Beautiful, but watch your pockets. Beautiful and serene, but watch out for your wallets and phones... Pickpockets are very active in this area. I had a phone stolen out of my pockets while visiting.Make sure to watch the interactions between the Monkeys and the Monks for some entertainment!
Great scenery.. The temple was nice and beautiful. So many monkeys (be careful). On the top, you can see the nice scenery of Nepal Valley. It's fantastic.

good place. The place is enjoyable for a one time visit, stairs part is the best.Hope the authorities took more care of it as the place is not very clean and very missy in some sections.Note:go with a local tour so you see the whole place as its a big place and you might miss some of it.
Top of the World. An outstanding view of all of Kathmandu from the top of the hill.Very peaceful and you feel pious energies.

The place whrere all the Races & Cast are under the same roof.. Swayambhunath Temple is in on a height from where you can see the entire city with your open eyes. where there you can not differentiate the peoples with your heart. Once can enjoy the view of the city with Spirituality and Peace. I heartily like to recommend you to please do not leave the place.
Monkeys everywhere :). The monkey temple - beware of monkeys, they take away all your goodies )))) climb the 108 stairs and free your soul!

Excellent temple site. Although it's over run by monkeys - who won't bother you at all - this is a great place to visit in Kathmandu. The entrance fee is neglible and once inside there is a lot to see, including the main stupor and surrounding temples. It is a bit of a hike up to the stupor, but the views are wonderful. If you're not good at climbing stairs. maybe give this a miss, but it's really worth the climb.Alas, there is a fair bit of earthquake damage as of August 2015, but far less than elsewhere and almost all the main sights are intact.The only real negative is that the one and only toilet on site is beyond description for it's disgusting state. Most of the stalls were locked and the one or two open left me retching. There was no way they could be used.
Monkeys and monkeys :). Very nice and funny place to visit.In the place, you will find a lot of monkeys, and you have a great view to the Kathmandu Valley

way to Kailash Manasarover Yatra. On my way to Kailash Manasaroer Yatra 2015 I had two stay in Kathmandu.So i visited this Sayambhuunath temple . It has 365 steps to climb.Top of the temple it has a Hindu & buddhist temple iconography.The emperor Ashoka visited 2000 years ago,But the earliest confirmed activity here was in AD 460.Part of the temple is damage by earth quake but construction is under way to restore the temple .This temple is Unesco World Heritage site .According to legend , the Kathmandu Valley was once a lake, geological evidence supports this and the hill now topped by Swayambhunath rose spontaneously from the water, Swayambhu, meaning 'self arisen 'The compound is centred on a gleaming white stupa painted with the eyes of the buddha looking all over the valley.By local devotees who make a ritual circumnavigation of the stupa, spinning the prayer wheels set into its base. it is a gteat place to watch the sun set over Kathmandu and city view .
Swoyambhu Stupa. Yes, some parts other them main stupas are destryed but its still great to see and walk around is is great. The repairing work is going on and hope it will be restored soon
Temple of monkey!!. Its a nice temple in kathmando There's many monkeys to see but be careful!!!!Its takes 15-20 min from thamel The trip takes 850-1000 NPR go&back Enjoy!!

Devastated by earthquake, but nice. To the tourists it's known as the "Monkey Temple" and, yup, there's a lot of monkeys! Overall a good experience, especially thanks to an amazing view of Kathmandu, but unfortunately a lot of it has been devastated by the earthquake.

This was a must see...no idea of it is still open. No idea if the area is still open. Loads of shops and restaurants around the temple. You only walk one direction around the temple. There was a fee for the area. An easy walk from hotels.
awesome view. the view of the valley was awesome. loved it very much and the stupa. makes my heart calm here. be careful of the monkey. lots of money here.

Serenity almost in the clouds.. This is an amazing buddhist Temple, safe as yet from China. I do not know if it survived the 2 earthquakes. It is at the very top of a narrow very tall structure with many stairs to the top Outside the perimeter of Katmandu. You will find monkeys there. I climbed half way up ,set out my lunch on a scarf which included a bananna+ a bottle of water and rested to get my breath back.The view is incredible around the Katmandu valley. I turned and my entire lunch was gone?? I looked around for it and then i spied it.There was a large brown monkey wearing my scarf and scarfing my food! I struggled on to the temple and walked around the central stupa surrounded by huge,really huge gleaming copper prayer drums and smaller shrines.What a glorious,beautiful and magical place.I forgot lunch and wandered around and around in a dream seeing and re-seeing everything ,over and over again. I loved it.Someday I will go back, but I have every thing locked in my mind for the rest of my life.

Weird and wonderful. A Gormenghastian experience - religious devotees, souvenir sellers, strange rituals, money changers, monkeys make for a heady mix. I occasionally feel that it's a temple in need of some cleansing (!) but it's well worth a visit.

Top Sight to See. We enjoyed a gorgeous tour around the grounds and were happy to continue our walk up and over the top of the temple to the mass of prayer flags at the further temple and monastery behind the top temple. Walk the stairs, see the monkeys, view the city, visit this temple.

Spectacular View. Swayambbhunath Temple is easy to access, 10 minutes by car from Kathmandu Durbar Sqaure. You need to climb 365 stone steps to reach temple complex at the top and enjoy spectacular view of Kathmandu city.Children like this temple because monkeys are present, either climbing at roof top and bathing at pool. The holy flags in various colors hanging from one end to another enhance beauty for this temple.

A "short" walk to the top. When I am in Kathmandu, I enjoy walking to this attraction with friends. When you arrive you walk up a long set of stairs, especially the end where it gets steep. The top has a magnificent view of the whole city, not to be missed. Many tourists, locals spend the day here, so at times it can get crowded. Spend a few hours here just relaxing, grab a tea/coffee and watch the people stroll by. The temple itself is very beautiful and maintained quite well. There is a small fee for foreigners to enter and the guard will usually stop you when you get near the end of the stairs, so be prepared to pay the cost.

Still impressive, and prayer activities also going on during reconstruction. From the temple hill you have a good view over the city, but from there you do not realize how much earthquake damage is present. Turning around you see part of the damage , but the main temple dome hill is still intact. On the lower side some of the smaller domes have been repainted, and work is in progress to repair other elements.

Beautiful View!. What I loved about this temple was that it was walking distance from my hotel in central Thamel, so it made for a great day outdoors, walking from hotel to the temple, all around the temple area, and then back to the hotel at night. It is a must-see place, not only for the beauty of the temple, but the view it provides of the Kathmandu valley. However, there are many steep steps and I do not think it is wheelchair or handicap friendly. There were also some nice shops and a restaurant at the top.
beautiful.... Like most of the Kathmandu's Temples, nice, characteristic and beautiful... absolutely suggested....
great view. you can choose swayambhunaths hight to view the kathmandu valley.there is not so much disaster after the earthqake.you can freely visit this place!!

Beautiful place with combination of religion and scenery.. This place is one of the must visit place in Kathmandu. We can see the whole city from here. The combination of the religion and scenery. if you can mange the time, it is better to go at the evening time to see the sunset and after evening light in the Kathmandu city.

Take one step at a time. Located on the top of a small hill Swayambhunath temple is one of the key attractions of Kathmandu and the perfect location for a 360 degree view of the Kathmandu valley. On a clear day Himalayan range is also visible from afar. The steps up the hill can be challenging for some due to the thin air so take it slow.

An Inspirational Must See (even post earthquake)!. Wow, This temple is an amazing place of ancient and current religious devotion. It affords fantastic views of the Kathmandu and see the old style architecture and brick work is a fascinating. Even with some earthquake damage this temple remains a focal point of prayer and devotion. There are many stairs to climb at this site. The monkeys are roam all about but are nonthreatening. Just don't disturb them.It is a world heritage site and so all new construction must follow the ancient patterns. It was great to see aid workers there restoring the buildings. There is a lot of work do to but one cannot come to Kathmandu and not visit Swayambunath.

Saddening earthquake damage. Ordinarily it's a wonderful place to visit - 5 dots usually - but the earthquake damage made my latest visit quite sad but a different and moving experience.I could not circumabulate the Stupa without walking over rubble from the destroyed monastery. One fo the towers collapsed and people were living under tarpaulins. Rubble was being removed but it seemed like repair and rebuilding was a long way off.However, I found it very positive to see people worshipping as usual; this seemed to sum up Nepali resilience after the quake.Even in this state, which I hope will not eb for log, it's still worth visiting.

Wow ! You will sense some eternal peace here. Please do come here ! An eternal sense of peace with the Buddhist Culture is totally Amazing ! You will hear the Buddhist Bells and the scents of the Prayer Sticks ! Its also called as the Monkey Temple as there are many monkeys here ! Om Mani Padme Hum :)

My favorite stupa. The stupa on the hill is definitely worth a stop. The combination of temple, views, and small shops makes this a unique spot. I was there soon after the earthquake, and the devastation was marked. But people were working continuously and manually to bring this place back to functionality. Stop into the Thangka shop for a great explanation of the process.

Learning about Nepali Culture. Visiting this temple was a great way to see how the Buddhist of Nepal worship and what their culture is like. However, I visited after the earthquake and the temple received a good bit of damage. It was surreal to see the effects of the quake not just physically in the buildings but also in the lives of the people as they were still trying to clean up what had been damaged in May. I would definitely suggest visiting.

Amazing place with a city view. This is an amazing place to be in, even being Nepali I am awed whenever I visit Swayambhunath. The view of the city is really beautiful from here and I think there isn't any other place from where you can see such beautiful view of Kathmandu. Lot of people and a chance to see the real culture. There are also lot of Tibetan eateries nearby where you can enjoy a good Tibetan meal. And for all those exercise enthusiasts you can actually climb lot of stairs to reach the top, it's on the other side of the road.

Beautiful place despite the damage. A very impressive temple set majestically on a height overlooking Kathmandu.The main stupa survived the recent earthquake unscathed but some of the surrounding minor structures were badly damaged.Well worth a visit.
Boudhanath Stupa. A Holy and inspiring place... very user friendly to visit and a chance to touch to Tibetan Culture in Kathmandu.I think everyone should visit here at least once.

the monkey temple. recovering ..but still the view from the top is just stunning.. and some of the place.building is intact.. Tips : don't run/panic when ,monkey approach u.. its bad idea to run.. hahah.. # i was so scared

Cute little Monks and Nuns. Just like any other Monastery but if you are a explorer then you would find those cute nuns sitting under the tree or in class rooms busy in studying or chanting their prayers. Most of them would be of age between 4-17...the younger ones are really cute and anybody can get mistaken them for monks...all are good at language and hymning Bollywood musics

Main Stupa still standing. The main Stupa is still standing but the small temples around it are almost completely destroyed, which is quite sad. There are monkeys walking all over. As it is in the top of the mountain, you can see Kathmandu city from there.

Beautiful view of Kathmandu. The monkey temple is one of those places where it seems that the time has stopped. Located just 40 minutes walk from Thamel, it is one of the best place to admire Kathmandu.
Beautiful Temple. Not very huge, but a real beauty. Simple dome, that you can climb up, yet nice. Lovely stalls nearby. You need to bargain though

Its a good historical place.. Swyambhunath temple is located on the high place. We can see Kathmandu city from the top of this place. One shouldn't miss this place if he or she has visited Kathmandu. Enjoy and have fun.

Monkey hill. Swayambhunath is an ancient religious complex atop a hill in the Kathmandu Valley, west of Kathmandu city. It is also known as the Monkey Temple as there are holy monkeys living in the north-west parts of the temple. top of the hill there are some shop . if you visit swayambhunath you can see hole of Kathmandu valley.
A site you must not miss. It amazes you to see such a grand Budhisth temple in Nepal. The natural co-existence of hindu and budhisth monuments are not rare in Nepal. A site you must not miss.
Visit to swambhunath. Swambhunath is a unesco world heritage site.You feel very peaceful at this site.it is a must see place when you are in Kathmandu.
This is a must. We enjoyed the syncretism of Hinduism and Buddhism here. The view over the city is great, but the smog is very evident.

Peaceful!. Very peaceful place... There is a sort of "throwing the coin" activity, where it is considered lucky if you aim properly and throw the coin right into the pot (near the statue). Monkeys never bothered us, and there are nice, small temples right on top. A really nice and peaceful experience!
Very tourists friendly place. It's a very tourist friendly place. You can freely roam around, take pictures and video. No pressure, no ripping off the foreigners.

The monkeys. Temple is damaged in the earthquake but is being cleared and refurbished. Some nice views from the top of the hill. Make sure you don't carry food in your hands, monkeys will try to steal it.

Also known as monkey temple. Secret place for Buddhist and Hindu's is located at Kathmandu. Have a long upward stairs and plenty of monkeys. Surrounding areas are full of trees and from the top of this temple you can see many places of Kathmandu valley

"I liked Most". When i went this place ,i liked too much because swayambhunath temple was top of hill net ,clean piceful place
importaint of historical things,monkey activites .We can watch all kathmandu vailly .all most like in the swayambhunath temple.I enjoyaed.

Breathtaking despite the destruction. The experience was really interesting. Dozens of monkeys greet you as you climb up a steep staircase. At the top of the hill, about a five minute climb, you'll take in some truly amazing views of Kathmandu. Despite losing much of its surrounding buildings during the earthquake, the temple is intact and still stunning to see. Plenty of good reasons to come check it out!

Damaged by the 2015 earthquake but worth it!. This is one of my favorite attractions in Kathmandu. Unfortunately it was badly damaged, but you can go and look around, and help some of the people that sells souvenirs -- there are not many tourists around and they need to survive!
Spend some time!. Just sit down and take in the place! Let peace soak in and be refreshed! Watch the visitors from all over the world be amazed at the sheer size of the place!
Don't miss this!. Despite some damage from the recent earthquakes, Swayambhunath Temple is still very impressive and well worth the visit.
special temple. Such a beautiful and peaceful temple! So happy we were able to be there before the earthquake...and thinking of everyone there!

Rubble. I am eating this place without putting full eyes on the place. It was closed following the earthquake, so I sneaked up a back path and climbed some rubble to have a look. Stunning and once repaired, well wirth a visit.

Must see!. A must see.A long walk up but worth the view.Busy atmosphere. Can see religion in practice and the place was full of life.But don't buy anything from here, its all over priced, better off going Thamel.A bit tourist-y but there also genuine believers there too.

Nice Place. Nice temple with lots of Stupa. Been there at the time of sunset. As it is located in a hill we had experienced a nice set set view from that temple. Lots of logs and monkeys roam around. No idea whether these have any connections with the temple or not but good thing is they are not annoying.

Worth to visite. Nice templ. . Should visit
Don't purchase from there the gift you can got the same from the city and will be cheaper
Superb View. Superb View. Must watch place. It is good place for shopping also apart from light snacks.. coffee..

Main stupa closed from quake - but plenty to see and great views. Access to the main stupa was unfortunately not possible as locals were still clearing rubble from the site following the April quake. It's possible it will be open again soon. Despite that it was worth the drive up the hill as there are plenty of other sights to see, and monkeys to photograph. The views of the Kathmandu Valley are great from many different vantage points around the complex. There are also some interesting combinations of Hindu shrines and Buddhist prayer wheels all in very close proximity - showing how much the Nepalese embrace both belief systems.

More than just monkey business. Unlike the Boudhanath Stupa, the Swayambhunath Temple complex is huge and is sited on a hill. (It is said that a single circumnambulation of this Temple is equivalent to 12 around Boudha!) Most tourists and visitors are taken only to the top where there is a concentration of small shrines topped by the famous "Buddha eyes" golden steeple and miss seeing the three huge golden statues at the foot of the hill!Visitors should be warned to take good care of their personal belongings for fear of them being snatched by the wily and quick-fingered hordes of monkeys that roam the complex! And, if you intend to feed them and the stray dogs, don't be surprised to see them fight over the tidbits you offer, although most are shy and wary of the human visitors and will make a hasty retreat at any sudden move! Also, unlike the other Great Stupa, there are many shops and stalls selling spiritual ware interspersed somewhat haphazardly amongst the various small shrines in the complex, making the Stupa more of a shopping attraction than a holy site for me. one also needs to walk the steps and pathways up and down the complex so proper shoes are recommended for this excursion.

Not clean. Holy place should be clean. This is the first time experience that i saw the stupa not clean. i didnt like the environment. the scenario is good from the stupa. when you get down from the stupa, do not eat ice-cream, otherwise you will be attacked by monkeys.

One of best views over Kathmandu. I was there for 2nd time this year but unfortunately the stupa area are closed to visitors due security reasons, the Nepalese Army is cleaning all the rubbish provoked by the earthquakes. By this time they have cleaning all for sure and maybe is again open to tourists. I spent my time here in Buddhist monastery, in the opposite side from the stupa, is open to public and no signs of earthquake. It was a great time filming a Buddhist puja. mons are really friendly.

The best view to Kathmandu valley. Totally loved the experience because of crowds of crazy monkeys running around. They are quite pushy over here and grab everything that you carry. I had a real fight with one for a bottle of coke. If you go up the stairs you will come to a beautiful square with temples and outstanding view to Kathmandu valley. There are a few cafes as well where you can enjoy a cup of coffee.

Beautiful temle. I loved the Swayamnhunath Temple. It on the top on a hill. Need climb hundreds steps.When on the top you will see the view of the city.And I like thinking when I sitted on the top.It is peaceful and calm in your heart.

Best for the Dusk. It's on the small hillock - for a religious peace feeling! Kathmandu can be viewed from the hillock. I suggest you to visit go there at around 4 PM and stay until it's a little dark so you can view Kathmandu in light while enjoying the cool breeze and a brilliant walkthrough one of the most gorgeous place!

Lots of climbing. A must see but not for the faint hearted, there are two entrances one where you have to climb hundreds of steps and the other you can get a taxi to and then you just descend the steps to the other entrance which all taxi drivers know about. Great to visit (of course) but if you missed it you wouldn't be too disappointed

Beautiful. I loved the approach to Swayambunath. Leaving the chaos of Thamel, you follow narrow roads where you will encounter more locals than tourists. when you reach the site, there is a long, steep staircase which seems to get steeper the higher you go. The main stupa is amazing as are all the statues, prayer wheels, and buildings. It definitely deserves the nickname "Monkey Temple." There seem to be hundreds of monkeys and they will steal water bottles and food if you let them. They aren't particularly aggressive, but they are opportunistic. I was kind of disappointed that this religious site is not much different from the streets with vendors everywhere trying to sell you stuff. Overall it is beautiful and the views from the top are great.

Still accessible . Hi. It is accessible and you can walk around the bottom bit. To go to the top bit you have to sign the book. It is quite damaged and the all hands team are helping to clear the rubble but the views are great.
Restricted entrance due to damage. Unfortunately, the earth quakes have caused a lot of damage here. Entry is restricted to teams evaluating and organizing reconstruction.
Unique Experience. It is a big campus in itself and also home to a variety of experiences. The big stupa in between, with a lot of shops and small temples all around, call for a long visit.

mesmerizing. this is another world heritage and it's the property of the world,it has something which you can't imagine about it.this swayambhunath temple is the best in the stupia types.it's on the top of the hill.being on top of the hill,you would be able to see the entire kathmandu valley.

Self emerged Temple !!!. A great place itself. If you r monkey lovers you shouldn't miss this place. No quake damage in the main stupa. Only place for the view of Kathmandu valley from the middle part.

Amazing Kathmandu Valley View. Visit this temple for the Kathmandu Valley view, if it is sunny we could see the Himalayan range on the back of the city. Sunset will add some color in the photos! Such an amazing place.

Monkey temple. This was fantastic! But be aware that there in lots of stairs up but all worth the walk up.There was a fair amount to see & monkeys from the bottom to the top.The view from the top over looking Kathmandu is amazing. The temples at the top were great to check out too.Highly recommended Darren & Lynell

Awesome views, aggressive monkeys. We walked to this temple from Thamel, was a nice walk through the city. Easy to find. Steep climb up the stairs with lots of monkeys to watch. But DO NOT BRING FOOD! The monkeys get very aggressive and are not afraid of people. Otherwise, the views at the top of the whole valley are incredible. With the snow capped mountains in the background. And the layers upon layers of prayer flags flapping the wind. Definitely worth checking out.

one of the best places in Kathmandu. Definitely one of top 3 places to visit in Kathmandu. A great opportunity to see lots monkeys and many temples altogether. Plus nice view of city from the top. We spent there about 3 hours but could easily stay longer. It is just one of those places where you can spend half a day doing nothing really. Although there is a fee to get to the top(I think about 5 euros or something) it is worth to pay it.

Post earthquake --- still amazing. I was in Kathmandu for 2 months and was in the Kathmandu earthquake. This temple on the mountaintop was my most favorite place for spiritual respite. Post-earthquake it still was.You can still get up there. The front maIn stairway is blocked at the top. Take the road around to the left of the main front stairway and you will see a stairway going up on your right --- take it all the way to the top where the monastery is (only minor damage). From there you can see to the next hill with the main white stupa. You can get there from the monastery. The front stairway was where the ticket booth used to be. Going around the left side and up --- no ticket booth.Two weeks after the earthquake the locals had once again reclaimed the top for their rituals. 5 houses and 3 smaller temples up there are undamaged, the rest of the structures are still there and even though damaged you can still get the feeling of what it was like pre-earthquake. The main white stupa is remarkably undamaged --- you can circle it and all the prayer wheels are also intact.Another must-do here is to walk around the entire base of the mountain. On the backside, undamaged, are 3 very large golden buddhas and a wonderful active temple area. If you continue around the circular base you will see, undamaged, the entire base white wall and also many huge prayer wheels in small enclosures. Walk slow, absorb it all. You can easily spend 2-3 hours wandering around here. Then ask a local where Nip's Cafe is and have a marvelous breakfast (or lunch or dinner).AMAZING STILL ! Early morning is best when you will encounter all the locals doing their ritualistic circular walk of the mountain base. I guarantee you will not be disappointed !
really beautiful. swayambhunath is so beautiful bBuddist monastery really nice to climb some steps .when you was there you can see all kathmandu valley from there.so beautiful.

In Ruins Now. One of the beauties, towering over the Western horizon of Kathmandu valley, Swyambhunath Temple, lies in ruins these days. Even though the main central stupa, with the famous eyes etched on a bronze tower, still stands like a sentinel, but most of the surrounding small temples have crumbled due to the recent earthquakes in Nepal. People are allowed to go in, as some of the paths have been cleared. I was there yesterday, and my heart sank to see the huge damage caused to this beautiful scared place. It used to be one of the places where I enjoyed visiting in the past fours years that we have been living in Nepal. I sincerely hope the Nepali government, with the support from UNESCO, and other donors, will be able to reconstruct and restore the temples back to their past glory. I do realize that it will take a long time to do so. Therefore, the world would just have to be patient.

Beautiful but crowded. The monkey temple.. quaint… the view of ktm form here is super.. but its so ill maintained.. and always crowded with nepalese and tourists, alike.. i got a feeling that they don't really care for their own culture.. but still loved being there..
Amazing. If you had one thing to do in Katmandu, choose this stupa... Amazing view on the valey and the monkeys are great... if lucky enough you'll get the chance to connect with this place

Amazing!. An amazing place with clearly hundreds of years of history and a true peaceful mixture of Hindu and Buddhist culture. Surprisingly, while in the thick of chaotic and noisy Kathmandu you can easily find solace here
Peaceful temple to visit at sunset.. After climbing the steps all the way to the top of the hill, you'll find a peaceful temple. Best at sunset. The views are excellent.

Fortunate to visit before the Earthquake. Brilliant and amazing place; we were lucky to visit before the April 2015 earthquake. We worth a visit then and hopefully will be again soon. The flight of stairs up was a good introduction to what was coming.

Incredible view of the city from the top. Once you have walk the 300 steps to the top, you can comtemplate the all Kathmandu city. Charming shops on top where you can buy something related to the visit.

Beautiful View. It's a trek going up all those (365) stairs, but post-earthquake they have blocked off the main temple. Before reaching the top, you can take a right and enjoy a nice walk in the trees to access the lower areas in the back - which are also earthquake damaged but still worth a visit. Take the time to read about it so you know what all the different constructions represent. Beautiful view from the hill, and the monkeys are fun to watch and very tame/non-aggressive. Worth a visit.

An interesting visit to one of the biggest temples. The whole atmosphere of buddhist religion is present on that temple. Smells and shops are everywhere around there. You can stop for food or a tea in a nearby place. I don't know if the place survived after the destructive earthquake!
Great visit. This is a great temple to visit. Lovely views of KTM, funny monkeys, and stunning architecture. Please don't litter.

A walk worth taking--what a view!. Our guide took us to the temple area--we would have never thought to have gone on our own. At the bottom of the area there is a wishing well and from there you can look up the hill and see the temples and flags flying--beautiful sight. There are clean public toilets available on the way up. From the pictures that I've seen, the damage from the earthquake was not too wide spread on the top structures. The view across the Kathmandu Valley is worth the trip.

Amazing ancient stupa. Visited the Swayambunath Stupa and Complex on a cloudy morning of 1 January 2015.The complex is known also as the Temple of the Monkeys , tough we saw that not too many monkeys ,insted, a lot of pigeons here.Took about 20 minutes to reach the complex,located on the western side of Kathmandu city ,our transportation was arranged by Outshine Adventures, as well as our friendly and knowledgeable guide ,Mr.Prasant.Center of the attraction is the Swayambunath Stupa , its the most sacred among Buddhist pilgrimage sites.For Tibetans and followers of Tibetan Buddhism, it is second only to BoudhanathThe Swayambhunath complex consists of a stupa, shrines and temples, like the Harati Devi,Anantapura Shikara some dating back to the Licchavi period. A Tibetan monastery the Dongak Chhyoling Old Monastery,the Buddha Thanka Treasure and more recent additions are also in this complex.The stupa has Buddha's eyes looking on all 4 directions, and eyebrows painted on. Between them, the number one (in Devanagari script) is painted in the fashion of a nose.There are also souvenir shops, restaurants and hostels nearby. The site has two access points: a long stairway with 365 steps,the leading directly to the main platform of the temple, which is from the top of the hill to the east ,and a car road around the hill from the south leading to the southwest entrance.Majestic Temple and Complex, and its one out of 7 UNESCO heritage sites in Kathmandu.Highly recommended to be visited.We are concerned about the condition of the complex after it suffered the Gorkha earthquake , hopefully if its damaged , it could be restored to its original state.We're wondered how was the condition of the stupa and complex, hopefully someone would upload pictures of it at the present.

Interesting and worth it. The views over the city and Kathmandu Valley and Himalayas are breathtaking. Lots of monkeys running around. You can spend hours just wandering around and looking. The buildings are great.

Shayakon. The entry fee is 200 Nepali Rs in April 2015. The stupa is on a hill west of Kathmandu's center. I took a taxi then no need to climb the stairs as the taxi dropped me in the car park behind it.Not so many monkeys as I expected.

Peaceful,serene and what a view !. Visited on 7 May, two weeks after the disaster quake hit this beautiful country, thankfully this so called monkey temple is totally not affected nor damage in many way by the quake unlike many other temple. Even so can see Red Cross tent build inside to help people in needs of help. This is definitely one of the best in Kathmandu to enjoy the best view of the cities itself, came about 5pm, just perfect when the sun is setting down, sit there pray ,soak the atmosphere with an awesome view, what else do you expect from this beautiful and serene temple , awesome . Heal Nepal together people

Just breathtaking!. Swayambhunath Temple (or Monkey Temple as most locals and cab drivers call it) is located at a hilltop that requires a bit of physical effort to get to, but I can assure you that it's worth it. The temple itself is like a miniature of what you would see at Boudhanath, but has a different feel to it due to the large amount of animals living there - especially monkeys, hence the name. The monkeys themselves are non-violent creatures and definitely one of the main draws to visit; just don't try to feed them. Even if you're not into the beautiful stupa and the various temples and shops of art, singing bowls, and other ceremonial souvenirs surrounding the hilltop, the breathtaking view of Kathmandu is well worth the price of admission.Unfortunately, based on recent photos from media and local friends, Swayambhunath has suffered quite extensive damage due to the earthquake. Although the stupa still stands with minor damage, lots of the surrounding temples, buildings, and the stairs leading up to the temple are heavily damaged. Hopefully after rescue and recovery efforts are made to the country and affected residents, they can start to rebuild their heritage again in an even better and brighter way. I hope to have another chance to revisit the beautiful country of Nepal and experience its cultural heritage soon.

Beautiful religious shrine high on hilltop. Tthis is a fantastic way to begin a tour of Kathmandu. It is high on a hilltop with incredible views and interesting religious traditions, both Hindus and Buddhists participate at this site as do the roving monkeys. It is an unforgettable site well worth a visi

Lovely views ALSO PLEASE UPDATE. There are amazing views of Kathmandu from here, and some great rooftop cafes to enjoy them from. The monkeys are calm and not like in some countries where they get a bit feral. Lovely architecture and some interesting markets - best to get dropped at the top and walk down!I have also been asked this:- - - - - - - - Begin COPY here - - - - - - - - Is this Temple (Shrine, Hotel or Restaurant) still standing please?UNESCO and The Archeological Survey of India have not released a list of temples and locations, lost in the earthquake.If travellers could photograph and post on the corresponding listings, of what is;a) Demolishedb) Damaged

Place of worship. A must see. Shiva Temple and you need to see from the four sides as also the other temples around the prakaram. Temple administration needs to regulate crowd better as there is much jostling once you are inside. While there is cleaning of the floors, can be improved.

good experience but tough climb. The climb to the top is difficult with lot of steps ,takes 20 min or so.Not for the elderly and those with knee problems.I went with my family in the late when it was lit golden yellow
Magnificant. Really breathtaking and a wonderful view over Kathmandu city while monks pray, and monkeys begging for your food. A lot of people and steep stairs but it's worth the difficulties

A beautiful monument. One of the most important Buddhist monument in Nepal, the temple kompleks is a must see. The architecture is unique, and the sight of people praying is touching. You can see the best view of Kathmandu Valley from here.
must visit. for the religious few and with a view to see the ancient heritage of nepal, pls do not miss this and pay a visit to the place.. you would be bowled out with the architecture

Amazing view of Kathmandu and adorable a monkeys . Must do while in Kathmandu !!! The monkeys add a special charm to the visit ... The peaceful coexistence of Buddhists and Hindu culture ... Lovely and unique handcrafted ...

Impressive and beautiful. A stupa surrounded with hindu shrines, bells, candles and monkeys... Swayambhunath is a really special place. Plus, it overlooks the city which gives it a solemn feel. The entry is quite cheap for the beautiful sight !
Scene of Kathmandu valley. It was a bit stink because of the monkeys. But you can feel the breeze and seen Kathmandu valley from above. Tourist will charge on the entrance gate.
