Monkeys!. i loved climbing the steps, the beautiful temple, the millions of prayer flags, spinning the prayer wheels, the view, and the monkeys roaming everywhere!
heritage. If you would like to visit and explore Nepal's heritage then visit Swayambhunath Temple. It is a great heritage site.

Now in ruins. Earthquakes on April 25 and 26 wrecked the temple and monastery area quite badly. Only the eye tower is still standing and even that badly chacked. It is likely to take years to rebuild the area.
Cultural smorgasboard. This is an amazing site to advance an understanding of much of the culture and history of the area. To understand Nepal one. Use understand the culture.

Amazing Views. The Monkey Temple to those who may not be the best with the Nepali language. Walk-able from the tourist neighborhood of Thamel, or a short taxi ride. We entered up the large set of stairs, which felt like much more than 365! Near the top tourists will be asked to pay a small fee (about Rs. 200). The view from the top is definitely worth all of the stairs. Going in the afternoon/evening ensures the best view as the skies are the clearest, you will be able to have a 360 degree panorama view of Kathmandu. There are souvenir shops around the Stupa, some have some really amazing paintings. The Stupa itself and surrounding temples are an amazing sight, everything is very intricately detailed. A must see if you're in Kathmandu.Watch out for the monkeys as they can be known to be aggressive. Also keep your wits about you with people out to make a dollar, they follow you talking about the history of the Stupa and then demand money for their troubles. The stairs are also lined with beggars

Aghori and Monkeys. Our visit coincided with Shivarathri - a festival to honor the Hindu God Shiva. Pilgrims had poured in to camp out in and around the temple, including Aghori and I'm kicking myself that I refused an invitation to sit with a group. Next time! Monkeys abound and were very active probably because of all the activity but even so they can be aggressive. Don't approach or try to feed. Guides offer services - be wary about pricing. We did talk to one very well spoken young college student who was very knowledgable. Wish I'd got his name!

monkey all around. the temple known to me was monkey temple.. enter there and see a lot of monkeys surrounded.. any thing in hand if eatables will attract them to u and they will snatch it so professionally

Amazing view - TONS of monkeys. This was definitely an entertaining way to spend the late afternoon/sunset.As has been written here before, there really is a great 360 degree view of Kathmandu from the top.I recommend walking at least one way from/to here and the Thamel, it is a 30 min walk that passes by some interesting areas of the city, and there are plenty of super cheap and totally local eateries to grab some food on the way.
Amazing view!. This was one of my favorite destinations in Nepal. Amazing view of the city, very serene. Perfect for a walk at sunset.

Disappointing. We decided not to climb the 365 steps up to the front entrance, but took our taxi to the back side where it is not so far to climb. The whole place bustles with vendors, vermilion, rice, and flower petals. There are also many miserable dogs. I did not find any sense of peace or spirituality here at all, unlike Boudhanath. It was very noisy and exhausting. No good coffee shops and the Western toilets were disgusting. It was interesting, but it depends on what you are looking for.

Peace in mind. I have been there with my fren. This temple is symbol of lord Gutam Buddha when you reach there you will feel relax and peace in mind. You can see whole Kathmandu valley from the top. I will recommend this place for short trip.

Monkey temple Katandu. Close to Thamel, taxi will cost about 350NPR one way. The taxi will take you all the way up where you have to buy a ticket for 200NPR. From there you can walk around in the park and view the buildings, monkeys and from the top there is a great view of Kathmandu. Nobody bothers you here. When you walk down to the exit that is situated lower, there will be people trying to sell you stuff. You can take a different path down if you want to be left alone. There is no ticket counter at the bottom, so if you want to save money you can walk the stairs up to the temple. Still worth the money aswell though. This is a nice place to visit and easily acessible, so when you have 2 or 3 hours to spare (including taxi ride) this is a good place to go. Taxi ride back to Thamel was 400NPR. You can probably get the taxi rides cheaper if you try harder then is did, but i thought it was about right for the distance.
Out of time. Watch people practicing their religion in a wonderful scenery. Nice view of KTM. Go up the stairs, rather than going from the car parking.
great experience. wonderful to visit and be blissed out. we went around touching the bells and had great view around standing on dome.

One of the must visit touristy places in KTM. While it's full of tourists, it's still a great place to visit. There's a nice view of the Kathmandu valley, playful monkeys, loooong strings of prayer flags hanging around, and of course the magnificent temple and stupa.There's all kinds of places selling souvenirs, but I went with my travelers instinct and didn't buy there because of the naturally higher prices.

Thanka Art Schools. Fantastic place! Full of history and the best view in Kathmandu if you can get up on the roof to take photos. A real co-existence of Hindu and Buddhist religion. Do turn the prayer wheels, and the wonderful stories of the caves and the King of Nepal!

Monkey Temple is a must!. Really a must if you go to Kathmandu! Not just the monkeys there but the entire temple grounds are history! Lots to see and this is where the famous pictures with all the prayer flags occurs. Easy to get there in a cab. From anywhere in town it should cost about $3-$5 to get there. For tourists it is $2 to get in.

Beautiful natural surrounding of KTM view . This place is such a great way to heaven , so nice views. And natural surrounding . Very ancient temples with so nice & amazing creative architecture, I have no words to explain it.Swayambhunath is a kind of nature Where you can find success of love
Interesting and a historical place to visit. Find a lot of nice handicraft, interesting trinkets,souvenirs, and different olden architecture. Enjoy going around the temple. Good place tovisit.

Love Love Love this place. This is also called the Monkey temple and it is overrun with monkeys but it is also a great walk and filled with little gardens where you can take a moment and reflect on the delights of the day. Vendors are limited to the front of the temple complex so you are not bothered by them as you are at some other attractions. The people here welcome strangers to light a candle and observe their traditions.
Wonderful meeting of Hindu and Buddhist. This ancient temple and stupa provides wonderful views over Kathmandu and well worth the long climb to the top.
a must see. fantastic views. a very important temple in Kathmandu. Would highly recommend getting a guide so you can get the full insight into this amazing place
Must see. Great views, very peaceful. There are steps to climb but it is well worth it. Anyone who visits Kathmandu should visit this site.

Kathmandu Valley View. Recently visited Nepal, Swayambhunath temple was one of the places we visited and it was an absolute wonder a top a hill. The temple is accessible by climbing few stairs and the view of the Kathmandu valley from the top is simply superb.The place is nice but the local vendors charge too high even for a small thing, may be due to heavy tourist visit.

The Monkey Temple is a must-see. Go early in the morning when the pilgrims are circumabulating the temple. I'm in my fifties and have knee issues but still climbed the 300 stairs to the top -- and it's worth it. The temple is incredible and the monkeys are so fun to watch but for me the big draw is being among the pilgrims and seeing the colors, the butter lamps, the wonderful faces. Enjoy!
many monkeys. interesting to see the prayer wheels and prayer flags and the views from the top over the city were amazing. overly commercial and pushy shopping opportunities all around.

Temple on the Hill's Top. The temple on the hill is worth watching. Though it remains crowded at the day time night scene of it seems amazing. Some street children may trouble you asking for money. You can enjoy the scene of Kathmandu valley from the Swayambhunath Temple.
best place in Kathmandu. prying monks, mischivous monkyes and lots of souvenirs to buy on the way and on the top. Also perfect view on Kathmandu. Be prepared for lots of stairs :)
like this place. The atmosphere is attractive and keeps you stay. It's also an excellent place for the view over Kathmandu.

Monkey fever!. What a fun place to go to watch the monkeys and to get a birds eye view of Katmandu. Beware the 375 steps you must climb to get to the top. We took a rickshaw there and our guy waited for us to come back down. So many nice people there in Katmandu.

A mix of sightseeing and mingling with locals. The willingness of local people to talk about their lives; the fabulous shopping opportunities, including books; opportunities to visit all the key attractions; centre for wide range of trekking activities; stepping off point for visiting Bhutan.

Buddhist stupa, temples, monkeys and great views. Swayambhunath sits on top of a hill to the west of Kathmandu. It's a very interesting 25 minute walk from Durbar Square and the Buddhist neighbourhoods en route are good for souvenir shopping. The steps up the hill are steep, but are mostly under trees and in shade. The ticket office is on the left near the top. Up here there's the big Stupa and several temples - all fascinating for people watching and brilliant for photography. The views over the Kathmandu valley are excellent too. Watch our for the monkeys - they are into everything!

Pretty cool . The temple is a worth a trip to. You can walk 30 minutes or so from Thamel or jump in a taxi for a small cost. It's quite peaceful after you have walked up all the steps and have got past the tourist crowds, with great atmosphere and incredible views of Kathmandu. You will need to navigate the abundant monkeys (some of which are very cute) and watch out for them stealing any snacks that you get up there.I think it might be best at sunrise for tranquility or sunset for the views. This is a peaceful place and a good spot for watching local rituals and seeing the odd monk passing by however you don't need note than an hour or so.

Sharing the temple with the monkeys !!!. While climbing the approx 300 steps to the temple on the summit, one has time to focus on the religious aspect, watch the monkeys watching you and/or catch your breath every so many steps...Once you crest that last step, you are blown away by all the intricate monuments surrounding the main stupa such as small stupas, temples, a monastery and several shops and restaurants. Next, when you finally look away from all this architecture, you get a bird's eye view of the city below. The whole experience is almost magical !!!

Great views despite the fog. Beautiful temple - worth getting as tour guide to explain things. Very steep climb up to it though - but worth the views which would have been even better if the weather was better. Lots of monkeys but luckily they didn't come close - you have to ignore them! Some nice little shops at the top aswell

Enjoyable hike up to impressive Stupa with awesome views over the City. We started our 4 days visit to Kathmandu with a visit to this Temple / Stupa and it was a good decision.Not too fat from Thamel by taxi our driver tried to convince us the steps were far too challenging for a couple of 50 year olds so he would take us up the (far longer route) to the back of the temple. Utter tosh - it's a pleasant 15 to 20 min hike up steps past religious idols monkeys and small stalls to reach the Stupa. There is a small ticket stall very close to the stop of the steps where non nepali (Or non Asian as i didn't see any indian tourists get charged) tourists pay a relativley modest entrance fee.The Stupa is large and the area around it affords great views over the city - ideal for getting ones bearings. There are plenty of locals attending to their relifious devotions to make this a genuinley interesting place to watch the Nepali way of religious life. That said there are plenty of large tour groups as well.Behind the large stupa are a few small temples and a plethora of smaller religious icons and mini stupas which are fascinating to wander around and take photos or observe life.All in all very well worth the not too demanding walk up the stairs to get here and a brilliant place to get ones bearings.

Great Experience. First, the so-called Monkey Temple where, I was told the monkeys are sacred, has lots of monkeys running around and that's pretty neat. Second, the views from the hilltop over surrounding Kathmandu are good. Third, the Temple itself is fascinating, with its proliferation of prayer wheels and flags, stupas, and interesting customs. The only blot on the experience was a persistent beggar who wouldn't leave me alone.

cultural site with great views. A reasonable walk from Thamel getting you out of the more touristy areas, along busy streets, over a disgustingly dirty river, and finally up all those steep steps to the temple itself. A good place to buy prayer flags if you're so inclined. Although the temple itself offers little more than others, the location high up on a hill makes it special. Great place to arrive latish, hang out watching people and the sun set. As with so many other places it's a bit annoying how randomly they apply entrance fees - if you're coming in along the only road where there's a booth and if they happen to be paying attention. Highly recommended.
Monkey temple. Not the nicest temple we visited but worth it for the views of Kathmandu. The monkeys are not well looked after and lots of stall holders who hassle you on the way up the stairs.

A worthwhile walk. As an introduction to Nepal, and Kathmandu this was a great experience. I was only there for a day, and as there was a general strike on, there wasn't much else to do during the day. It's free to visit, and well worth the the walk. Wonderful views out over the city, and some very dramatic staircases!Definitely worth the climb.

Worth the walk. I walked all the way from Freak Street ( Basanthpur) to the Temple and stopped in little tea shops along the way. I suggest dont waste money on a taxi. The walk to and up to the temple is relaxing, good exercise and you get to see much more. The best time to bargain for souveniers is mornings when they charge at a more reasonable price.
best view ever kathmadu. Normally i was at morning but this days i was at evening WA how beauty for Kathmandu and surround the best place to relax at Kathmandu....
Must visit. You need to walk up the 364 steps to reach the top. It has a nice view to Kathmandu city. The stupa is magnificent and all the statues and icons are amazing.

Very interesting place on top of a high hill.. You need to walk up the 364 steps to reach the top. It has a nice view to Kathmandu city. It is known as monkey temple but we only saw a few due to the festival happened that day.

very interesting trip. We went on a trip here and found it absolutely fascinating.The stupa is magnificent and all the statues and icons are amazing. The monkeys add a bit of light relief! I found the smells and colours amazing and was lucky enough to watch a lady doing puja which involved a holy man burning insense.

Worth the climbing. Wear your walking shoes as there are hundreds of steep stairs to climb to the top. For certain, worth the effort as the views of surrounding Kathmandu are excellent and the religious structures at the top are interesting. Bring you camera for certain. You will get chances to picture the hundreds of monkees living towards the bottom - near the entrance. The usual sellers of everything will be on your right and left as you slowly ascend the steep stairs. There is an admission fee for foreigners at the very top. The structures and stupa are amazing. Lots to see up top, inclusive of the Buddhist temple. Great place to look around and people watch. You really get above the hustle of Kathmandu and the noise. There are even green patches and trees.
On top of Katmandu. View most of Katmandu from this holy site. The climb is worth the effort and the buildings are intriguing. Vendors abound but remain mostly respectful. A "high" lite of Katmandu.

Decent View Point. More than the temple and its religious relevance was the fact that the hill top gave an excellent perching point to click photos with a distant mountain landscape on the edges and an ill-planned, unregulated, polluted, Densely populated city of Kathmandu as a backdrop.Hardly the best view you would have in any other mountain holiday trip but nevertheless one of the standing out places of the city. A good fifty steps of walk also added the much needed exercise for me. The monkeys were far and few and bothered more with themselves.

Nice harmony. It's located on the top of a hill, overlooking the city of Kathmandu. What really interests me is the harmony embedded by this temple. Gods/Goddesses from Hinduism and Buddhism are worshiped at the same place and even some saints are both. Religious separation doesn't exist in this place and people are inspired to achieve universal wisdom. How wonderful!
perfect. such a peaceful place, to wander around and/or have a coffee nearby. make sure you climb the stupa and have at least one walk circling the entire structure

Nice location on the top of the mountain overlooking the city with lots of monkeys. The second biggest temple in kathmandu but the best one to visit . You need to climb lots of stairs to reach the top but the view worth it indeed .

Quite a climb, but worth it!. I walked from my hotel in Chhetrapati to the Monkey Temple, which took me about 30 minutes, including the climb. It's quite a steep climb, so make sure you are ready for it! Bring water, as you might get thirsty climbing up. It's really near, so I do suggest walking instead of getting a taxi. The temple is absolutely breathtaking and there is also a view of the Kathmandu Valley. There are some hand-crafted souvenirs sold in the area.

Monkey temple. Westerner calls this temple as a monkey temple. There was a pool for a monkeys and a lot of them mingle with visitors. The guide warns us if we have a food they will follow us to the car.

Nice temple with great view . This is one of the most famous place for tourists. If you can go morning time around 10 am with clean and clear sky then you can see city from here.you need to climb a lot to reach this temple as it's on hill top. On the way to temple you will get lots of monkey.just be careful ..If there is no food then it will not be big problem. I feel this is the one place ..like iconic place of kathmandu so you must take pictures keep back side of the 2 eyes marked temple top. As there are lots of souvenirs shops so you can buy as we bought. But need to do heavy bargaining. Must visit place in kathmandu Nepal.

A delightful place. A myriad prayer flags blowing gently in the breeze, cute cheeky monkeys,a small temple, and then we climbed further to the top. On the day (about 9 am)we were lucky to witness the painting of the stupa, as well as the changing of the flags and putting up of colourful banners, as it was an auspicious day. It was incredible to witness the agility of the climbers up to the top! Monks walking around the stupa, turning prayer wheels, other little ceremonies taking place, monks reciting their mantras outside and then the sound of the monks from inside the monastery with drums, shell blowing and horns provided an amazing atmophere, more intimate then Boudanath stupa.

Leading Attraction of Kathmandu. This is a leading and one of most favourite tourist spots of Kathmandu. The temple is also known as monkey temple as there are so many monkey on the way to temple. The temple is on hilltop and you can see entire view of Kathmandu Valley and Kathmandu City also.there are two way to climb for temple.Swayambhunath Comlex consist of a Stupa and some temples. This is a Budhhist Spot.You will be tempted to take snaps.One of them is enclosed.

A place to view Kathmandu city. Better to visit early morning and wear full cover shows when you visit there. Place is not much clean to use sandals. If the air is clean can see nice view of Kathmandu city.

This is one of favorite attractions in Kathmandu. there are steps that takes you to the top of the small hill where the main temple and stupas are located. please visit here for the unhindered view of the himalayas. you must visit here to see the talented craftsmen carving masterpieces out of slate stone. one thing to watch out for are the monkeys. they can be a nuisance.

Not to be missed. This is one of my favorite attractions in Kathmandu.A peaceful oasis to sit down and watch the crowds of tourists, enjoy the view and the breeze on this hill. And of course, the stupa itself is very impressive.Avoid shopping for too many souvenirs here, the same articles would be found for better prices in the city proper.

peace within kathmandu limits. a short distance from kathmandu city a small drive to a hillock brings you to this place. once you reach here you will see a wishing pond. dont worry if you dont have coins. there are vendors selling coins. there are steps that takes you to the top of the small hill where the main temple and stupas are located. please visit here for the unhindered view of the himalayas. you must visit here to see the talented craftsmen carving masterpieces out of slate stone. one thing to watch out for are the monkeys. they can be a nuisance.

Pilgrimage Sunday. We visited Swayambhunath Temple on a Sunday, it was full of many local residents on pilgrimage preparing their bags of rice, flowers and others for ritual purposes to be placed within the several shrines as offerings.There was even a huge ritual offerings of bread, fruit, and other foods with many pilgrims singing accompanied by their musicians.There seemed to be a mixture of Buddhist and Hindu rituals all in one. The monkeys roaming about in General did not bother much unless they saw food. Might be a good idea not to have any visible so as not to call attention.It is possible to visit the old monastery and sit awhile.mit is necessary to take off your shoes.There was foo course a lot of noise and movement. Not sure if this is so other days of the week.Cost for foreigners to go in is 200 Nepali rupees. The man at the ticket counter said the temple was open until 8:30 pmThe temple is well worth the long steep climb up.

Beautiful temple just be careful with the monkeys!. This is a beautiful temple, but there is a reason it's nicknamed the Monkey Temple. They're very smart and quick and will steal anything so keep your bag closed and your eyes open. That being said, such a beautiful place with amazing scenic views!

Good Views. A Buddhist temple and Unesco World Heritage On top of a hill overlooking Kathmandu. Great views of the over the City.
It is sometimes known as the Monkey Temple as large number are free to roam around. Worth a visit. Really steep stairs to the top, so bring plenty of energy.

Sumptuous. You will leave behind you the noisy, buzzy, and crowded streets of Kathmandu to make your way up along a lengthy staircase leading to the temple. Once at the top, the tour truly begins. Very touristy, very pleasant place, could have spent several hours just contemplating the magnificent invigorating stupa rising before me. As well great place to take amazing panoramic shots of Kathmandu and its valley by clear and bright weather.

a MUST SEE experience. Visiting the MONKEY TEMPLE truly is one of the premier places in Kathmandu. Every time I visit KTM I make the trek UP the steep stairs to the temple.You CAN sit in the monastery while the Monks do the rituals of daily prayers. You can sit just a foot or two behind them and get the once in a lifetime experience. Of course lots of shops if you are looking for some genuine Buddhist icons.Some great small food shops to get a cold drink and some simple food. Great views.

Well worth a visit. One of my favourite places in Kathmandu. very beautiful, lots to walk around and see. For the best time to visit, try early morning and be prepared to spend a couple of hours just chilling out. Good cafes for a dude chiya at the bottom of the hill.

Watch out for the monkeys!. Visited here at part of a city your. Didn't walk up as it was the end of a full day of sightseeing.Plenty of monkeys running around looking for opportunities to get some food-watch out if you are carrying food!Great views of Kathmandu from the top.

Nice stupa with monkeys all around. Great view from the top showing you the whole Kathmandu city. The temple is full of monkeys I would suggest that you dont try to feed any of them. Around the stupa are little shops selling interesting items.

Freedoms of Monkeys. It's a such a great experience that seeing the monkeys around hanging out freely.=)At first you could think monkey could attack you but if you don't bring any food with you (recommended) monkeys doesn't interested with you =). you can take a breath while climbing the stairs.But buying some gift is not recommended(demanding over price comparing with Thamel). While you finished the climbing stairs Kathmandu Valley view waiting you.You feel like same level with clouds. It is not forbidden to enter Buddhist Temple buildings located top of the Swayam. Temple. There is a must see place and location is about approx. 500-600 Npr taxi fee from Thamel.

Nice little piece of Nepal. Crowded and touristy, but still worth a visit. Lots of shops if you are short on time and don't mind paying a little more. Cute monkeys and photo opps and excellent views of Kathmandu

I love the monkeys...the temple is nice too.. If you visit this temple please remember to bring a couple of kilos of bananas and oranges for the moneys. The monkeys natural habitat has been over taken by pollution and urban encroachment. You can buy the oranges and bananas near the temple. The monkey also love apples and pomegranates. It really made me sad how many of the Nepali people, especially their children were cruel to the monkeys. I saw a group of children throwing rocks at a group of moneys even hitting a baby money in the eye. Seeing these highly intelligent creatures frolicking about and interacting with each other was the highlight of my trip to Nepal.

Silent Place. I gives the traveler the peace of mind and rich culture association.
Must visit. The monks are very dedicated and the true culture of nepal is reflected from the walls of the temple

Good one. A smaller form of Boudhanath with lots of stairs and monkeys. U climb stairs but the view from the top is amazing. The snow claded peak seems to bask in the rays of the sun.its a nice place surrounded with small temples.good place for shopping

Not Bad. It's not bad. A smaller version of the Boudhanath. It was interesting to watch the locals do their prayers.
Enjoyed walking the flight of stairs to the lovely sovenier shops alley.

Worth to wake up early!. It´s a truly beautiful place. When you walk up the many stairs and the first sunlight guides you to the shimmering stupa, it´s just an incredible feeling. Behind you the city, which slowy starts to get busy, and in front of you the temple, which gets bigger as higher you walk. The area is pretty big, so the 200 Rupien entree fee for foreigners is alright. There weren´t as many monkeys as I thought there will be, but you can still see a few. Many Nepali people do their morning sport here, and little kids trained karate. It´s just a nice spot to connect with the ancient architecture of Nepal.

Great views, worth the climb. Two ways to get to it - hike up a long flight of stairs or take a car to a point and take the small flight of stairs. But its worth it. Lots of places to sit and watch the sunset. You can relax on a corner perch and look at the mountain tops.
Pretty Cool, mind the monkeys. The story behind the place is pretty cool, and you'll have a great view of kathmandu from the stuppa .

Lots of monkeys & stairs!. It's an easy 30 minute walk from downtown & a bit of a workout getting up the massive flight of stairs to the top, but the climb is worth it. There's some great sweeping views over Kathmandu from here, too. It's a shame that there's so many souvenir venders as it clutters the place up alot. There are toilets here, but only to be used in an emergency!!!
best views. 15 minutes ascend the stairs. seems like a hiking. my 2 hours there , looking, sighting are very interesting.

Magical place - go in the early morning!. It is a place full of sprititual energy. I really loved the people doing their prayers and ceremonies. Go in the early morning to see them or in a special Buddhist day for monks in prayer.

Wonderful Place to Visit!. One of the best places to visit close to Kathmandu. Rage view of Kathmandu from the top is exquisite. Architecture is beautiful. The monkeys with their babies are quite cute and well behaved (one did try to attack our camera when we went in too close but that was us disturbing him :)) The place is not in pristine condition but than again what is in Nepal? It is a beautiful place well worth the visit.

Worth a visit. We walked from our Chetrapati Hotel to Swayambhunath Temple in the afternoon. We had to make our way through many narrow winding streets. Once having reached Swayambhu, it was a steep flight of steps to the top of the hill. The monicker Monkey Hill was amusing and not too apt because in India we are used to monkeys in most hill temples… :-)There are water troughs where monkeys, dogs and pigeons drink water. There is an area where these animals and birds are fed too. However this did not stop a monkey from snatching a bar of chocolate from another tourist.The view of Kathmandu is stunning. But it brings into focus the urban sprawl….Tip: All the streets all look the same. So if you too choose to walk to Swayambhu, I advise you to carry a map and to ask for directions regularly. We needed to confirm with the locals that we were taking the correct route while walking back to Chetrapati. And do read about this World Heritage Site before making the visit.

Great Views. This temple is also fondly known as Monkey Temple- and rightly so, there are a lot of them hanging around! There are good views out over Kathmandu Valley when the weather is good. Definitely worth a visit to see this stunning temple and learn a bit about it's history!

Wonderful views and interesting people. Having been mugged by monkeys at the airport I visited the monkey temple sans fruit! However, the monkeys here are well fed and were better behaved. The buildings on the hill are superb but spoiled by unchecked commercialisation, too many stall holders selling the usual 'stuff' to be able to feel the special spiritual significance of the place.

Magnificent Stupa atop a hill. Visit the Swayambhunath Stupa on my way back from Dhakshin Kali templ, Pharphing and Kirtipur. Reached late in the evening and the whole place was full of people going round the stupa praying. Evening is a good time to visit, keep about 2 hrs and one can combine it with other visits. As the sunsets you can get a breathtaking view of the Kathmadu city. There are a number of shrines around the stupa and each has its own story and history so it is useful to read about them before the visit.
Beautiful. Great views of the city. Hold on to your food - the monkeys are crafty and naughty. They will steal the food out of your hand. This does provide entertainment for onlookers however

Stupa with a history longer than Boudha stupa. This stupa with its open compunds and various statues attached to it is considered very holy. Just go round it seven times if possible. Do-able as its compound is smaller than Boudha Stupa. Just focus on the stupa while there and think good thoughts. You do not have to enter the surrounding temples. Avoid carrying things like plastic bags or bottles on your hands as the monkeys can mistake it for food.

The monkey temple!. This was an absolutely extraordinary experience whilst in Kathmandu! You can get a cheap taxi around 250-300 rupees from the Thamel area that will take you to the bottom of the temple, which you can then walk the steep path up towards the temple (be prepared to meet many a monkey). It will cost around 200 rupees to enter when you arrive if I remember correctly. The temple is a stunning sight, one you will never forget. Catch a photo with pigeons in flight that swarm near the temple, or a selfie with a monkey, (be careful they'll steal your stuff). If you're lucky and it isn't foggy, you can see the whole Kathmandu Valley, it's quite special! If you're looking for a cultural experience, it's all on show at the monkey temple!

Sacred place to Purify Oneself. When climbing the stairs, meditate. Focus your mind on your breath (inhalation and exhalation) while absorbing the heavenly journey to the 1,600 years old temple. Go straight to the praying areas and do not allow yourself to be distracted by the beautiful artwork you can buy. Do that later and do that wisely. Find a pleasant corner and sit for a while. Contemplate. Breath. Stay quiet. Focus. Your questions will be answered. Then stand up and continue to enjoy the market, the people, the sounds. This place is one of the few places where I have seen monkeys living in peace with dogs. If they can do it, we should be able to live in peaceful coexistence!
UNECSO Heritage site. Its a UNESCO site where you can have a excellent view of Kathmandu specially in sunset time , equally good in morning for sun rise too.

Stunning!. Awesome place to go especially if you are into Buddhism! Loads of monkeys and interesting people. Cafes with wifi and roof top restaurants allow you to soak in the beauty! One problem is sale men and women are too persistent but that's the joy of travelling

Budham sharnam gachami. Very calm and peaceful place, with nice location but the sorroundings are not clean at all and looks haywy in a way but overall if I say will be a gud to visit and mst visit place in KTM.

Worth it on a number of fronts. A good walk up the steps with lots of variety up top: stupas and chortens, pilgrim's praying, lots of sellers, monkeys, dogs and good views over Kathmandu. Toilets are ok

Not a fan. Personally, I didn't think this place was very well cared for. The view from the top is probably the one redeeming feature. I felt nagged by the souvenir vendors and the monkeys were not well. Many had open sores. Furthermore, there were at least three monkey battles while we were climbing up. At the top, the 200 rupee entrance fee made us feel like turning around. We did see a lovely bird on the way up, so there was that...

The Self-Created Temple. Swayambhunath (pronounced 'Swahi-an-boon-eth), located on the a green hill, also knowns as the Monkey Temple, as there are holy monkeys living in the temple.Legend:The bodhisattva of wisdom was raised on the hill which the Swayambhunath Temple now stands on. Majusri grew his hair long and head lice grew. Legend said that the head lice transformed into the monkeys that now live around the temple.Two entrance:East - A long stairway with 365 steps leading directly to the main platform of the templeSouthwest - A card road direct up to the hill, but escape the long stairwayThis temple is among the oldest religious site in Nepal. There have entrence fee.Point of interest:1. The main stupa surrounded by many small shrines and temples2. Shikhar Temple - erected by King Pratap Malla3. The biggest vajra (thunder-bolt scepter) 4. Statue of Vairochana Buddha 5. Dipanker Buddha Statue of 7th century, made of huge single stone6. Monkey pool7. View on Kathmandu valley from the hill

Excellent !. Ones again it's once in a life time to visit such a unique place.Climb the 106 steps, and you come a such a beautiful view. There are shops here & birds" & monkeys & the Main Stupa for prayers!!!!! As you come down, real nice souviners to buy!great!!

Must visit Stupa on the hillock . The meaning of the stupa is "self existing awareness". Somehow it is also known these days for tourist as monkey temple, simply because there are monkeys in and around the temple. The temple is the oldest in Kathmandu valley and is one of the world heritage sites. The iconography of two tall temples on either side the main stupa is surprisingly resemble with that of Orissa in India. I came to know that the Shantikar, the prince from Orissa visited this temple during 5th century. You see the Shantikar temple on the north west side of the main stupa, who is believed to have been meditating below the temple since centuries. The main stupa houses five buddhas and bodhisattvas (one who aspires to become Buddha and is on the bodhisattva path). This means that this stupa is of five Buddhas (Buddhas in metaphorical sense). The Amitabh Buddha on the western part of the main stupa is revered much by the devotees. There is also Ajima temple just by the side of the main stupa who is protectorate of children in Kathmandu valley.

View of Kathmandu Valley. Overall its good! Not that extraordinary but the surroundings are nice and its nice to see the Kathmandu Valley from the top which I liked most. Yes, someone can include this on his/her list of things to see in Kathmandu.

Incredible sight and architecture, nice gift shops. You start this visit by walking up stairs to the top of the hill. The last part is very steep so just be careful.Monkeys are everywhere and easy to photograph. You can also give them fruits or biscuits but do not show them you have a lot of it otherwise they will follow you ;)The place is quite and the atmosphere very pleasant, the view is impressive as you can see the whole capital city from there.Beggars ask for money but do not harass you, they only sit and wait. Thus allowing you a nice walk without being disturbed every two minutes.The shops around the place a nice and inviting and the merchants are welcoming and kind.

Beautiful. Beautiful place, peaceful, tranquil.Great view of Kathmandu.Had to climb a lot of stairs up but it was worth every pain !Just be careful with the monkeys. I was told they can attack people and I saw them literally chasing some tourist!

What a View. I am an American in Kathmandu, Nepal on business. I had a day off so I took the opportunity to obtain a guide and tour some of the temples. I visited The Swayambhunath Temple. It sits high on a hill so once you climb to the top you have a most impressive view of a large part of the valley. I was fascinated by the monkeys, of course that is the reason it is called the Monkey Temple. I recommend that you include this on your list of things to see in Kathmandu, Nepal if only for the fabulous view.

Good but not the best. You may think that having such an extraordinary site on a hill a bit out of Kathmandu would mean that Swayambunath would win over Boudhanath in terms of atmosphere every time. Not so. Yes, it's beautiful, yes it does have atmosphere but is also has busy shops with the usual pushy stall holders who seem to ignore the supposed sanctity of the place, loud music (or muzak?) and a lot of rubbish all round. The monkeys, while contributing their own brand of exoticism, do not add much more to the place than what you would expect. Sacred they may be but their manners leave something to be desired! All in all, if I had to choose, I would always return to Boudhanath, not here.

Stairs, monkey, view, art. The Swayambhunath Temple isn't located very far from Thamel area. I choose to walk from Thamel to here (be sure to wear a mask). The walk was pleasant. you'l have to climb up flights of stair to reach the top. It was exhaustive of course, but take it slow. Along the way there are mane small stupa etc. Once you reach top, apart from the temple, you'll be blessed with the panoramic view of Kathmandu valley. during clear day (which is very unlikely as it is always dusty) I believe the view would be amazing. the temples and stupa is amazing too. Overall, this is worth a visit and be careful of the monkey.

Must visit. One of temple that you must visit while u in kathmandu...located bit outskirt of kathmandu approx 20 minutes by taxi...from peak of temple people observed kathmandu valley view, so don't forget your camera...many interesting object around this temple

known as the monkey temple. We could see this Stupa from our hotel room and it night it was illuminated. You walk up a lot of stairs and once you get to the top you see lots of temples as well as the stupa. Took a picture of wife with two monks.There are lots of monkeys all around hence the name Monkey temple. It surprised us that once we got to the top there are also stores and vendors selling sodas and snacks. There is a great view of Katmandu from the top as well. Well worth the trip up.

Wonderful views. We were happy to take the long walk up the stairs and saw our fair share of the monkeys - which were very tame and did not perster us or try to steal our bags etc as some monkeys have done in other temples. To be honest the families of monkeys making their way throught he foliage was a lovely sight to see. The stupa was pretty awesome as well as were all the statues and the view across Kathmandu was worth everything - well worth a visit.
Beautiful!. Very nice stupa, its on top of a mountain so expect great views. there are many monkeys around. There are little shops where you can get souvenirs.

Great views and beautiful environment. An easy walk up the long stairway. Beautiful harmony between Buddhism and Hinduism...however too many shops which kinda spoils the tranquility...the tiny museum is also rather disappointing with exhibits that does not seem well taken care of and are not labelled so visitors could not understand more about them. Overall beautiful environment with great views.

An ancient melting pot. Although chained up monkeys may not appeal to everyone, this famous temple is well worth a visit. The prayer flags at the gates signal that this 2,000 year old shrine is is a sacred Buddhist place, with many prayer wheels engaging the devotees. There is also a Hindu temple included. There is a lot of quiet excitement to observe, with butterlamps, fire, bells and many, many pilgrims. The commanding views are inspirational. A visit is highly recommended. Bring your purse as there are many stalls.

worth the walk. the temple location is at kathmandu valley, up the hill. to get there u must walk the stairs with monkeys and people selling stuff along the walk. but after u reach the temple, u can see kathmandu view from above. dont forget to drink some tea at nirvana cafe. the waiters will show you their 3rd floor so you can take a better picture of swayambhunath temple.
Monkey Temple. great historical place, with a guide probably better because they can explain to you the details of the temple history, and nice spot to see the Kathmandu city.

one of my favorites in Kathmandu. I truly love this place and every time i go to Kathmandu i come at least a couple of times. It's a really peaceful and spiritual place and you can enjoy an amazing view over the city. If you reach the monkey house area, much less crowded you can seat in the shadow, at the sun, in a peaceful corner and relax, meditate or just watch around. Lovely

great view. save yourself a heart attack and take a cab to the top and you are right by the peace pond and restrooms(western style). a short climb and you are among all the stupas,temples and trinket shops.a few beggars too. best bit is the view if not too hazy from the air pollution

Inner Peace. This place generates vibes hidden inside your mind. Your soul will feel the harmony and tranquility you desperately seek. Being close to the watchful eyes of Swayambhu Buddha, you will never feel bored. Also the scenario, visible when your inner eyes see the surrounding, will mesmerize you to be here repetitively. Don't look at the uncivilized concrete jungle beneath, the true beauty of the valley is observed with your purified mind. The happiness you seek is within your grasp. You just have to feel it.If you want to feel what I speak, you just have to visit this place and search for the answer of your question within yourself.Monkeys, Hawkers, Unnatural structures, Couples romancing, people visiting for religious purpose etc. are mere distraction for you in seeking the philosophical meaning of this heavenly place.

Don't miss it. it's quite a sight, although what once was a tranquil place with nuns chanting prayers and monkeys harassing you the temple is now surrounded by the KTM urban sprawl. Still worth a trip as an initiation into Buddhist culture. Be prepared to fend off aggressive souvenir hawkers and so called guides

Fantastic & Historic. A magnificent place, just a walk of half n hour to the hill and you will observe the whole 360 view of city.As the Stu-pa's two peaceful eyes watching the whole world with justice. mostly known as the Monkey Temple, it is the collage of Hindu & Buddhist Temples on hill. rise above from ground you can fill the horizon of skies unlimited..

Real harmony and great lesson for world!!. This situated in perfect place middle of kathmandu, where you can see panoramic view of kathmandu valley as well beautiful langtang region, jugal himal range, beautiful place lies like a spreading religious freedom, peace , love for everyone with 'Buddha eye'.... This is perfect place of harmony for extremist religious people of world, see here who can beat us religious harmony look both Buddhist and Hindu were respecting each other but why all of you guys are fighting for religion, learn from nepal.

Monkey grab my grapes. Oh! monkey grabs my grapes on the way up to stairs of this temple. It is great exercise and fun like a hiking to climb up to the swayambhu temple(monkey temple) Great views of kathmandu and air conditon atmosphere. typical day tours of the kathmandu i feel more refreshing there.
Excellent view of Kathmandu city. A little walk using stairs & you reached a place to get a beautiful city of Kathmandu. A must visit place if you are visiting kathmandu

Wonderful site, steep climb up the pilgrim's steps. Don't even listen to what the Lonely planet guidebook says: its not easy to get there on foot. Take a taxi. Have the driver drop you off at the steps going up and enjoy the site You don't need a guide. There is a toilet ( squat style) near the bottom of the steps you can use before or after your visit. Then take a taxi back to Thamel if that's where your hotel is.
Incredible place. A must see in kathmandu !! Peaceful, great views and monkeys :) beautiful sunset, I spent a whole afternoon just enjoying the views, people watching and relaxing

Beautiful view of Kathmandu City. Although the steps leading to the Swayambhu Temple is steep, the view of the city from the temple top makes for the hard climb. Do take care of your belongings as a lot of monkeys hover around right from the steps all the way to the top.In case you staying at Thamel, just catch a Micro Bus (Van) for a nominal price of NPR 15 to reach here. Get down from the other side and you can head to Boudhanath by another Micro Bus.

Scenic, fun, and interesting attraction. The Swayambhunath or Monkey Temple is not far from downtown Kathmandu, and it is definitely worth the trip. Since it is on the top of a hill, it offers excellent views of Kathmandu. This is the scenic part.The temple itself is impressive, but there are also many other artifacts and interesting things to see.We spotted our first monkey on the approach road, but then when we got to the temple itself there were no monkeys to be found. Then someone threw out some popcorn, and all of a sudden there was a congregation of hungry monkeys. It was as if they were waiting for an invitation, because after grabbing some popcorn they stayed around and offered good photo ops. Their antics were definitely fun to watch.There were souvenir shops, but nobody pestered us to buy. I tried out one of the ritual horns, about 8 feet long, but didn't think I could fit it in my luggage.We spent over an hour wandering around, and thoroughly enjoyed the visit.

Ongoing Temple Worship. Historic site to this faith. Not as well maintained as the Buddhist Temple, but still something to see. Again, the climb up the steps will cause you to stop for air. Be careful of the monkeys. They are not tame and actually snatched something out of our hand. Also, be prepared for public cremations. We witnessed four in the 30 minutes we were there.

Scenic Beauty and Divine Blessings. A great place to visit when you visit Kathmandu. A combination of Indian temple and a Boudha temple. Feels great by seeing the beauty around. Walking to the place is a good experience. Must visit

Gave us the creeps. Dirty, unsettling.. Perhaps our experience was an enigma, but my friend and I arrived at the base of the stairs to find the place eerie, dirty, and unwelcoming (unlike most everywhere else we visited in Nepal). The people along the stairs of the temple were chastising, and when we arrived at the top we both had the sensation that something sinister was up. I know that may come across as hokey or strange sounding; I'd be sceptical reading that, but it was what we experienced. The monkeys were also kind of terrifying. They overrun the place and a group of them broke into a screeching fight right next to us. We couldn't get out of their soon enough. Maybe it would have been a different experience if we'd gone earlier in the day, but upon the recommendation that we see the sunset there, we went in the evening. This lent to the feeling that the place was touched with (for lack of a more appropriate term) evil. Make of that what you will. I'm not one to scandalize, only trying to honestly review our experience. Definitely will not be returning there. Again, there could be a number of reasons why our experience seemed weirdly tainted, but I think there are much more worthwhile places and spaces to visit in and around Kathmandu.

Superb.... not to be missed. Swayambhunath Temple is one of the attractions of Nepal that can't be missed. Fabulous temple; fabulous views of Kathmandu Valley; inspiring and peaceful. As everyone notes, the steps leading up are many and steep, but if you take your time, they're not bad and the rewards are well worth it. Be on guard for marauding monkeys, which can be aggressive and easily attracted by shiny or colourful objects and pretty much any item they can snatch.
Awesome. Great views and awesome experience. We liked this place and have some breathtaking pictures as well captured there.
Very spiritual. A long hard climb up but worth it an amazing place ... Go there you won't regret it . Lots to see and stunning view over Kathmandu

Well worth the trek up the steps!. I was really hoping that I wasn't disappointed seeing how I had to walk up millions (perhaps a few hundred) steps--I wasn't! There's a great view of the city, and great pictures (whether or not you subscribe to the religious beliefs). Worth the trek & the 200 rupee ($2 USD) fee. It's a must see.

The Buddhist samovoznikšaâ swayambhunath stupa.. Swayambhunath stupa is the second largest stupa in Nepal, honored by all followers of Tibetan Buddhism. On all four sides of the square base stupa placed "the secret eye of the Buddha". The stupa is located on a high Hill to the West of the city, to climb on it, it is necessary to overcome the 365 steps, according to the number of days in a year. After the last step, you find yourself near the huge Dorje. Dorje is the Tibetan Word for the Sanskrit vajra meaning-"lightning", the most important symbol of Buddhism, the Vajrayana-describes the early enlightenment.

Nice place to visit. Nice in the top of hill, situated on the top has spectacular view of Kathmandu from the top.
Lovely place to visit and highly recommended....

Monkey Temple - Kathmandu at your palm. It was rainy summer morning when I got there. 365 stairs between you and Swayambhunath Temple. It was scary at moments, especially near the end of the stairs, but I survived. :) After you get there, you are surrounded by beautiful stupa, shrines and temples. People in meditation and prayers, monkeys freely jumping around, climbing up the temple. View from up there is spectacular and you can see entire Kathmandu. If you want to have lunch, or a cup of Nepali tea, restaurants are on the spot. Also, you will find various souvenir shops and people selling souvenirs at the stairs. On the way back, it is a bit scary and steeply, but you will survive. In any case, you will enjoy this place.

Very nice old temple complex. This is a very nice historic place on top of a hill over Kathmandu, also known as "monkey temple" because is is full of monkeys (than can be agressive some times. Be careful!). It is also a good place to get away for a while from the chaotic Kathmandu without going away of the citi.

Landmark sight in Kathmandu with great view of the valley. We took the easier route to reach the top - drive to the back side to the closest point and then take the stairs up. Didnt count the steps, but it wasnt a hard climp up. We were greeted by a family of monkeys playing and jumping around as soon as we entered the temple complex. They didnt bother or hurt us in anyway and few of them infact entertained us with their swimming skills in a nearby pool! I really liked the stupa at the top, revered by both Buddhists and Hindu alike and it offers great view of the Kathmandu valley. There are few souvenir shops at the top.

Best view of Kathmandu!. Swayambhunath or the Monkey Temple, as it is called, is within walking distance from Thamel (5 kms). Be prepared to climb up the stairs with slightly bigger steps than usual. There are lots of monkeys and hence the name Monkey Temple.one you get to the top, you would get a mesmerizing view of the Kathmandu Valley. Definitely visit the nirvana cafe there.

a must, wonderful. You can walk from Thamel; sort of West and follow your instincts.Watch the kites hunting the monkeys. And the dogs v monkeys.And generally a wonderful atmosphere. A real MUST when in Kathmandu.

Best view of Kathmandu. If you have the legs, visit this place as you will find the best view in kathmandu. I went in the morning and I was rewarded with a great sunrise over Kathmandu. Definitely visit it, a great highlight of my tour

Temple and Monastery together. One of the places showing Buddhist and Hindu faiths together in Harmony. Sharing the basic tenets the place very beautifully mixes the two faiths. The view from the top overlooks the entire Kathmandu valley and had a very amazing look.

350 step to get up.... ...but for sure you wont miss the top of the "Monkey temple". Not hard to reach by walk from Thamel, but be prepared for the 350 step to arrive at the top. 20r for locals 200r for SAARC and others countries

Must see. We took the short route of 100 steps to reach the top to view the temple. What a wonderful place. The temple was beautiful & the monkey's fun, guarding this sacred place. The monkeys and dogs didn't bother anyone, rubbing along side by side
More religions side by side. It takes many steps to get there but if you find the way behind the tempels it is not that hard. From the top there is a fantastic view of Kathmandu and surroundings.

A don't miss!. I've walked the front stairs twice and the back stairs 3 times....go with the back stairs to go up, take the front down. Check out Namaste café and just relax and enjoy this little oasis.

Symbol of Nepal. This great Buddhist temple is one of the most popular symbols of Nepal, also known as the 'Monkey Temple' after the large troop of monkeys that amuse visitors. There are great views over Kathmandu from its hilltop setting. On top of the white dome of the stupa, there is a gold-coloured square block depicting the eyes of the Buddha, a question mark-like nose and between the two eyes is a third eye, which symbolises the Buddha's insight! Again, as in all the stupas, there is a series of prayer wheels set around the base which pilgrims spin as they pass by. Each prayer wheel carries the sacred mantra 'om mani padme hum' which means 'hail to the jewel in the lotus'. The prayer flags also carry Tibetan mantras. Bring your camera and take lots of photos of this very impressive stupa.

Spectacular. This temple is simply spectacular. A must visit for Hindus (because only they are allowed inside), this place is beautiful atop the hill which provides a great view of the city. A definite visit. Be careful of the monkeys though.

Sacred Self Arising Stupa of sacred site of Buddhist master Nagajurna. A must to visit that's known to be the sacred place of great Buddhist master Nagajurna. You may take outer route or middle route or direct to the high point of the stupa. Great place to do aspiration prayers; hanging prayer flags; Circumambulating the stupa.

icon temple of nepal. it's also called the money temple though I myself do not like calling it that. it does have lots of monkeys around and they are so much fun to watch. only take the stairs if you think you are fit - I take the easy way - by car around the back and take a few steps up to the top. on a clear day beautiful view over the Kathmandu valley. DON'T carry any plastic bags as the monkeys will think there is food in them and they WILL come to get it.. I'm talking of experience!

Worth visiting. Very close to Thamel. Bit of a climb by stairs. Entry fee of 50rs for Indians and 250 for other foreigners. Beautiful statue of the lord Swayambhu nath. It looks like a very old temple. A good view of Kathmandu from the top of the mountain. Beware of the monkeys!
A Kathmandu Must. Gorgeous, surreal experience. Lots of good restaurants with rooftop seating. Cheap cab ride from Thamel. A must-see great for spending an afternoon.

Hey hey We Are The Monkeys. Just like the title song and group from the 60's The Monkeys are why you come here. This is monkey heaven . Big monkeys to small monkeys come here to get you monkey fix. Climb up the steps to go to the stupa whith good pictures all around. Prayer flags flying all around make it peaceful and enjoyable. Shops are interesting here too. But by far the main attraction is The MONKEYS!!!!

High above the city. You will have to take a really steep staircase to reach the very top and almost at the top you will have to pay an entrance fee of 200 NR...but it's worth it.Great views and a really spiritual place.

Nice view of the City. Worth the climb of around 500 stairs for a very picturesque view of the City of Kathmandu. Monkeys will accompany you in the premises. The Prayer wheels will take you to a different world.

500 steps. We walked here from the Thamel, which took 30-40 mins and meant we got to see a few villages without all the tourists. There wasn't really anything along the way that was spectacular but it was nice to escape the swarm of Westerners.The temple at the top is decent enough to look at for a few minutes and take a few photos, however it's the view of the city and the mountains that attract the masses - on a good day you can see for miles in all directions!My girlfriend counted something like 496 steps up to the temple from the bottom, and the last 100 or so are pretty steep. They are pretty sly with tickets too and don't try and charge you 'til you are about 20 steps from the top, although it was only about $2.50.At the top there are plenty of people selling drinks and jewellery etc. but the views and the monkeys are the draw. We had nuts on us by chance and the monkeys gathered all around us but were very patient in waiting for us to feed them.Interesting place but i'd suggest going early before the crowds.
Must Go.. Great place to go to. Monkeys, prayer wheels and you get to buy some trinkets. Excellent pictures with monkeys amazing place.

Magnificent views, worthwhile visit. It is definitely worth climbing the long row of steps it takes to make it to the top of the temple. Apart from the splendid site of the large stupor at the top, the views out over Kathmandu are really spectacular. I really enjoyed visiting the monks as they taught the students and spinning around the giant prayer wheels is both rewarding and fun. The monkeys are also pretty cute, but don't walk up with any food on you as they an sniff it from a while away and before you know it you will be surrounded by a pack of viscous monkeys fighting it out for the food. Overall well worth a visit for any and all religion types.

The temple is not so grand but the view is superb. The stupa and the area is beautiful and detailed but no so grand. But you can see almost all of Kathmandu from up there. And of cause, there are a lot of Monkey (not so friendly but nothing to be afraid) If you don't want to wank up all those stair. Just get there by taxi and tell the driver to drop you of at the back parking area and then you just need to walk a little bit to reach the stupa.

Monkeys monkeys monkeys. I enjoyed the long flight of steps up to the monkey temple. Great view of the city, and you can grab some food / hot tea at a cafe on top as well. Fun bit of exploring. I don't know if it was the time of day but at sunset those monkeys came in droves (for the pasad food that they are given, probably). It's one of several temples to see while in Kathmandu. And if you are intrepid (and you should be since the Nepalese are courteous, friendly and good people) walk from Thamal...it's only about 30 minutes and takes you through some local neighborhoods - just ask someone to point you the way if you aren't sure - you'll pass lots of stalls that sell Bodhi mala beads for inflated prices that they love to blame the Chinese for making so expensive. There's a fee to pay at the top of the steps - about $2.50 if memory serves.

GOOD PLACE TO VIEW STUPAS, KATHMANDU, MONKEYS AND MONKS. Average temple area for Nepal, but what makes it interesting are the views over/across Kathmandu and the monkeys, that wander around the grounds. As with most of Kathmandu, this temple area/ground is crowded (not only with tourists but many locals) and on the dirty side. Keeping the environment/your community clean is of little to no importance in Nepal. The monkeys make for great pics, but be careful, they do sometimes bite. There are lots of small stores on the street to the temple selling all kinds of handicrafts (in many of them you can watch the craftsmen making the product - hand painting mandellas, carving slate or wood products, etc.). You can walk among the many smaller stupas and/or around the large central stupa and turn the prayer wheels. You may also have the opportunity to see a group of young monks walking around the stupa after classes or a group of older monks practising their debating skills.

Definitely worth a visit. For anyone trekking in Nepal, this temple complex is a must see. As a trekker, I found it an easy walk from the Thamel district. If you are not a trekker, or are directionally challenged, it is easy to get to by other means. Pick a fine day to go, so that you can enjoy the view while up there, and won't have to cope with the steep steps when wet. There is a large stupa at the top (the eyes signify that God is always watching, and the symbol where a nose would be is the symbol of unity, the # 1), but multiple others of varying degrees of antiquity and beauty. The mix of people is fascinating, with everything from the devout to tourists to couples having wedding photos taken, and mixed in are the monkeys and the usual stray dogs. Don't take food, as the monkeys are great at snatching it, and will try to pick your pocket if stray ends of a bag are protruding from it. You can buy all kinds of items from kitsch to beautiful thankas, don't forget to bargain. Stay as long as you like, but plan on at least an hour or two, and don't miss out on this amazing place.
Nice. Also known as the Monkey temple. Nice spot with many steps to get there. Lots of monkeys and a good view from Kathmandu valley.
A bit of a culture shock. This is where Nepalese traditionally cremate their departed. But if you're in for their tradition and culture, this is a must!
Insightful. The temple is quite a trek to get too, but, it is very different to anything I had seen before. The locals can give you a good guide for a decent price too.

Stairway to heaven. Swayambhunath is on top of a hill in the Kathmandu Valley. It is also known as the Monkey Temple as there are plentiful monkeys living there. There is a stupa, a variety of shrines and temples. The stupa has Buddha's eyes and eyebrows painted on. There are also shops, restaurants and hostels. We had to climb a long and steep stairway to the hill top - later found out it was 365 steps.The monkeys will keep you entertained all the way. Old, yet beautiful architecture. We were fortunate to see the filming crew filming part of a Napelse movie.

Tranquility at its best. We had to climb a long flight of steps to get to the temple but this can be shortened as cars can get to the car park nearby. The views from the temple are very good and there is a sense of tranquility to this place. Watch out for the monkeys but they kept mostly to themselves. Have a go at the prayer wheels and there are little restaurants if you decide to have a snack. The entrance fee for foreigners is reasonable but the temple could be kept a little cleaner being a world heritage site. Get a good guide to explain the temple to you and the experience will be very informative.
Very nice place. Swayambhunath temple also known as monkey temple was an amazing experiencing . There were monkey`s everywhere .fees applied.

Fantastic place for views and colours. This is a special place in Kathmandu and you must really want to go there to see it ... because there are 380 steps to ascend before you are rewarded with seeing the Temple in it's glory! It is a fantastic place to wander around!

Hilltop wonder. This stupa is one of the best in Kathmandu. On a hipptop, you get to it by climbing a long, steep flight of stairs, accompanied by the local monkeys. The stupa itself is magnificent and looks out over the Kathmandu Valley. Down to the front are enormous statues of Buddah. Fantastic sight.
Another failed Unesco site. The temples are beautiful yet the maintenance is of poor quality and dubious interest. Filthy and poorly kept.

A gorgeous place, good views. Not only is Swayambunath an amazingly beautiful place in itself, but it also offers very nice views over Kathmandu. If you have limited time for sightseeing, I'd recommend making Swayambhunath your number one priority. The 200 rupee entry fee (for non-SAARC nationals) is very reasonable, especially when compared to those of Pashupatinath and Boudhanath. The statues, stupas, prayer wheels and building are all gorgeous and there are small restaurants and tea shops in case you get hungry/thirsty (and a number of shops as well). Beware of monkeys and "guides".

Watching the people is the best part. All these UNESCO sites are free to locals and that's a good thing for us tourists. This is because they themselves are the stars of these attractions! Unlike most of the cathedrals in Europe, these places are active, living religious sites. Tibetan Buddhism is full of Hindu stuff and spirit worship too so observe all the prayers and offerings etc. (Pure Buddhism is atheistic: there's no one to pray or offer to.) I enjoyed interacting with the locals, doing what they do. Don't forget to toss a rupee coin in the fountain! Most of all, smile. The Nepalese are pretty friendly when you do.
Site of peace and tranquality. This is one of the must see places if you are travelling to Nepal for the first or 100th time. One feels elated by merely being present in the temple complex

Don't skip the lesser known section close to Ring Road. There are some amazing statues and surrounding square and garden at the bottom of the hill just of the traffic artery called Ring Road.For those that are lazy, you can ask a taxi driver to drop you off at the top of the hill. From there it is only a few remaining steps to the top platform of the Monkey temple.

Awesome experienc. First time in my life to see this Great Temple. Life and death. UNISCO Heritage. Architecture, People feeling about death. Thinking that the life is short to fight each other for stupid things. Love life and enjoy the beauty of life

a must go temple. also known as monkey temple with a lot of them around. it will be good if you can climb the steps from the bottom otherwise you can drive almost near the top. you can see the whole of Kathmandu from here. a should go place
Walk it up!. Beautiful place and another must visit while on visit to Kathmandu!Do not miss the Buddha park when you get down........ also worth a visit.

Worth a visit. Besides enjoying the typical temples for the area, I particularly enjoyed the views of Kathmandu at this elevation as well as the distant view of the Himalayas. The numerous monkeys are both a curiosity and a nuisance.

Must to see. We like the temple and the location is nice because you can see the Kathmandu valley. The Stupa is know as monkey temple and the monkeys are all over picking up the food that Hindu and Buddhist people offer. The architecture is also very interesting
Great View. A fairly wide area. We can enjoy a wonderful afternoon here. We can see Kathmandu city view from the hill. Falcons and monkey createing a natural atmosphere.

Awe-inspiring temple. This is a MUST. Stunning in every respect....but especially if you are at all spiritual.A first sight will take your breath away. Take time to savour the atmosphere and feel the energies of all the visitors.

The taxi ride there is also interesting!. This was our first stop in Kathmandu and we did arrive there a bit later than planned, due to the traffic, but still managed some good sunset shots.This is a great stupa to visit and the complex itself is very interesting.Definitely worth checking out.
Revered by both Hindus and Budsdhist. This shrine is situated on a hill 260 feet above the valley floor. The monument is a shiny golden spire on a large white dome.

Not to be missed. We're very used to temples but this was our first encounter with a stupa so it was unlike anything we'd seen before. It's built on top of a hill so you'll enjoy some breathtaking views even before getting there. There are also lots of interesting shops to browse along the way. Learn about thanka and other traditional Nepalese crafts while you're there. Then walk around the stupa and turn the prayer wheels.Just don't get too close to the monkeys in case they get irritated.
peace monkey place!!!. this is our first attraction in kathmandu visit. such a great view from the the top of stupa. like very much theirs mokeys activities!!

Spectacular!. I have never seen anything like this temple before. You can also see the entire city from this temple hilltop. It was a holiday and it was filled with locals which made it all the more interesting. A must see while in Kathmandu!

Many things to see and feel . The architecture along with the views of Kathmandu from the top, here are the best. A visit to Kathmandu without a visit to Swaymbhu is incomplete and less I really loved the sculptures and could have easily spent a complete day just appreciating in each of them, there are so many things to see and more....... So if you are in kathmandu don't miss to visit this place
Great view. Beautiful monastery/temple area (although lots of dogs and monkeys) and offers one of the best views of the entire Kathmandu valley. The 103 steps to the top didn't feel too steep.
Lots of monkeys. Filled with monkeys, stray dogs and garbage. If only it was a bit cleaner. Have in mind that if you've seen one stupa, you've seen them all, so I would recommend Boudhanath.
Great view. The great view and it was really old and around there many people worshiping. I have seen many monkey on this tour.

Great view over the city. As the temple lies a bit outside the city center, you have a great view over the city and the whole Kathmandu valley. The beautiful stupa is located on a hill and can be reached by taxi. Watch out for the nasty monkeys!

It's not about the monkeys. Monkey temple detracts from this complex of stupa's and temples. On a clear day you will also get a good view of the city. Sadly the smog was bad on the day I visited. Irrespective it is a very ancient and interesting complex. Enjoy

Monkey Temple. This is another stupa sitting atop of a hill also known as Monkey Temple. Why, because the place is flooded with monkeys, its their home and you need to be really careful where you walk. You need to climb up on top of the hills through stairs and there are 3 ways to reach this place, the longest and the steepest, the middle one and the shortest stairs. I visited this place twice first time with family so took the shortest route up. The Stupa is a beautiful architectural wonder with ancient sculptures, carvings, the humongous bells with inscription, and so is the reason its also a world heritage site.Don't forget to light ghee diyas at the Stupa and ask for you wish in the wishing well. To ask for a wish, you need to toss a coin and for the vessel which sits right under Buddha's statue.

Cultural Experience. Also known as Monkey Temple, this area is a must see when in Kathmandu. Rich culture and history here. When we visited, there were even Monks out praying at the top. The monkeys are adorable, and not as sneaky as other monkeys we have seen (like Bali stealing sunglasses!). I enjoyed the Boudanath Stupa area better, but it's worth it to see both!

Long walk up, but worth it. The view from this temple is worth it. You would however have to walk up 365 steps, past some monkeys, before you are greeted with a view of the city, some shops, and the temple.

Excellent (Monkey) Temple. We really enjoyed this temple. It was at the top of many (200+?) stairs and was a bit overtaken with monkeys. But that added to the whole ambiance as people still came as though they weren't there. The monastery was beautiful inside with many butter lamps lit, the views would have been great (it was cloudy/drizzly when we were there) and the monkeys added another facet to the whole experience. Would definitely recommend a visit.

Mystic. The Swayambhunath temple is one of the pride of Kathmandu. It offers a great view from the top and the overall ambiance is mystic. The area is infested with monkeys. The colors offered around the stupa areas through the flags are unique and absorbing.

Swayambhunath Temple- you could affford to miss it if you are pressed for time. If ypu see the site after having seen Boudhnath stupa you will be disappoinbted. If you come around the place when your bellies are crying for food you will be frustrated .There is no good place nearby

A place of reflection. Throw a coin in the bucket of the peace pond and you will have good luck. The view from the top over Kathmandu is amazing, we were taken right to the top of one of the buildings by our guide. The monkeys are everywhere. Lots of monks and well worth a visit to see this stupa.

Monkeys, temple & view. The monkey temple is home to... many crazy monkeys of course. It's quite fun to see them playing (unless you're unlucky to get attacked by them. Don't take food with you!).The stupa, the monastery and other Buddhist features also provide a great reason to visit Swayambhunath. In fact they're the main reason.Lastly, location location location. Situated on the top of a hill, the temple is an excellent viewpoint on Kathmandu valley (in the rare days the atmosphere isn't too polluted). Try to time your visit around sunset and expect a spiritual experience...

Amazing Views. Well worth the climb to the top, views from the rooftop cafes are the best in Kathmandu. The ambience of the temples are marred somewhat by vendors trying to sell you things around every corner but all in all it's a charming hilltop temple, with monkeys!

Excellent. A beautiful Stupa and surrounding structures, Monkey's galore, and some excellent views of the Kathmandu Valley. It's typically a busy area, but on a quiet day you can feel the energy pulsating in this culturally significant spiritual area.

Amazing landscape. Definitely worth the hiking. you can see there the wonderful landscape of Kathmandu valley. Also can get some culture of the Buddhism and see some monkeys at the monkeys temple. This is 30 minutes walking from the Thamel but i recommend to take a taxi because the complicated streets of Kathmandu.

Also known as the Monkey Temple. Absolutely amazing!! If you are in Kathmandu, you must visit this sacred site. Very peaceful and spiritual....be sure to spin the prayer wheels. Be aware of the monkeys who will steal your food right from your hands if not careful.

Feel the peace. Wonderful to experience how 2 of the world's great faiths respect and tolerate each other. It was fascinating to learn how some people adopt facets of both religions and seek to live their lives, practising these accordingly.

A uniquely Nepalese mix of Buddhism and Hinduism, very comercialised but a must see!. The number one must-see place in Kathmandu, Swayambhunath temple (though you'll have to tell the cabby "Monkey temple" before he'll understand where you want to go) is a large complex atop a hill just a bit outside Kathmandu's central district. When you go there, don't take a tour bus that drives you to the west entrance, but walk all 365 steps up the east side. Not only is it a great workout, you get beautiful views of the Kathmandu valley. You will more than likely be greeted by a person saying you'll need them to tell you all about the temple, and unless you are very familiar with the unique blend of religions expressed here, you might be better off believing them. After the climb (and a few minutes to catch your breath) you walk around the Stupa [CLOCKWISE] and take in the sights and sounds of the locals and pilgrims at prayer, both clearly Hindu, Buddhist and a mix of the two. In the courtyard you will see many shrines and relics as well as a large dorje or thunderbolt, the symbol of Tibetan buddhism.Take the opportunity to visit and quiet yourself in the adjacent monastery, where you will also find a beautiful mandala (one of the forms of thanka painting) apparently made by his Holiness the Dalai Lama. Again, walk clockwise through the building (start by walking left from the door) and remove your shoes, even if the guide just walks in, as it is an expected sign of respect. Oh, and when you getthe fancy to spin the prayer wheels (all around the outside of the Stupa and a big big one in the monastery) you spin them with the RIGHT hand. It is not in poor taste to direct people traveling in the wrong direction as to the correct path, by the way, and many will appreciate the good karma you are bestowing them. Thanka's are also available for purchase in the complex, as well as a lecture on the making process delivered in good English, if somewhat mechanically.
