Thanka art is not usually sold by the Tibetans and there is a certain dilemma about buying these beautiful works of religious devotion. - Whatever you do, don't be fooled into buying the poor flashy reproductions available in Thamel! Be prepared to spend premium prices ($200 and up) on the higher quality ones, these are no mere souvenirs! Other sights in the complex include the swimming pool for the monkeys, who may or may not be swimming, but will definitely be hunting for any and all unatended food and rip apart any plastic bag they see, no matter how scary the person holding it may be. The monkeys are the first thing you see, approaching the temple hill and are with you all throughout your visit. And they can be vicious. Stay clear of them and they will mostly leave you alone. Hopefully. Next to the monkey pool is a fountain with a pot that people toss coins into for luck. Most seem to miss, though. If you want to join in and show of your skills, you'll need to exchange money for copper coins at one of the nearby vendors sitting on carpers along the sides with piles of coins ready in front of them. This obviously, because local currency is rather short in the coin section. Around this is also a veritable bazaar of stalls selling all the ubiquitous souvenirs and curios. Watch out or you may find yourself surrounded by people packing stuff in plastic bags and rattling off how much you owe them. This really is a huge tourist trap! If you came in from the west entrance, feel free to read this guide from bottom to top, to get an idea of the order you will see things in.

Interesting. Though the traffic was very heavy on the way to the temple, but it was worth it. It only cost 200 nrs entrance fee. Lots of stuff being sold around the temple. We bought some beautiful locks, fossils and decorations. Of course as usual you can bargain (esp if you are good at it!). Lots of monkeys with their young ones scampering around. Besides tourists, many local come to say their prayers and you can see them ringing the many bells at the temple.

Worth the exhaustion. First of all, be warned that you have to climb 365 steps to get to the temple if you take the main entrance. But once you are there, given the skies are clear, you get an amazing view of the Kathmandu valley. You can even see the planes landing at the airport. Sit down and have some coffee at one of the rooftop cafes while overlooking Kathmandu. Beware of the monkeys though, they can be notorious if intimidated.

Watch out for the monkeys, and fighting dogs but make sure you visit here. The monkeys are part of this place but stay well away from them, they didn't look friendly to me - and don't carry food in here with you, they know and will harass you. The view over Kathmandu from here is good, when the fog/smog clears. Like most places there are the usual shops for tourist trinkets. Oh, and watch the dogs on the upper level, they had a huge dog fight going on when I was visiting, a bit of a distraction and a bit dangerous given the stories I've heard about rabies.

Soyambhu. This is the first place we visited in Kathmandu with Central Himalaya Treks and Expedition, we were completely enchanted with the atmosphere, with rich history, culture, pilgrims and monkeys.

Must visit. The stupa is located on a hill. It is better to take taxi up to the gate to do less climbing. There was some religious activity going on when we were there last week. Many lamas. There were also many monkeys, the stupa was also named Monkey Temple. It cost us 250rp to take cab from Thamel to the stupa.

Lots of interest here. If you approach from the East there is a long but historic stairway to climb or you can start from the car park on the western side and ascend more easily past some small stupas and a Buddha.The top has the iconic stupa for which Katmandu is famous for as well as temples, shops and a small monastery. Whe we visited there were many monks sitting beside the stupa chanting their mantras. Plus of course hundreds of monkeys all over the hill (hence the name Monkey Temple).The view over the city is excellent depending on the days polution level.Well worth a visit.

Brimming with life and many religions. Come before 7 am or in the evening when devotees are visiting. Even better, walk the hill with devotees one morning if you happen to be there during a festival month. Amazing site to see.

Monkey paradise. A place that a lot of monkey living in, it is interesting that the monkeys fight for the food from visitor. Remember to go up to have a bird's eye view of the kathmandu city and also the Himalayas.

A Curates Egg. This is a must see. The proximity of the Buddha's eyes, And the views of the city make it. Unfortunately it is crowded [of course], filthy dirty, and commercial. You will see a lot more monkeys than monks.

Bustling with activity, a feast for the senses. One of the most memorable places to visit. The temple is perched at the top of a steep climb. There you can follow the other pilgrims and walk in a clockwise manner and spin the prayer wheels.It's a great place for a photographer like myself with plenty of action. Not much of a view of the city due to the air pollution. The religious reverence and activity is certainly impressive.

Great views!. I fully enjoyed visiting this temple. The views from the top were amazing! Loved the prayer wheels! The monkeys are a sight to see. Witnessed a couple fights between them. Also witnessed a shop worker teasing them, which was obviously irritating to them. We didn't walk the whole set of stairs, only the final sets. Not sure I would feel the need to go again but it was definitely worth going once.

A must see part of any Kathmandu visit. Also known as The Monkey Temple. Breathtaking! My second visit. I absolutely love the whole feeling of this place. A lot to see in a small area. Very spiritual. Views are spectacular also.(Be prepared for steps, but can be taken slowly)
Good place to go once. Nice place. No need to climb all those stairs. Just take the bike/car almost close to the top area. Worth spending 1-2 hours. Not more than that.

Up and close with the monkeys . The city must see; it's a beautiful historical and religious site, with a panorama view of the city. Monkeys roam around freely and can get naughty against each other or visitors if teased with food. Witnessed monkey feeding times, done by the monks living at the temple. A very interesting thing to see:-) like a mini monkey invasion coming out of nowhere! Highly recommend a visit.

Chanting monks 1980. I walked into a dark room to the sound of 20+ monks chanting in a very deep tone. Standing for a few minutes listening to this was an experience I will never forget. Very other world-like. I wonder what the place it like now so many years later.

Monkey Temple. My group got driven all the way to the top to the entrance, however if you are feeling brave you can take the pilgrim stairways and climb to the top. Its very clear to se why so many people call it the monkey temple once you are up there. Once near stupa you will see many different temples around the stupa. The guide we had with us explained how Buddhism and Hinduism have mixed together at this site. Really good views of Kathmandu from here if you are luckly with the weather, however the views from my visit where not great due to the amount of smog above the city.

Full of legends. Its said that this pagoda was built around 2 thousand yrs ago by Manjushree who came from China.At that time this valley was said to be a lake,so Manjushree with tantric powers cut the chobar gorges & let the water flow out.After that he threw a magical lotus seed in the remaining water which later became swayambhu(self created)in sanskrit.Although these r just myths,there is probably more scientific reason behind its construction.

Worth the climb. Go early in the morning when it's quiet, before the monkeys wake up, and when the revelers come. It's beautiful. Kathmandu is pretty congested, so views of the city are hard to come by.
There's a cool monastery on the grounds too- check it out.
Seriously, don't give the monkeys any eye contact...
Wow, what a place!. Wonderful view of Kathmandu, fascinating exotic atmosphere. This place is gold. Beware of the friendly monkeys though!

Interesting Experience. Our taxi driver took us to the higher drop off and entrance point for visitors - or if you prefer you can walk up the pilgrims stairway. There are numerous temples within the large complex - all around the main largest white stupa. You can easily hire a guide as soon as you enter the complex but we preferred to stroll about with map in hand. Be prepared for lots of 'gangs' of monkeys running or sitting around and although I did not experience anything, you should exercise caution in case you get too near and they snatch any of your belongings. The views of Kathmandu are amazing. As a guide we had completed all the sightseeing we wanted to do in under 2 hours - and that included a short refreshment break.

What a place!!. Love the area. It's on the hill and you can drive to the top. The city view from here is excellent. Guide took us directly up so we miss the beauty of the base. but if you have stamina and courage to climb steps, you should do. Must visit place in Nepal

A blend of Hindu and Buddhist.. The line dividing Hindu and Buddhist is very blurred here. They merge, borrow elements from each other till you are not sure what you are looking at. Magnificent! Just like the Nepali culture. Loved walking the prayer wheels.
Monkey temple. Impressive Stupa, wonderful view from there over all Kathmandu. Very busy and less calm as Boudanath Stupa. But a must see as well!!

On The Roof Of The World. To get to this magnificent stupa you have to climb about 600 steps. It is NOT for the faint or weak of heart. Once there you are rewarded by awe inspiring views of Kathmandu and the surrounding hills. This stupa is more commonly known now as "the monkey temple", so if you decide to walk there (which I highly recommend), then ask locals for 'monkey temple" because you will surely make an idiot out of yourself trying to pronounce Swayambhunath and be completely misunderstood.The monkeys are certainly an attraction, but they can be highly aggressive, so do not under any circumstances expose snacks or foodstuffs around them or you will surely regret it!The temple itself is... well words cannot adequately convey its sheer beauty. Maybe photos will give you a better idea, but even photos do not capture it adequately. Totally worth the arduous climb... and once again, if you are a regular visitor you will soon work out the way that the locals avoid paying the ridiculously low charges levied upon them!
Wow. Must see. For the variety it offers. For the panoramic view of Kathmandu. Be a little careful of monkeys. For the elderly, avoid steps both when going up and down. Take the road instead

Bit Underwhelming. Maybe because it was a Saturday when the locals have a day off but the temple was less a religious site and more a place to hang out, try and get the offering coins into the basket in the middle of the pond (to cheers). There are the many stalls at the top but not much religious observance. Yes there are hundreds of monkeys doing what monkeys do, stealing offerings and having sex.

Fascinating Place. We took a taxi from our hotel in Lazimpat, then worked our way back on foot. This was a fascinating attraction with great cultural and religious significance. The views from the top are well worth the trip alone. It was sad to see so many injured and sick looking dogs there, though.

amazing view of the city. temple in top of the hill, you can have clear view of the city from the temple,, very big area covered by this temple,,, so many monkeys jumping from here to there,,, like this place very much

Beautiful. If you come from the ringroad side, there are so many things to discover in the temple area that it took me 2 hours to go up to the actual attraction. On Saturdays, it is very crowded but I enjoyed observing the children chasing the monkeys and the little monks played football.

excellent place to see in kathmandu.. swayambhunatah temple is my best favorite place in the kathmandu.when i do have time ,as go to monkey temple.that is ancient place.while on the top of monkey temple we can see city view of kathmandu.where we can see monks and so many local people as well as tourist too.there is so many monkey they are fitting @ kidding with each other.i really enjoy it .i recommended to all of people .

WOW!. The short-cut road to Swayambhu (Buddhist Temple) from Thamel with the help of GPS was worth every step as we explored the real Kathmandu. Climbing about 300 steps at Swayambhu was a fun experience with monkeys around, snatching away our Sprite bottle and then drinking from it. The view of Kathmandu from the top is breathtaking!

Scary monkeys. Having visited Swayambunath in the past it was high on the priority list to show friends, but the experience was overwhelming tainted by the over abundance of sickly, rabid-looking monkeys screeching and running everywhere. The view over the city is great from the stupa, but we couldn't wait to get out of there.

....easily my favorite place in town..... ......as it always happens...sometimes best things are not planned and happen randomly....as with my visit to the Monkey Temple. With half a day left after trekking and before the airport, i grabbed a dusty cab and headed to Swayambhunath....its hard to describe the energy that engulfs you there but its certainly a special place....300+ stairs felt easy after 10 day trek and the climb was worth it.....the temple is a beautiful place and can be explored for hours if not days. i was fortunately enough to visit during the holiday and observed colorfully dressed adults and children, listened to music and was surrounded by lit candles. dont leave Kathmandu without visiting this magical place!
Good Place!. One of the must visit places in kathmandu! Very similar to Boudhnath structure. A bit of climbing to do in order to reach this place from the parking.

A great site to visit and spend time ..... It's a historical site with beautiful Buddhist status and artifacts. The wild monkeys added some charm and exotic appeal. I feel that more can be done to provide visitors an insight to the displays and artifacts.The number of start dogs do not add glamour and the place could do with a team of good cleaners to make it more appealing.It's recommended visit but wish more thoughts and care to make the place more appealing.

Ascend to this Wonderful Shrine. Our guide kept telling us about the Monkey Temple. I wondered about it, but once there, I understood from the moment we reached the entrance. Hundreds of monkeys scrambling into and around the trees; feeding on offerings; grooming their babies. Monkeys, indeed, were everywhere. They mostly minded their business, though one of our travelers had a bag with a newly purchased necklace snatched by a brazen monkey.We started at the base of small hill. Cars can't go beyond this point. There was a wonderful pool with many prayer flags and a gilt statue of the Buddha in the center. An umbrella was set above him. This was called the World Peace Pond according to a sign. We walked up and up...some three hundred steps and talked with a monk halfway up. Nice fellow; he told of his visit to the U.S.At the top are many shrines and temples, banks of prayer wheels, and monasteries. Legend tells of how Majushri had his hair cut at Swayambhunath. And each hair became a tree on this hillside; the lice became monkeys. Note how richly decorated the statues are here and take some time to savor the superb views of the city from this hill. Don't feed the monkeys; but do take some time for shopping. There were many fine shops and touristy venues to buy things. Prices were very good and items were somewhat different than in other spots.
Temple Life. This temple is on the tourist path, but well worth a visit. It gives you the Hindu side of Nepali culture, while the Boudha Stupa gives you the Buddhist side.
Very big. Its near the hill,, and in the top of the city from where you can have a beautiful view of the city easily,,

Good view of Kathmandu city. Also known as the monkey temple. Lots of monkeys here and they are not afraid of us. Most ancient and enigmatic of all the holy shrines in Kathmandu valley with a golden spire on top of the stupa and the view of Kathmandu city. There are shops and stalls along the way uphill when you enter and downhill when your exit

More than monkeys. Yes there is an abundance of well behaved monkeys that provide ample photo opportunities. But uphill are some great views, interesting temples, devotees undertaking their rituals plus artisans crafting interesting items for pleasure and sale

Views and Monkeys. The big stupa, the numerous hindu shrines, sculptures and architecture along with the views of Kathmandu from here are the best. A visit to Kathmandu without a visit to Swaymbhu is incomplete and less than a hour's drive from the city to here is well worth it. I really loved the sculptures and could have easily spent a complete day just appreciating in each of them in greater detail - and am hoping to do that during my next visit :)

Stairway to Heaven. The temple is located on a hill top offering breathtaking views of the city on a clear day. The complex has Hindu shrines as well as a dominating stupa. The temple can be accessed by a very steep stairway ( around 150 steps) which is a playground for monkeys, and the other way is by partially driving up hill and then climbing some steps.

Best sightseeing spot for travelers. Its an ancient religious spot located at a hill in the Kathmandu Valley, west of Kathmandu city. It is also called as the Monkey Temple as there are holy monkeys living in the north-west parts of the temple, it is probably the most sacred among Buddhist pilgrimage sites. For Tibetans and followers of Tibetan Buddhism.Swayambhunath complex consists of a stupa, a variety of shrines and temples, some dating back to the Licchavi period. A Tibetan monastery, museum and library are more recent additions. The stupa has Buddha's eyes and eyebrows painted on. Between them, the number one (in Devanagari script) is painted in the fashion of a nose. There are also shops, restaurants and hostels. The site has two access points: a long stairway with 365 steps, leading directly to the main platform of the temple, which is from the top of the hill to the east; and a car road around the hill from the south leading to the southwest entrance.

Monkey Temple!. Monkeys, monkeys, and more monkeys. Don't bring food and hold on to your belongings! There are literally hundreds of monkeys. The place is amazing though. It's very spiritual and even if you aren't Buddhist it effects you. Highly recommend to go. Watch the climb (365 steps) up and down, kind of steep.

Real temples, real stupa, real Buddhism. Unlike Boudhanath, which is very clean, neat, tidy, well presented and surrounded by pretty (and overpriced) thangka shops, Swayambhunath is a hill top stupa where real worship goes on and monkeys run around the area regularly. Little bit crowded, fairly messy, but if you want to experience Buddhism up close, don't miss this one!!!

Nice for a few hours. Road to get there was an adventure in the rain as the taxi got bogged in the mud.Close to Thamel about 10-15 minutes in a taxi and 395 steps to get there and a 200 rupees to get in. Monkeys are considered sacred and run around freely. Not bad for a couple of hours !
Great view foul smell. It is sad to see such a beautiful place falling apart due to poor management. If you can fight through the smell you're almost in heaven.(watch the sunrise)

Morning prayers. If you like to pray at a Buddhist temple this is one of the few in Kathmandu. Watch out for the wild monkeys. They will not attack or bother you. My tip to travellers do not feed them, just mind your own business and they won't bother you. Good place to take photographs because it is situated on a very high ground and can see the whole of Kathmandu

Amazing Views.. I had an excellent day here amongst the monkeys, temples and the views over looking Kathmandu! It is a must see place when visiting the city and the monkeys will keep you entertained all day. You can see the temple high up on the hill, which is a beautiful sight and makes getting there all the more exciting. If I had to recommend one temple in Kathmandu this would be it.
incredible. The monkey temple was my favourite sight in Kathmandu, monkey roam free around the hilltop top which boasts awesome views over the city!
Loved the monkeys!!!!. Great view of Kathmandu!!! The monkeys were very mischievous. Must visit this place if in Kathmandu.
Excellent view of Kathmandu Valley. Its a little far away from the city and gives a clear view of Kathmandu valley. Loads of monkeys. Must visit on your trip to Kathmandu

Fun Experience. This temple, also referred to as the Monkey Temple, was on the outskirts of Kathmandu and a bit of a trip through some narrow streets. It was a very interesting sight to see, with monkeys skittering about and plenty of sights to see and a good source of souvenirs. Bring your camera and your walking shoes and enjoy the sights! Note: there is a slight fee for tourists, roughly $2-4 per person, which is used to maintain the site. Well worth it, in my opinion.

Must visit in Kathmandu. Been to Boudhanath and Pashupatinath too, but Swayambunath is my favourite. We went in the evening. The most poignant was walking up the 365 steps to the top of the hill where the Monkey Temple was located ( the last 100 steps were quite steep -70 degree incline ) There were many monkeys and stalls selling crafts and souvenirs along the way. Ticket booth is at the top ( Rs 200 per person ).Enjoyed the panoramic view of Kathmandu and sunset.At night the temple was beautifully illuminated. Took a taxi near the World Peace Pond behind the temple back to Kathmandu.

Worth a visit! Great view of KTM. The temple is nice! The sunset is a good time for visiting the place although in winter it might be a bit cold aires it is high! So take some good jacket! The view from the top is great! Also the monkeys are a great attracction! Monkeys are all around!

Go EARLY. We hiked over to the temple first thing in the morning and are glad we did. Smaller crowds, better air and sights, better light for photography, too. The stairs are a wonderful way to start the day, too. Probably my favorite visit in the city for a single site!
Must see. Great views of the city, beautiful structure. Have to pay $2 to get in at the top of the steps, but definitely worth it.
lovely place to go in kathamndu. it is nice place , where every trekkers and tourist goes there, it is like island ,from there you get to see Kathmandu valley.

Busy Spirituality. At an end of the city lies the Swayambhunath Stupa. This is a very busy place, full of visitors, animals and hawkers. It is a powerful place. The stupa goes up high. One may stay there for longer hours if they go during early mornings as it is quiet around that place. During weekends it is avoidable.

Liked the temple and the sunset view. Liked the temple and the sunset viewed from there. It gets very dark so if planning to watch the sunset go prepared with a good torch as you will have to descend steep steps in the dark.

Three in one architecture :). Swoyambhunath (Often known as monkey temple) this is another fusion of three different architecture, i.e. One white dome stupa style, Pratappur and Annatapur are on Pyagoda Style and Temple of Harati Ajima is in Shikhar Style. According to local out there when Buddhist people suffered from chickenpox they don't have any specific god to pray for so they burrow Hindu Goddess named Harati Ajima to pray. This is perfect example of religious harmony. Don't forget to throw a coin on wish pool, enjoy view of Kathmandu Valley this is best hill station for good view of Kathmandu and peace of mind. I had upload one picture where you can see all those three different architecture on one single frame.

Monkey temple. Otherwise known as the Monkey Temple (because of all the cheeky monkeys that live here), Swayambu Temple is one of Kathmandu's five World Heritage sites and worth spending a few hours to visit. The long climb up the stairs to the temple complex at the top is rewarded by magnificent views of the surrounding countryside. Hang on to you purse or camera and be very careful not to leave anything unattended though. The monkeys are quick and often try to steal whatever they can from unwary visitors.

Excellent view point for Kathmandu Valley. This is one of the place in Nepal that where you can see combination with Hinduism and Buddism. Many many Peoples will be visitors of that Temple/Stupas. After climbing the more than 250 stairs you will be able to reach there.It's Nick name is Monkey Temple because there are thousands of monkeys living around so need to be very safe with monkeys around and make sure that you wont bring any food items or drinks in your hand or in your hanging bags, it may snatched by monkeys.The Buddist prayer flags all over the Temple/Stupas and throughout the surrounding area is magnificent to see.The temple overlooks all of Kathmandu Valleys which is an amazing view.It will provide you much opportunities to take amazing photos at all.

Worth the climb. And if you don't want to climb, turns out there's a road on the other side allowing you to come up by taxi!Amazing views of the city, beautiful temple and surrounding areas and about a million monkeys roaming around!

Buddham Sharnam Gacchami. This Temple is for Lord Buddha and is on a mountain...You need to climb stairs to reach this temple...Also the ccar can go till the temple...There are also some monkeys...There are a lot of Buddhist Monks...You can see the view of almost most of the kathmandu valley from this place...A Good attraction for few hours...

Got a little dizzy walking down!. Very interesting hike up many rocky stairs. Lots of cute monkeys misbehaving, and monks behaving quite well. Watch out if you are afraid of heights, the walk down is at first a bit scary!!!

Not just monkeys.. This is a large stupa or temple in Kathmandu also known as the monkey temple. There is a huge flight of steps to get to the stupa but you can drive to the top if stairs are an issue. The monkeys are amusing, if a little unpredictable and definitely not friendly. The stupa is interesting and the views are a amazing. We had a good lunch in an outdoor cafe right up the top of one of the buildings up there which was great.Definitely put this on the list for Kathmandu.

Lovely place. A bit of sweaty work to climb the stairs but really rewarding up there. Nice and peaceful temple. Gets a bit outshined by the multitude of monkeys. Nice to see around but watch your belongings

Lots to see and do. Great experience overall. There are literally monkeys everywhere, which was a cool experience. You could literally spend a hour just watching the monkeys go about their day. It was very safe with the monkeys around, just make sure you don't have any food or drinks hanging out of your bag or in your hand or it will be snatched by a monkey. The temple overlooks all of Kathmandu which is an amazing view. The prayer flags all over the temple and throughout the surrounding area is magnificent to see. Overall, there's lots to see and walk around to experience and I would highly recommend it.

A must see in Kathmandu. We were dropped near the top in our vehicle which saved our family the hundreds of stairs from the bottom. It is an amazing experience for everyone with great views of the city, heaps of monkeys, many beautiful temples and some amazing photo opportunities.

Must see!. Big climb up to the temple, but lots of entertaining monkeys to view along the way. The view up top is worth the climb and it was fascinating to observe all the religious activities - offerings, votives and prayers. Very peaceful and restful.

Watching over the Katmandu Valley. You need not take the long strenuous climb up the stairs these days. A motor-able road will drop you three quarters of the way up to the Heritage Site.The gigantic Stupa by itself is very imposing and the the golden colour of the top makes it glow in sunshine.Innumerable small chortens ans a number of gomphas surround the stupa. There is another beautifully crafted temple worshiped by both Hindus and Buddhists to protect the children from small pox and other ailments.Do not buy from any of the hawkers or the memorabilia shops in the compound. Everything is available and at a much cheaper rate at Thamel.

Monkey Temple. Take the climb up the 300+ stairs! It's completely worth it...and if not, at least you got some exercise in. From the top you get an awesome view of Kathmandu, chanting monks, and a ton of photo ops. We walked here from Durbar Square. Probably a 40 minute walk from Thamel.

Nice place to visit. I liked everything about it including the million (slight exaggeration) steps you have to walk up and then surprise surprise there is someone right up the top who wants your money. Too bad if you left your purse down below. It wasn't expensive though.More than anything I liked the atmosphere with people praying and wandering around. It wasn't overrun when I was there.You also get a good view of Kathmandu.On the way down you can use a path which takes ypu past another stupa and a small pool where you can watch the monkeys play.

Monkey Temple is the other name. It is worth the walk up to the temple although it is fairly long, well worth the effort. There are two temples at the top and monkeys everywhere. Also street merchants which are your normal demanding sellers. We used a local taxi to get there and for a very small amount of money he guided us around the grounds and even took us into places tourist wouldn't get to go, for example into the teaching rooms for the artist and beyond onto the roof for amazing views. He then let us to look around ourselves whilst he waited. Well worth considering.
City view. One of the oldest buddhist stupa. Great view over Kathmandu city and planty of monkeys arround. Good place to seat and feel the spirituality of Nepal. For sure it worth a visit.
Large temple complex. Great temple complex, very important to Nepali Hindus. Have your photo taken with the holy men for a small fee. Lots of interesting temples.
Amazing. In my opinion is this the most beautiful place in Kathmandu. It's very surprising and lovely. The view from the top over Kathmandu is amazing. You just realize how huge it actually is.
dramatic eyes. Great place to visit and fantastic views. If stairs are a challenge for you get a taxi to take you to the other entrance at the back of the temple - much easier walk to the top.

What an experience!. We loved everything about our visit to the "Monkey Temple!" Great views of Kathmandu from the top; many shrines, temples, craft shops, wonderful sites and sounds and of course- many monkeys!
Would highly recommend this tour!

Mystical and Magical. This is a wonderful place to soak up the spirituality of Nepal. High on a hill overlooking the Valley of Kathmandu, this ancient stupa is always buzzing with pilgrim and priests and monkeys and children and pigeons... The sounds and colours and smells are an intense potpourri of all that is wonderful about Nepal. Get there at dawn to see the sun rising over the valley mists and you will see why I have titled this review Mystical and Magical...

so worth the stair climb and entrance fee!. Was definitely one of the cheaper entrance fees of the places we visited in Kathmandu and well worth it! you get amazing views of all of Kathmandu once you get to the top. I highly suggest bringing some type of snack to feed the monkeys, it makes for a great photo-op :)
Peace of Heaven. There's something really special about walking up all those stairs to see the golden stupa at the top.Protip: Don't feed the monkeys!

Love the visit. Definitely, its a tourist attraction, surprisingly, the souvenirs sold are cheaper than other places.! Bought a few as a donation to the sellers there, entrance fee is acceptable at NPR200. Getting there is quite a climb. magnificent view of Kathmandu valley. Bit crowded at weekdays and spent about an hour photographing.
Recognizable symbol of Nepal. a 2000 year old Stupa, designated a World Heritage Site, crowns the hilltop overlooking the Kathmandu Valley, four sides painted with the compassionate eyes of Buddha.

Tidy visit. We were lucky in a way to visit on the day we did. The SAARC conference was getting under way and Kathmandu was getting a big clean up. This place was included so it looked especially smart. We walked about with the lonely planet book as guide and it helped. It would be good if this place had a small booklet giving more info and an insight to the place as a whole. We enjoyed our time here and latterly were asked to leave as all other tourists were as the dignitories were arriving to visit in private. I would say it is a good place to visit; 1 for what it is and represents and 2 as a good city viewpoint. Try to get there using the back streets as there lies a different flavour to Thamal and the city centre parts.

Great views, sights and monkeys!. We arrived at the Swayambhunath Temple, paid the entrance fee and entered the site. The first thing we encountered was a vendor who wanted to give us a tour and his sales pitch was quite annoying - he wouldn't leave us alone!There were may different structures to see and corners to explore with great views over Kathmandu. Also, there were Monkeys and being the first time I saw these I was quite excited. However after travelling a fair bit after this I realised the monkeys were not well looked after. I saw a monkey with a big cut on it's leg and it was quite saddening. When I went to the Monkey forest in Bali the monkeys were all well taken care of and in good state with a first aid place available nearby. Starting to rant a little - I guess i'm comparing apples with oranges!Overall, definitely a must see if you are coming to Kathmandu!
Monkeys all around. If you go there on foot from Tamel, you get to see the 'real Kathmandu'; climbing the steps will get you sweaty but the reward is the best view over Kathmandu!

Monkey Temple Visit. Great place to visit. Good views of Kathmandu city. Following the advice of a Tripadvisor reviewer we went at about 4.30 and the light was great. Be careful of the monkeys, one climbed up the leg of one of our group and grabbed her drink bottle and took off with it.
A favorite. One of my very favorite places in Kathmandu--feels authentic every time. Easy walking distance from the Vajra Hotel, and even from Thamel with great people watching along the route.

monkey temple. very touristical sight. On the top of step lot of shop. anything else. But the seeing sight is huge, so you have on one part, the monastry with temple, another part "the three bouddas's statues".

Steep steps!. Two ways up, the steep steps or the easier ones at the back. Only found those when we were leaving! Nice views lots of people. Great fun watching the monkeys diving into the monkey swimming pool!
Go at sunset for spectacular views of Kathmandu and surrounding valley. "Monkey Temple". Wonderful ambiance here; lots of stairs to climb to get to the top, so bring your water bottle!
The Buddha eyes are memorable. There are good views across the valley and this is a well known pilgrimage site that must be on your itinerary.

Amazing!. This was our first stop in Kathmandu and what a great way to start! The view is unreal of the city and the monkeys climbing all over and the best! Not to mention the great stupas and temples in the compound. A must see for sure!

Peace & Serenity. Our guide gave us a good look around this Stupa. Amazing experience - feel the peace and tranquility! Visited the Thanka Arts - bought a lovely painting. Definitely worth a visit for a few hours.
Amazing. These place has great diversity, and the elevations seen from the top is outstanding... these place gives me comfort but I hate monkey's cz they try to snatch people stuffs so.

Monkey temple. Seems to be one of the most holy sites in Nepalese Bhuddism. Massive temple complex, the whole site is covered in prayer flags. Need to climb stairway to get to main complex but it's worth it when you get there. Has a real sense of peace and serenity missing a bit at Boudhanath

Iconic site... A spiritual place with a wonderful view of the Kathmandu valley. The monkeys were well behaved and we enjoyed the stroll around the temple with our informative guide..Binod, who stayed with us during the trekking and was of great support to our team.
A must see part of Nepal..
excellent view of kathmandu and must visit temple. gives you a good view of kathmandu . a great place to shop some good antiques. great place to take good pics of unique buddhist temple architectures

Atmosphere. This place was amazingly spiritual,the atmosphere was calm and ethereal loved it!
Nobody should miss this place if they visit Kathmandu!

Kathmandu's icon. Climb hundreds of steps to gaze across the city from beneath the iconic Buddha's eyes on the stupa.. There are Buddhist and Hindu worshippers as well as sightseers from all over the world - and watch out for the monkeys !

First cultural visit. Arrived by suzuki taxi from the Malla hotel - 500 rupees (think we were overcharged) walked up a long and steep flight of steps, but a fine and excellent way of gaining the temples above. A small entrance fee and optional donations to various shrines within the walls of the main temple. Fascinating place, don't take food the monkeys will have it before you know whats happened.
Great place to visit. Get a local guide and go here. Lots of pesky monkeys around, but they are harmless and playful. A decent climb, may rain so take an umbrella. Very old syncretic temple shrime.

Bird's eye view of Kathmandu Valley. Most sacred temple amongst Buddhist Pilgrims. 365 steps to climb from one site and only 65 steps to climb from parking site. Two eyes of Buddha signify wisdom and Compassion. There are many monkeys on the site. Bird's eye view from terrace gives a feel of massive Kathmandu Valley.Location worth visiting.Nidhi KMViharin.comA glance beyond your window, come have a look!
Nice gem at night.. If you go here at night and there will be no crowds and you'll get a lovely view over Kathmandu at night.

By far the most important site to visit in Kathmandu. I was in Kathmandu 4 days and with the help of an excellent guide, hit all the top spots in the valley. But my favorite and the most moving experience was visiting "The Monkey Temple" AKA Swayambhunath Temple. I was blown away with the number of significant shrines and temples, many dating back to 6th century. The Temple complex sits atop a hill overlooking Kathmandu and the valley with many photo ops. Plus the monkeys, which are considered sacred, add another dimension and they often pose for photos. There are also shops and vendors selling paintings and various art works. Also the temple complex covers many acres - it is huge. Do not miss this site - it is a must see.

Monkey temple gone mad. Have been visiting this temple for many years and while you can still sense the magic of the place there is no denying the amount of places to buy local produce has increased substantially.
Loads of locals still make it a very holy place and of course the monkeys keep all us tourists occupied in between the shopping temptations

Monkeys at the temple. I visited on a Saturday. It was very busy and therefore difficult to feel any holiness amidst the noise and crush. However,that is much the same with St Mark's in Venice and Westminster abbey on a busy day. May be it was a kind of holy scrum! Good views from the top over Kathmandu and the macaques were funny to watch.

Don't Miss This. This is another site not to miss. Located on a high point and many steps to the top but it is worth it. The views of the Valley below are neat as is looking at the four sides of the stupa. There are some shops up here and the whole atmosphere is one of awe. There ar m onkeys all over the place. While we were visiting a monkey was drinking a bottle of coke that it had taken from a visitor. We took pictures and it was a sight we will never forget.
Must see. This site gives you an insight into the influence of the religion on the culture. Even if you are limited in time you should make the effort to see this amazing sight

Hinduism and Boudhism Tag team. Combination of Hinduism and Boudhism....something nice to see, Entry fee was a bit expensive (still less than Boudhanath), Shops in the area are too expensive, Trust me you can get all these in Thamel/Poshupatinath for less price.
Great energy. Amazing place with great energy! Definitely worth attending. Relaxing place with an amazing view on the city

You love it our you hate it...loved it. Amazing place and atmosphere, vibrant colours, the small of incense everywhere, monks chanting.Loved my visit, walked around and it was awesome.Ok you also have many shops around, but that is the world we live in.It was my favorite place in Kathmandu.

Monkey Temple. Beautiful view of valley. Nice to go at sunrise but if that's too early, go at sunset, have dinner there, and see the monkey temple at night - it's quiet and so beautiful as the gold on the temples are lit up by beautiful lights.

Favourite place in Kathmandu!. Loved this place so much that we went here twice! Go around sun set as the light over the city gives amazing vistas, and the stupa starts to glow. Also the monkeys are a lot more playful around sunset and especially after dark. Great atmosphere, lots of photo opportunities, a wonderful place.

Monkey Temple. This was a very busy and vibrant place. Lots of Temples, both Hindu and Buddhist, and lots of monkeys. The steps up from the main entrance were very steep but the top entrance was more accessible for people with mobility problems. Great views of Kathmandu.

Awesome. We did not climb the stairs all the way, went up by car and walked up a bit. The place is surrounded by monkeys. I didn't make eye contact with them :D and kept my camera and mobile safe as I don't want them snatching it. The stupa is lovely esp during sunrise(we went during sunrise) with the sunrays falling on it giving it a lovely golden glow. walk clockwise and pray :) light some lamps, take photos :) It closes early as in the shops near it close early, when inquired why they said something like the fog descends quickly.

Atmospheric. Another place I just have to go to whenever I am in Kathmandu. Best at a quiet time and simply walk around quietly. OK there are tourists at many times and can get busy, but its easy to just ignore others and take in the atmosphere, and also sit on a wall and gaze out over Kathmandu.

On a hill with great views. We visited on a Saturday which is the only day for weekend in Kathmandu. Plenty of locals were here putting up prayer flags and making offerings. Plenty of monkeys around as well. A nice little art school here is worth the visit to learn how traditional art is made. Plenty of stalls with trinkets or offering items available.
serene. This was on top of a mountain with plenty of monkeys around... was a nice serene place, worth a visit

Great view of Kathmandu.. You understand the scale of city from the top.If you are not very fit you can take a taxi to entrance and walk down the steps.Monkeys are fun but not everybody loves so many of them so hectic around you. if you have kids scared of them be causious.
really cool. really good views, lots of monks, shops, and monkeys. It was quite beautiful lots of prayer flags hanging over the temples really like it
Monkeys!. They are monkeys everywhere! Be aware of them, they take everything! It's a nice view of the city! ypu should go in the mini jungle they have, if you haven't had enough monkeys ;)

Gleaming Golden Monkey Temple with a fantastic view. We drove from Hotel Encounter to Swayambunath Temple. Quite a number of steps to climb to reach the top , however its childs play comparing it with the ABC trek :-) . It was pretty chilly at the top . The innumerable monkeys at the site would randomly snatch anything very attractive from your hands, so be careful . The view of Kathmandu from the top is fantastic.

Don't miss. Beautiful temple and interesting to see all the monkeys! I would recommend taking the stairs up, as it is a nice entrance to the temple, you see vendors (if you like browsing or seeing local people) and it is a bit therapeutic walking up.Once at the temple, the view is beautiful. I went at dusk and the colors were wonderful. You can see a number of people walking around the Stupa (clockwise) and a ton of monkeys!! If you walk down the other side, the view is also nice - and more monkeys!!This is a highly recommended temple - just tell your driver "Monkey Temple", as most people know it by this name, as well s Swayambhunath.
beautiful. beware of monkeys, don't show them any food. Around the temple you have a lot of souvenir sellers. You can have a noce view of Kathmandu from the top

Be aware of the monkeys. Lots of steps to climb to get to the temple and monkeys around everywhere. But be aware of anything that may fall on your head. Dealers along the staircase sell prayer flags and souvenirs to tourists. Lots of shops, galeries once you've reached the (temple) top.

Bit overcrowded. All in all a nice place to visit. We were lucky to have a car, because it is a steep walk up. Workers were busy with painting the stoepa so it looked nice. Lots of souvernirshops though, with mostly the same items, which is not very interesting
Swayambhunath. Nice place to visit ,and see the view of Kathmandu valley .By the way Be aware of monkeys there are lot of monkeys =D

Steps to nirvana!. Swayambhunath Temple is the place to go if you have only a short time in Kathmandu. Stupas everywhere, pilgrims, encense, prayer flags, even hords of monkeys.
Great place, do not miss!

A fascinating place. This Temple is a must see when in Kathmandu; it has marvellous views of the City, beautiful Temples and loads of Monkeys!Obviously it is a huge tourist attraction so visit as early in the day as you can, it get's pretty crowded.One highlight is the Pool just upon entrance where you will see numbers of Monkey's enjoying a swim including some spectacular diving!If going by Taxi you will be driven to the higher level of the hill thus saving you the few hundred steps up from the base of the hill.Another bonus is watching the Eagles fly both above and below you.A beautiful place in a beautiful setting.

Great views of Kathmandu. It's a good idea to visit Swayambhu first, before the rest of Kathmandu, as it's set on a hill, and the view from here will help you get your bearings. To understand the symbolism of the Swayambhu stupa, and what each part represents, it's worth coming with a guide or reading a good guide book.

An important place to seein Kathmandu. There are a number of tempels and stupas at the site. Monkeys with tails can be a real problem here and need to be discouraged. Many beggars are always present here too.
A heaven for a photographer. but for the rest of us, without the camera, there was nothing much to do after the first 20 minutes or so. The view, of Kathmandu, from the top is awesome though.
Amazing Views. A lot of steps but well worth it, we saw a local ceremony taking place, the monkeys provided lots of amusement, the views are incredible a great half day trip

Great views. The "Monkey Temple" is on the brow of a hill offering excellent views over Kathmandu. There is a short uphill walk from the car park to the temple and lots of monkeys on the way - they add lots of character to the temple area. The temple area, though busy, was very tranquil.
Amaizing site of religious worship. Within walking distance of the center of Kathmandou. Many steps to climb to reach a wonderful view over the city. Entertaiment from monkeys living here.

Great half day out of Kathmandu. Fantastic temples, views and experience. Highly recommended for a morning or afternoon. Taxis seem to charge about R500 - 600 and are honest for return journeys to the city.

Monkey Swimming pool. Swayambhunath is situated at the hill top. A place most scared among Buddhist pilgrimages . This is also called as Monkey Temple . You will find monkeys diving in the swimming pool . A worth watching scenes . On the top of the temple , one can have a nice view of the Kathmandu city.
worhty. My wife like but not me,maybe I don't like the Monkey,but the view is good ,it can watch whole KTM,it worthy to visit
Spectacular view. A spectacular view of the whole city that you wouldn't want to miss, the monkeys roaming around everywhere are a plus too.

A summary of Kathmandu`s chaotic daily life. Swayambhunath temple or "the monkey temple" is in my eyes the place where you have an offer to all your senses. Especially if you are here in a festival time you will also have colors of the sacrificing objects too. Here there is a hidden power circulating around with the monkeys making your eyes and mind wonder around, searching to find events and happenings where there are a lot of. The amazing shops around and the view of the Kathmandu valley gives an other dimension to the huge area.It is almost impossible to get yourself rip away from this multi functional place.

Monkey Business, great city views. watch the monkeys, they might steal your purchases looking for food, a great hill top enclave with stupas and shops, very old and fantastic views. Tourists pay more than locals to get in, but still modest. Get a car from your hotel with a driver...much easier to find and access.

Found a peaceful place. This place is lovely and feels like a tranquil place amongst the madness that is Kathmandu... You do feel a certain spiritual power from this place... Whilst there we also witnessed Buddhist monks ranging from maybe 7 years old chanting, that was amazing! If you are in Kathmandu it is definitely worth seeing this place... :-)

Overpriced. Walking up the steps of the east entrance as the sun rises, the Swayambhunath stupa glows in the sunlight. I paid NPR 200 for "keeping clean the environment, conservation, and management" of the area but the temple complex was dirty, and there were no information boards. I thought it was overpriced.The surrounding park area was actually cleaner, and was filled with locals doing their morning exercise, as well as going up to the temple to pray. I got to see the Nepali army trainees run up the steps, pay their respect to the various gods and jog back down again. It was a charming sight.
Great view of Kathmandu. You can get a great view of Kathmandu city from here. Good place for some peace amongst all the chaos of the city. Also a good place to buy knick knacks....

Only second to Boudanath. This stupa is not as nice as Boudanath and has a lot of Hindu shrines within the Buddhist complex. Varied but confusing. I didn't like the monkeys...they are everywhere and quite aggressive.

lovely view of kathmandu. swayambhunath has a lovely location, the architecture is amazing it looks like its been converted from a hindu temple as statues of Ganesha and Vishnu are clearly visible which incidently might have taken over by Buddhism,the best thing is they have not destroyed it and so we can see the mixture of both the religions together.Buddha eyes are beautiful and can be seen from a long distance,can be very crowded during vacations.

Fantastic. We arrived at the temple around 6am, it was a great time to get there as there were excellent views of the city before it became too hazy. The monkeys were also very active and entertaining to watch. The temple itself is beautiful and has many different areas to explore.A must see in Kathmandu.

Beauty at sunset. We went there despite downpour and when it stopped we were rewarded with magnificent views of Khatmandu, beautiful sunset reflecting in the gold of stupa and monkey antics :-). Just watch them out as they fight with each other plus sometimes may use you as a bouncing off point :-).
Awesome!!. It is incredible! Everything you read really amounts to nothing compared to the feeling of climbing Ll the way up those stairs and seeing all of Kathmandu amongst the monkeys!

Beautiful. Breathtaking view, and RECOMMENDED to visit.Note: there is a Nepali guy (looks like security) stands before the entrance at the end of the stairs he asks you for the fees 200 Rubee, if you wanna pay US dollars pay him 2$ as he insists on 4$ even tho it is written in board it is 2$. Dont let him cheat you.

Go in the morning. We started the steep climb up the Swayambhunath a little bit before 7am and before the tourist rush. It costs 200NPR to get in if you are a foreigner (although we only saw a ticket booth at the main entrance, not the other sides). There is a lot to see, so give yourself some time to explore, there is the main stupa and many other shrines and temples. There are people practicing Buddhism around the entire complex, so we made sure to be conscious to respectfully stay out of their way. There are a lot of monkeys running around which was a bit unnerving at first, but for the most part they ignore people.

Beautiful temple, worth the visit!. It was a lot of fun to visit Swayambhunath Temple, worth the visit if you have time in Kathmandu. We visited in the morning and the place was not crowded or overly noisy, very nice for Kathmandu!
one of the best temples to visit in the valley. A must visit. Big temple complex. Very interesting and busy. Csn usually see large number of monks praying and chsnting.

Beautyful temple with lovely view. During my visit to Nepal with my family during the month of May,i went over there.Its really worth visiting there.Beautyful temple on the top of the mountain.Although little stress to climb the stairs,but not an big issue.Be causious to the monkeys,as they can pluck the food packets from ur hand.Great view from the top.U can able to get an eagle eye view of Kathamandu from the top.Also on the top there is an lovely museum of Budhist culture.Lots of soveniour shops around.We enjoyed a lot there.Its an must if u r at Kathamandu
Fascinating temple in Kathmandhu. Beware of the monkeys here...they will give you a nasty nip if you get too close. A fascinating temple complex where you can easily whilñe away several hours.
Cool. I've liked the city view from the top and stairways to go up. But was confused while coming down and lost my way, hehehe poor me!!
Lots of monkeys and pigeons. A great number of pigeons deposit excrements all over the place. The monkeys steal, when they have an opportunity.

Top of Temple of Kathmandu. Its a very nice temple with a very beautiful scenic view of kathmandu because it is situated in the top of Kathmandu. It is a very amzing place. Everyone should must to go there.

The monkey template (Swayambhunath). It is a huge area with a big stupa at the top. Many things to look at and take photos of including the active monkeys. You will find monks chanting in a temple in front of the stupa.
Great Art Work.... Loved the Climb to the Temple...Lovely landscapes and Scenery around...The World Peace Pond was amazing and so was the Dongak Chhyoling Ols Monastry...

STAIRS.... We came to Kathmandu at the end of our trip in Nepal, and a couple days after finishing a trek in Pokhara (Poon Hill) so we were kind of exhausted and sick of stairs. This temple has a lot of stairs leading up to it, but it's worth going up. The area as you walk up is very pretty. I'm not a big fan of monkeys (which I knew there would be lots of beforehand), I think I've seen the movie Outbreak one too many times. I don't mind being around them, but I prefer to keep as much distance as I can and if you're like me you might find that a little difficult because they are everywhere. Monkeys aside, This temple is beautiful. There are amazing views to be had, and the vibe is almost overwhelming (in a good way) at times. We probably walked around the whole area for a good two hours or so. This is a must-see when you're visiting Kathmandu.
The Sway to Nirvana. The steps to the top are steep but the activity around this magnificent monument and view makes it all worth the effort.

Iconic Nepal. Beautiful temple and a definite must visit during your trip!The architecture is simply marvellous, and it was such an amazing moment turing the corner from the flight of stairs and seeing the golden tip temple for the first time. The entire place was just vibrant with colours and energy, from the Buddhist flags all over, the monkeys lurking around, and prayer rituals we witnessed... absolutely brilliant!

Love to shopping here. While everybody talked about the surroundings, I will talk about the shops here.Many interesting stuff sells here. Extraordinary choices for locks (yes, they had lots of unique locks that I couldn't find anywhere else), cheap tibetan singing bowl with beautiful different motifs and cute unique vintage jewelry.

Interesting stupa with lovely monkeys around.. Monkeys around are lovely. It is a really peaceful and harmonious place. Dogs were also lying around and sleeping. The dog never barks to men, but only to other dogs. One of the shops selling Thanka introduces the process of painting Thanka properly and well. I learn a lot about Thanka painting and Buddha life story there.

A truly amazing place. Swayambunath Temple is a temple on a hill, but it's so much more than that. It's inhabited by monkeys, has a somewhat scenic view at the top, and is visited by many Buddhists local and afar. I visited at the time of Tihar (I think it's the Indian equivalent of Diwali) and there were lots of prayers and rituals happening which gave it an intense air of devotion.The top is dense with beautiful temple structures. The cost is 200 rupees for foreigners at the ticket booth on the main steps from the east, but the site is easily accessed for free, from the secondary entrance, from the road along the south side of the hill, and even from stairs from the road on the north side.Along the entire perimeter of the bottom of the hill is a low wall containing prayer wheels. And if you go to the bottom of the hill, to the south and west, near the ring road, there are lots of smaller Buddhist temples, some with the large prayer wheels inside, and one complex with large Buddha statues. I went here and it was such a nice surprise.It is nice just to hang out and observe the religious customs. There are plenty of wares to be purchased, and a lot of advertised rooftop cafes and restaurants. I got a tea and sat on the ground level to observe the Buddhists doing their prayers.

I love this temple!. It will take maybe around 500+ steps to see this temple, aka the Monkey temple because of the many free-roaming monkeys. There's also a monastery there where I saw monks playing futsal.
must. Swayambhunath is old and you really feel it. You have to be aware of the monkeys. What I dislike there is all the buisnesses in the templearea
Very interesting Temple. We really enjoyed the visit to this Temple. A lot to see, and a great view of Kathmandu. The lemur monkeys that run around the lower level are a plus.

LOVE the Monkey Temple. This is definitely a must see when visiting Kathmandu. It was one of the highlights of our 2 week trip. The monkeys are everywhere and the babies are adorable! Don't have food or water bottles in your hands when going or the monkeys will come right up and steal it. It is quite a hike up the 300+ stairs to the top but worth it. The views are amazing and the stupa was beautiful. Tip: Make sure you see BOTH sides of this temple. There are huge golden statues on one side and we missed those during our first visit so we went back.

Breathtaking.. A must see. Do not let your driver press you for time. Stay and soak up everything. Great views of katmandu. Please respect the clockwise direction and if possible stay for sunset when the atmosphere changes and becomes clogged with burning prayer candles.

When you think of Kathmandu.... When someone says Kathmandu, this is where I always think of. There are a few temples with the "buddha eyes" on them, but Swayambhunath Temple up on the hill is my favorite of them all. You not only get great views of the city, but you can hang around with a bunch of monkeys ...how can you go wrong???

Monkey' heaven. Loved everything about this place. There is an interesting combination of spirituality, marketing, people watching, monkeys entertainment, beggars, pilgrims, and western tourists. All this with views of sunset over Kathmandu. Come around 4pm for the best light!
Great place to hangout.. Its all in one. A dating spot ;), hangout with friends, explore the great view of the Kathmandu city.

Bird's eye view..... The entire kathmandu city is viewable from the place.. the western entry point where the parking are has less stairs to climb to the stupa... the Indian's entry fee could be easily skipped..but we didn't ... the place has a divine atmosphere with all the souvenir shops playing tibetan chant music.... we enjoyed a lot...

Oh, scary monkeys!. I've been here three times and not tired of the place yet; even though I was attacked by the monkeys there one time. It was really scary!!!I just went there in the 3rd evening of Tihar festival (Festival of light) and the view of Kathmandu was magnificent!. The whole city is lit up in lights, which is a luxury and only happens once a year during Tihar. The stupa is lit up at night as well with light bulbs. I was sort of expecting lots of candles but the reality is there's no one who has enough time to light that many candles. However, still a beautiful place to visit and hang out with incredible view of Kathmandu.

Up, Up and Away to the Monkey Temple. Such a beautiful place, just outside Kathmandu, up so many steps I lost count!! But the silver lining of of those steps is that on each level there are parts of the temple that are worth circling before taking the steps to the next level. Such beautiful and ornate statues, such a lovely sight of prayer flags. There are little market stalls that will sell you little trinkets for keepsakes of the really marvelous temple site. There's a great cafe at the very top so that you can quench your thirst with a Nepali Masala Tea or a Lassi. This is a 'not to be missed' famous site in Nepal.

Buddha of Nepal. According to legend the first place of kathmandu valley was this hill with its famous temple/stupa. the walk up from the stairs is a killer, really nice though with all the things going on and the huge buddhas on the way....the two other ways from the other side are good too, and can drive up almost 80% of the way...so walk up one drive down the other:-)The temple are is really magical and has so much to see, feel n experience. Visiting the monastery on the sides is a must while here!Enjoy it when its at its best, around sun rise or late afternoon before sunset and get a super view of the kathmandu valley and the highest place inside the valley!And please help preserve this World heritage site!
Brilliant. Brilliant place with exceptional views over Kathmandu. Normal sellers on the steep staircase and only 200nrs

The climb is worth the experience. Despite the climb being strenuous, the temple complex is beautiful. The view of Kathmandu is also wonderful if the weather is good. I am not sure if they open for sunrise or sunset, but if they do, the view from here muse be sublime.

Positive Energy. I loved that this place gives me a positive energy. The religious meaning surrounding this place is so amazing. I went to this place twice just to feel the energy. As weird as it sounds. Loved it!
good view on a clear day. liked to walk upstairs. dis liked the panhandlers around.like the souvemiers dis like the captured birds... you pay to realise them and they are being captured again...
Nice atmosphere!. Its worthy of climbing 365 stairs up to the stupa. Nice view of Kathmandu valley. The time I spent over there became even more serene with the music. Must see!

great views and atmosphere - needs a clean. Sadly the rubbish at this world heritage site detracted significantly from the enjoyment. the temple square has a commanding location and is worth visiting for both the temples and the view. Just don't look over the edge at the squalid rubbish pile.

one of highlights of Kathmandu. Very interesting area, can go during lunch time and after lunch you should visit the main temple, take a walk around Swayambhunath, lots of small shops with souvenirs, and now to make it easier they have benches where you can rest.

Simply Gorgeous. The walk up to the top of the Swayambhunath Temple, otherwise known as the Monkey Temple, is a fierce one but you will be well-rewarded for your efforts. At the base of the Swayambhunath Temple there are monkeys everywhere. Make sure that any food you have is hidden away in bags and try to do the same with water bottles. Monkeys will snatch the water bottles right out of your hand or bag!Along the hundreds of steps to the top of the Temple, people will be selling their wares and you will be able to see monkey and possible other wildlife (we spotted a huge snake). Periodically, be sure to turn around so you can get great views of the city.Near the top of the steps, you will be required to pay a small fee to enter the main area of the Temple. Worth it! At the top you will see some of the best views in Kathmandu, be able to watch people worship and shop at different stores.

Great Local Stupa. I came here just after sunrise and loved it. There were live musicians, a constant stream of locals praying and doing their morning exercises. People had skipping ropes, weights, were stretching and zipping up and down the many stairs. A variety of local sellers selling flowers and other prayer offerings. I loved how people incorporated their morning exercises and prayers. I met a sprightly eighty year old who makes the trek up at least once a day.Great view point over Kathmandu. Taxi's wait at the bottom to take you to your next destination.
one of the top sights of Kathmandu. Interesting to wander around, but would have probably got more from the visit with a local tour guide.

Beautiful. Swayambhunath stupa was my favourite site in Nepal. The beautiful colourful temple will amaze you and the best time to go is evening, when local people bring up huge picnics and sing and dance.
Swayambhunath Temple. An impressive temple. Overlooking the city of Kathmandu. Worth a visit. Espacially the staircase going up/down the hill.

Nice and Peace full place to be. It is one of the closest World heritage site to be in and it's nice place to go, Monkey, Jungle, people, temple, Architectures are awesome. One of the best place in town.

Interesting but beware the monkeys. A mix of Hindu and Buddhist worship place. Walk around and there are certain areas where you can get a very good view of the surrounding city. The place is swamped with monkeys, big and little. Interesting if you have the time to stop and observe their behaviour.

Fantastic view. Your visit will not be complete if you have not visited this temple. Very lovely view of Kathmandu as far as your eyes can see. Be careful with your belongings as there are monkeys every where. The monks always welcome the visitors during the meditation! Be ready to climb the steps to this temple but its definitely worth the visit! Namastee n have a wonderful stay!
Magnificent architecture!. The rain kind of spoilt imy visit, but it is certainly worth going here. I liked the various places of prayer and the monkeys that roam about makes it surreal!
Walk from Thamel to enjoy the city. Lovely place. I would recommend you walk from Thamel area which is a good 45 min walk but you get a chance to take in the local atmosphere.

Beautiful temple with great view on Kathmandu. Walk up the 365 stairs one for each day and enjoy one of the greatest views of Kathmandu, During your climbing you will see all monkeys everywhere.Once you arrive wander in the temple and take your time.Go and look for the Buddhist monks singing, try to throw coins at the statue of Vishnu.Tips: you can go by foot from Thamel, it takes about 25 mins to get there otherwise a cab which shoukd cost about 200-300 NPR.Entry fee: 200 NPR
Just splendid!. A jewel of Buddhist Nepali architecture. With wonderful views on Kathmandu. Watch out for the monkeys. Some are very aggressive especially toward women and children. Hide any food.
A must visit while in Nepal. It is a peaceful place. The architecture reflects the Buddhist culture. you can see almost entire kathmandu from here.

Awesome place in ktm. Based on center of kathmandu ,can view around Kim valley if whether favour you able to see white mountain as well .this is combination of Hindu and Buddhist temple.you can feel peace in top , monkey ,monk and prayer flag is main attraction of this temple

Monkey temple. Would recommend this place if you want to see Kathmandu valley in evening, great view from temple. Beware of monkeys if you are carrying any open food items in hand. Close to Thamel and entry fees is not high too. Monkey swimming pool is great attraction as lots of monkeys will be taking bath in it. In evening locals will pray at temple.
Nice and high . A must visit on your itinerary. We took a taxi however you can probably just walk down from Thamel as well. Make sure to try some local noodles at the restaurant as well.

best place to see all kathmandu. nice place I like it,so many monkeys there.do not eat anything infront of them they snatch you .beautiful sceanery you can see from this place .I love this place really enjoyed

Last day of Dashain festival. The title says it all, the normally busy Complex was extra full of Hindus celebrating the last day of Dashain. It was colourful, busy and enjoyable to experience.Had a good time browsing the stalls and having lumch at the Cafe de StupaIf you are in Kathmandu you really should go, the antics of the monkeys drinking from the well is worth it alone.
Monkey Temple Beauty. UNESCO loves this, so did I...very rare and special...golden yellow monkeys, busy streets, ancient temples here for centuries....

What an amazing way to start off my trip in Nepal. Stayed in Thamel,decided this will be the 1st place to visit.
Got up early 6:30am, grabbed an egg roll for breakfast and walked to the temple from hotel (around 40 mins), started raining halfway but cleared up once reached the top of the temple (alotta stairs)
the view was definitely worth it, amazing temple and all the monkeys!!

great views of the city. Half an hour is enough to see the whole area. Careful with the monkeys as they can get very aggressive. Enjoy the "beautiful" views of Kathmandu from up there. Did not find any ATM and restaurants did not take credit cards, so make sure you bring enough cash if you want to have lunch or buy souvenirs.
The Eyes of the Buddha. Peaceful Ambience. Friendly people who tell stories. Little stores selling knick kancks. Panaroma of the Valley.

Must visit. Firstly recommended for good reasons.
The temple is just a few minutes drive from Thamel by tuktuk or taxi. The view from the temple is fantastic, and watching the people praying and doing their spiritual costum was extraordinary.
Beware of the monkeys - they are greedy.

What a Temple!. As we stayed in Tamel district, we went by foot up to Swayambhunath. A good choice to see that part of the sity.
The temples itself is just breathtaking, with bhudists and hindus visiting in harmony, and monkeys and dogs in disharmony.
No one should visite Khatmandu without seeing Swayambhunath!

Fantastic. Visited in October, 2014 with family. An excellent place exuding awe and peace. It is an architectural marvel. Has shops selling excellent paintings and other antique items. The whole of Kathmandu city can be seen from the temple. A must visit while in Kathmandu.

Monkey swimming pool the best bit. Yes we liked the stupa and the temples and the view and the monks chanting and all that. But the great surprise and highlight was watching the monkeys in their own swimming pool, swinging and dropping from the trees into the water, doggy-paddling across and then getting out soaked, sometimes to be shoved off the side by their mates. Hilarious, gorgeous, brilliant fun to watch.

Must see temple in Kathmandu. The climb up can be a little strenuous but its well-rewarded when you reach the top and see the various stupas and statues, and the vast expanse of Kathmandu valley spread out in front of you. Definitely a must-visit if you are in Kathmandu and especially if you are in the Thamel area (400-500 NPR by cab, 30-35 minute walk)

Peaceful escape. After the climb up it was such a moving and peaceful experience with the Buddhist monks and other travellers although hot and humid it was a truly enlightening experience Walking around and stopping to spin the prayer wheels and taking time to reflect and meditate Was my very first big spiritual day in Nepal and it is a must do experience

Must see. the history and architecture is a must see here. Don't miss out on one of the jewels of Kathmandu. The monkeys and prayer flags were great photo subjects. The views of the city are remarkable.
awesome temple. its at walking distance from Thamel area, if you don't get lost or stop often, its around 35 minutes away. small e hough for a couple of hours but still impressive

Monkey tempel. Nice tempel on top of a hill. It's an 15 till 20 min walk from thamel. The entrance fee is 200 npr p.p. The road is easy and the locals are willing to help you if you think you took a wrong turn ;). If you walk. Make sure that you make a short stop at a little tempel just before the river. There are no tourist here and you can take a view photos.

No monkeying around!. Another UNESCO World Heritage Site, this shrine is located on a lofty hill west of Thamel, about 10 minute cab ride for NRs200 (~$2). This stupa, second in structure size to the Boudhanath, is locally known as Harati Devi Stupa or Monkey Temple to the tourists and foreigners because of, well, the monkeys that flood the area. Once you get to the foot of the temple hill, you can either walk around to the back to avoid the tiny fee of NRs200 entry - or climb the 300 odd steps to the top, pay the entrance fee to the boxed-in man on the left, and witness the glorious symmetry of the stupa as it's peak rises to your eyeline. Don't forget to turn around - the view of Kathmandu city isn't bad, either. The only thing you really need to remember when visiting a Stupa, is to always walk around it in a clockwise direction and never the other way.
Great Visit. Great place. Lots to see including many monkeys! Many stairs to climb if you like, but if stairs aren't your thing, then no worries, there are ways around the stairs.
Must see destination. Excellent atmosphere, stunning view of Kathmandu city, beautiful array of stupas. Must see destination in Kathmandu.
Impressive. Beautiful setting and impressive constructions With a very nice view of the city. Definately a must while in town.

Great view and interesting temple. This is also known as the "Monkey Temple" because there are so many monkeys. But beware of the monkeys as they will steal your bags if they detect any food inside of them. The temple is a great place to see the entire Kathmandu Valley.

sunset, great view. It was called 'monket temple', located not far from Thamel. Most important temple for Tibetan Buddist after Boudhanath in Kathmandu. It was oldest religious site in this country. The complex consist stupa, shrines and temples. Main stupa has Buddha's eyes and eyebrows painted . Between them, the number one (in Devanagari script) is painted in the fashion of a nose. There are also shops, restaurants and hostels around complex. Two way to access to the top: Stairway with 365 steps, to the main platform of the temple, or a car road around the hill from the south leading to the southwest entrance. Popular point to catch stunning sunset. can have the whole city view of KMT Valley. One shouldn't miss the small local market right opposite the complex. Can see and feel how locals life there. Entrance fees 100rs. (Sept 2014)However, monkeys there can be dangerous. How to go: -In between walking distance from Thamel-possiblely less than one hour. -rent a bike.

The Monkey Temple. If you love monkeys and Buddhism, than this is the must go place to you. It is on the hill and you can have great view over Kathmandu. You need some coins to drop in the water, perhaps it should bring you some luck after ;) . It is a very green area (which is rare in Kathmandu already) with lots of trees and monkey on them. Some great views, some pictures, nice time spending...

Nice Temple with top view.. You can see Kathmandu city from the top of the Temple. It was really awesome to see the city from the top of the temple. You have to climb lots of stairs, but it worth. This is must visit place of Kathmandu. Overall the temple is very good.
Nice Temple, nicer monkeys. it was fun to watch the monkeys, clearly the main attraction. watching them take a bath and jumping into their "pool'" was funny.

Worth the hike up there. This place is well worth the effort, there is a lot of steps to walk up but the view over the city is pretty good, as well as the temple itself. Entrance fee is 200 NPR for tourists. A taxi from downtown Thamel should not cost more than 250 NPR.
Go check it out
Great view. Worth the trip out there - though the monkeys can be aggressive. Best view of kathmandu though. Definitely should be on your list in Kathmandu.

Don't trust the monkeys!. This is such a beautiful temple...one of my favorites in Kathmandu; however, this is also called the Monkey Temple for a reason...there are monkeys everywhere, so don't have any food visible and keep your belongings close or in a closed bag. They won't attack you or anything, but if you have something they want, beware! My friend set his water bottle down to take a picture and the monkeys took it and bit/tore it open! They're pretty funny to watch, I'll admit.The little shops all around the temple are more expensive, but it's nice to get a keepsake from such a beautiful temple. I bought one of the nicest singing bowls I could find from a shop by this temple.

Monkey temple. Brilliant views from the top. We went on a holiday so the Temple was really busy with locals making their prayers at one or other of the Shrines. Lots of locals selling their wares. Monkeys were everywhere but didn't seem to bother with visitors.

Good. This monastry is one of the biggest stupa in Nepal .This place is very good for buddhist and hindu people other people could also enjoy this place and have great fun.It looks like tibetean society near area.I Had Enjoy this place a lot and I Had great fun with my friend in this place.

Must go place when you land in Kathmandu. The name itself represents Buddhist religious place. Felt very peace with positive vibes from my heart with fascinating view of the kathmandu city.The sad part was climbing high stairs however the quiet, peacefulness would be always in my memory. I would love to come again....don't miss this place to visit.

Nice but should not be top priority in Kathmandu. This place is a classic in Kathmandu. It is of course nice and impressive, but it needs a well-deserved clean-up.
