My favorite in Kathmandu!. The Swayambhunath Temple was my favorite to visit in Kathmandu. The surrounding of the temple outside the city is memorable, but the highlight by far is the incredible panoramic views of the entire Kathmandu that it offers.
Amazing view. Really nice temple on the mountain, should definitely visit it if you are in kathmandu. Awesome rooftop restaurant

Pleasant Temple with views over Kathmandu. Visited this temple with my father and guide about 9am. Very interesting stupa with many people exercising, praying and going about their daily business. Pleasant views over Kathmandu despite the cloudy conditions. Interesting and informative visit to one of the "painting" stores and the monkeys were tourist friendly.
Fantastic Heritage. The monkeys here are well behaved and tourists need not worry. One of the oldest Buddhist holy site in Kathmandu. Many old statues of Lord Buddha

View of Kathmandu. I went there in the morning, found locals, worshiping.. some exercising, well nice place for exercising mentally and physically, and I went there to see view of Kathmandu, it was a nice experience... I liked it..

Very cool!. Make sure you go with a guide or a local so they can explain to you what's going on. Otherwise its just pure madness. Also, the tea that they serve at the top isn't very good ;) Anyone who has tried it will know what I'm talking about.

Chanting in the monastery. We were there about 4:00pm and went into the monastery in the back and were graced with a group of monks chanting, drumming and blowing on the super long horns of Nepal. We spent nearly an hour mesmerized. Not sure if they have a schedule, but if you're lucky enough to be there when it happens its well worth it. The monkeys and central stupa are amazing as well. The steps can be a challenge, but are worth it!

Must see views. Really cool, glad we went and saw this. Hated the masses of peoples, dogs, pigeons, and monkeys. So many moving things to watch out for and a very busy spot. The veiw above the city is pretty cool, so its a must do if in Katmandu
a spiritual experience. Watch out.....lots of stairs but worth it for the views. Recommend going first thing in the morning to avoid the crowds

Meditation on the top. Perched on top of the hill you have a choice of tracking up or driving up. It is a long heavy climb recommended for the fittest. The view from the top is thrilling. Be careful of the monkeys as they are a menace and do not feed them. Do spend a few quite moment at the prayer hall. It is relaxing. The sputa gives a great background for a photo shoot.

A little bit of a tourist trap. The monkeys are scary and the temple seems to have lost its charm. Don't get me wrong, the views are amazing and the architecture is interesting but as a spiritual place it felt like much more a tourist attraction. A shame but still none the less worth a visit for some good photos.
Good view, nice little hike. Every city needs a point to eagle eye out the city and this is it for Mandu. Nice little climb, good views and there is a hill behind it. Overall, so-so

Wonderful temple complex sited in an inspired location. Given the importance of this site and the number of people out for religious observances, the hill-top location absorbed these and the accompanying tourists with ease; allowing for a restful walk amongst the stupas and temples and permitting a detailed inspection of the carvings.Inevitably a local street market has built up but the vendors were friendly and approachable without being a hassle.
The eyes are watching over you. Stunning with great views over Kathmandu. Not too many pushy vendors on the way and the place feels fairly relaxed and inviting.Also a good workout up the stairs ;)

Monkey temple. This stupa is also called monkey temple, so beware if carrying food, monkeys will try to snatch it! It is beautiful complex with many temples, Buddhist and Hindus, and since it is on a high, you can view the entire city (and it pollution). Great for a half day sightseeing, and you can find some average restaurants too nearby.
Swyambunath Temple. Excellent introduction to Nepal culture. However, there is a multitude of salespeople outside - and beware the monkeys!

good place for sightseeing. the temple has a pond and if you throw a coin in to the jar in the middle of the pond then you'll be lucky. Other good spot is the painting training center, where you can learn about Buddha and the unique paintings of Mandala.

Nice... but nothing extraordinary. You'd like the view, the stupa but you might find it dirty and smelly.
Don't forget to have a look at the monkeys (That's why this place is called Monkey Temple after all )
a must. The temple is a must. It is just fansinating to walk through. Just need to enjoy the whole seen. The culture is wonderful to take in.
Great View. The temple has a great view of Kathmandu. There are a lot of little shops and cafes around the temple where you can buy souvenir items and drink some tea.

Two eyes of Buddha makes you feel peace. This is the place where I use to visit often.especially in night time it looks wonderful by the effects of lights and from where you can see the nice night view of Kathmandu valley as well.really great place to make your mind peace with the two eyes of syambhunath which is also the sign of peace.

Zabojad Exploring Nepal Resham Firiri Tour 2014. Enjoying a sunset on one of it's Roof top Terasse with my friends of Exploring Nepal in this wonderful place of Peace and Serenity is among the best experiences of Kathmandu. Really enjoyed the feeling of my heart fluttering like silk in the wind while enjoying a hot Lemon Ginger tea.
The Monkey Temple. A Temple definitely worth visiting. It is culturally rich and there are heaps of monkeys there. Interesting location.
Magical!. First time i saw Swayambhunath Stupa was so Magical and peaceful. And we can saw kathmandu city from above.

Great view of KTM . Loved this place - it offers a great view of KTM so take your camera.The monkeys are everywhere and can be quite scary - so take care especially if you have food like chips ect ... They will try to steal it! Try go on a clear day in KTM as the view from the look out point is amazing !

Good but little bi dirty. I like the Stupa on the hillside and you can see almost whole Kathmandu valley but don't like when you see lots of rubbish near by the next temple. Too many monkeys too, one almost took my camera.

Temple, monkeys, and good view of the city.. I visited this temple at sunset and it was a pleasant experience. The walk up the stairs wasn't very difficult. The temple itself is fairly basic, but still nice. There are lots of monkeys and scroungy wild dogs, especially at the top. Be especially careful of the monkeys and don't carry food or drinks with you. My favorite part was the great views of the city and the sunset.

Lovely temple with a great view. Its a lovely temple on too of a hill and you will get a panoramic view of Kathmandu. Monkeys are roaming around freely making it a little bit more interesting when they climb about the stupas. There is a great Thanka place where the guy can explain the details and meaning of the paintings.
very impressive area with a lot of monkeys. nice view over Kathmandu valley and very nice figures / shapes on top of the hill - I preferred the steps on top of the hill, not the trip by car.

Calm and peaceful. Worth walking the many steps up to the top, calm and peaceful. You can see and appreciate things at your leisure without being hassled (too much) by beggars or hawkers. Go with a guide to tell you what it all means.

Interesting Place. The monkey temple is very interesting to visit. The combination of Buddism and Hinduisam in the architecture and statues are very attractive. A lot of small animals wandering around the temples, monkeys and dogs. Just too much small pedlers and beggers, gives us a negative feeling.
Gorgeous views. Expansive views of Kathmandu, monkeys, music...there are lots of stairs but keep in mind there are two ways to get in. It's totally worth a visit!
Temple. Nothing much to see, so crowdy and so dirty, did not like the place. traditional temple.For the people from SARC country don't need to pay for ticket.

Beautiful stuppa but. So beautiful Buddhist place, old stupa and a lot of pictures from there. You could enjoy from that place a stunning view over the capital of Nepal Kathmandu.BUT: you could see everywhere written on stuppas and monuments so many graffitis from nepalese, they wrote their name or stupid things on them, what a shame because you can see on your pictures these graffitis.
Great atmosphere. Great atmosphere with prayer flags, music, shops and monkeys! Views over the Kathmandu Valley are nice too.

The other side of the city. It is quite far away so better plan your rout ahead so you can also visit other places nearby to save time. The roads are also bumpy even we hired a nice car. Once we arrived, it was worth the trip, even I had to be careful among the money's so just make sure you don't show any hints of snacks, or even the noise of plastic bags. As you go uphill though, there are less and less moneys so you can concentrate on your visit, enjoying being on top of the city, taking photos etc. Same rule about the shops. If you are not interested, simply don't look at their products at all and they will leave you alone. They are overall friendly and polite people trying to make a living.Our driver dropped us off at the higher entrance to avoid the steep staircase, which you will see at the top and that's where you can take a panoramic view.We didn't stay for coffee as we continued our visit to the dubar square which was about 20min away by car

Monkey Temple. There were a lot of monkeys! That’s all I can say. I was strictly warned not to bring food and especially to eat in their presence. That warning really scared me because I’m such a kid when it comes to food and eating there might be a stampede of monkeys coming my way. It was an awesome place to visit though. I can’t feel the solemnity that I was expecting because I was too scared. I’m not a fan of animals, especially the ones that I don’t come by everyday.A religious tourist spot. I can’t imagine what it could have been in the old days. I caught the attention of the scary stairs too. A place that is worth the visit. You must be there in order to experience the place. All in all a great experience expect for the monkeys.

Good place. it is a very good place .... i really enjoyed here ...and those were very precious moments in this temple when my love holds my hand and i was walking with her ...i just luved those time :)

A magic temple and beautiful views of the kathmandu city. Swayambhunath temple is a very special, mistic place. The religieous arquitectura, atmosphere, landscape and sense experience. And over there is is posible to enjoy of one of the best views of the city and kathmandú valley.

Temple on the hilltop. Climb by steep stairs, I avoided. Smart shopping area with clever shopkeepers selling Shankhas, Rudraksha, handicrafts, woollens. Lots of South East Asian tourists here to put money in Peace well.
Monkeys!. Liked: the stupa is beautiful, the monkeys fun and the view can be stunning when there is no cloud cover/little pollutionDislike: so many people trying to sell things!

Very Cool. Also known as the Monkey Temple, take the main entrance and walk the stairs to the top (you can also take a road around that brings you closer to the top) but I recommend walking up the stairs to see all the Buddhas and stupas. The view from the top is beautiful and monkeys are fun to watch. Be careful if you have popcorn or other small snacks, if you put them down the monkeys will steal them. There are small shops and tea houses that you can visit. Price for tea about 30-40 NPRs

I found peace here. Went to Swayambhu twice in my trip, never had enough of it. might be because of the animals that I found or maybe the view, although I went to without any expectation the whole place left me spell bound.You just need to be careful if you are carrying food, the monkeys might jump on you. feed them and they are happy with you.Do not forget to visit the small shops in and around the temple,
temple on a hill. well worth the climb; priests, monkeys, worshippers, architecture, views of Kathmandu and surrounding hills; peaceful, historic atmosphere

1st taste of NEPAL. on my 1st day roaming in Kathmandu, its a good thing that the hotel taxi sent me here.
in this place you can see the Buddhist side of Nepal, you can see stupas, monuments and view of the Kathmandu valley.

with family. I went to Swayambhunath temple,, 2 days back, with my family. this place is at height and can view the kathmandu valley I loved this plce but climbing up was tiring for my mom and dad. Very religious place

Much more than a stupa on a hill. Plan to spend several hours walking around Swayambhunath. You will discover both Buddhist and Hindu temples and get up close and personal with the resident monkey population. Be sure to make your way to the Thangka painting school towards the back - you can get a free lesson in how the paintings are created (absolutely fascinating), and support the school by buying absolutely gorgeous hand painted pieces of all sizes.

Monkey Temple. The first time I came here was 1978 so it has old good memories for me. On all 5 trips to Nepal, I stop, loving to get up EARLY, go, climbing the steps to the top (NOT the tourist drop off at the top!). The views are great of the city and it just says Kathmandu!

Monkey Temple. This was an amazing trip. You can walk up the long flight of steps or drive around. We did both, but the walk up the steps is the best. We had a palm reading done by a Tibetan Monk off to the side of the step for 300 rupees. It was a fun and made a good story.
lovely place to visit. its beautiful temple on hills you can see kathmandu from top and lots of ppl visit this place temple was beautifully build on hills have to walk few steps to reach on top

View of Kathmandu Valley - Monkey Temple. There are a lot of places to visit in Kathmandu but personally i really enjoyed this temple. Partially because im fascinated with monkeys and you get to see a lot of them up on this mountain but more because you get to see a great view of Kathmandu valley from up on top. I recommend going in the evening so you could see the sunset with all of Kathmandu in view. Also the entrance fee is more than reasonable here. Unlike the most other temples which are prices above 750 the entrance fee for this temple was only 150.
Monkey Temple. A World Heritage site, and a traveler favourite, this temple is atop a hill, looking down at Kathmandu (if the weather is clear)

Temple With A Beautiful View. There are so many temples to see in Kathmandu. We wanted to see them all so this was one of them. Personally I enjoyed each one and was able to take a lot of great pictures.My girlfriend thought it was a little repetative, so if you are low on time you can visit the other popular temples instead. There was a fee to enter every temple, so if you are on a budget choose your temples wisely.Consider having a private driver take you, so you do not have to worry about haggeling with the drivers that wait outside. I am glad I did not have to deal with that.

Monkey Temple. I have been to the temple many times. This offers a beautiful view over the city. This time we were driven to the top, well near the straits in order to walk up. We usually wLk back down the other side which I recommend but our group wasn't up for a walk down the steps that were a little steep. The steps up from the parking area were fine for all. This is a working temple area with Hindu temples and Buddhist temples occupying the same hill top area. The macaque monkeys are everywhere too but be careful not to touch or feed them. We had a guide to take us here and as he lives in Kathmandu, he tells the history of the site and I would recommend always going with a guide because you will understand more of what the temple area is used for. I love to see the giant birds flying overhead also. People try to sell you things as you go up to the top of the temple area but they get sopped now from following you all over which is refreshing.

Something to add to other reviews. I have been to Swayambhunath several times - it's a must see attraction, but I would like to add some additional information. If you go very early in the morning, before sunrise, you will see another spiritual side of this temple as it comes alive. The small and large monasteries are open and monks are chanting throughout the whole of the dawn (you can go in quietly and respectfully to sit and enjoy this); bells, cymbals and trumpets are sounded, Nepalese people are doing their morning rituals and exercises as the sun comes up and musicians are playing. This is a magical time to visit. A taxi will take you up there and will wait for you (you will have to climb the many steps as that is the only entrance open). You will see the sunrise over Kathmandu - it's s lovely time to visit, so enchanting!

Very nice place to experience Buddhism. You certainly feel the mantra in the air once you're there. The moneys are nice too unless you're carrying food in your grasp. My suggestion: Don't carry water bottles or food in your hand. Water bottles are ok in the bag. Be careful of snatching by them monkeys though. You get to see the panoramic view of Kathmandu Valley from this place. A small fee is applicable. For SAARC country citizens it's a very small amount.

Giant Vajra. Giant Vajra at the entrance was quite interesting. Good View of the town from top. Surrounded by small temples and towers and Bells. You can either drive up to the car park and walk for 5 mins or walk all the way up for 20/30 mins.
interesting place to visit. A very interesting spot to visit, lots to see, plenty of monkeys, more expensive shopping to be had, a nice view if there wasnt any smog

Great views of Kathmandu. Don't miss the Swayambhunath Temple when you're in Kathmandu!You can walk or take a taxi there from the Tamel...The views are extraordinary (and they are very different from the views you see in the treks), and the monkeys are fun to feed and watch...Get there a little before sunset so you can see the sunset from the temple...

Peace of mind. You not only get peace of mind but also an excellent view of city from the top. Beware of monkeys though. and like all such places, do buy from the shops on the way to the top, after bargaining of course
Beautiful view. Liked :- Beautiful all around kathmandu valley and its ancent templesDisliked:-Crowdy and bit pollution

nice place a long walk. Swaymbhunath temple is must visit if you are in kathmandu. I climbed ladder from backside and boy it was a long and tiresome walk. But when I reached the top, view from it was excellent. It is in great height
Wonderful temple with city view. The temple is located at a point that overlooks the entire city and mountains in the region. There are many monkeys and dogs around. it is recommended to visit.

Unbelievable scene of activity. This was by far my favorite site in the Kathmandu Valley. As you walk up the many steps to the top, more and more monkeys appear. The scene at the top is a mix of monks, worshippers, tourists, monkeys, pigeons, dogs, shopkeepers, and more coexisting around the stupa, prayer wheels, monastery, statues, and shops. It was truly and unbelievable sight to see! Admission is NRP 200 for non-SAARC. Well-worth the time to visit!
Remembering Lord Buddha. Beautiful Buddhistic temple, but a very steep climb through stairs. good view of the city. Worth visiting to the style of buddhist culture and rituals.

Another stupa in kathmandu. This is another stupa and when you ascend about a 100 steps to the top of the stupa the view of the entire city can be seen . On a clear morning the view is a good one and the stupa is also nice to see with a huge statue of buddha inside .Beware though , there are many monkeys in the enclosure.

sacred and funny place. Sacred because of the religiosity. Funny for all the Monkeys. Don't miss the art school on your way back from the main temple. Ask for an explanation and get ready to be surprised.

Mindblowing. The journey to the stupa starts with the Buddha park at the base. the statues of in this park are huge and mindblowing. I realised why it is called the monkey temple while going on the top to the stupa. Stupa is very old, well maintained. However to deserve the UNESCO world heritage tag it should do a lot more on cleanliness, organisation and being tourist friendly.

Great area.. It is a bit confusing at the top of the hill where Buddhist stupa mixes with Hindu temples so ideally you need a guide or good book to explain the various buildings. Good views over Kathmandu from the top and as other reviewers have mentioned take care with the monkeys - one member of my group had her bag snatched off her and it didn't even contain food!

The monkey temple is a must see. Any photographer will love Swayambunath. The monkey templ combines hindu and buddhist traditions to great effect. Make sure you walk up those steps. Don't carry food or the monkeys will steal it. Have a fully charged battery in your camera.

Most important Buddhist temple. The temple is impressive because of his dimension and religeous meaning. It's standing on a square place, demarketed by old Nepalian houses. You can walk on the first dome.

Not just for the Monkeys. Thehighe st point in Kathmandu is aTemple to Buddha known as Swambhunath, or to those that prefer it,, "the Monkey Temple" It can be reached by taking astroll from the city centre, as you approach the hill upon which it sits, a row of gailly painted Statues of Buddha in seated Lotus posture greet you at the base of a flight of stone steps. It's worth taking a breather here as they stretch upward and number 365 in total. One for every day in a year. A word of caution here, keep anything edible out of sight and hold on to anything that you might be carrying. This is not known as the Monkey Temple for no reason.They are expert bag snatchers and muggers and appear out of nowhere and the ice cream you were just about to put to your mouth will dissapear in an instant. But when you finaly reach the top not only do you get a wonderful view over the.city but the Prayer wheels spin continuesly sending out Karmic energy to the world. The huge Eyes on all 4 sides of the Temple looking down upon you, and in the background the deep Bass tones of the Monks Chanting and the Dulcet ring of Temple Bells, gives a magical air, if you can be silent to feel it. Once more i cant tick the date box for my visit was in 1971 so will tick for today, but see 1971.

Place with a great view. Located on top of a hill. A great place to see the lovely temple. Also a nice place to see the Kathmandu valley and the surrounding mountains. Nice for kids as there are monkeys in the temple area.

Great views over the valley. Better known to westerners as the monkey temple, it is definitely worth a visit if you have a few days in Kathmandu. The stupa isn't as impressive as the one at Boudna however, there are spectacular views over the city and of course monkeys. The monkeys and dogs are so use to humans they will leave you alone, unless you are carrying a plastic bag, which the monkeys assume is food. A good tip is to get dropped off at the top rather than walk up the 500 steep stairs. There is also a rustic but appreciated cafe with great views at the top!

Beautiful panoramic views. While I was killing time in Kathmandu and trying to get my bearings I took a short taxi ride up to the temple. There were beautiful views across the city and into the mountains, it was lovely to get a view of Kathmandu from another perspective. Well worth the trip!
Monkey Temple. This place is great, definitely do not miss in Kathmandu. Expansive views of Kathmandu from the top of the mountain.

Amazing views and monkeys - lots of monkeys. If you love walking, take the 350 odd steps from the north side, else go to the southern side, there are only around 120 steps there. The whole place is teeming with monkeys, so don't do anything to disturb or agitate them. There are quite a few shops selling knickknacks. Don't forget to haggle, you can get the prices down by one-third easily. The views from the top of the city are spectacular. But don't ignore the small shrines and temples surrounding the main stupa, they are quite beautiful.
Great ancient architecture. I enjoy looking at the craftsmanship of the features of this ancient temple. The view all round is lovely too.
More than just a stupa. Lots to explore at this hilltop temple - just allow time for the climb up the stairs to it or take a taxi to the rear entrance!
Great views. if there is no pollution. But the monkeys are a bit intimidating. I preferred Bodnath Stupa.I liked the views but not the monkeys

OK.... You can see this temple in a lot of films but when we went it was really crowded with tourists. Great views of Kathmandu and probably worth a visit if you are in town but do not set yourself very high expectations.

magic in the air. With all the changes (many for the worse) in Kathmandu, Swayambhunath ( the monkey temple) remains mostly like its been for hundreds of years. Like many tourist attractions in Kathmandu there is now an entrance fee, which you must pay after going up the 300 or so steps up to the top. On a clear day you will get an amazing view. Unless it just rained the night before, you're not likely to get a clear day. If you bring bananas for the monkeys, be careful. If they see you have a handfull of them they'll come and grab them from you. It's a great spot to hit really early in the morning before the crowds appear.

serene. The best time to go there is during the evening when the sun is about to set. Make sure you walk up the steps because when you get to the top, an amazing feeling of serenity and mystic takes over you. The prayer flags and the prayer wheels along with the magnificent stupa is something surreal. You can also enjoy the crazy monkeys running wild all over the complex. Very good opportunity for amazing pictures. A must visit place.

Beware of the monkeys l. Lots of steps if you walk up but can go be taxi around the side still some steps but not as many . Lots of places where people are trying to sell you things and can be very crowded
Walk up in the morning for a real expereince. In the early mornings hear chants and music as you gaze out on Kathmandu as it wakes. Definitely worth the effort.

Monkeys...a lot of monkeys. The Monkey Temple is an interesting place to visit but feels dirty and over crowded compared to the beautiful Boudhanath. If you have time to only visit one then i'd suggest Boudhanath.Be aware there are a huge amount of monkeys roaming the temple, most people are prepared for monkeys it being called The Monkey Temple but trust me there are A LOT!!!!Compared to Boudhanath it just feels a little dirty and tacky although the views of the Kathmandu valley are stunning from the top.Should cost around 250-300 NPR in a cab from Thamel. DO NOT WALK. I cannot believe guide books suggest walking in this area as the roads are insanely busy and there are no pavements.

Nice Views. Its one of the Must see attraction in KTM, we went around evening during Sunset. The views were great, with colourful mountains. The place itself is wonderful with many small temples, shopping and some houses.
Amazing. Definitely the highlight of Kathmandu. Views from the top and monkeys wondering the sight really added to this gem.

Don't miss this place. This temple complex is amazing. The size itself is inspiring, with the many smaller temples surrounding the main stupa. However it is the nibble monkeys that are a real draw card. They are everywhere and Helen help you if you drop a bag of oranges meant for the gods. While we were there this happened and the monkeys were quick to take up the opportunity to get a free feed. This place is a must see. A few issues with hawkers and photo bombing locals that want money in return, but it is all part of the fun.

Our kids loved the monkeys. We spent a couple hours at Swayambhunath. The kids thouroughly enjoyed observing the monkeys run about. We were able to go into the Buddhist prayer session and listen to the monks chant. Very relaxing!!!

Worth a visit. This place is nice to spend few hours, taking photos, listening to thanka stories, enjoying the view of mountains and city (subject to air quality). Going around spinning the prayer wheels and admiring statues (and monkeys).

Peaceful.... After the madness of Kathmandu coming to this place is a treat.... There is no words to describe the peacefulness of the temple, the sound of chimes and mantras, and the spectacular view....

Smelly but unique. Bodies are cremated at the riverside here. So, you can imagine the smell you get. Not very pungent but still there. Cover your nose and stay at the opposite side of the cremation activity side.

Always worth a visit. Location gives a birds eye view of the city and mountains (when the air is clear) and the stupa and surroundings quite unique. The monkeys have never been a problem on any of my many visits

More or less like Boudhanath..... This is also known as Monkey Temple. This is also considered as most sacred among Buddhist pilgrimage site.
For us we found it like a mini version of Boudhanath.

Worth the climb. I looked up at the steep ascent and all those stairs and thought this better be worth it and it was.
Firstly the view over the Kathmandu Valley is amazing, the Stupa and surrounding temples are beautiful, and if you like Monkeys then there are plenty to observe. Entry Fee NRs $200.
Good view of Kathmandu with Monkey. I found this place peace full with fresh air. Beautiful view of mountain east,west,south and north. And big statue of Buddhas in the west side are really artistic.

Go mid week. We visited Swayambunath on a weekend and not sure if it made a difference or not but it was incredibly crowded. WE also told our taxi driver to take us to the east entrance where we would have walked up the steps but he took us to the very busy parking lot on the west side instead presumably to persuade us he could wait for us for a return trip which we declined. Make sure they drop you off on the east entrance at the bottom of the steep steps.
Highly recommended. The "monkey temple" is definitely a must see attraction in Kathmandu. We really enjoyed the visit and it was worth climbing all the steps.

A Pilgrimage rather than an attraction. If you are looking for a typical attraction with nice views and chaeo souvenirs, yes,well, they are there and you can also take a taxi or coach quite close to the top.But it is also something more. Its one of the most important Buddhist site in Nepal, its the second most important pilgrim site in Tibetan Buddhism and it is full of symbolism, not least of which is the 365 quite high steps that the pilgrim has to climb to the top of the hill.Once you are there you are rewarded by the view, by the quite beautiful stupa, by the very friendly dogs and by constant antics of the holy monkeys.A special reward is a little cafe hidden in one of the corners - Cafe de Stupa. Wonderful fresh juices, tasty snacks and great views - a great place to round off your visit to the Stupa. You may consider going down by foot but on the road, its much more comfortable than the steps if a bit longer.
A bit to crowded in shops!. Nice to visit the place, but difficult to fully enjoy while the site is crowded from littles shops all selling the same! Nice views on Kathmandu.

beautifull. great view from here once you have managed the steps up, and navigated the monkeys sliding down the railings, dont have any food that can be seen, as it does attract them,a hreat time to go is in the evening when the candles light the place up and the sun is about to go down,not as many people as during the day and more monkeys.

Nice. I much preferred this place to the Boudhanath. Nice views from the top. This stupa still maintains its rustic charm of the past. Lots of monkeys...but they seem tamer than those I see back home. Do not eat in their presence.
Go in the morning for best view. great view of the mountains and city of Kathmandu. morning is the better time to go. beware of the monkeys.

It is what it is.... Nice enough place. Another place that nepalis will grab what money they can from you. Alot of touts. It is pretty and the view of kathmandu make it a worthwhile place to visit. Plus the drive/walk to get there is interesting. Lots to look at.
Beware of the monkeys lol!
Naughty Monkeys. beautiful temple with treacherous stairs, definitely worth a visit. The view is AMAZING! just don't look at the monkeys too long...

Visit to swayambhunath. Before leaving for Kathmandu I read reviews about this place in all those it was mentioned that 365 steps have to be climbed so I nearly skipped visiting this place Then I decided let me see if there is a car route surprisingly it had our vehicle reached up to the top we had to climb only 65 steps that too with very low height.Another thing exaggerated was about the monkeys.though they were there in large numbers they were mindin

Peace comes dropping slow. Yes, there are other tourists. Yes, there are monkeys and hawkers and beggars and stray dogs. But there is also ancient legends that ties this magnificent stupa to the very birth of Kathmandu. There is confluence of Buddhist and Hindu faiths. There are moments of aching beauty in the brush of centuries. There is peace in the simple turning of prayer wheels. And if the spirit moves you, request for a set of your own prayer flags to be set aflutter from the Eyes of Truth.Go. For all this and more. Take your time. Swayambhunath is not just a tourist destination. It is is a spiritual space first, one that you should not miss if you ever make your way to Kathmandu.

Lived up to its rating. We walked from Thamel (please note don't go in rush hour) we thought the temple was fantastic ,the monkeys were no problem.We spoke to quite a few of the monks and learnt a lot about the history from them.

Awesome climb. My son had a great time climbing up the stairs to the Swayambhunath stupa from the east side. There were a few beggars with kids at the entrance. There are sellers along the lower part. The stairs become steeper the higher you go. Entrance fees for foreigner Rs200.Great 360 view of Kathmandu. There were more pigeons than monkeys.The peace pond is more like a wishing pond. Lots of coins in it.
Monkey Temple. Nice and historic buddhist temple on a hill. Lots of monkey should visit around 4pm to see the sunset and the lighting in the temple

Must See. The temple is a complex of both Hindu and Buddhist shrines that requires a significant climb to the top of the hill. Since this is a major tourist destination (actually walkable from Thamel but most take taxis), there will be many merchants at the base of the hill. You will be approached to buy various items, but this is Nepal--they won't hound you if you immediately shrug them off.Depending on the time of day that you visit, you can expect to see hoards of monkeys throughout the complex, especially on the lower levels where they are looking for easy handouts. The monkeys make look cute from a distance... but do NOT bring food for them and do NOT try to touch them. They are nasty and will bite--requiring rabies protection.The temple complex is very beautiful and offers a fine view of the city. Go when the lighting is best for photos (if you're into photography), so early mornings and late afternoons are best.

Take it or leave it. The Buddhist Stupas are certainly more beautiful and well kept than the Hindu Temples around Kathmandu but Swayambhunath, aka "Monkey Temple" is heaving with monkeys who are taking over the place. It is filled with local vendors trying to sell you their trinkets. The view back over the city is nice, although the smog can block the view. Much more beautiful things to see.
Good Place. The steps are steep, you have an entry from a back on top of the hill and the number of steps will be less
Monkeys and shrines!. The temples were very beautiful, but I also got a kick out of all the monkeys and the temple dogs. It's quite the view of Kathmandu as well.

Well worth a visit. We were there on Election Day and motorised transport was banned which made walking through the streets to the monkey temple a pleasure. The biggest danger was from children playing football in the empty streets. A lot of steps are involved in getting to this place but it's well worth the effort. The temple area is fascinating a mixture of religion meets capitalism. A great place to relax with great views of the city. We relaxed in a small cafe just letting the day go by.

Smashing good time. The Swayambhunath Temple, aka The Monkey Temple, is a 300Rs taxi ride from Thamel and a 20-30 minute walk from Bodnath Stupa. There are monkeys all over the place the second you enter the temple grounds, along with merchants selling jewellery, souvenirs, snacks and henna tattoos. It's a bit of a hike to the actual temple, maybe 5-10 minutes of stair climbing, but there's lots to stop and look at along the way. It doesn't cost anything to climb the stairs but there's a booth at the top with a security guard waiting to charge non-Nepalese 1000Rs to enter the upper grounds. 100% worth every rupee because the view of the city is spectacular and it's just so good to watch monkeys eat juice boxes and smash cameras in half that don't belong to you.

Suprisingly peaceful terrace at Swayambunath. I wanted to just sit down and have something to eat and climbed the stairs to the Nirvana Cafe and, surprise, there's a lovely terrace looking away from the temple complex on to that lovely hill to the west.The lunch was neat, staff very friendly, boss chasing monkeys, out of the Om mani padme hum. After a good hour up there, I was fresh and ready to enjoy new details of the temple Platform.

A temple for both Buddhists and Hindus!. Excellent place to observe the harmony between both religions! It was a public holiday and there were tons of local people lining up for prayers. Sitting on top of a hill, the temple also offers a nice view of the city. Foreigners have to pay entrance fee, but it's worth a visit.

Sort of a must do. Swayambhunath does have the best view in town overlooking Kathmandu.Don't even think of feeding the monkeys roaming the ground. They, the dogs roaming all over the grounds, seem to multiply by a dozen if a cracker or cookie is tossed to them. The feeding frenzy is not pretty to watch.The "long walk" up to the top is better than the back door entrance. A lot of color.

reach the top got value from long stair. I went there on election day of NepalNo have transportation even taxi all shut down.I hire bicycle. The way to go so difficult can't find on the mapHave to many ask till reach there.It's long stair and step to walk up.But when you reach there....see wisdom of eye.I fell release of my tired from walk.I spend time there for hour walk around see 4 Conner of wisdom eye.Also you can see view of Kathmandu city.Great you should to visit.Entrance fee 200Nrs
Long walk. Long walk to the temple. Nothing much to do other than take pictures. Many monkeys. Great view of Kathmandu Valley

Monkey business :). A timeless location full of atmosphere, best to visit very early before the tourists and beggers take up positions. Walk up from the bottom, dont use the road access from the back, you miss a lot of the foreplay on the way up to the stupa.
Nice view over Kathmandu. The best way to visit the "monkey temple" is walking up the (particularly) steep steps from the east side. The view from up top is great - try to go on a clear day though.

Great place, great view. Swayambhunath is second only to Bouddhanath for peaceful places in the city of Kathmandu. Don't neglect the view to the west, where you can see many monasteries and stupas in the hills.

Atmospheric at sunset. We went at sunset which was pretty cool.  We didn't see many monkeys until an army of them arrived which was a bit scary at first! We skinned some prayer wheels, walked around the stupa, saw the sunset over Kathmandu and watched some dogs chase the monkeys. Very cool place even if it is quite touristy.

Come for the view. This temple is set out of Kathmandu, on a hilltop above the city. It is some half an hour ride from downtown. It is also called the Monkey temple because of hundreds of them messing around. As you climb the top you, you'll find a dozen of shops (heavily overpriced), a very beautiful stupa atop, and a fascinating view across the whole Kathmandu valley, even with the Himalayas in the background (if it is a clear day).

Wow! Somewhere you can walk and not be run over!. Apart front the great views, playful monkeys, odd wandering dog and the religious symbolism, another great feature of this must see attraction is that once inside you don't have to negotiate the traffic chaos that has become part and parcel of the Kathmandu scene. For those interested in high energy exercise, pacing up and down the steps are a welcome relief from an otherwise unhelpful environment (well, there are a few gyms around with running machines). And somewhere to work off all those pounds that are accumulating from the great food available in Kathmandu. There is a 200NR fee at the top which is fair enough as tourism is the main foreign currency earner for the country and the site is reasonable well maintained.
Nice view. Enjoy yourself with fresh air which comes from mountain. Low cost, good food, Nice people and there behave all everything feels you good.

Good view of Kathmandu. One should definitely visit swayambhu when in Kathmandu. We can have good view of Kathmandu city. It is half an hour drive from the city. We have to climb stairs from parking area to reach the stupa.
Definitly must see. There is no reason to visit Kathmandu if you decide to skip this temple with its magnificent stupa! From Thamel it is a very pleasant walk.
Relax your mind and body. A great Buddhist and Hindu worshiping place.If you go to Kathmandu make sure that you visit that place.Its a great place to relax and then have a great view over Kathmandu.

Money temple. Beware of the monkey. If they suspect that you have flood in your hand, they will bite and you will end up in a hospital taking all sorts of shots. Worth seeing, should not miss it. Go early. It gets very crowded as it is the second important temple of the budhist, and is considered holy by the hindu.

Disappointing. I'm not a great fan of monkeys so being surrounded by them as I walked up the steps was not a good start. For me the mass of shops and stalls and people trying to sell me things completely masked any feeling of peace I might have gained from what is an incredibly beautiful place. The air pollution in Kathmandu spoiled the views that there are supposed to be and it felt very sad to see the mountains through a dirty haze.

Well worth a visit.. The temple is just amazing as is the view of Kathmandu on the climb to the top. Yes, there are monkeys everywhere but they are great at spoiling any photos you try and take of them as they run off or turn away the minute you get your camera ready! There are young Nepali boys that offer to guide you around the temple and down to another attraction as well of three giant Buddha statues. We thought hiring the young man was totally worth it. We learned more than if we had just wandered around. This temple is a must see in my opinion.

Interesting. The walk to the temple from Thamel is a very local experience. Lots of people trying to sell trinkets and stuff as you go by the stair entrance. Monkeys everywhere, hence the nickname "monkey temple" I enjoyed visiting the temple and walking the grounds, its part of Nepali life.

large area of high buddhist temple. the first place we visited in nepal was the swayambhunath temple. we visited this place on 7 Oct, 2013. we went there at afternoon and we experienced a great temple at the very first day. the temple is situated at the top of the hill. we had to climb up the hill by long continuous stairs. the journey of the stairs was a long and hectic one. after reaching the top of the temple, we found the temple with so many monkeys. it ws a great spectacular view from this place towards the kathmandu city. this was the most memorable experience of the temple visit. we stayed there the whole afternoon and the evening. it was really a memorable experience!

Proud of Nepal. Swyambhunath temple, one of the ancient and religious monoment of nepal, is very attractive in the design. Reflects the best buddhist art and architecture..Since it is at the top of the hill, we can see the whole kathmandu valley.Peaceful environment...

Love this place!!. This place was simply awesome....walking distance from Thamel...on your way to this temple, you easily get a genuine feel for life in Khatmandu....once you arrive at the temple areas, you will see a long flight of stairs. You cannot miss the spectacle of all of the monkeys hanging out in this area. All of this could never top the marvel that this temple is...and the wonderful view of the Kathmandu valley. Simply stunning!!

The Other side of Life and Death. When we visited it was a very hot day and for some reason there were also a large number of cremations happening on the pyres alongside the river. This is something that the western mind does not easily accept, seeing bodys being burnt in full view and did upset one or two people in my group. Having said that this is a cultural difference that should be expected when travelling.

Quiet and Peaceful. I visited this place back in 2007, during new year time with friends. Its an ancient Buddhist religious complex atop a hill. The air there is so fresh that you feel lighter. We met a french guy in his late sixties who was visiting this place probably tenth time. It's generally not on the tourist radar as compared to famous Pashupatinath temple, so remains quiet and peaceful. One can feel the happiness and solace which this place gives and you automatically become quiet and inner-directed while in premises. So definitely worth a visit
My #1 in Kathmandu. So much to see and do. You could spend hours wandering around the area. Best views of the city and great spot for pictures of the monkeys!

Excellent view of valley from heights!!!!. We can enjoy the great scenic view of kathmandu valley from here. Though situated right at heart of city , this place is free from pollutions. According to mythology, it is believed to be formed when manjushree drained the lake which covered the valley. This stupa is popular destination for tourists as well as local people for refreshments. It is one of the holiest places for Buddhists. Excellent demonstrations of art and culture can be observed. It is included in unesco world heritage site. You cannot miss this place if you are in Kathmandu .

It is a must. The Monkey Temple is a must if you visit Kathmandu. It is great and grand even though the monkeys may be a bit irritating. We watched one monkey steal a water bottle from a tourist. Cheeky little thing. And quick.So, there are monkeys and stray dogs and tourists, but there are also the buddhist temples you can enter and hindu temples that you cannot enter if you are non-hindu. And the giant white stupa with those hypnotizing Buddha's eyes.Another good reason to visit the temple, the views from the Swayambhunath are quite stunning. And there are plenty of hawks circulating above the valley on your eye's level - very charming sight, indeed.

Monkeys galore!. On a good day, you'll be able to see Kathmandu from a high vantage point. When you arrive, you'll be immediately greeted by monkeys, especially so if you have bananas with you. The stupa is beautiful and massive. If you're feeling adventurous, you can walk up and down the 365 steps. Alternatively, you can ask your driver/guide to go to the shorter route up.Overall the area is quite a touristy place but there are still enough of a local culture presence and things to see and buy.
Swayambhunath Temple. Liked - Amazing views of Kathmandu at dusk as the lights came on. The temple and stupa.Disliked - begging children and naughty monkeys

Enjoy the view. The Monkey Temple is almost all the time crowded with tourists, but yet it's a nice place to visit and has an excellent panoramic view over Kathmandu. You can get some nice pictures. I think the name should be more like Dog Temple or Pigeon Temple, because there's a lot more of them than monkeys. Try to look through the thought that you're surrounded by tourists and feel the monk's and the temple's peace. Make a donation so the people living in poverty here can continue their traditions and buddhistic ways of life - that's what keeps them going.Ofcourse there's a lot of business going on in the area and it's perhaps not very wise to eat up there, cause it's kind of expensive, but you can enjoy the steep stairs up there, it's called working out... :)

just ok. a place overloaded with tourists, it's probably best avoided if you expect a peaceful walk to a place of tranquility. the view is awe-inspiring though, that's for sure. not that many monkeys at the temple itself. we left around 5pm and when we went down the stairs we were surrounded by dozens of monkeys doing their business, which was amazing. monkeys are awesome

Buddhist and Hindu Temples. Stunning views of the Kathmandu Valley, Buddist stupas, Hindu temples, monks, worshippers, monkeys ....... A holy place in the valley which encapsulates Nepal's religious heritage as well as spreading the whole of the Kathmandu valley below you. A must visit.

Must visit. Also known as monkey temple. From the front gate, we had to climb hundreds steps. While walking up, pass a lot of many small achitecture, streetside stall, and absolutely many monkeys. So very enjoyable. Before reaching to the top, there was a small room on the left hand side to collect the entance fee. The fee is 200Rs. Anyway, it was worth to pay. Upstair, apart from the stupa, we could see the landscape of Kathmandu valley. Very impressive The taxi fare from Thamel to Swayambhunath temple was 250 Rs (Oct 2013). We actually tried to negoiate at lower rate but all taxi drivers refused so, the final rate we got was 250 Rs one way.

The Stupa with a Dazzling View. Went here right before the sunset, end of October. We climbed the ladders, and the air was really nice. Perfect weather, perfect blue sky. While the stupa was beautiful, the view from up there was something to gaze all day long. Find the little, old Dongak Chyoling Monastery (there's a wood ladder to climb), and take a peek inside. Get a good cafe with rooftop terrace to oversee the sun setting behind the golden stupa.

Want to go back. in Katmandu, a must see. Known as Monkey temple, this attraction is well worth the long climb. The stairs are dotted with sellers of all kinds on Nepalese items, some of which I didn't see anywhere else on my trek. This is a holy place for the Buddhist in Nepal and around the world, be aware of the monkeys because they will still your food no matter what. I want in the morning at about 7 am there were already hundreds of people here not just the locals but even the tourist because this place truly one of the best place in the world.

Monkey temple very unique. Lots of steps. I did it with a fractured ankle though...Spiritual Mecca for Nepalese lots of people lots of stores surrounding this area. You would be missing out if you go to Nepal and don't visit this place. Make sure to take a trip around the outside of the temple to turn the prayer wheels unique experience and unique to kathmandu.
you must see. full of monkeys and full of poor people. but this is Nepal. Hundred steps for arrive in the Stupa, full of colored flags. On the top a beatiful view of Kathmandu's valley.

Magical atmosphere at sunset. Despite the neverending stairs, you will be amazed with the scenery when you reach the top. When sunset is playing its lights over the temple, the atmosphere is breathtaking. It is a magical moment with the smell of incense, with the sounds of mandala wheels, with the monks around and with the sunset, painting the temple slowly to red.. A visit to this Buddhist temple is a must in Kathmandu. It is 30 min walking from Thamel. The admission is 200 rupee. Also, called as "Monkey Temple" which is confirmed by the population of monkeys around :)

Very spiritual place. Swayambhunath, also called the Monkey Temple, is an ancient religious complex which sits on top of a hill in the Kathmandu Valley, west of Kathmandu city. It has been in use since the 5th century AD. This sacred site is also home to hundreds of monkeys considered holy to Tibetan Buddhists and Hindus. The site consists of a magnificent stupa as well as a variety of shrines and small temples. The Tibetan name for the site means 'Sublime Trees' for the many varieties of trees found on the hill. For Tibetans and followers of Tibetan Buddhism, it is second only to Boudhanath. On each of the four sides of the main stupa there is a pair of big eyes. These are symbolic of God's all-seeing perspective. There is no nose between the eyes but instead you can see a representation of the number one in the Nepali alphabet, telling that the single way to enlightenment is through the Buddhist path. Above each pair of eyes is a third eye, signifying the wisdom of looking within. No ears are shown because it is said the Buddha is not interested in hearing prayers in praise of him. Our guide very kindly suggested we enter the temple complex from the top and leave via the 365 steps. But the stupa has a far greater impact if you enter it by the stairway. It was rather crowded on the day we visited but we were still able to take great photos and admire the view over the Kathmandu Valley. This is a ‘must see’ in Kathmandu, it’s a very spiritual place and the monkeys are delightful, just don’t let them know if you have any food or you’re likely to have it stolen!

Impressive stairway approach to evocative temple. We walked here in about 20-30 mins from Durbar Square. The approach is impressive: a huge flight of stone steps leading up to the temple, though why it is is called 'monkey temple' is a bit if a mystery. (We saw a handful of monkeys but were certainly not mobbed: there are far more at Pashupatinath). Entrance ticket is about 200rsThe temple / stupa itself is fascinating, particularly at sunset when it is lit up with spotlights making for great photos. You can't stay in 'mandu without seeing this.Taxis back to Thamel cost 300rs / cycle ricks will do it for 100.

It packs a big holy punch in a small package.. Swayambunath is close enough to Thamel to walk although it would make more sense to taxi there (it's uphill much of the way) and walk back. At the base of the steps you have no choice but to walk but think of it as a devotional exercise.The temple area at the top is relatively small and (when I was there) very crowded. It's still possible, though, to take interesting pics, of the structures and of the people (and don't forget about the monkeys). At the bottom, after visiting the site, I encountered an old monk from Tibet who pointed out to me that it's the second most holy site in Nepal, after Boudhanath. It certainly packs a big holy punch in a small package but the feeling is more like a carnival.

really interesting and expansive complex. We walked out here from Lazinpath and back again, quite an undertaking, but once here it's a great place to explore, very expansive and lots and lots of photo opportunities. Can get quite busy, especially if there's a festival on. Watch the monkeys, there's a lot of them!

A must. If in Katmandu, a must see. Known as Monkey temple, this attraction is well worth the long climb. The stairs are dotted with sellers of all kinds on Nepalese items, some of which I didn't see anywhere else on my trek. Once at the top, the views of the city are beautiful, and the temple grounds are full of interesting artifacts, including a Buddha statue from the 6th century. If you are at all interested in Buddhism or history for that matter, GO!!!!

Monkey Temple. This temple is a must see when visiting Kathmandu and isn't far from Thamel. It sits high atop a hill visible from the centre of Thamel and looks imposing. There are two ways to reach the top of the temple and the hardest is climbing the hundreds of stairs from the bottom of the hill or the other is arriving by car and parking in the car park near the top. It is a place you can quite literally spend a few hours visiting especially sitting watching the monkeys playing all over this area. The architecture is beautiful and you will take a lot of photographs at this place. A nice place to relax away from the chaos of thamel.

A Monkey Temple Indeed!. Perched atop a hill on the western edge of the Kathmandu Valley, the ancient Swayambunath Stupa (known to tourists as the Monkey Temple) is Kathmandu’s most important Buddhist shrine. Also, one of Nepal's oldest Buddhist temples and it has an ancient atmosphere, especially when one approaches on foot with the pilgrims.It was great fun for the kids to see the monkeys and it was not as big as the Bodnath Stupa that we were able to go around it several times. The view from the Stupa is also good. As we were able to see the Monkey Temple from the Durbar Square - we had fun looking out for the square from the temple - that is, if we are not destructed to see the monkeys. They really are everywhere in the area - really adorable creatures!
be careful with monkeys!. Really nice place, a short and interesting walk from Thamel. Beware of monkeys and food, one tried to take my bag from me.

swayambunath temple is in nice place.... visited this trmple in oct-2013 , this temple contains good numbers of tourists, i appreciate this site. because in all directions we can view kathmandu city. very nice place, i like principles of budha, who is a peace lover. we sat there more than ahour, lot of monkeys are there. so dont use any type of foods in the premise. monkeys may attack ...

Nice++. It's in a walking distance from Thamel but the way was a bit confusing, it might be my fault though. There's a high steep stair to the temple but it's worth climbing since you can get a really good view of Kathmandu from up there, and the temple itself was also interesting. There're lots of monkeys and I found that they're cute, compared to monkeys in Indonesia, and didn't feel like they'll bite me like my friend said at all. Anyway, being careful is better than being careless. The sellers along the way up to the temple might annoy you sometime, but if you just said "No, thank you.", they'd understand you easily.
Monkey Temple. Well worth climbing all those stairs! Beware of the monkeys though, they can be aggressive. impressive view of Katmandu from the top. One of my favourite places to visit.

great view with lots of moneys and birds. lots of steps, monkeys, and birds while climbing up. but the view is really nice, and the temples are worth visiting as well. go by another way to exit, you will past by a wishing pond. if you throw your money where its suppose to land, your wish will come true. I heard the locals explaining to other people. why not?

Always packed. But a fun, quick trip. The "Monkey Temple" is filled with tourists and quite a few people hassling you to hire them as a guide or sell you things, but its still worth the trip. Its definitely filled with monkeys and the temple itself is quite pretty. There is a small fee.

Gorgeous and spiritual. Swayambhunath or monkey temple is a gorgeous and spiritual place with amazing views over Kathmandu. While you wander around different parts of the temple you can hear spiritual music and smell incents from the shops and see colorful prayer flags hanging everywhere. There is a special atmosphere and if you are lucky you can see the monks pray. The monkeys are everywhere and if you like them don´t forget to check out the monkey swimming pool. I could sit there for hours watching them swim, play and jump in. But be careful with bags and stuff because they can steal from you. It is a rather big site and a lot of steps so take your time. It can be a bit crowded, there are women and children begging for money, guides trying to get you to hire them and sales men that want to sell you stuff. But it is worth it. It is a special place to me because the 2 times I have been in Nepal I have been teaching at a monastery next to the temple so it was a part of my everyday life. I went there to relax and soak in the spiritual energy and the views. So take your time, look around and then find a quiet place to soak in the atmosphere and the views.

Great Views, Temples, and Lots of Monkeys!. This temple (known by many as the Monkey Temple) is definitely worth a visit when you're in Kathmandu. Great for photography, and you really do get pretty close to monkeys. With the exception of the babies, they're not as cute as you may think. There were LOTS of tourists when I visited in October, but it is still quite enjoyable. When you climb to the top, you have a great view of Kathmandu valley. Many souvenirs for sale.

Beautiful site. The first temple I visited after arriving in Kathmandu. It's also referred to as the Monkey Temple. Although I expected to see monkeys all over the temple, they are pretty much confined to the steps leading up to the temple. Next to the temple there is an excellent restaurant with a rooftop terrace offering an astouding view of the city of Kathmandu.

wonderful. my husband liked this place most of all the ones we visited in Kathmandu and the valley.the valley views are spectacular. the shops/layout reminded me of Epcot at Disney in a good way. we were not approached by anyone trying to sell us a tour (a plus). we loved the monkeys. it was just peaceful and beautiful.
Fantastic views over Kathmandu. The temple is great but it's too crowded. Worth going to see especially because of the monkeys. The place needs cleaning up though, it really detracts from the site
Peaceful. Out of all the temples in Kathmandu, I think that this would have to be my favourite. Take the time to sit and take in the surrounds.

Awesome place to visit with kids. Great to see the monkeys and the view of Kathmandu! We stayed there for hours just watching the people and taking it all in. One of those places you'd really want to see when visiting Kathmandu.

Worth a visit. Iconic temple with the 'seeing eyes'. Great views of Kathmandu, however, many tourists and too many 'trinket stalls', fascinating to watch competition between stray dogs, pigeons and wild monkeys. Steer clear of the monkeys - I would not feed them - there are hundreds of them and they rule the roost! Get the taxi driver (300 rupees from Thamel) to take you up the top so you can walk DOWN the very steep stairs (especially if you have just returned from a long trek!)
This is one you shouldnt miss. Great setting, very nice. If there is just one temple that you can afford to see in Kathmandu, this would be my choice.

Visit in the late afternoon. We arrived at a great time, around 4.30pm when the sun was shining directly on the west side of the temple and lit up the golden wall where the all-seeing eye was. From the temple, you can also get a fantastic panoramic view Kathmandu city.

Very interesting temple - use the guide so you fully understand the history of the Temple. You pay to get in I think it was 200 R. entry fee. Immediately I was approached by the guide who said it was 200 R for the tour, I ended up giving him a big tip as I really enjoyed the tour and he was a great asset to the visit to the temple. He took me into see the Mandalas and I believe had I bought one he would have got a commission, but they were very expensive and I basically didn't want one. Although I really enjoyed the talk the guy gave about how the Mandalas where made I did feel pressured to buy, so if you don't want to be put in that situation don't go and look at the art. Apart from that the tour was very informative and a highlight of my trip to Nepal. I think my pictures speak for themselves and although the day was cloudy and a bit drizzly it didn't dampen the outing. I think I would class this as a must see when in Nepal.

A nice temple in the hills.. I visited the temple with friends on a hot sunny afternoon. The places wasn't too crowded and thankfully there weren't too many monkeys around. I've heard they can be a nuisance. The temple was nice although there were many tourists and it didn't really feel like a temple. It felt like just another tourist spot. The views of the city from the temple are amazing. Make sure to carry a hat, wear sunscreen and take water with you as it can get very hot.
Very good temple, most interesting site and adoreable monkeys.. This is a most memorable place to visit. Remember to walk with the people (clockwise). The road up to the temple is most interesting.

A beautiful city view. We walked up the Eastern stairway, which is also called the pilgrims path probably due to the very steep stairs, and arrived right at the Stupa. It's a really great place with a lot going on, although there are A LOT of pigeons so some parts can get a bit smelly...After having a walk round and avoiding the monkeys we carried on to the Western stairs which were in smaller sections with another stupa and loads of prayer flags, the effect was quite breathtaking!

A must visit for one and all. Swayambhunath poses a challenge in the form of the flight of stairs one has to take up the hill to reach the popular tourist destination. For the less devout there is a winding road to the top after which the number of steps become very few. Apart from the majesty of the structure one is awestruck by the antics of the hoards of monkeys. They have made the place their home and feel at ease. Some even provide wonderful poses for the shutter bugs. The view of Kathmandu from the top is amazing. Also watched the sunset from the top.

Something to see. An eye opening experience, with many cremations going on at the same time. We were trying to see the temples and not interested in the cremations, but it isn't possible to avoid the cremations as you have to walk by them to get to the temple. Bodies were carried by us to the fire sights along the water. It is a cultural experience, for sure.

Swayambhunath. This is an extremely amazing place that must be visited within Kathmandu. This is a complex of very ancient Buddhist stupa and there are many monasteries around the main stupa. Also, many funny monkey waiting for banana and you can enjoy walking around. I suggest you to have an evening walk in this temple and see the sunset at the top, the main stupa,
Monkey Temple.... Great place to visit. Be prepared for many, many stairs, beggars and great views.It is become a little' touristy' but needs to be seen at least once.

Great view of Kathmandu, cultural & many monkeys.. Nicknamed Monkey Temple, I went there with a friend and climbed the steps to the top. It was probably the most scenic viewof Kathmandu. The monkeys were everywhere and as long as you respected them they left you alone. Very cool place and a must see while in the city.
A must see, but stingy and dirty. This place has a great view of Kathmandu valley and the stupa arquitecture is great but the place is dirty and smelly so is not as enjoyable as Boudhanath Stupa.
I wanna be there again. It's a great place, when you will climb up by the stairs monkeys will guard you there. From the top you will see the whole Kathmandu. It's a must see place.

Must see place in Kathmandu. That day we went to see several places and I enjoyed every minute of it going there and again being charged high entrance fees just to get in. You feel like prices in Chicago yet you are in Nepal and food is cheaper for four then the fees to see attractions for foreigners......

the monkey temple. very accessible from old Kathmandu, but a steep climb up innumerable stairs, guarded by monkeys (hence the name) and sellers of many things. Amazing view from the top and an impressive stupa and other buildings

Bad experience. When we reached the temple, the ground was wet after a heavy downpour. What chased us away was the stinking smell that surrounded the place. It became worse when we descended the steps at the back. It was so bad that we had to cover our nose all the way to our cab. From the feedback of our driver, there was a celebration the past few days and the garbage was not cleared. In all fairness, it was a case of being there at a wrong time.

Great Place for peace and quiet. Do not drive to the back of the stupa, instead climb the stairs. The effort is worth it. According to my guide, walking up the stairs resembles the path of difficulties one has to endure to attain nirvana. And the view from the top absolutely makes this effort all the worth.

365 Steps to Heaven!. Wonderful Experience climbing these steps, which get steeper and tougher towards the top, but it is worth it to climb out of the smog in the Kathmandu Valley. You just need to take it slowly and enjoy the scenery, statues, the many fluttering prayer flags and the Monkey's. At the top the views are fantastic and I felt really humbled by this very special & spiritual temple.

Great views and good example of a temple. Loved the view of the valley and the many buildings and flags. Good shopping on top for all kinds of souvenirs, but did not like the idea of having shopping at a Buddhist temple. Oxymoronic and diminished the experience.

Spiritual view. Amazing panaromic views of Kathmandu from the top. Due to the heat I chose not to hike up from the bottom. I heard it is a challenging way to get to the top.I loved the thousands of prayer flags floating in the breeze. I spun every prayer wheel I could find here.

Great view of Nepal. Got to be in shape to get to this Temple over three hundred steps to climb or you can cheat and go around the back. Lots of monkeys keep you entertained,met people from all over the world here.

unforgettable. legends surround the building of this stupa,one of the holiest place for the buddhists and most celebrated masterpiece of newari art in Nepal.the green hill,populated by monkeys,has given the name of "monkey temple" to this place.step by step ,climbing and enjoying the many statues ,the colorful maniflags ,one earns the spectacular sight of the Buddha's eyes slowly emerging above the steps.watching altars,exquisite statues,stupas ,maniwheels,devotees,monks in the monasteries chanting and performing pujas .....one can spend hours on the top of this hill.there is a misterious small,simple temple behind the stupa,where is told endless chambers and tunnels should take to Pashupatinath temple,but the inner gate is always closed,open only during special occasions and the entrance is forbidden.too many new altars, and an enormous Buddha's statue ,built mostly by tibetan devotees,overdecorations and oversized stupas have spoiled some parts of the hill,ruining the poetic simplicity of the original project.

Worth Seeing. This world heritage site, affectionately known as the "Monkey Temple", is certainly worthwhile seeing. Take the 365 steps up to the complex itself from the front gate. The views of Kathmandu & the Valley from the top are worth the climb.

Interesting architecture, must see. there are many different architectural styles represented here, plus it is on top of a hill so you have terrific view of the Kathmandu valley. Definitely should be on your list of places to see.

Temples. Unesco World heritage site - architecture is something different from all the other temples. There are many western resturants to get western food as well as Nepalese cuisine. Generally on roof tops. Great views.
A LOVELY PLACE. I loved the place, the steps and everything up there. The sight of Kathmandu from the top was wonderful. People can buy statues and trinkets at the temple.Lovely place.
Must see. First time visit for us in Nepal. This site has amazing views over the whole on Kathmandu. Well worth the visit !

monkey mayhem. my son loved the monkeys; made a good afternoon out and seemed a good place to chill for a few hours ; great views and interesting temple culture ; quite a walk up the main steps.I didnt like the way all the rubbish was thrown over the wall at the top unsightly and profane though the monkeys and dogs dont seem to mind

Jay Swayambhunath. Swayambhunath is an ancient religious complex atop a hill in the Kathmandu Valley, west of Kathmandu city. It is also known as the Monkey Temple as there are holy monkeys living in the north-west parts of the temple

Total Peace. This place is amazing. Each time I visit this place I feel so peace in kathmandu. This place is similar to country side, no traffic, no pollution, no noise..... I like both dome and pagoda in this place and both have their own powerful significance. Even the monastries and monks were good.

Majestic Stupa. The 4 dimension Buddha eyes watched over us with authority, there is nowhere to hide Being a not-so devouted Buddhist, this Holy site still contribute a heart felt peacefulness, we walk up the dome and enjoy the wonderful view with the wind against our face.The "Ice Coffee" on the left side on the entrance served some great Ice lemon tea!There are plenty of souvenir shops in the area, most are quoting at sky-high price, do take time to bargain more than 50%.
must visit. the trip to kathmandu is not complete without visiting this place, this is about 15 kms away, but wotrh to visit. there are 150 or so steps after u r left by car in the parking,

heaven in the top of the city.. Very quiet and located on top of the city. You can almost see the Kathmandu city and beautiful scenarios around valley. world heritage site and one of the not to be missed from many stupas in Nepal.

Not quite magical. Have to admit I was somewhat disappointed. There were a lot of visitors at the top around the stupa when we went late Saturday afternoon, so didn't really feel the "magic" other visitors have raved about. I am not a devout Buddhist nor Hindu however have certainly been entranced at other religious sites.Like every where else in Kathmandu/Nepal the site was very dirty, with people spitting indiscriminately. Lots of monkeys (albeit holy monkeys) all over the temple, they were aggressive and were pretty scary to be honest. Also stray dogs running around the place, youths playing hacky sack around the stupa.. not what I expected of a holy site to be revered.Lots of tourist shops and stalls on the way up and around the temple.

Center of Kathmandu. if you have heard about the story/legend/myth of Kathmandu and how it was formed, you will definitely understand the appeal of Swayambhunath Temple.It is said that there is eternal glowing lotus underneath the stupa and who knows it may be true. Certainly the Nepalese believe it. Perched on top of the hill in the middle of Kathmandu, you will be able to view the city from here provided first you climb up the 1000+ steps.Going around the main stupa, turning the prayer wheels with the background chanting of Buddhist hymns will sooth your soul even if you are a non-believer. Be wary of the monkeys, they are a funny and sometimes nasty lot. do not attempt to carry plastic bags or any stuffs loosely in your hand for they will snatch given the opportunity. Dont try to be friendly or feed them for God's sake as it will backfire.Go in the morning or if you have the chance in the evening on a full moon as the true beauty of this place will come alive when hundreds of butter lamps will be lit in and around the entire temple.

Buddha Eyes. Situated on a hillock near Kathmandu, it gives a birds eye view of the Kathmandu city. The main temple surrounded by multiple prayer wheels with the colorful ribbons swaying with the wind is a sight to remember. This stupa sports the original "Buddha Eyes"

Monkey Temple with a great view of KTM. The astonishing number of monkeys & statues of worship is what's worth the trip!Up you climb to the hilltop where there's monkey everywhere, and from there, you will be able to see right over Kathmandu - excellent for panoramic photos of the city! Besides being amazed by the various statues of worship & the architectural beauty of the place , there were a group of people practicing traditional music when I was there, and it was truly an experience to watch them enjoyed themselves so much & a glimpse of their way of celebration.

AKA Monkey Temple. I liked the structure and mostly the feeling all around....See monkeys everywhere...people from all over the world. I got to do my exercise of the day climbing the steps...love it!!

A must see in KTM. This temple is situated on a hilltop which has got stairs but is not too steep. When you reach there, you will be mesmerized with the soul-touching Buddha prayers being played therein. Also when you reach the other side, you can see the whole city fro therein. A must visit

One of the most beautiful places to see in KTM with an astonishing view over the city. This also so called "Monkey Temple" (you know why when you go there) is centered on a hill a litlte bit off the loud and noisy city of Kathmandu. There are several stairways to go up to the Stupa. You need a decent breath to take them all at once but the small hike is worth the trouble. On top you find yourself a beautiful Stupa, peaceful and quiet with an impressive view over the city of Kathmandu. Compared to Boudhanath it is the second nicest one to see.
Monkey Temple is a must see!. Great view, cutest monkeys ever, spiritual, nice exercise to get to the top, one of the best things to see in Kathmandu. Go there!
So Impressive. Very nice, well maintained and colorful. Shops surround the area for purchasing local arts & crafts.

Amazing Views!. This stupa sports the original "Buddha Eyes" (or so I was told). The shops at the top are friendly, although not as pushy as other places (like Bhaktapur). We ran into a few people who wanted to take pictures of us, but nothing major. The view from the top stupa is spectacular! The three statues at the base are also beautiful and huge! Definitely a site to see.

The most liked sacred places nearby Kathmandu. Situated on a hillock near Kathmandu, it gives a birds eye view of the Kathmandu city. The main temple surrounded by multiple prayer wheels with the colorful ribbons swaying with the wind is a sight to remember. If you are lucky, you can witness one of the traditional Nepali Bansuri (Flute) bands playing & participating in the religious rituals there, which I got a chance to witness. Tip: The temple is quiet uphill, but small cars go up to the finals steps of the temples so those who can not climb up large number of stairs, can go by car up to the last steps.

A feast for all senses. Climb up the steep, series of steps to the top where you will find glorious views of Kathmandu on a clear day as well as infinite carvings, magical prayer wheels, incense, aggressive monkeys, crowds of visitors, music and all this under the watchful eyes of the Buddha. An experience that is not to be missed.

Come early/late. Still nice to walk around but Busy with tourists a d shopkeepers. Come early or late so it will be a bit more quiet. The stalls are very expensive. Still it is a nice place to sit and watch things happening here.
