Was expecting more. From what I heard, I thought it was going to be a magical and spiritual place with monkeys, and it was a real disappointment. A lot of steps- some not so even so not so safe for people, and lots and lots of tourists- more so than Boudhanath Stupa. Not many monkeys, which was a disappointment to me. It was just ok but if you've never been to Kathmandu I'd still suggest a visit.

Culturally fascinating!. Swayambunath (meaning “self-arisen”) Temple or the Monkey Temple (as there are holy monkeys living there) has spectacular, awesome panoramic views of Kathmandu valley. It sits on top of a hill. When you reach the top, you will see the whole of the Kathmandu valley which will make you feel that it was worth the climb. It is just on the outskirts of Kathmandu and is among the oldest religious sites in Nepal. Although the site is considered Buddhist, the place is revered by Buddhists and Hindus as well.The Swayambhunath complex consists of a giant Stupa (the stupa consists of a dome and a structure with Buddha’s eyes - representing Wisdom and Compassion - looking in all four directions with the word "unity" in the main Nepali dialect between them), a large ensemble of shrines and temples, and also includes a Tibetan monastery, a museum and a library. This site has two access points: a long stairway, claimed to have 365 steps and a car road around the hill. As you are in the site, you’ll hear the beautiful and relaxing Tibetan Buddhist chants.A note on monkeys: The place is overcrowded by hundreds of monkeys. There are two versions about them: 1) People warn that you might be harassed by monkeys who are clever enough to snatch your bags, hats or even camera; that they are a menace and that one should be careful of them.  2) Monkeys seemed to mind their own business, are quite well behaved are quite well behaved and won’t bother anyone. In a word, they are not troublesome. MY personal opinion: I have always been used to monkeys confined in zoos. I’m not saying this is right. I’m just describing my experience. I didn’t feel like having personal interactions with the hundreds of monkeys freely roaming this site! Instead, I enjoyed the aura of peacefulness that the place retains, turning a deaf ear to souvenir vendors, self-proclaimed guides, hawkers & gawkers!What to expect: Thousands of devotees paying their homage (mostly fruit and eatable stuff so the place is not clean indeed. Cleanliness ends up being an issue as in most parts of Asia). The wishing well at the bottom of the stupa: the idea is to flip a coin into a basket at the foot of an idol in the middle of a pond. Lovely! A lot of people competing! Fun! Culturally fascinating. It should be on your list.There is an entrance fee to the site for foreigners.
Historic place with great view. We visited the temple while in Kathmandu. I liked the bells at temple, they look amazing. You can have a nice view of the city and good place to visit

at the heights. a very beautiful buddhist monastery situated at a good height. the scenic view of kathmandu valley from top is excellent. its a very good place for photography as well. be careful of monkeys though.
Mountain trip. Great place with great view of the city. Nice historical monument and a nice walk up the stairs. Take your time!

Great views, and an insight into shared temples in Nepal. Swayambunath Temple, or the monkey temple has beautiful views of Kathmandu valley. It sits on top of a hill, and is only a small walk from Thamel. The temple is shared by people of both Buddhists and Hindus, and you can see different aspects of their faith in different parts of the temple. A Stupa sits in the middle, and is surrounded by smaller structures, some housing Hindu gods.You reach the temple by walking up a big set of steps to the top. You can take breaks while climbing up these steps, with many rest points on the way. You can also get great views from these points, and enjoy some of the nature that lines the steps. I believe there is another entrance with more accessibility, but haven't seen it myself. Although people warn that you might be harassed by monkeys, the only harassment we've received were from souvenir vendors and self-proclaimed 'guides'. The monkeys seemed to mind their own business and not bother anyone really.I recommend that people visit this temple, but not reserve an entire day for it - although it is beautiful, it is not that big of a temple, and a few hours would suffice for a visit. Including it with other nearby attractions would probably be best.

This is the essence of Nepal!. I love Swayambhunath Temple. To me it represents everything that is Nepal. The Buddha, the amazing view of Kathmandu, the walk up the mountain, the prayer flags, the beauty and harmony, and of course the monkeys. The monkeys are clearly used to the people. They come very close to you sometimes but completely ignore you all the same. They are wild animals but they clearly coexist with the people just as I saw all over Nepal. I was warned they can snatch food from your hands or run off with cameras but witnessed no troublesome behavior. They are sure fascinating to watch.The place retains an aura of peacefulness even though there are tourists and sellers everywhere.A must see place!

Better not to visit in Monsoon Rain. The Temple is at the top of a hill near the river where people are ceremonially cremated. We visited in Monsoon season during a downpour so didn't see it at it's best. Great to see the monkeys so close up but I believe they can be aggressive, especially if you're carrying bananas! Great view from the top. There is also a pool which the monkeys jump into, but we missed that because of the rain.

See the valley from top of the temple. It is a busiest place of the valley. Thousands of devotees pay their homage every hours and days. But the view is fantastic. You can take a panoramic glance from the top. The hiking is also good for health. However, it is also overcrowded by hundreds of monkeys who are clever enough to snatch your bags or hats or even camera. The main temple site on the top is not properly cleaned after people pay their homage, mostly fruits, materials etc.
Leave me here,I'm happy. wander around this sacred place and soak up the blessings.Drink tea,meet people,make offerings,hang prayer flags and look inside the quaint shops.Go on you know you want to.
Nice location. The Temple location is very nice as you can see all Kathmandu from above. However be careful if you do not like Monkeys don't go there

Worth a visit.. Lovely temple, all the flags make it very colourful. Incense wafts everywhere and the views over Kathmandu are amazing. The atmosphere is very good and I have to say we weren't pestered by people selling us things. The monkeys can be a bit aggressive and are best given a wide berth.

Monkey Temple. The temple are infested with many monkeys. Good view of Kathmandu valley during dawn time. Have the option to walk from the foothills or get there by car or motorcycle. Need to walk a flight of stairs to reach the temple top. Has a Tibetan Buddhist monastery within the boundary. Admission fees required for foreigners.

beware monkeys. the monkeys here are a menace. be very careful of them. and then there are the hawkers and the gawkers! difficult to move around with all the pestering. cleanliness is an issue. road to the monument is not good but the views from the temple are better.

Simple but impressive monument. I liked the harmony of the construction. After so many over-decorated temples in Tibet, this white stupa is a relieve.
The atmosphere is spiritual and even the shop keepers are not pressing you to buy. recommended.

real monkey temple,. we been 2 times there ,nice view point place but monkey ohh my god...how meny there, we carry our bag every time moneky trying to take it, some time they are very naughty, but nice cool place, love to hike always bottom to the top,
Temples of Kathmandu. Worth getting a guide (not expensive) we paid $45 for a guide and car for the day.Just make sure he is Knowledgeable

cool place. Steep, hard and long steps takes you to a peaceful stupa. The steps up to Swayambhunath steep and very hard to climb, but when you reach to the main temple or stupa you will get fantastic view of Kathmandu valley and a peaceful environment
beautiful temple with inquisitive monkeys.... busy temple with lots of monkeys free to roam. Many interesting sculptures and Buddhist artefacts, but not a place to go for quiet contemplation...

Steps to Peace. Steep, hard and long steps takes you to a peaceful stupa.
The steps up to Swayambhunath steep and very hard to climb, but when you reach to the main temple or stupa you will get fantastic view of Kathmandu valley and a peaceful environment.
Fantastic Views. Loads of steps to get up to the top. Take your time! Fantastic views from the top over Kathmandu Valley. Iconic site within Kathmandu; a "must visit"!

Great views, beautiful place. Beautiful place, do the lazy thing and take the car straight up to the stupa! The wishing well at the bottom of the stupa is real fun! :) you have to flip a coin into a basket at the foot of a idol in the middle of a pond. :) it had a huge crowd competing and was really fun to watch!The views from the stupa are awesome! you get a panoramic view of Kathmandu valley all around.if you choose to buy something from the stalls, bargain hard. We bought something for NPR 100 whose starting price was NPR 400. Monkeys are quite well behaved and will not bother you - unless you start waiving fruits around in your hand!

The exercise stupa. A beautiful stupa with an interesting following. The steps up to Swayambhunath are a little steep, which I suppose are what inspired the first exercise nut to lay claim to the stupa as their gym. Seriously! There are many slightly overweight men working off their middle doing the most entertaining exercises for you to gawk at. Membership fees? None!

Impressive Stupa, monkeys and great views. The walk up to the Stupa is pretty steep and would be hard work for anyone who is unfit but once at the top you are rewarded with great views looking out over Kathmandu and the valley.The Stupa itself is very impressive and is completely different to the hundreds of other Stupas we have seen on our travels around South-east Asia. The monkeys are an added bonus and you can easily stop and watch them for a while as they run around the place and climb over everything. On top of this there were quite a few falcon like birds flying around in front of us which also impressive to watch.To get to the top you have to pay 200NR per person which is a bargain.You can easily walk back from the Stupa to Thamel, even though the taxi is cheap the 30min or so walk was worth it and took us along less touristy streets.

Monkey temple. The views are quite nice, and one of our group saw a monkey dive into a pool of water. The walk up the stairs is quite long, a lot of people beg at the bottom of the stairs which is a bit intimidating and one of our friends got hustled out of Rs1000 when we were at the top. Just keep your wits about you when you visit here.

Watch out for the Monkeys. In the inimitable buddhist fashion all life is respected. So, the monkeys are given free run of the place. They are crafty little blighters though. We saw one steal a Snickers from a girl's bag, and then unwrap it and eat it. This is when you know we have dented nature :(

great view and love the monkey. we visited monkey temple , its too good , we was their on night , for katmandu valley view , its just wonderful and beautiful view .when our guide explain its histry ad about eyes of Buddha , its to important and feeling lucky to be there .

An Excellent Visit!. Start your visit by trying to toss a coin into a jar in a fountain (hard to do!) then visit the temples above. The nickname "Monkey Temple" is well chosen - monkeys everywhere! Don't get too close while trying to take a picture; they'll grab your camera.
Very Peaceful. I like to go here sometimes when i am upset. Gives me a lot of peace. Something about this place that can not be explained.

Morning walk. While staying in Kathmandu do what the locals do and go for an early morning walk before the traffic takes over the roads.If you are in Thamel then the hilltop stupa of Swoyambhunath is a great destination. Follow the devotees spinning their prayer wheels to find the way. The 365 stairs that lead up to the stupa are a real heart starter and do be aware of the troops of monkeys that throng the slopes of the hill. Once at the top, the views out over the city are spectacular, especially if you have arrived in time for sunrise
Swayambhunath Temple. The temple and the surrounding looks really good full of religious feel. The view from the top was breathtaking early in the morning.

Its okay to explore around.. Its good to explore around but faced many monkeys around made my wife scare. Sometimes they can be nasty too especially when you have something on your hand, eatable things so on. the view of houses in kathmandu valley is amazing. Still cant believe how messy the city looks with all small small houses. The Buddhist stupa siren and hindu temple combination touched. its good.

Monkeys are awesome. As a person used to seeing monkeys in the confines of Western zoos, I found the up close and personal interactions with the hundreds of monkeys freely roaming this site amazing. Definitely a "must do" for a visit to Kathmandu.

Quick visit to Kathmandu. Lovely temple perched high up on a hill. Culturally fascinating. A great moment was watching the macaques going crazy diving into one of the pools on the lower level. You are better off making purchases at the Bodnath stupa as the prices of the vendors around the the upper level of this temple were extremely overpriced. A good place to visit and certainly if you only have a couple of days, this should be on your list.
Take a bike or take a hike. Getting here on foot or by bike will make this a nicer experience. If you do come by car ask for drop at the bottom of the stairs and walk the last part up to the temple.

On top of Kathmandu. This temple is also known as the Monkey Temple as there are so many monkeys. However, they are not troublesome. There is a quite a climb to get to the top and it is generally regarded as a Buddhist temple. There are three large statues of the Buddha just as you start the climb. However, some of the Hindus also believe that the term "Swayambhu" refers to God Vishna. On your way up, there will be so many sellers who try to sell small items such as bracelets, necklaces, singing bowls (a small bowl which is sold with a piece of wood. When you rub this piece of wood, it makes the "om" sound and it is used in Nepal for meditation). The sellers will be a bit of a trouble if you stop to just look at the items which are for sale. They will tell you that it is bad luck for them if you do not buy anything and would emotionally blackmail you into buying things. When you reach the top, you would see the whole Kathmandu valley which will make you feel that it was worth the climb. My husband and I spent some time on top of this place. You will constantly hear the Tibetan Buddhist chant "om mani padme hum" which roughly translates as the "jewel of the flower" which I believe to be a reference to the birth of Prince Siddhartha who later became Lord Buddha. This phrase is written over small cylindrical objects all around the stupa which is situated on the top of the hill. This is a 'must see' for all tourists who visit Nepal!
Long stairs. The long stairs are worth the effort, though. Nice view over the valley. You might see the dogs almost fighting with the monkeys.
great view of city plus peaceful air. I went with my sisters and it was very fun, roaming around and Buddha Park, its nice. and be careful of monkeys, they try to grab things from your hand.

Worth the climb. The temple is atop a large hill that requires a few breathers to complete, otherwise you can take your taxi around to the left of the stairs and up the side of the hill and remove the stair climb. I however advise the climb as the views as you ascend are the best of Kathmandu. It's a great spot to see some monkeys and a nice temple. A must see for Rs200!!!
City View. A monkey paradise from where you can see whole Kathmandu. Ancient Buddhist stupa and temple near to stupa was the highilight.

Grate Monkey Temple. This great monkey temple is just on the outskirts of Kathmandu. No one actually knows who built it. Many believe that the Lichavis constructed it while others believe that emperor Asoka had already visited it in the 3rd century. The Swayambhunath complex consists of a giant Stupa, a large ensemble of shrines and temples, and also includes a Tibetan monastery, a museum and a library. This site has two access points: a long stairway, claimed to have 365 steps, leading directly to the main platform of the temple, which is from the top of the hill to the east; and a car road around the hill from the south leading to the southwest entrance. The first sight on reaching the top of the stairway is the Vajra.
Monkey Temple. Very nice place on top of a hill overloking the city of Kathmandu.You should visit in the serene evening when the sun is going down.

Walk or by car. If u want to spare energy than let the cab drive u till the top. Buy small candles , take u shoes of en light our candle. They will try to sell u the big one but buddha will take ure small on aswel. Dont take the rooftop restaurant, overprised and not the best vieuw.

Fantastic location ... you can see this from everywhere. I loved visiting this Temple, it is right at the top of a hill in pride of place. It's really fascinating, lots of people visit to worship and it's really beautiful. You can see it from everywhere - the buddha is marvellous. It's really work the visit.

swayambhu stupa, kathmandu. Make no mistake, Swayambhu is the self-arisen stupa, rising rounded from the valley floor, especially worshipped by the local Newar communities, Kathmandu's indigenous inhabitants. Climb straight up slowly, past the ancient buddhas, crazy monkeys, sellers of mani stones, and other forms of life, human and otherwise, Once at the top, circle slowly, left to right, stopping to admire the giant vajra, the view and the glorious images in the sharmapa gompa. Then find your way back to the Manjushri hill and visit the shirine that is at once the 'female' Saraswati and the 'male' Manjushri, both deities of wisdom. Try to do this without thinking too much, and you will find your own wisdom self-arising from within.

Hustle and bustle. This is another must in Kathmandu. A hive of activity, from people praying, to people selling wares to monkeys stealing the offerings, it's a great place to be at dawn, throughout the day or dusk; there is always something to see and going on. This is a photographers paradise and Saturday is especially worth a visit as there is plenty to see and watch. The usual bartering needs to be done wit the stall holders who will always overprice as this is a big tourist attraction. Go early and you can get a better deal as the first customer of the day.

Morning walk. I go everyday in the early morning for morning walk, so it is one of the best spot to get cool mind and meditation, and get peace in your mind. Travelers also visit here to see about the Buddhism, because its also the world heritage site.
great spot. Wonderful views of the city! Although fewer monkeys than I expected. The pilgrimage up the steps is definitely an experience!

A Must In Kathmandu, try around Sunset. When you think of Kathmandu, you are probably thinking Swayambhunatha Temple. The Prayer Flags, the Eyes, the monks, the monkeys.Though its almost identical to Bodnath Stupa, it sits on a hill looking over Kathmandu. Climb to the top around sunset, view the valley and Kathmandu and breath it in. You are in Nepal.
Rabies. Nice spot, just don't mess with the monkeys, man. It ain't worth rabies. Check out the iPhone equipped monks. At length, if you're dropping rupees in the box.
Buddism. Stupas and monasteries are excellent .The great temple in world for Buddhism.Beautiful place near valley with hill. monkeys can be seen everywhere.

Monkey Temple. After taking the 356 steps up you feel like you have just reached Mount Everest. And up there you are welcomed by an extraordinary view and by some holy monkeys. The Stupa is beautiful, white and gold and there are also many other tempels and shrines around.
peace. on a nice evening.. you can visit swoyambhu.. watch beautiful kathmandu..and relax. peace, calming environment. Locals very helpful and smiling.. very beautiful experience.

Great views and lots of monkeys. It's a short walk uphill, but the paths are good with lots of space and railings. There are monkeys hopping all over the place ready to snatch your camera! They're very curious, not shy at all, and will let you take great pictures. There are many different shrines, vendor stalls, and unique things to see and watch. There is a view of the whole sprawling city that makes it seem so much more peaceful. You can spend no money at all, or plenty of money on stall trinkets and souvenirs. Definitely a tourist attraction to check out.

Temple on the hilltop of Kathmandu. If you're staying in Thamel, Swayambunath can be reach by walk, if not, taxi only cost Rs 150-200 from Thamel, depend on how good your negotiation skill is, do not worry if the driver won't lowering down the price as many taxi available to take you to this site. Prepare yourself for long and tiring walk, bring plenty of water and if you want to go to toilet, it is available right after the entrance gate for Rs 10-20 fee. Watch out for the monkeys scattered around temple, locals told me its ok to feed them or play with them as long as you're not disturb the baby monkeys. At the temple, is quite same like Bodnath, but you can see the view of all Kathmandu valley from one side of the temple, nice and worth the trip.

Great view and Monkeys!. The stairs will give you a good workout, but it is worth it. The view of the valley is also amazing and the prayer wheels are beautiful. The monkeys are not too aggressive and fun to watch. Not to be missed if in Kathmandu!

Amazing views of Kathmandu. This monkey temple is well worth a visit. It costs 200 rupies to go in and be prepared to go up lots of stairs. The monkeys can be aggressive so be careful. If they come too close, bend down to touch your shoe and they'll generally run away. The statues on the other side of the hill are even more impressive, so don't make the mistake of thinking that there are only on the top of the hill and come down via the same stairs.

Be Ready to Walk Much. This temple is well worth visiting, but be ready to go up and down steps. The temple is beautifully decorated with sutra flags and a view of Kathmandu is superb. There are many monkeys, but they are not aggressive unless you disturb them. Some baby monkeys were so cute and I enjoyed taking pictures of them. The admission costs Rs 200 and you must pay at the ticket counter on your way up to the stupa.

Must visit. The view from the temple top of the Kathmandu valley was breath taking. The temple premises have lost of budding painters showcasing the printing on the way to temple. There are lost of shop which sell articles of different deity.

A view of all Kathmandu. This is a great spot to visit if in Kathmandu. The temples at the top are wonderful, and Buddha's eye will be watching. To experience the culture, wildlife (literally) and such a significant spiritual place for so many is as impressive as anything in Western Civilization. It is a significant climb if you are out of shape, so if you are not used to walking a great deal, plan accordingly. Namaste.

" Compassion flows down the valley". "Swayambu" means self-arisen ....So, "Swayambu-nath", the self-arisen Stupa, on this hill top, keeps Lord Buddha's eyes of compassion, watching the four directions down the Kathmandu valley...There are couple of Ashoka Stupas around the Main stupa, confirming the visit of Emperor Ashoka to the site in 250BC, and thus concluding that Lord Buddha has visited and made sacred the place with the touch of his holy feet..There are plenty of Sculptures and statues and shrines which were built in various times in the history.A wandering group of Macau Monkeys may be noticed and thus got a nick name as 'Monkey Temple'.From heart of Thamel Kathmandu I could walk there in 20 minutes, and the climbing takes like 10 minutes.On top of the site you get the panoramic view of Kathmandu Valley, both day and night..The entrance fee to the site is 250 NRs. fro tourist other than SAARC countries. Entrance is free for locals.

A place you must visit!. Very beautiful Temple to visit when you are in Kathmandu. All on top you have a really great view over the whole city. And the temple is surrounded by beautiful trees, it was very green now at the moment (july).

Get taken to the top. Make sure that when you visit you are dropped off at the top of the site so that you do not need to wak up the 655 steps. You should suggest to your taxi driver (or tricycle driver if he is strong) that you meet him at the bottom before you go on to Patan or wherever. The stas here have some of the highest prices in the city so be careful.

As far from a Western funeral as you can get. American funerals are antiseptic and private. At Swayambhunath, family members grieve at the rivers edge after which the body is cremated and ashes spread into the water. It was one of the strangest experiences that I have ever witnessed. It is hard for someone with Western values to comprehend the spectacle of cremation and spreading of ashes into a holy river which to an American seems polluted beyond imagination all the time with monkeys scrambling along tin roofs making unbelievable racket. East meets west and it is something that was very difficult to understand and comprehend. You just sit back and marvel at the entire process and its meaning.

A must see in the Kathmandu Valley!. The Stupa at Swayambhunath is a must see for anyone visiting the Kathmandu Valley. It rises majestically out of a hill in the central valley of Kathmandu. Legend has it that the Stupa arose miraculously as a gift from a Buddha of a bygone era. It is a hike up a few hundred steps to get to the top but well worth the view and atmosphere that waits for you at the top. The surrounding temples, monasteries, and prayer wheels are interesting, just watch out for the annoying monkeys! The view of the city below is also worthwhile, not to mention the clean air which is a much needed relief after breathing the otherwise heavily polluted valley air.

Swayambhunath Temple. This is the place that every traveller who comes to Kathmandu will see. It is worth the walk up the stairs but I do recommend if you have multiple days to try to get up there after some rain or wind to get the best views of the city, it is supposed to be amazing. I unfortunately when when you could hardly see 6 foot in front of you for all the smog, but the temple complex made up for the lack of view. Early in the morning is popular but quiet, the later in the day the busier it gets. There is an entrance fee, which is hardly anything given that the temple relies of this for maintenance, a donation is also welcome. It is a decent walk out of Thamel, a bit further than I was expecting, just keep walking the way all the guide books say and you will get there. It is very unexcess-able for those who need assistance as there are hundreds of very steep stairs.

Buddhist Monastery for Peace. Swayambhunath Monastery is popular buddhist stupa in Nepal which is located on the top of the hill which gives nice view of Kathmandu city. Also Buddhist Monastery gives perfect feeling of buddhism spreading in the world for that top hill. People and devotees attended that place everyday from morning to evening to offer buddhist calm and peace lamp for the world.Buddhist philosophy is respected by world which mantra said no violence, no war, no sins in the world.

The Stupa with a view. Swayambhu is magnificiently situated with views right over the valley of Kathmandu and beyond. It is know as the "self arising" Stupa and is clearly a very blessed and special place for the Tibetan and Newari Buddhists. The monkeys run wild and the tourists love the monkeys.
Eyes of Lord Buddha !. Sangrila La... Temple (stupa) of eternal peace. The statue od Lord Buddha is fantastic ! Wonderful place.

A lovely and fun temple. I normally wouldn't classify a temple as 'fun', but that's precisely what it was. Swayambhunath is known as Monkey Temple, and I knew beforehand that there would be monkeys to be seen--but I had no idea there were so many of them running about! They were so adorable and fun to watch, and they were EVERYWHERE. Swayambhunath is located on top of a hill. I climbed to the top (where the temple is), and saw a good view of the Kathmandu Valley. The stupa of Monkey Temple is also pretty, although not as amazing as that of the Boudhanath.Entrance fee for foreign tourists is 200 Nepalese rupees (approx USD 2), I think--not bad at all. A bit chaotic but still a must-see in Kathmandu.

Monkey temple. This is definately a must see. Swayambhunath is also called the momkey temple and sits on a hill which can be seen for miles around. Be ready for a slow walk to the temple itself though as there's a step for each day of the year, and they're in a pretty bad state some of them. That said, once at the top, it's amazing. Small temples, shops and other things tio see are here, including a temple that has a resident Buddhist filling his butter lamps, amazing to see. It's also great to see the school kids as they visit the temple and can be seen sitting and eating their lunches, all very cute. If you can get away from the larger crowds it's also a very spiritual place and a great place to chill out and even meditate if you're into that. As I say, this is a must say.

Great View and Flight of Stairs. Swayambunath is one of the stupa which were built to protect and oversee the land of Kathmandu. It is near Thamel (a place where many foreigner visits).It is situated on top of a hill and takes approximately about close to 1 hour to circumambulate for Buddhist. Once reached, there is a giant manmade dorje on top, and along the ascend, one can see many monkeys.There are a few restaurants and shops.The main purpose to go there is to pray solemnly, borrowing its positive energy to fulfill what we prayed for.The site is only a plus.
Great Experience. it is neat and clean. no one disturbs you. you can walk around leisurely and have great view of mountains and kathmandu valley.

go at sunset ! or sunrise !. amazing atmosphere, this is where i bough my wheel of peace draw by a monk. ( plenty of choice , shop in the different school and let them explain the different meaning of the drawing !

picked up by a buddhist monk, showed me around the whole city. Amazing experience - this senior buddhist monk asked if I wanted to follow him. He showed me around Swyambu, then took me to his monastery down the hill. The woods out back of the temple are full of monkeys and peace. I don't think I'd walk alone being female, but it was overall a very good experience!

Worthy add on to your Kathmandu to do list. Monkeys? check. Stupas? Check. Locals worshipping at the temple? Check. It was a nice walk up to the top with monkeys all along the route. It was not too crowded when we went, which added to to serene atmosphere. The stupa was interesting along with all the smaller temples surrounding it. There was at least one row of the prayer wheels there. So you can do your requiste spinning of the prayer wheels. You get a nice view of Kathmandu Valley from the top. Although the view was very hazy when we were there.

Also known as "The Monkey Temple". Break out the walking shoes and head for this magical spot. It is a great work out and the walker is rewarded with great city views and lots of inspiring photo opportunities. Be warned though, it can be a tough walk and can get very hot. Wear light clothing and go early to avoid the temperatures and crowds. The final approach is a 'never-ending' series of stairs laid into the mountain-steep slope. Take water and wear your most comfortable running shoes. There is a nominal entry fee at a kiosk located near the top of the stairs. It is home to hundreds of monkeys that can be a little aggressive and equally cheeky. Keep a close eye on your belongings as they are not afraid to grab anything you may set down. Sometimes we choose to walk right from Thamel but there is also the easier option of having a taxi take you up the back road. This road winds it's way almost 3/4 of the way to the top and you avoid all the front facing steps. If time, age, weather or health is an issue, this is the way to go, have the taxi wait for no charge). At the top are countless unique shops and keepsake stores. It is also an active Buddhist Monastery so you will undoubtedly see Monks of all ages in the surrounding buildings and walking amongst the many daily visitors. This attraction, located on the one of the city's only elevated areas is dramatic, spiritual and well worth a visit. (**a popular option is to have a taxi take you to the top of the back road, then after a couple of hours spent exploring, walk back home to your hotel in Thamel**) Highly Recommend!

Amazing heritage site. Amazingly beautiful heritage site. Everyone visiting Nepal should visit this buddha temple. beautiful view. This is just 2-3 kms from Thamel. It has got 2 Big stupas .One while entering temple and 1 at the top

Monkey temple. really there are monkey, i heard it is made from the lotus flowers. orginal name is swambhunath stupa. from there nice views of the kathmandu valley and forest atmosphere feeling. both location and its history are very fascinating. A day tour there are many recommendation.

Good fun!. Monkeys galore! Steep steps which sucked but were a great practice for the trek ahead. Lovely fresh mint tea in one of the roof top cafes, with great views of the Kathmandu valley. I hope to return next year. Watching the puja/ offerings was very interesting.
Beautiful temple. Brilliant architecture & awesome work of art. The temple needs to be given time if one like work of art.
Temple on hill top. Beautiful temple on hill top. we have to ascend some steps to reach the top. We can have a nice view of Kathmandu. We have to bargain the shops.

The stairclimbing was a good workout and worth it!. Once you get up to the top you can enjoy the wonderful view on a clear day. The inner temples and old monastery were a joy to see. Local people were doing their lighting of candles, prayers and chants. It was not something put on for tourists, but the real thing. The monkeys are unemployed and supplement their life by stealing... watch out for these little opportunists. Don't miss it!
Peace, Peace, Peace. Went on Budh Purnima day...the chants, scent of the lighted sticks, lighting lamps and decoration....made my day.
Very nice place. Interesting to see, gives a good hint of religious life in Nepal today. We spent a day visiting different templs, stupas etc and this one is in this case a "must".

one of my favorite spots in Nepal. beautiful views from up here. Local people worshipping and hanging out. Impressive religious art. the monkeys scared the crap out of me. I would not recommend having food or drink in the open. They took a soda bottle from our guide.
A definite must do in Kathmandu. Wonderful sight, great view of the city, amazing spiritual feeling here. Worth the climb of the many many steps!

Monkey temple. The foremost Buddhist monastry overlooking Kathmandu. Need to climb many steps to reach the top. A good place to see both the Tibetiens, Nepalese and others. Nearby incense materials are available.

Buddha temple, a must in Kathmandu. This is THE place you cannot miss on your visit to Kathmandu.The temple has to be walked as all temples clockwise 3 times. Go inside the room where Buddha is and take a pic there. Dont forget to take your shoes off. Its a question of respect. Keep silent and feel buddhism everywhere!!

A must-do in Kathmandu. Worth the climb not just for the temple but also the spectacular views over Kathmandu. It's very reasonably priced (compared to Durbar Square), at just 200R per person. If you go on a Saturday expect it to be crowded with locals and their kids. It's easily walkable from Thamel, so don't pay a taxi driver through the nose for the ride up.

Lots of stairs lots of monkeys. After a fun walk across Kathmandu from Thammel, I would recommend enjoying the site from east to west then grab a taxi home. There is so much to look at, check it all out on the way up. Do be courteous at the ticket booth, they will chase you down if yo don't pay.a group of Chinese youth thought they could slip by, I was embarrassed for them. The stairs are being repaired right now so if lots of step intimidate you take a taxi to the west side and it is an easy walk. Read up on the different types of shrines, it make the trip more fun and educational.

Enchanting!!. A beautiful stupa atop hill! You can experience tranquility amongst the surroundings. Also one can witness a glimpse of Kathmandu city from there. Beware of monkeys and try your luck at "Make a wish pond". I loved this place!

Historically Beautiful!!!!. What an amazing temple. No wonder it is Unesco World Heritage site.The artistry and the architecture is awe-inspiring.Suggest you take a taxi to the higher part then walk a few more steps to the top of the temple. It is easier to walk down the stairs to the bottom than to go from down to up.While going down the stairs it is slightly steep so hold the railing.On the way down you can pick up singing bowls and other things.Bargain and you can get a lower price.Mind the monkeys especially if you have bags.DEFINITELY WORTH THE VISIT!!!

Must do as the view is amazing. stairs seemed to never end but the view from the top of Kathmandu Valley is amazing. Dont get too close to the monkeys they are vicious, all they want is food they are like scavengers. Heaps of people begging all up and down the stairs. Only costs 200 rupee to get in once you reach the top.

When in Kathmandu....worship with the people.. I walked around the stupa many times spinning prayer wheels and chanting. A monk appeared out of nowhere and offered me a chunk of amber for sale. I bought it for a reasonable price, as I had planned to make an offering to the temple, anyway. To this day, I take the amber with me when I travel, a protective amulet, incorporated into a string of holy beads purchased in Kathmandu.
First Stupa visited. Nice and high situated stupa with great views. Nice shops with the famous singing and healing bowls. Dislike the beggars and it was quit dirty up there
Very interesting experience!. I liked to understand other people rituals and religion.the temple was very well preserved and the atmosphere was great.

Enlightening and entertaining. If you don’t like monkeys, don’t go here. If, like me, you do – definitely go! Built on a hill this Temple extends on and on up the hill. There are prayer wheels to spin, candles to light, prayer flags everywhere, shops with trinkets and spiritual items, and monkeys. Having never been to Nepal this was a great glimpse of their culture and beliefs.
I’d recommend going early in the morning. We visited temple 2 times while staying in Kathmandu.I’d recommend going early in the morning – it is much more peaceful and quiet.

Great view over the city on a clear day, watch out for naughty monkeys!. The temple is a beautiful mix of Buddhist and Hindu iconography and the climb gives you a great view over the city on a clear day. Watch out for the naughty monkeys - they will snatch anything on offer!

Swayambhu Stupa. Swayambhu Stupa is one of the two largest stupas in Nepal; the other one is Boudha Stupa in Boudhanath, which has become a tourist hub with it's ups and downsides. Pricewise, all in the Swayambhu area is much cheaper...
Beautiful. It's a working temple so all around, people were dancing, eating lunch, praying, i.e. it's not just full of tourists.
Swayambhunath Temple. One of the main places in Kathmandu. Every trip be sure to attend it. The best time early in the morning, at dawn.

Monkeys Everywhere. This temple was a great experience. Our driver cheated and drove us most of the way to the top. The historical temples at the top are amazing and the views of Kathmandu are wonderful.

Why call Monkey Temple.............................. The whole complex on the hill is somewhere you should definitely visit. The approach from the Pilgrim's Steps is the best, with the hard climb up to the top. I found it was good coming early morning , as there were no other tourists but a lot of locals were praying. It was best to stand at the side and be...

A Buddhist stupa with a view. Said to be the oldest religious site in the Kathmandu Valley, visitors should walk up the hill to the "monkey temple" to earn the view and get in shape for trekking. Sometimes monks are chanting. Like many religious sites in Nepal, this is one of the wonderfully syncretic ones, not just Hindu or just Buddhist.

I'm Left With One Memory ..... I have difficulty thinking about this place as I witnessed one of the stall owners dragging her little boy right across the temple courtyard and kicking him hard in the spine. So not exactly a holy spirtual experience for me ... just rather depressing.

Must see. The whole complex on the hill is somewhere you should definitely visit. The approach from the Pilgrim's Steps is the best, with the hard climb up to the top. I found it was good coming early morning (about 7am), as there were no other tourists but a lot of locals were praying. It was best to stand at the side and be careful not to disturb anyone. There is a massive mix of Hindu and Buddhist religion on the site. It is worth having a guidebook with you so that you know what the different things are. The monkeys were generally friendly, but some of the bigger ones could be more aggressive!

great but mine was funny. this is a great temple... the view of kathmandu valley from there is just to die for.... there is a shortcut to get there without climbing the billions of stairs.... please take that... we went with a nepali friend who told us we should climb the stairs... it was a steep climb... but it was fun... for those who cannot do stairs there is a back entrance with a mild climb....

Well worth the hike up the steps. The only thing that spoils this visit is the pollution that obscures what would be a spectacular view over Kathmandu. But you're really here for the temple and whole experience of exquisite shrines, carvings, devotees, monkeys, stone carvers and gentle mayhem. If touts and grime bother you, better to go and lie on a resort beach somewhere. The 300-plus steps are a challenge. Smile and say no thanks to the would-be guides, and keep an eye on the monkeys. Up top it's a wonder and worth a good hour just to watch and marvel. Go early to beat crowds and the heat.

The serene place full of prayers. This was absolutely a great experience to behold. The steps that led me to the temple told me a million story with each. The calmness that is present there is so surreal that its feels almost dreamy. The presence of beauty keeps reminding us how much faith the people here carry in their hearts. The astonishing views to great arts and craft, one of the best place to be and feel.

Awesome Experience. It's amazing the monkeys are everywhere and are so fun to play with and feed. It's an amazing experience, a must do when is Kathmandu. Ask for the story about the origin of the temple and monkeys!

You can see a big part of Kathmandu Valley. It's good for people who likes to climb and hike. But the top of the Temple is not very clean. always full of wastes from 'devotees' offerings of fruit, flowers etc. Be careful about the monkeys! they can snatch your bag or camera or food.

Great view, tons of monkeys. Beautiful view, go to rooftop restaurant/cafe to enjoy view and warm breeze in the sun. Loved seeing the monkeys running around in their natural habitat, swinging from the trees, not in an enclosed zoo. Many baby monkeys too, one only a week old barely able to walk just hanging onto mom. Enjoyed walking up the many steps getting ready for a trek.

Beautiful views over Kathmandu.. From Thamel its easy and cheap to go by taxi to Swayambunath. Ask THE driver to put you of at the top, so you don't have to walk all the steps to the Temple. If possible go in THE afternoon. The vista's are great.

Beautiful temple. Swyambhunath temple is one of the must visit place of kathmandu..local people says that this temple was created by its own, that's why the name is swayambhunath..also known as monkey temple..temple for hindu religion people too..wonderful and peaceful place..
Spectacular & peaceful place. Overview of Kathmandu city. A peaceful place to visit. Spectacular Stupa on top of the hill...Would like to spend more time on this place again.

Amazing place, must visit!. The stupa itself looks very amazing and it seem have surrounded by Tibetan elements on itself. Standing tall on the top of the hill whereby you can have a best view of the Kathmandu valley.
Best place. Nice Place enriching Hindu culture in Nepal. the temple was in underground tunnel naturally created in the Huge Rock.
Early morning pre trek exercise. This is the Monkey temple. Go early to see the monks and the band! I imagine there is a good view when the air is clear

Swayambhunath-365 steps. Swayambhunath also known as the Monkey Temple as there are holy monkeys living in the north-west parts of the temple.Although the site is considered Buddhist, the place is revered by both Buddhists and Hindus. Numerous king Hindu followers are known to have paid their homage to the temple, including Pratap Malla, the powerful king of Kathmandu, who is responsible for the construction of the eastern stairway in the 17th century.

A great experience. Climbing hundreds of steps to the beautiful stupa & tiny medieval temples at the top, surrounded by devout pilgrims making their way up & resident monkeys & dogs [who seem to know this is a special place & all get along together very well] make this a very special experience.We go back whenever we're in Kathmandu, breathless as we reach the final steps & then realizing at the top just why we did it again.Its truly magical just before sunset when the light hits the gold of the stupa's spire and the old stone buildings are warm in the final sun.And from up here on a clear day you can see the whole of Kathmandu..

vieuw over Kathmandu is nice.. You can go up all the stairs from the main entrance but there are about 260 steps to climb.There is also a "backside"entrance which is much easyer to take.You can get there by car/bus.Swoyambunath is still a holy place for some people but it is very commercial also. A bit to..........The buildings are nice to see, there are stil monkeys and the view from the hil-top is nice.

Not just monkeys at this temple. Undoubtedly one of the Must-Sees in Kathmandu, this stupa sits at the top of a hill just west of Kathmandu proper. It's a short taxi ride or a 30-40 minute walk from Thamel or Kathmandu's Durbar Square. You know you're getting close when you see monkeys walking on the power lines or the roofs in the area.It's a good number of stairs up to the temple itself but well worth the haul - the stupa itself is absolutely stunning up close, and it's surrounded by a number of interesting temples and shrines. There are also panoramic views of Kathmandu and the surrounding area, making it a great place to catch a sunset.I'm sure everyone visiting Kathmandu will come to see this place, and for good reason!
Little Tibet. Must see this temple, this is one of the most interesting cultural place to see in Kathmandu, you can walk there from Thamel, 20 minutes walk and see on your way interesting streets

Great place for scenic view and peace of mind. We went early morning of 14th April which is the new year's day in Nepal. So there was lot of rush. We went by bike and the ride was awesome. The road was under construction in patches but overall it was maintained well. There were many shops in the stupa campus where one coud buy souvenirs, paintings, bags,etc. At the top, there sitting areas where one can enjoy the view of Kathmandu Valley. A must visit if u are there!!

Sunset over katmandu. We planned this visit for late afternoon as you can see the sun set.Fascinating temple with markets surrounding. Found a little cafe at the top and sat with a beer and watched the sunset. Relaxing and enjoyable. Small entry fee

Awesome place, great views of Kathmandu Valley. Went here twice; once with my friends and once again with our tour group. Awe of the place was not lost upon our second visit. Looking out from the top of this hill, you can get an amazing view of the Kathmandu Valley and the whole spread of Kathmandu. The Stupa itself is equally amazing, as well as the meditating monks and monkeys constantly running amok. As well as this, it is a fantastic place to have a great cheap lunch while enjoying the views, as well as pick up some amazing canvas paintings. This geniunely is a 'must-see' while visiting Kathmandu. Brave the 365 steps to the top; it makes the views all the more rewarding.

I just like it. It's beautiful. It's a great conveniently located classic stupta and temple spot. Beautiful view over Kathmandu on a clear day. Monkeys! Great people watching. I liked the vibe of the place.
Short walk from Thamel. About a 30 minute walk from Thamel. If the skies are clear great views of Kathmandu city. Worth a look.

Good place to see both Budhism and Hinduism practised together. This is one of the place that is frequently visited by local hindus and Buddhist people. Excellent views of Kathmandu valley from the temple on a clear weather. All in all a very interesting temple premises

Sunset. I had the pleasure of being at this temple just before and during sunset. On this particular day, the clouds had rolled in just right so that the sun set for a long time. It made viewing the city below, the mountains and the temple just lovely. Beware of the monkeys and the haze. If you get lucky you will see half of the city from the top. They were also shooting a music video the evening we were there, quite interesting. Worth the visit to get an idea of just how big Kathmandu really is.

Nice view from the top of the mountain. It provides a nice view from the top of the mountain overlooking the entire Kathmandu Valley. But there is another similar type of temple in the city of Kathmandu so if you don't have time, probably just go to the one in the city, which is more famous as well.The one in the city is called "Boudha Temple" - Tibetan Temple
Beautiful temple, but no view anymore. Wonderful temple, but don't expect a "view" of the valley. There are no views of the valley anywhere anymore, as it's perpetually shrouded in smog.

Stunning - favourite temple in Kathmandu. Beautiful and well worth a visit. You get a great view of Kathmandu as you take the steps up towards the temple. The stupa is stunning, as are the prayer-flag covered hillsides surrounding it. The temple and surrounds are overtaken by monkeys who have made it their home. This was my favourite of the temples I visited in Kathmandu and the Kathmandu Valley. You can get there easily by cab from the town, and it's possible to walk.

Well worth the visit!. You can't possibly go to Kathmandu without visiting this beautiful temple. My favorite memories are the prayer flags fluttering in the breeze, the smell of incense in the air, and flickering flames of the butter candles. A very large Stupa dominates the center, surrounded by prayer wheels which are constantly being turned. Although a little misty the day we were there, the view of the Kathmandu Valley is fabulous. It is also referred to as the Monkey Temple, but both times we visited, the monkeys were few and far between, and well behaved from what we could see. For those who find climbing 300 stairs a little daunting, there is another route which can be reached by car, there are still several stairs to climb, but it is much easier. Well worth visiting!

After all the amazing reviews, I was disappointed. I was so looking forward to this visit after the reviews I'd read. But simply put it just didn't live up to what I had thought it would be based on so many reviews. First, it was so crowded you literally were bumped the entire time. Second, frankly the number of hawkers and stores even within the stupa itself was a very big turn off; third, well you can chose the monkeys who run across your feet or the pigeons that leave their tidings literally everywhere (including on two women who were on the receiving end in front of me). I will say the view, if you can get to the viewing area through the throng of people was amazing. That said we were pushed constantly to move along and not take up space and time to take pictures. Overall, my opinion as stated in other reviews is other temples and "things to do" are far more interesting and better use of what limited time I had.

Beautiful destination but beware of the monkeys. Monkey Temple was our first sigtseeing destination in Kathmandu and we did thoroughly enjoy it! It is a bit of a climb, there are over 300 steps, so be prepared for that, but once you are up, it is worth it. It is a curious mixture of bhuddist and hindu although officially it is a bhuddist temple. We made it there early in the morning and we think perhaps that is why there were few monkeys and they were all well behaved. We did however meet someone who was bitten by one, so they are obviously not as timid as they appeared. The views from the Tempe are quite something in their own right.

great views and amazing Stupa. one of my favorite places, the Stupa so beautiful and the view of the Kathmandu valley just stunning. The smell of Incense fills the air, Monkeys fooling around and hundreds of pigeons gurgle and leave there little unwelcome gifts to the Stupa. The prayer flags in the winds, the song of om mani padme hum from the souvenir shop and the squeaking of the turning prayer weels..... get an idea? you gotta go!

A must see. Visited this on the first day of the Nepali new year 2070. There were many worshippers up here so it was very crowded, but a great atmosphere. A beautiful stupa. Walked up from the back of the stupa and descended from the front. Be careful when walking down as the dust and grit can make the steps slippery. The top offers some great views of the city. There are also different temples and many stupas to visit. A great visit and a must see for anyone visiting Kathmandu.

Essential visit in Kathmandu. Commonly known as the Monkey Temple, this site is well worth a visit. If the climb up the steps is beyond your abilities, ask a taxi driver to take you to the car park at the opposite side from the steps. There are magnificent views from the top and quite a lot to see. The number of souvenir sellers spoils the tranquility of the site but still a must see in Kathmandu.
Take your water!. It was my third visit. I found it harder climbing this time than in 1998! Remember to take your water! An absolute must for the visitor to Kathmandu.

Kathmandu Panorama. Beautiful view of the city and a fun walk up the steep stairs, especially towards sunset time. Bit saddened at how commercialised it has become at the top, with vendors setting up stalls and playing horrible loud music that didn't suit the beautiful original architecture.
great temple. great temple to see there is quite a few steps to get to the top its worth to see the great view .there is the monks inside the temple praying
Swayambu Stupa. Be prepared to pay an entry fee to go up and see/circumambulate one of 3 self arisen stupas. And there are monkeys.
very nice place. This Stupa has a very nice view of Katmandu, nice temple, it was very interesting! Also there is a lot of monkeys!

Great view of Kathmandu city, full with devotees.. late Feb-Mar 2013Swayambhu Temple -- was a nice walk uphill. Monkeys are everywhere although are not over agressive (as those in Bali's 'monkey' temple). Nevertheless, I kept things well-away from snatch-sight, just in case. Do not need unnecessary-care. View of Kathmandu city is superb and would imagine a visit in the evening will be lovelier. There is a Hindu and Buddhist praying sites on the main stupa ground, very interesting. On the entrance ground, there is a newly built pond with a Buddha statue in the middle where many will try throwing coin into the bowl held.…….. The 'flags' are prayers that are continually said as each flies in the wind....... mantra for peace is written on each. So we have the explanation as we've always wondered why the many flags.
nice view of the kathmandu valley. It has a nice view of the whole Kathmandu valley. It's worth a visit. It also calls monkey temple but the amount of monkey is not as much as I thought :p

Monkey temple. It's like Boudanath stupa with an edge. The edge refers to the hilltop views and the monkeys who are everywhere. Watch out for things they can mistake as food. The climb can be steep and long for the unfit. You have the option of driving to the entrance. You still have to climb a little bit to reach the stupa. Definitely worth it.

Visit at dusk for spectacular sunset views. Wonderful to visit in the evening and watch the sunset over Kathmandu.A couple of guides offered their services, but when I politely refused were not too pushy.Great to wander around at the top, and watch the tourists, locals and monkeys !

Gorgeous View!. The stairs may be a bit steep and hard to climb in the heat but once you get up top, be prepared for a stunning view of the city! Of course the temple itself is beautiful and there are monkeys all over! Worth visiting for sure.

Magnificent view!. One can get a magnificent view of the entire city from the hill, where this temple is situated.I went there in the late evening. So it was quite cold. And there were countless monkeys everywhere!They leave one a bit shaken, but then again the view makes one forget about anything else...

A nice hike and good views of Kathmandu. If you have visited Bodhnath before this one, then the only addition would be the views of Kathmandu valley. There is a small monastery right behind the main temple that is often missed by tourists. There is a small staircase behind the main temple that goes upto this monastery. I spent some time there - it is a very peaceful place and mainly because not enough people make a trip here. The noisy tourists and their cameras are not seen here. Bodhnath is certainly better, but you should visit this one if you have spare time. It is a good short uphill hike too - helps if you are planning to hike in Nepal !

Best place to view Katmandu. We were staying in the popular area of Thamel and it was a short but bumpy rickshaw ride to the base of the hill where the temple is. There are two ways to access it but we preferred, by chance, the steps from the village below the temple. As we approached it we could see the beauty of it dominating the hilltop. There are the ubiquitous hawkers on the way up but they have a living to make and we are tourists with more money than sense some times!On the way in we paid the small entrance fee and then were immediately entrance by the stupa with Buddha's eyes looking over the whole of the city.There are shops, other temples and rooftop restaurants where it is possible to while away a few hours, soak up the atmosphere and decide which way down. We walked down the opposite side past a small shrine in a pond where you can throw small coins and make a wish. The walk this side also takes you past the very poorly maintained Natural History Musuem. It is one of the best temples and places to visit while you are there as it gives ypu on a clear day a birds eye view of Katmandu.

Beautiful but disappointing.. Beautiful temple area with superb hilltop views of the city. However, the entire area has been taken over by market vendors. I could barely get any pictures of the beautiful architecture and historic site without vendors and their cheap made-in-China souvenirs in the background! It was really disappointing and degrading to the meaning of the whole temple area. What a shame!!

2nd to Boudha Stupa. Good view of Kathmandu and environs. More tourists than monkeys. overall less "authentic" in atmosphere than the Boudha Stupa but worth a visit if you can spare the time. Been here before and probably would not return in future.

Awesome view.. You MUST walk all the steps up. Don't let your driver take you up to the top. The walk is the experience. There's also a great cafe (The Nirvana Cafe) tucked behind the square that you have to enter a few doors to find. There's no better place to have an Everest beer and watch the sunset...
Fascinating temples - magnificent location. This was the first temple I visited in Kathmandu - the dome and architecture is marvellous and the culture is fascinating.

Monkey Temple. The temple is at the top of a hill. The views are great on a clear day...... The complex of teples are very interesting but a bit dirty and of course full of monkeys from the forest near by.

Nice temple and setting. The temple is right on top of the mountain. The temple it self is not very special, but the fact that is very much still in use give it a good atmosphere. Arrive early in the morning so that you can enjoy the locals.

Good view and nice place to shop for souvenirs and paintings. There are two entrances to the temple and one has fewer steps than the other so choose what's convenient for you. There are nice souvenir and painting shops here and they are actually cheaper and more genuine than some at Durbar square so do have a look and bargain well to get good deals. I got a nice deal on 2 paintings after heavy bargaining but its truly a steal
Monkeys!. A great place to see monkey's climbing all over a temple. On a non foggy/smoggy day, you have a good view of Kathmandu too. It's my favorite of the temples in the city.

Good overview of Buddhist practices. Close to Thamel, this stupa is a good example of all the parts of a stupa: plinth, prayer flags, spire, eyes of Buddha, butter lamps, bells and prayer wheels. The monkeys roaming the grounds add to the atmosphere.

My fav KTM location. I love monkeys and I love looking out over the city so Swayambhu is my fav place. Please do not eat or drink in Swayambhu unless you want the attention of the local Macaques. If you get thirsty the trick is to sit with someone selling the water and drink there. They all have catapults so will be able to keep the primates away.. If you come in from the back you will see the three Buddhas, Compassion, Knowledge and Power before coming to the 1st mount which is much quiter. then drop to the wishing well in the middle to try your luck getting a coin in the pot then up to the main Stupa and views ... Completely in love with this little island in the valley ...

Beautiful but neglected.. This temple is one of the most beautiful places in Kathmandu, particularly at sunset time. It is very much a working temple although there are a lot of stalls selling trinkets etc. However, as with many other places in Nepal it is neglected, with many of the side buildings in a state of decay and lots of litter and decaying rubbish lying around. It wouldn't take much money or effort to sort this out.
inspiring place. I love to visit there again and again .This is very beautiful and inspiring place spiritually with good views of Kathmandu valley and Himalayas
I loved this place. You must visit the two stuppas. I love this one, with trees all around and the monkeys! Really special! And an amazing view from kathmandu?, you can go by walk also
Must see. I walked from my hotel Shakti and it took me about 45 - 1 hr after getting lost.Entry fee is paid when you are almost at the top.Monkeys everywhere.

Hardly worth seeing. In years gone past I am sure that this temple would have been well worth seeing, but it is now very run down, dirty, and absolutely full of souvenir shops and touts trying to get you to pay them to be your guide (beware, most of them know little about the history or the construction of the temple). The only redeeming feature, is that on a clear day, you will get a great view of the Kathmandu city and valley.

Lots of steps, few monkeys. At least part of the reason we visited was to see the monkeys, but there were only 2 or 3 there when we visited. Even without the monkeys, it's a wonderful place to visit with fantastic views of Kathmandu. There are many steps to climb to get to the top, so it's not for the frail.

hand in pocket again. over -view of KTM & central holy site for locals - Monkeys are a side issue but bit diasppointed in the stalls on site. like most tourist sites we visited in KTM- free for locals but not so for tourists!!!

Nice walk from Thamel. Beautiful temple, totally worth it. Watch out for the monkeys, no drinking or eating or you will have one of them on top of you. You have to pay a fee when you almost up there and tt costed Rs200.
Beautiful place to see. Was fortunate, because it wasnt crowded with tourists. Otherwise visitors do not like it that much. For me it was the best place I have visited in/around KTM.

Nice temple and nice view of the Kathmandu Valley. There are many many stair steps, so you better be fit. The temple itself is very nice. As it is on top of a hill, it gives a clear and nice view of the Valley of Kathmandu.
You can use telescope to view the city (for some fees).
There are some small temporary shops selling souvenir and cd's.
nice view. nice place for a day visit, loitering around the area is fun, especially watching people, either local or traveller.

worth the climb. Even tho the steps are many and steep it's still worth it to see this temple and all the worshipers gathered uptop giving offerings. On a good dayit also allows for a nice view Kathmandu valley if the fog lifts.

Please don't call it the monkey temple. Although there are a lot of monkeys there, it is not a temple to monkeys. The Kathmandu valley was once flooded and when it drained this hill and the stupa remained (that's the short story). You can walk around the bottom of the hill (kora) and/or you can take the 108 steps to the top of the hill. Get to the top if you have time. It's not just a Buddhist site, I think it has other connections.

365 Steps worth taking. An opportunity to share this moment in life with people from all around the world, monkeys and birds all watching one another. There is great meaning, it's worth paying a guide at the bottom to tell the value and intention of all the aspects we notice but don't understand. All the deities and honorable traditions represent and honorable ans sacred place. The vendors on the lower steps offer some amazing hand carvings.
Beautiful view. Love the night panorama view, we saw the beautiful during our recent brief visit to Nepal, hope to come back soon!

A steep climb - but worth it. After you negotiate the stairs,that get steeper the closer you get to the Stupa, take a moment to stop and enjoy the peaceful ambience. People take their walks and the prayer wheels spin, whilst the monkeys take the offerrings back off the shrines to get a mid day snack. A lovely insight into the nepalese way of life.
Monkeys and view. Worth the quick trip and walk. Monkeys everywhere but the didn't attack people, cool temple, nice view form the top.
good stupa. good stupa, and we can see good view of the kathamndu city from the monkey temple, the monasteries around are nice, good to go in sunset time, many monkeys, be careful with them.

Excellent views of the city. You get excellent views of the city from this Temple. The views alone are worth the hike up the 365 steps. The Temple itself is nice; lots of monkeys make the experience special. We had lunch on the top of the hill with outstanding views of the city. I recommend it, even though the food was mediocre.
Good view. Lots of monkeys around, but they are quite harmless. Good view of the Kathmandu city from here, provided it is not hazy.

Tourists, faithful and picnickers mix. I loved the colour, exuberance and spirituality. I'd have liked more monkeys! Going on a Saturday morning meant that it was very crowded with locals but somehow it made it feel more alive. There is a small cafe with steep stairs and good views - and diet coke (which I found rare in Nepal!)There are lots of stairs particularly if you start from the bottom of the hill. we drove -from the car park you are probably 4/5 of the way up.
Wonderful!. From the top you can see enitre Kathmandu Valley! Best place to photograph, talk to people, and has a mix of budhist and hindi temples and statues of both Gods's or deidities!

best sightseeing in Ktm. This temple complex is built on a hill in the center of the town so it affords view of all the city. The main Buddhist dome, white and bright, is surrounded by smaller but very richly decorated temples. There is a lot of movement of devotees there, very interesting.
Lots of Monkey. All was good, the Budist temple and all.. but main problem Monkeys.... lots and lots of monkeys. You have to be very safe and careful. And mostly with your food.

Nice view only. This place is quiet high above the ground and once can see a view of Kathmandu from the top which is quiet nice. Also this place is called the monkey temple as you will find lots of moneys roaming around u which is quiet interesting. One can pay a little visit there if have time.
Historical. Very poorly maintained, hundreds of monkeys walk around, you may trip on them as the lighting in the evening is very low/poor.
Wishing Well. Do make a wish and throw a coin into the wishing well. Do make an attempt to let it fall on the statue.
Swayambhunath Temple. A must see with a great view of the city. Walk there and take the taxi back. Watch out for the monkeys.

Be there for sunset or sunrise. One of the most beautiful temple of Kathmandu. Go there for sunset or sunrise to admire the whole city of Kathmandu and the moutains with a unique sunlight. Do not hesitate to go far on the north side, and take the stairs to the huge three buddhas!

The monkeys are fascinating. This is working Buddhist temple, but the monkeys steal the show. There are hordes of them and they are totally unafraid of humans. This is also a good place to look out over the Kathmandu valley.

Very interesting & great views. Even if you're not interested in religion, like us, then this is still a most interesting place to visit. Known as the Monkey Temple for obvious reasons, there are some fantastic views of the Kathmandu Valley and if you want any Budhist related souvenirs then this is probably one of the best places to visit, having said that the hawkers here did seem a bit more 'pushy' than in other places we visited in Kathmandu.
A Panoramic view. It is situated on a very high point of the city with panoramic views of the valley uam. It is common to find mujito devotees and follow their rites.
Beautiful panaroma view. Am not so much a temple person, but the panaroma valley view from the top is spectacular and breathtaking. Do give it a go!
one of the most sacred site in Nepal. This place is located on a hilllock of Kathmandu valley. It is known as a monkey temple as it has been guarded by a large group of roving monkey for centuries.

Great location with great views of Kathmandu. Quite a climb to reach this stupa but worth it. I loved the prayer wheels. Some nice artists to be found around the stupa. Lots of monkeys--one stole a sweater from a child so be careful!

Monkey Temple on the hill. This is an interesting visit. There are a Hindu temple and Buddhist temple on top of a long flight of stairs which lead through a maze of hawkers and artisans. Watch out for the monkeys, don't feed them and don't look them in the eye as it is seen as aggression. The west side has a temple and a market. There are 3 huge Buddha statues just up from the west market. It is a nice walk around the kora at the base of the mountain in an easy hour. Swayambunath is well worth it for the views over Kathmandu and the valley.

Good exercise to get to the temple!. It was fun to get there after so many steep steps. It's a Buddhist temple on top a hill, with a nice view of the valley of KTM and local handicraft stalls everywhere. There are plenty of monkeys around, so beware pickpocketing

The "Monkey Temple" is worth walking up the stairs. Take a taxi to the back side of the side and avoid walking up the 300+ stairs; this Buddhist temple is unique and worth a couple of hours. A population of monkeys live at the site.
Holy Hill. Rising abruptly from the city is the Monkey Temple, small shrines, a large stupa, great views, and a sense of floating above the busy city below.

Monkey Temple. Getting past the scam artists wanting to give you a tour of any facility you can imagine, I actually did hire one of these guys to show me around the temple. It was very impressive, and had an active Buddhist Monastery where you could visit and observe them during devotions. The temple is 1/2 Hindu and 1/2 Buddhist in nature, each side coexisting with the other. The monkeys had free reign in the "Monkey Pool", and it was fun watching the little critters play. The bad part is the hawksters (as always) getting in your face to buy their stuff; this is helped along by the "guides" steering you into their friends stall.

Also called monkeytemple. Very old and impressive temple with lots to seeYou can climb all the stairs from down street but also it is possible to let you drop off by taxi, especially when you re not able to climb all these stairs.Very nice shops around the temples and also a spectical view off KathmanduWhen you re down the street again it is closeby to visit Budda park where you can walk around 3 special Boeddha statueesAlso very impressive to see

Must visit. 365 steps to reach the top. There's a shortcut but this is Kathmandu so take the stairs and experience it to the fullest. Monkeys are everywhere but ignore them and you would be fine. Entrance fee is 200 rupees. The place itself is amazing. It's ancient, religious, cultural and historical. It's better to have a local guide who could explain it to you what the place is all about. That's the best way to experience it.

Magical, Magnificent View, Very Religious, Must Visited Attraction in Kathmandu. This place is amazing. If you can climb stairs, for sure, take the stairs from east. Taxi from Thamel should be 150 to 300. Get water from entrance area. There are many monkeys (big and small) on your way. Avoid eating snack bars or any obvious food. They are very smart and will surround you in matter of seconds! If happened, just through the food to them!Get your ticket after payment as you can come back here without further payment. I guess the person should stamp it with your passport and visa number on back side.The temple at top is amazing. You can see serious prayers going around the main temple clockwise; bending, kneeing and lying down on the floor again and again and again. Lots of Respect.The view to the city is amazing. If you have read about the history of this place, try imagining the ancient lake and how shiva was overlooking the valley.There are many birds of prey flying around and coming down on surrounding trees.You can hang around here for couple of hours, depends to your interests in history.Very interesting sight.Totally Recommended.

definitely worth a visit. very atmospheric. full of monkeys & worshipers and a nice bit of exercise up the many steps! we bought some lovely slate carvings from one of the local artists. salesmen here are friendly and not too pushy. put away any snack before you reach this temple as the monkeys can be quite aggressive if they see food!

Fantastic location - great views!. It's a really beautifully located temple - above Kathmandu overwhelming smog, it allows you to get a deep breath of fresh air - finally! If you are fit enough then don't go by taxi - take stairs, there are beautiful Buddha monuments on the way up, monkeys and a few places to rest for a while. Great photo opportunities also! Don't forget to take something to drink! The stupa itself is impressive - very big with a lot of smaller ones around. Great views over the city, especially if you happen to be there on a clear day. I found craft shops there to be a bit less expensive than in the city so maybe it will be a good opportunity for you to buy some souvenirs.

A lively, interesting and spiritual place that overlooks Kathmandu. This place was amazing. An amalgam of Buddism and Hinduism. I loved it. Colourful prayer flags, lots of monkeys, people selling their wares, the sounds of chanting, monks going about their daily business and many visitors, both local and from far afield. It made for a fascinating and rich experience.
Beautiful place. Unusual Buddhist atmosphere. View on entire Kathmandu. Close Thamel, 30 minutes walk. Exceptional souvenirs. You will take beautiful pictures

Great place to while away an hour. Soaring temples, prayer flags, monkeys, great views over Katmandu. You don't need a guide your guide book will do. A bit of hassle from hawkers but not really in your face. Worth the effort to climb up to the temple especially on a clear day.

Monkey Temple. On a clear day an excellent view back down into Kathmandu; in January quite a bit of smoke in the air and the view was limited.The term Monkey Temple is well deserved; they are everywhere but not overly agressive as I have experienced at Hindu Temples on Bali.In many ways it reminded me of Wat Phrathat Doi Suthep in Chiang Mai Thailand. However, not quite as big or ornate.

Best view of the Kathmandu city. Not well maintained but worth seeing as you get the birds eye view of the valley and the Kathmandu city looks beautiful in the evening when the city is fully lit. Beware about monkeys which move in gangs and are present in big number. Lots of shops selling Nepali handicrafts and paintings.

Monkeys, Monkeys, Monkeys!. Awesome monkey temple, which we visited as a birthday surprise. Take a taxi from Thamel for about 300rps and walk up a huge set of stairs to the beautiful temple at the top. Great views of the city, lots of playful and cheeky monkeys (they will steel your food) and plenty of souvenir shops. It does cost 200 rps per person for foreigners though but worth it. Give yourself at least an hour.

Terrific. One dreams of being part of this city and its sites - i have been lucky to have been here twice.When you are up close you will experience the rich history and spiritual energy of this place.World class attraction and a definite must see.
Another Historic Site. Like Boudanath Stupa, this is one of the most important Buddhist sites in Kathmandu. My 7 adopted Buddhist Nun granddaughters accompanied us and made this a memorable visit.

Best place to visit for religious experience and best view of the Valley. This place is also called Monkey Temple obviously because there are lot of monkeys on this hill. The temple is situated on top of the hill with the best view of the Kathmandu valley. Go in the morning or in the evening for fantastic of sunrise/set. One can also climb the stairs to reach the temple.
