It's a good cardio and they will be rewarded with the pleasant view of the valley, beautiful stupas, temples, galore of gift shops and nice restaurants and cafes. I really enjoyed this place. We made a decision at the last minute to visit this place due to limited time and we are glad we visited this place. Must see place if you are in Kathmandu valley. Please do not feed Monkeys.
The monkey Temple. It was great, but may be crowd of venders should be reduced. Except That great place itself and to view the city as it lies on the top of hill.

Make your wish come true at the Monkey Temple. It is believed that if you go there and make a wish. You wish comes true. The temple is build on a mountain and when you climb up you meet stupas and smaller temples. Very impressive. Be careful from the gangs of monkeys that snatch every thing that looks like food. the view at the top is very spiritual as the temple is frequently visited by local people.

Also Known as the Monkey Temple.. Beautiful! Great pictures to be had here. This is the temple that can be seen on the lonely planet cover. At least of the version I had. There will be monkeys all around but they don't interact much with visitors. Free bathrooms for foreigners. Also, at the entrance there is a small fountain where people try to toss a coin into the center bucket for world peace. This would be a nice place to take kids as well.
Go in the early morning. We went in the early morning when the place was still half empty - not too many vendors, not too many tourists, yet beautiful views and an amazing experience.
A high, high point. While in Kathmandu you must see this temple if only for the magnificent views of the city it offers.

If you see just one thing in Kathmandu, let it be Swayambhunath. We named our new and very precious miniature foal Swayambhu as a lasting reminder of this extraordinary place. The monkeys certainly add to the atmosphere but there's also the views and palpable history.

The most Attractive in Kathmandu!. It is a must visit in Kathmandu. Big dome and a lot of Tibetan people. The people counting beads and praying makes the environment religious. Also i saw some of the western monks meditating and reading in the temple premises. I enjoyed one full afternoon here as many restaurant are available for hot tea in this cold weather of Kathmandu!

Hilltop Temple. Offering splendid view of the Kathmandu city from the hilltop, Swayambhunath temple (also known as Monkey Temple) was another World Heritage site in Kathmandu, quite popular among tourists.It was fun testing our aiming skills throwing NPR 1 coins in the donation vessel inside the water fountain at the entrance. The temple has a stupa and smaller temples. There are 2 access points, one from the east which is much longer with 365 steps while another from the south is much shorter.There are many shops selling beautiful handicrafts and local work of art - especially the paintings were worth a deko.

Awesome visit, monkeys, Buddha eyes, and a view. This was one of our first sights in Kathmandu, and one of the most memorable. The temple is beautiful itself, those Buddha eyes on the golden temple with the thousands of colorful flags draped along the temple and the trees are very interesting to look at. Many people were worshiping at the temple, but it wasn't over-crowded. You need to watch out for the monkeys, but they really cute to see. There was more shopping there than I might expect, it kind of ruins the feel, but there are some interesting buys. From the temple, you can see a very nice view of the city.
Well worth a visit. Took a private car but could arrange public transport. Was very interesting, good hour spent here. The kids were fascinated with the temple.

ancient -great feeling. Everything from the narrow streets to the people , monkeys;craftsmanship,night life;safety;food;heritage spots ;cycle rickshaws; gift articles esp great bags window shopping and the monasteries and temples
Not to be missed. Part County Fair, part religious pilgrimage sight, part shopping opportunity. Like no place else. It is a fun place. The monkeys were plentiful but not aggressive.

Not to be missed. Known by tourists as Monkey Temple this ancient temple and monument is a must see if visiting Kathmandu. There are many monuments to see on the complex, the most famous being the stupa at the very top of the hill overlooking the city. There are various places to stop, sit down and enjoy the atmosphere and views of Kathmandu city whilst watching the monkeys go wild, although I would avoid eating anywhere on the complex as the monkeys are very tame and unphased by humans and are quick to steal from naive picknickers - you may increase your chances of being attacked by a lot of monkeys!There are many ways to get to the complex; local bus costs 15 rupees, private taxis obviously more, or you could walk up to the temple and see much more of local life along the way.
Monkey Temple. Very interesting place with wonderful view in clear day on all Kathmandu and mountains in distance. Not very clean, but do not pay attention to it if you want to enjoy local culture

Lovely place for sunrise. Walked here from Durbar Sq to watch sunrise. Full of people doing exercise and daily rituals.
Also known as Monkey Temple, early on a morning it is full of monkeys!

Great Views of Kathmandu. This is one of the landmark places of Kathmandu. There are an amazing set of stairs to the top, where you can find some great views. Around the bottom of the temple, there is a large Kora round, that has some interesting temples and statues to see, so this is worth doing a circuit of as well. This would take some time to walk right around.Only downside is all the people trying to hussle tourists here.

One of the best View poing of the town.. The Great Stupa of Swayamvu is the wonder that was Nepal, the glory that was Nepal. It is indeed listed a World Heritage Site of Culture to prove that it serves as the nerve center of faithful worship for all the devout Buddhists of the universe.

A panoramic view point of Kathmadu with Buddhist tone. Not only for those people who believe in Buddhism, it's a mind blowing place for all the human beings. From there we can get inspiration to live as human being. All the ancient infractures push us to show a kindness in thinking, believing and helping. Buddhism is not a religion, it is way of living which keeps us happy, satisfied and healthy. It keeps our society peace, fearless and disciplined.

Another Must Do when in Kathmandu. A great way to start your trip is to walk from Thamel down to Durbar Square, have lunch there and then walk accross to Swayambhunath Temple. Great way to get to know the city. Great views form the Temple, enjoy the walk up the steep steps and look out for the monkeys.

Great temple. I love this place, always buzzing, particularly in the early morning- you can join in chanting next to the main stupa. Monkey watching a good way to spend the time, and lots of little hidden areas to explore. Good cheap momos in the little cafes around, and good place to get incense etc at a cheap price.

vast temple mixing Hinduism and Buddhism!. Once arriving you would be welcomed by monkeys, thus the nickname of the place (Monkey Temple). The place is quite vast and worth spending a couple of hours, it mixes temples, buidlings and constructions of Hinduism and Buddhism styles, carries a mystical atmosphere, and offers stunning views over the city. Definitively worth a visit!!

great view of Kathmandu from this place... Climb up lots of steps to reach the stupa area.From the top you can see almost the whole Kathmandu view, very nice during sunsets.This is one great place for photographer, my suggestion is the best time on morning and evening.I've been there on both time, great lighting.

Good to go but not a must. Had a good time walking up the stairs, thats the only peaceful and introspecting moment here. Once at the top you will be greeted by hordes of monkey's and do not be fooled by their cuteness, they are used to being aggressiveness particularly if they smell food or see you carrying some satchel or bags. Place does offer a nice view of the city afar. Good to visit for the first time, do not see any sense in a revisit.

Set aside 3-hours. Referred to as the "Monkey Temple", this site in Kathmandu is a "must-see" sacred site. What makes it compelling is the temple contains both Hindu and Buddhist shrines and stupas. It helps explain why the Nepalese people are widely tolerant of everyone's religious choice regardless of faith. If all people were equally understanding there would be far less conflict in the world today. The site is quite large and takes at minimum of several hours to see, but give yourself another hour or two so as to walk around the entire complex. There's lots of shop selling just about everything, prices are good - actually some of the best we found on the trip. Be sure to barter - meaning walk away the first two times. Do that and you'll for sure know what to pay, but a good spot to buy a few things for family and friends. We toured the site as part of a day using a rented vehicle and driver, but its easy to find by walking. I need to revisit this site next time in Kathmandu.

If you are strong.. walk. The guide books will tell you how amazing this temple is on it's hill. Walking up the front steps past the monkeys is a "pilgrimage" But I'd recommend if you're strong, and adventurous that you walk from Thamel. Find the Chetrapati chouk (crossroads) and head down to the river, cross a bridge then do not walk up the street. Find a series of narrow steps that will lead you up to the foot of the temple steps. This will lead past ghats (cremation temples) and many mini temples. Take water this is hot dusty and long 1-2 hours. Not touristy.. gritty and real Nepal.
beautiful wood. not as special as other places we visited, not as well looked after maybe, little access, just too ground level, upper level was closed.

Number 2 in Kathmandu. If you must choose, go to Bodnath. But if you have the time, by all means climb the pilgrim stairs and enjoy the atmosphere and the fabulous views from the top of the hill. We took the long stairs up and the short ones down and circled the stupa area. It lacks the grandeur and serenity of Bodnath, but is filled with gaiety and joy.
Well worth the climb. An energising clamber up the steps rewards you with fantastic views of the city. We were there at sunset, and it does you good to climb up above the smog.

A little overrated. Compared to so many other similar religious sites I found this a little disappointing. I thought it was worth a visit, but didn't dwell here too long. In contrast to Bodnath Stupa, where I felt refreshed when reluctantly leaving it, I couldn't get out of here fast enough. i felt I was "ticking a box" instead of exploring another culture's spirituality.

Great place to spend evening view. Was there suggestion by Silver Home staff first day of my evening time was so nice view. Start down step is little hard to be on top but you will see amazing sunset view and can play with monkey too if you are not afraid with them hehe. I m glad to be there and still okey entrance fee for tourist then other temple. Anyway all of travelers not missed this temple once you in Kathmandu.

Watch out for the students wanting money as guides!. Even busier than Bodnath Stupa, the lookalike Yogis nearly fooled me, they ask for money having had their picture taken, the public toilets are a no go zone, they are a hole in the ground with no water to flush. the open-water raft burning burials are a site as well as the monkeys that roam free all over the site

Excellent place to visit day and night. This had history, location and atmosphere (spiritual and architectural) and was easy to get to with stunning views. It was a little hard climbing to the top, but well worth the effort, and the climb gave you time to look at different parts of the city on the way up.

If you survive the hundreds of stairs..... If you go to Katmandu and don't visit this tempe , something is wrong with you!There's a fee for the entrance, but it's well worth it, if you survive the crazy amount of stairs to the top, you'll be happy you've made it!Amazing views, amazing statues, little temples, and crazy monkeys! Not to be missed!

Great, but beware of monkey. This is a very big temple complex on a hill, in the hearth of Kathmandu. Ity, not far from Thamel (20 minutes by taxi, 45 if you walk). The entire complex is very interesting and full of things to see so take a half day. There are places restaurants too, but beware of monkey, they snatch any food they can!
Stunning Views!. It was good to have a guide when visiting Swayambhunath Temple. The views are beautiful, you can see Kathmandu from above. There were monkeys everywhere.

Night visit, magical!. I visited this place at night time, it's was magical to see the temple with the lighting around it and you also have a view of the city from up there, it's beautiful. It was very impressive to walk down the stairs with the monkeys jumping all around us.

Approach this temple using the Steps.. We visited this temple on a free day, we walked from Thamel. Fascinating place to visit, with a good outlook over Kathmandu Valley. We enjoyed the photographic opportunities with the resident monkeys.
A must do!. If you go to Nepal, yo have to go there! The stairs up give the experience a special touch. Also, a lot of monkeys!

The monkey temple is worth the stairs. After climbing what feels like an endless set of stairs, you are greeted with a panoramic view of the city and an amazing temple. You're surrounded by monkeys that are treated as holy beings and you can watch as they are fed crushed berries and fruit. You can also find souvenirs and a nice meal at the top. Definitely worth the hike up. It is a well maintained temple.
i lived near here for months..... i was there 4 the buddha's birthday,totally amazing!!!i fall in love with swayambhunath,it's the most beautiful temple in Kath!!!

A bit overrated. We traveled to Monkey Temple on a cloudy day with a guide through intrepid. While he was very informing the temple did not astonish us beyond belief. The monkeys were good to watch but got old fast. Would'nt say it is a must do attraction. Durbar Square was much more fullfilling
Never Miss This!. Even though this was my second trip here I loved the sights and the smells!Do read about the culture before coming here and do behavve!
Worth a second chance. I did visit this temple twice for photographic purposes and the second time it was much cleaner.Lots of steps, so take it easy and watch out for the monkeys!
A must see. This was one of my favorite temples in the Kathmandu Valley. I would highly recommend this to anyone staying in the valley.

Swayambhunath. Swayambhunath is an ancient religious complex atop a hill in the Kathmandu Valley, west of Kathmandu city. It is also known as the Monkey Temple as there are holy monkeys living in the north-west parts of the temple.The Swayambhunath complex consists of a stupa, a variety of shrines and temples, some dating back to the Licchavi period.The stupa has Buddha's eyes and eyebrows painted on. Between them, there is something painted which looks like the nose - but is the Nepali symbol of 'unity'.There are also shops, restaurants and hostels. The site has two access points: a long stairway, claimed to have 365 steps, leading directly to the main platform of the temple, which is from the top of the hill to the east; and a car road around the hill from the south leading to the southwest entrance. The first sight on reaching the top of the stairway is the Vajra.According to Swayambhu Purana, the entire valley was once filled with an enormous lake, out of which grew a lotus. The valley came to be known as Swayambhu, meaning "Self-Created." The name comes from an eternal self-existent flame (swayaṃbhu) over which a stupa was later built.Each morning before dawn hundreds of Buddhist (Vajrayana) and Hindu pilgrims ascend the 365 steps from eastern side that lead up the hill, passing the gilded Vajra (Tibetan: Dorje) and two lions guarding the entrance, and begin a series of clockwise circumambulations of the stupa.

Monkeys. This temple is an old favorite and located in a beautiful part of town with nice view of Kathmandu valley. There are many symbolisms here so a guide would be good to explain them. Try you luck in throwing a coin into the container in the fountain. You can change notes for coins with a nearby vendor selling coins.

Fascinating.. Well worth climbing all those steps to see this wonderful Stupa. Surrounded by lots of shrines and other aspects of Nepalese culture. Be sure to pop into the monastery late afternoon to quietly observe the monks ceremony. the views from the stupa are amazing and the monkeys are great fun to watch. A visit well worth the mony.

Monkeys, monkeys and fun. There are many places in Katmandu that are attractions for tourists. My vote goes for this place - also called Monkey Temple and rightly so - is a spot you should never miss out before you return. If you don't mind a good climb, go from eastern side. If you don't want to climb follow the western side. But be there. They have entrance fee but worth it.

Beautiful temple and city views. It is a little hike up the stairs, but provides wide vistas over the city.The worshippers, monkeys and merchants at the temple provide a myriad of colors and sights with ample photo opportunities.Unfortunately there is a NPR 200 fee for foreigners ($2.5 USD).

Spiritual. Its a hugh stupa. Its really nice coz it is still a spiritual place for all the local Nepalese so you can see the way they pray. It is different from taoism which is widely practised in Malaysia.Lots of souvenirs there as well but I can verify if the pricing is good or not. But the business people there are very professional, they are friendly and they don't pester you when you are just browsing.At the top, you can get a really good view if how large Kathmandu city is too although it looked as if it is covered by smog.We were there pretty early at about 8.30 am and the place us buzzing. For those who are not fit, its better to cheat and drive up 90% of the way! ;pThe stairs are pretty steep so do be careful when you are going down.Lots of monkeys but we were not bothered by them. Either you get out of their way or they will just casually walk past you.
Worth a visit. The site offers something for everyone... for the curious, the casual visitor, practitioners and locals. It was great to go up by taxi and walk down
stunning view and calm atmosphere. extraordinary views from peaceful religious site is a perfect visit if you have just a few hours to spend.

Religiously amazing!. Most of my trips seem to be amazing mainly because I have come back with an overdose of Culture and the same applies here! Culturally and Religiously, it has a lot to offer! Though the monkeys are some people you ought to be careful of! There was a festival going on because there were the Bhajans being played it was a nice place to be at! I had an amazing view of this temple from my room at the Radisson!
Nice view. Taxi from Thamel is 200, back 100 in Dez. 2012Lots of Touristsouveniersellers around, but the view ist awsome.
A little late to see it.. We were there after dark, so could not see much except for lots of monkeys. But we had a treat to some Bhajans.

One of my places to visit while I was in Kathmandu.. Swayambhunath temple, the famous pilgrimage for Buddist and no doubt also for hindu. And the followers of all religions are welcomed here. when I was in kathmandu for pursuing my higher studies, Swayambhunath which is situated at Swoyambhu, Kathmandu was just Rupess 10 away distance for me. It is situated at the top of a hill. From where, we can enjoy beautiful panorama of Kathmandu City.

great place but watch out. it was all good great place for the day the only thing i found not too good was the way some shop owners swapped the goods you buy for much lesser quality ones so watch out for that especially singing bowls sellers down the steps on the leftnot honest !!!
Must Do in K'd. Blow by the vendors on the way up. Bask in the uniqueness of this ancient Newar temple and vistas at the summit. Great in early morning or late afternoon.

A stupa where the views are amazing.. A stupa located at elevation, approximately 100 steps up, not only is the stupa and the immediate interesting, but you have a wonderful view of Kathmandu as well.

A Must See. Once you get to the top of about 300 steps (or 150 steps if you take a cab up to the base. Note, there are no elevators to help with handicapped people that I saw), you have a view of the entirety of Kathmandu. It's quite breathtaking.The temple itself is also gorgeous with various structures and religious monuments incorporated into the entire temple. I think the only issue I may have had is that 1/2 the temple has been turned into what seems to be a marketplace, like Thamel, for tourists to by lousy crafts. Regardless, 100% worth seeing.
A great mountaintop view. There were some interesting shops here. Don't bring all your money if you don't want to spend it. As all the attractions, the best pictures are early in the day, or later.
spiritual. Like: its ancient historical & cultural upkeep &the Nepalese people's dedication towards spiritualism.Dislike:nil
Nice. Good view of the valley and city from the top.Reasonably clean place and public toilet.Monkeys were not vicious to tourists.Nice little enclave selling stuff.

Ancient temple high on the hillside. This is one of the handful of Kathmandu sites that must be seen. Appropriately called the monkey temple, you will see ancient temples, a view of Kathmandu and the monkeys and eagles.
Nice temple. With more than 500 steps to reach the temple. It was a good practice for us before we started our trek to everest base camp. You also get a nice 360 degree view of Kathmandu valley

Worth climbing there.. The temple is located at the top of a hill and offers an amazing view over the entire city of Katmandu. The entrance is 2OO rupees for tourists (under 2€) making it the least expensive of all the main temple in the city : others like Pashupatinath, Bodnath, Patan and Durbar square range from 500 up to 750 Nrs. I don't understand why because this site with its numerous temples, amazing architecture, breathtaking view, photo friendly monkeys everywhere and magnificent statues clearly is a site not to be missed. Make sure to walk down the stairs opposite the main entrance to discover the garden and the three different gigantic boudha statues at the bottom.

don't feed the monkeys!. quaint, ornate, amazing and such an incredibly holy place. do not, under any circumstance, take any food out of your bag when walking up. You could otherwise be hounded by a gazillion aggressive monkeys!

Monkey Temple. This is worth a visit if you are in Kathmandu. Like it's nickname, there are numerous monkeys that run around the stupa. The hike up the stairs to the top is long, but there are nice views along the way.

Peaceful. Another place of beauty, peace and history. On a hillside outside Kathmandu. The air is clean. Some people did the pilgramage up all the steps but we cheated and got a taxi to the top. Well worth it for the view.
The view from the Monkey Temple is fantastic. The view from the Monkey Temple is fantastic. You can see over the valley. Got some neat prayer wheels and singing prayer bowls from the vendors too.

Not bad, but there are better alternatives. This Buddhist temple is a standard attraction, but Bodnath is a similar and more impressive temple and Pashupatinath has more monkeys, so if you are short on time I would skip this and see those instead. Also, be sure to haggle with vendors -- you probably shouldn't pay more than a third to a half of what they first ask.

Panaromic view of Kathmandu Valley is the plus point. The plus point for climbing up the flight of steps to Swayambhunath Temple will be the panaromic view of Kathmandu Valley. On a sunny clear blue morning, the view is beautiful with eagles soaring in the sky.

Splendid View of the KTM valley. Its nice to come out here in the evenings..you can feel the temperature drop by then..but then again it depends on which month you choose to visit this place..weekends and weekdays are crowded..lots of Nepali school kids roam about in their uniforms adding color to this temple.Monkeys are everywhere so be please apply caution..And at times there will be a monkey+dog fight believe me! Many shops selling souvenirs and handicrafts..when approached by the vendors please dont be rude to them and just say no if you are not interested in making any purchase..they are just trying to make a living..life in Nepal is not easy hey..Having said that this is a good lookout point and you can feel the cool breeze once you are on top of the hill for which you have to climb up some steps..but once you are up there the view is rewarding...when i was there i had the opportunity to speak to some monks about their life choice to become a monk and it was a good experience..All in all its worth a visit
The Monkey temple. It is a beautiful Buddhist temple with many shrines around it. There are monkeys everywhere to add some interest to it.

Symbol of Nepal. This is a buddhist temple, it is said to be more than 2000 years old, painted with 4 side of the spire's basewith all seeing eyes. Due to it situated on the top of a hill, you can have a good view of Kamanthu Valley.

Monkey Temple. The Monkey Temple is awesome. Great place to go at sunset (which is when we went). You get amazing views of the Kathmandu Valley, the temple is beautiful, the shops are pretty nice, and there are monkeys EVERYWHERE. It's worth it just to see the monkeys, but everything else makes it one of the best stops in Kathmandu. Quick walk (2 miles maybe) from Thamel if you don't mind walking a bit.

not spiritual, teeming with monkeys, people and tourist shops. Fantastic views of the city (in the smog) but otherwise we thought not worth its reputation as a'must see' of Katmandu. Having just trekked and seen beautifil peaceful monasteries, this place was noisy, crowded, full of shops and vendors of drek that Westerners would never buy, and the least spiritual place we visited.

Too much of a tourist attraction to enjoy!. Noted that it was our last day, that our flight was at 11pm and we were over doing the 'touristy' stuff we forced ourselves to go to Monkey temple. Already scarred by a walk past the golf course near the airport where the monkeys ruled the roost, I was scared by the furry mammals. Needless to say the place was peaceful, despite the rabid dogs and annoying yankees. Much more exciting places to visit out of Thamel.

Climb the steps!. 365 steps to the top - steep and a little tiring - but worth the views of the city from the top (or just take a taxi to the back entrance!) Good views, active temple so there are people engaging in prayer. Don't be a dick and take pictures of people while they are worshiping - that's rude!

Great palace to be. The Swoyambhunath a great place to be on your visit to Nepal. I would recommend anyone to visit there specially in the morning time not more crowded and nice view of all there city.You can enjoy with them monkeys there and lot of buddhist people around the stupa. A good recommendation buying souvenir.
on top of small hill in Kathmandu. Great valley view from the temple area. lots of monkies around and great nepali architecture and crafts. very peaceful place.

monkeys. This is the stuff postcards are made from. The walk up the stairs makes it rewarding. Love all the monkeys. you are accosted by people selling stuff. once inside the sight is incredible. A great view of Kathmandu. This is a must see.
Partial Access. You can watch cremations along the riverfront...but there's no access to the temple area to see the rituals or interior decor.
Must visit. The view from the moutain was so nice, you may see the whole katimandu view from the top of the moutain.

a climb to the top. we took the short cut where our car nearly took us to the top. the balance few steps though did take our breath away both with the climb and the view thereafter. tried some local tea there at a small cafe .. the people were as warm as the cosy dining place.
What a temple! Of another world!. A very contemplative place in the midst of a bustling city. Just of another world. What makes it special is that it is not overrun by mass tourism.

loved it. really, really great experience...touristy, yes, but still a lot of fun. i actually bumped into a friend of mine from the other side of the world due to its popularity. take pictures of the monkies, Kdu and of the many stupas and prayer flags, negotiate on anything you buy there.
A must see while in Kathmandu. Very close and to the city, easy to get to and a beautiful and interesting temple. Be careful of the monkeys. There's lots of them and they're hungry.

'Must do' in Kathmandu. A little tip:
Allow some decent time to hang out around the stupa at the top, browse the stalls and have a cup of tea or snack checking out the views from the Terrace Restaurant.

Me & the monkeys!. So much to see here from one of the most elevated spots in Kathmandu. Temples, monkeys, craft sellers, Bhuddist flags, great views of the city and much more. Careful with your food & drink - the monkeys will snap it from your hand. Expect to hear screams from female tourists every 10 to 15 mins as they become the latest victims of monkey surprise attacks!The soaring Kestrels were maybe my best memory, and some of my best photo shots. Don't forget the 300mm lens! Next time I return will do so at night to get shots of the Kathmandu lights. But not too late as the electricity gets cut at approx 10 to 11pm each night and the city descends into darkness.Do not visit Kathmandu and miss this temple treat!
Mountain of monkey king. Ther are a lot of temples there. Buddist and Hindu. Many tombs of saints who realised the body of light and leave only hair and nails after death. and monkeys everywhere

also very old temple complex. it is very interesting,but there are many steps to clime.if you have difficulties with this youcan askdriver to drop you off on higher level.also many many shops here and lots toseeand buy

Temple of the monkeys. Yes, there is a few monkeys. And plenty more cool things to see. If you have time make your start from the back entry, travel up the stairs to the left, there is some lovely statues and prayer wheel houses along the way that are worth seeing.

beautiful!. another site not to miss when going to Kathmandu, although there are a lot of sales going on on the way and even on the stupa grounds, it is still a wonderful experience. and the view of the Valley is a great one as well. well worth the trip!

Monkey Temple. Its a nice walk up to the temple itself enjoying the antics of the locals, Both with and without tails. The Stupa and the views are excellent. Take the time to relax and reflect on life, Its shorter than you think
great views. after puffing and panting up hundreds of steps you are rewarded with spectacular views all over Kathmandu from one of the highest points
Monkeys!!. Brilliant - we missed the view over the valley because of the weather but enjoyed it all the same. Bought prayer flags from here and had them blessed at a monastery.

Monkeyland. The hill it sits offers incredible views of the city. This alone makes it worthy of a visit for the pictures. The temple is similar to just about any you would come across in Nepal. I'm sure if I were more educated in their history I would appreciate it more. The monkeys are abundant (and safe). We sat & watched them dive into a pool for a good while. Definitely one of the highlights of Kathmandu

Worth climbing the stairs :). I would recommend you to enter through the back gate if u don't want to climb 350 stairs.. But is is really worth..Beware of monkeys and do not carry food (one of them stole a tourist's samosa from his hand!!!) I would recommend not to carry anything in hand that might look like food :) Stupa and temple are very beautiful.. You can find cheap souvenirs from the stall that is exactly in front of the temple gate on the right. Entrance to the stupa was 100 or 200 NPR per person...

Holiest Buddhist Chaityas. A must see to see why this chaityas is the holiest and why so many buddhist faithful visit here. To visit this and realize it is over 2000 years is very impactful. Also there are many monkeys that live around the Swayambhunath temple. You could spend an hour watching them and how they interact with the visitors.

Swayambunath - Monkey Temple worth a visit. Have you ever seen monkeys up close and personal? They are scrambling all over the temple. The temple itself was interesting and historic but the monkeys make the attraction more fun. Climb the many steps up the front of the Temple instead of walking around from the bus park. Great views of Kathmandu valley. Also, if you have time, I recommend walking 10 minutes up the road to "Ring Road" to see the 3 big buddhas. It's free and worth the short walk. Along the way, stop at "Fine Bakery" for lunch. Great, sandwiches and spaghetti.

Also called monkey temple.. The monkeys were abundant, and fighting during our visit (breeding season). The temples themselves were well worth the visit, and you are also to get an overall view of Kathmandu and the surrounding area.

For your own peace. Everybody must visit here. You can see stupa already from far, because it is situated on a hill. Buddhist one, but hindu,too. Good view to the Kathmandu valley. Entrance fee, unfortunately. Small but nice restaurant backside. Put your own candle to monastery.
Well worth the trip. I love the peacefulness and location of this temple. Another treasure worth going to many times in Kathmandu.

Worth a visit. I preferred the Bodnath Temple to this one generally but this one had the obvious benefit of the views at the top which were pretty awesome. The monkeys and their facilities (including a swimming pool!) were also quite cool to see.

Aeons. It is a great adventure to wallk around the stupa at the street level, as you weave in and out of villages and shops and other people's lives. At the top, there are relics of many belief systems, all still venerated, living side by side in peace and fulfilment.

Worth the Climb. The view is spectacular, the temple is very old and rustic- worth to see. The climb itself is a real challenge so be sure that you are fit and have bottle of water in hand and take your time walking up the steps.

Swayambhunath - The Monkey Temple. As expected there were lots of monkeys but at no stage was I ever threatened by them. Some good advice, DON'T carry any food in your hands and the monkeys will leave you alone! The antics of the monkeys were funny. The views from the temple over Kathmandu are fantastic and well worth the effort. There is another way to get to the top without climbing ALL the stairs which is very helpful if you are not planning on proving your fitness. Be prepared for the hawkers that line the steps but a simple "No" is enough for them to leave you alone.
A superb sight to visit, not least for the views over Kathmandu. Be prepaered for hawkers all along the steps but a simple no thanks seems to send them on their way without further hassle!

Great views, steep approach. This temple (aka the monkey temple) can be reached on foot from Thamel, across a bridge and up some fairly steep climbs. There are a very few signs for the temple in the streets in Thamel, and it would be fairly easy to get lost, but it's worth persisting (takes, say, 30 minutes). On the right, just after the bridge, there is an initial small temple you can visit. On the bridge, stop and view the huge accumulation of garbage (plastic bags etc) in the water and ponder whether tourism and development have been a benefit for this city? Indeed, you can ponder this almost everywhere in Kathmandu.Once at the Swayambhu Temple, there are two entrances - the very steep-stepped "town side" entrance, which is quite a challenge to climb, steep steps and lots of them, and a rather more gentle approach from behind the temple, where it seems most transport drops and picks up. Access for people with mobility problems would be very difficult. As you'd expect, there are numerous monkeys (Macaques?) around. We're not great fans of monkeys - as we have a lot of these critters where we live at home - but they seem on the whole reasonably docile and we didn't witness any confrontations or monkey bag-snatches that sometimes occur elsewhere. They are of course great climbers and get everywhere. In many places, the adult males (especially) can be aggressive. In general, it's a big mistake to feed monkeys - it has changed their habits, made them pretty fearless and demanding, and also the food people give them is often bad for them. But, nevertheless, people do so ....We noticed some people were charged an entry fee both at the bottom of the steep steps (NRs150?) and again at an official post near the top (NRs200), and we heard some students complaining about this. Most likely only the NRs200 collected at the top (or at the entrance gate at the more gentle approach) is official. Gifts and artifacts at the top are of course overpriced. Bargaining no doubt would work, if you really want to buy things. But this temple is really a place for the views over the Kath. Valley, where you can see the extended views but also, sadly, the air pollution.If you go back by taxi, of course, these need careful bargaining and many are not in great condition.

Swayambhunath Temple. Interesting place. The stairs could be a challenge for those who don't intend trekking during their stay! You may be lucky to be there when the monks are praying and beating the gongs and blowing those horns. Take a taxi, don't walk - streets are congested, the air's polluted and it's a bit away from Thamel.

Beautiful place. Excellent beautiful place, monkeys there on your way up, be careful with your things.Nice view of the Kathmandu city from a top.Monk prayers can be seen in the monasteryA lot of things for sale at the temple, but very expensive, must bargain a lot.

Don't miss the monkey pool. It's a major sight for those interested in history, temples, understanding cultures and wanting to see the surrounding city and valley from a prominent hill. But while you're there, be sure to check out the monkey swimming pool. I was attracted to it to find the source of laughter and exclamations. There was an impromptu audience of perhaps a hundred Nepalis (including school children) who were being entertained by monkeys swimming, playing, wrestling and launching themselves from nearby trees into the pool.I don't know how long or how often the monkeys do this but it's worth taking a look if you're up there.

Beware of monkeys. Very interesting place to visit. Pleasant accent by the staircase to the beautiful temple. You are all the time surrounded by monkeys. The monkeys even attacked me when they saw bananas in my hands. They caused no harm but was scary enough I let them take the food :)
Our daughter loved the monkeys!. It's a very holy sight with fantastic views of the city. Go early in the morning before the tours begin.
Loved it... I loved this temple starting with the monkeys as you walk up the steps the eyes watching you all the way. The views across the city were amazing.
Beautiful, peaceful and spiritual. I couldn't find any dislikes about this place. I think this is a must go place when you are in Kathmandu.

Worth a quick stop. You can climb the steps from the bottom level but you would need a real head for heights. The views from here over Kathmandu are excellent but try to go in the morning before the haze decends.

A Unique Temple. Situated on top of a hill, this temple provides a spectacular view of Kathmandu below, framed with hundreds of prayer flags.365 steps take you up to the main area where there are shops and restaurants.Along the way up, there are large groups of monkeys and also many groups of beggars.There is also a monastery at the back which you can enter and view people praying.To get here, we took a 10min taxi from Thamel which costed us 200 Rs on the way there and 300 Rs on the way back. Note, this was during a national holiday where prices are slightly inflated and we still had to negotiate down from 400 - 700 Rs.Entry fee for tourists are 200 Rs but cheaper for visitors from neighbouring countries.A very interesting and unique place to visit for an hour or so.
monkey temple. Holy place, but be aware for the monkeys, they try to steal whatever you hold in your hands and they 're not always friendly

Went there twice. Was fun, the stupa is pretty cool, but just the walk around the area to the monetary and threw all the shops was fun. They were stringing up new prayer Flags. Careful of the monkeys...... Could get a little cheeky, but cool to watch swimming in the monkey pool

Beautiful temple with great views over Kathmandu. We were driven up so I missed walking up the 365 stairs.The temple is beautiful, there is a lot to see and there are charming little shops.Beware of the monkeys, they are cute, but don´t touch them.....

A must in Kathmandu. We visited Swoyambhunath stupa as a part of organized sightseeing tour. The sight is simply wonderful. The stupa is centuries old and it still stands magnificient, in full glory, inspiring visitors even today. A must in Kathmandu for all.

wonderful really awaken place. your visit is wourth.. monuments' architectural style and the view from there. Over htere You can enjoy with monkeys while they are swimming. throwing the coin into the The World Peace Pond and visit saraswati temple etc

Especially Nice with Sunset View. There's no doubt to call this temple as "Monkey Temple"... Really lots of lovely monkeys running & jumping around us. Just feel like they are our neighbour =D
Better go there before evening and catch the sunset. It is really very nice to overlook Kathmandu city with the sunset!

Definitely worth visiting just for the view. I hiked here from Thamel, which only took about 45 minutes. Easy to find, locals will point the way, its the giant hill on the edge of town so it is hard to miss. It is a lot of steps, but it really isn't that bad. The typical tourist wares are up there, along with the stupa, prayer wheels, temple, etc, but nothing you probably haven't already seen a million times in Kathmandu. It is a quick trip, so don't miss it.

If you have the courage to climb the steps. It is a worthwhile effort to climb the steps and go thru the monkeys' toll. Not dangerous but do not bring any food at all. Once on the top the view of the Stupa is amazing. The best place to take pictures of the Buddha on a stupa.

Nice views of the city from here and great if you like to visit temples. Our family has been kind of templed out, but it is on a hill overlooking Kathmandu valley and had beautiful vistas. We liked watching the monkeys too.

nice view for sunset/ lots of monkeys. A giant water tank came crashing down over the edge of the stairs rolling towards my 12 year old son, along with that came dozens of panicstricken, screaming monkeys. Luckily my husband and a monk were able to stop the tank from knocking anyone down the steps. Aside from that, the touts line the walkway to the temple, but once you arrive at the top, they disappear.

Monkey Temple. its ok not my favourite place BUT the VIEWS are worth it You HAVE to walk up the million steps the first time and there is an easier back entrance if you can't manage them Monkeys ewww not my favourite animals but a must see place Buddhist and Hindu traditions blended together

best attraction in Kathmandu. If you only have time for one place, (which I hope is true because Kathmandu is gross and you should get out to Pokhara FAST) visit this temple! It's fairly peaceful and you'll get great photos. Note: we got a private taxi for five hours to take us to all the touristy places for 1,300 rupees total
monkey temple. always a great place to go. it is well worth walking all the way around it on the road below (clockwise I think) once in your life. heavy duty selling to tourists.

Yuck! Filthy, smelly and uninspiring for such an important religious site. It's disappointing how such an important religious site can be allowed, by its users, to be chronically filthy, with dog and monkey feces (often is a diarrheal-looking state) everywhere, locals spitting everywhere and clearing their sinuses on the floor. I also saw a huge dead rat lying out in the open. The shrines themselves were also in very poor repair...and I don't mean intriguingly so, like an Angkor-temple’s poor state of repair, for example...I mean decrepit and junk-looking. Very disappointing.
My favorite!. This is my favorite of the many wonderful temples and attractions in Kathmandu. Great views too - spend at least half a day here if you can.
great view!. the view is beautiful from the temple. we saw lots of monkeys. we spent 2 hrs. great experience! I recommend every one to visit at least once

Monkey temple one of the best. Great temple. Monkeys everywhere. Bit of a trek up to the top but worth it for the view and different parts of the temple to visit. A few tacky shops along the way but what can you expect. I'd say this and the Boudha Stupor are the best temples to visit
Monkey Temple. the hard way to up with this killer stairway hahhha OMG like the rocky movie .... amazing place amazing view of KTM valley must see amazing mystic history.......

Must see while in Kathmandu. It's a great experience and surely a place that you could spend few hours. Great view of the whole Kathmandu valley and big stupa in the middle. Indeed, the temple itself is nothing special inside but outside you have plenty souvenir shops, caffe and a chillout place. There are 2 ways to get there but both of them involve steps climbing... You have to pay for the entrance - about 200 RPS if i remember well.If you want to avoid the crowd come at early morning and avoid weekends. Monkeys can be sometimes tricky but most of the time they are just looking for food and don't care about you or them being photographed. But still most serene and cool place to visit if you ask me :)
Buddhist Temple. A very famous place for Buddhists,called as monkey temple,you can have great view of Kathmandu valley from this place.
Best views of Kathmandu. The temple itself is pretty small, but there are great views of Kathmandu and it's fun to watch the monkeys. I would recommend going on a weekday when the crowds are less.

getting there is half the fun. we grabbed a map and walked from our hotel near Thamel to the Swayambhunath Temple. This afforded us a glimpse of everyday life as the route cuts through residential areas.Loads of loads of steps on the way up to the temple but if you're visiting Nepal in the first place, that shouldn't be a problem.The stupa is ringed with shops for knick knacks and such, so beyond circumambulating the stupa, there isn't THAT much to do.
great views and divine place. Very nice buddhist site and worth a visit. Please beware of monkeysYou also need to walk up number of stairs so may not be one for afternoon heat.
Monkey Temple. Great view of Kathmandu. Good workout walking up to the top. Fun monkey show (wild monkeys, whenever they decide to perform and act like wild monkeys)

Worth the climb. This was one of my favorite attractions in Kathmandu Valley and is definitely a Must see. The climb to the top was both terrible and enjoyable at the same time and I'd reccomend taking the stairs up if you can. I went for sunset and the view of the valley was beautiful.

Best panorama. Because of a strike, we had to go there on foot from Thamel. Took the steep stairs, and got the most breathtaking views of Kathmandu. The place itself has a unique religious atmosphere. A must-see in my opinion!

Beware of the trained monkey. This place is worth visiting. Excellent view of the valley and the temple is well maintained. Rich in history with beautiful sculptures.. Sorry that I have to give a poor rating to raise attention. My friend and I were visiting this place in different days and both of us almost got robbed by a trained monkey while we were taking pictures back down from the top of the stairs. ( the long stairs next to the lookout ) The monkey tried three times to grab my shoulder bag. He was strong and aggressive that I couldn't scare him away until the help of other people.

don't forget the monastary. It may be quite a walk up the hill but its worth it. Easier to get to than Boudhanath but more of a climb. The main stupa has been done up in recent years so is shining like it only does every few decades, though not for long given the air in Katmandu. Great views from the top and you can watch the kites (birds) soaring above the city. Theres an imprisoned saint up here (who you can't see) and a working monastary (which you can) Lots of stalls and it feels less spiritual than Boudhanath as its less used as an actual centre of worship. but well worth a visit if you can face the climb. Not as good restaurants as Boudhanath either!

Swayambhunath. Please don't miss visiting Swayambhunath it is well worth the trek up the 365 steps. I went up early afternoon and spent all afternoon there enjoying the shrines, temples, feeding the monkeys, visiting the numerous traders (I picked up the most amazing Krishna bronze figurine), and enjoying the stunning views. Be sure to take your camera as the sights and people are stunning. Coming down the temple steps as the sun is setting took too long as there were so many photos to clic (especially of the local kids playing). I walked from Thamel which was awesome as I got to see so much more than in a car (just keep asking the locals which way to go they were awesome) but got a taxi back as it was dark by then. I would even visit Swayambhunath again.
Excellent place. Great temple that leaves you spellbound. Place is also well maintained. The entire complex has lot of shops where you can buy shawls, bead necklaces and other curioes
Beautiful. The view of the city up from Swayambhunath is breath-taking specially after a good rain. Also known as monkey temple, monkeys are in abundance there. But none of them try to do any harm.
Best massala chai.. Visiting monkey temple at sunset was beautiful. Go to the tibetan tea room for the best massala chai in Kathmandu!

Beautiful golden dream. Even though it is known as the monkey temple, what struck me the most are the wonderful golden decorations on top of the golden temples as well as the prayer bells. After something of a climb, it all leaves a beautiful memory blurred in photographs and in the mind. One not to miss. Going back soon again.

a must stop for everyone visitng ktm. either hike to the top of the hill from east side or take a vehichle from west side. soak in on the sights, smell and sound. see the hustling bustling valley doen below. a must stop for anyone visiting ktm.

Essential part of Kathmandu. We always visit Swayambhunath and Pashupatinath on the same day, just to contrast the spiritual diversity in Nepal. The entry fees for both have gone up every time we've visited. I recommend the stairs at Swayambhunath, if you have strong legs, good lungs and the ability to contend with beggars. The leg work will give you a taste of trekking if you are headed to the hills. If your legs and lungs aren't in great shape, you can drive almost up to the Stupa from the back gate.There are lots of monkeys and they can be very peaceful if you leave them alone. However, you never know what will provoke a monkey and this last time one of the buggers rushed me simply for taking his photo. Their teeth are quite impressive. (See photo) They are also thieves, especially of shiney things and food. I have not personally been victim of a monkey robbery, but I have seen it happen. These are not pet monkeys. It is best to keep that in mind.This is a deeply spiritual place for some people and it is important to remember that the monks prostrating themselves are worshipping, not offering photo ops. They will pose for you to take a photo sometimes, but please ask before just snapping away. It is the height of rudness to interrupt someone during worship though. There are many opportunities to photograph images of the temple itself, and the pigeons and the monkeys (if you're ready to run).  It is apparently very important to walk to your left when circling the stupa or the prayer wheels. There is a myriad of symbolism here, and unfortunately I do not understand most of it. It would probably take a very long time to understand all of the layers of religion in this one location.
Monkey temple. A tiring climb but wrth it. Beware salespeople along the climb. Beautiful on top. Bring white scarves for monks.

The place has changed in 15 yrs. I've been here twice. 15 yrs aho it was full of monkeys and not many people. Really cool place. Now it is the other way round. And quite commercial.
Take along lots of water. There are many steps to climb and the stalls up there are rip offs

I look a lot older but Swayambhunath looks the same. I have been there 6 times since 1985. It looks the same (I don't of course) but now I am finding the stairs a lot tougher. Watch out for the monkeys because there they rule. Well of course it is unmissable. When I go there next time the next stop will probably be Pashupatinath where I will be the centre of attention as I go up in flames by the river. There is nowhere like Kathmandu- of course it use to be better but its still great. I feel sorry for young people who can never see it as it use to be. I hope I get to this temple again before i die- but i have a feeling i will return in the next life. Can you do a tripadvisor review of the bardo between lives? Now that would be interesting.

Good but beware monkeys & touts. this is a must-do; however, you will be followed up the stairs by beggars, children, homeless women with newborns, touts wanting to sell you singing bowls at a "bargain" price of 2500 rupees! but once you're off the stairs, it's a nice, peaceful place and has great views of the valley

Scenic Views of Kathmandu. Visited Swayambunath Temple on a recent visit to Kathmandu. The temple is one of the better ones in Kathmandu and offers great views of the Kathmandu valley area. The by lanes near the temple offer very interesting art and handicrafts with local artists painting Thangka paintings or doing ancient stone carvings outside their shop. Also, has a few small cafes around to rest after the climb. Beware of the swarm fo monkeys usually loitering around the temple area.

Great Experience. I spent a few hours at Swayambunath because the atmosphere there was wonderful. I chose to walk up the hundreds of steps because the surroundig area was great. When I reached the top I attended a puja and that was a wonderful experience. It's a MUST for all visitors to Kathmandu

"Monkey Temple ". I had occasion to visit twice, once alone and once with my volunteer group. A very nice view of KTM . The temple itself is nice but not as nice as many other Buddhist temples I have visited throughout Asia. The monkeys are an added touch but beware especially of the mothers with babies. I am told that the best time to go is near sunset provided it is a fairly clear day. Since I was here during monsoon, I did not readily have that luxury. Still a must see for any visitor to KTM.

More chaos, less karma. Billed as a Buddhist temple but, given that the Hindu deities sit side by side the Buddhist stupa, this is above all a very Newari place to visit.  Actually, make that a very Kathmandu place to visit because, alongside all of the religiosity crammed into every available inch of space, there's still plenty of room for an overwhelming number of over-stocked trinket shops.  There's a bit of Thamel up here too.And yes, there are plenty of monkeys too (though when we visited most of them seems to be congregated on western approach to the site).Swayambunath is not for the feint hearted.  Even on a quiet day, at least 4 out of 5 senses are completely overloaded as you walk around the site (it would be 5 if you stop for lunch).  As such, it can be a little overwhelming unless you happen to be here for the religious aspects of the location.  And whilst it's great for people watching it doesn't have the scale of Bodhnath.  There might be time for a little self-reflection at the latter; at Swayambunath the only thing you can reflect on is the sea of humanity flooding around you.

Beautiful View and worth the Climb. It's 200 rupees for entry. It's 365 steps to the top. There are a lot of vendors and beggars going up to the top. They will up sell you 4x the price for things at the top. Everything can be bought in Kathmandu for much less. Don't pay 400 rupees for prayer flags at the top. There are also a lot of people that will give you information as you climb then ask if you need a guide or expect a tip. Walk away and don't engage unless you want a guide. Everything is negotiable. It's worth the views at the top of Kathmandu valley. It's so pretty. I highly recommend the trip.

A must visit place of Kathmandu. Swayambhunath temple is on the top list of every travelers coming to Nepal. I am a foreigner living in Kathmandu and I frequently go here to give some peace to my heart. This place is so beautiful, great views of the town and the Stupas there are amazing. The statue of Buddha and other Buddhist gods are amazingly created. Your will see lots of religious people worshiping and wishing to get blessed! Give it a try!
Great atmosphere. Great views from the top of the temple, overlooking Kathmandu. A really beautiful place to visit, lots of colourful holy flags & incense. A great atmosphere.
Beautiful view. Came and returned by foot from Thamel, a 30 minutes walk. Nice view of the city and the location. Very few monkey to see.

monkey temple!. Very nice place to visit. there are a lot of monkeys. From the top of the hill there is a very nice view of Kathmandu. There are buddism and hindu temples inside, so in this place is possible to understand the real concept of nepali spirituality and culture.

Swayambhunath in the 70's. I lived near its base for a couple of months in 1977. It was amazing than. Im thinking about going back. I just saw the map and I can't believe the changes. There were only two little very dark restaurants run by Tibetan Refugees at Swayambhunath. I still remember the door ways were very small and full of greese at the top where people banged their heads. Chillams use to pass around at meals. To go to Kathmandu we use to go through this horrific narrow bridge made of slats of timber and rope. Buffalos use to be killed and chopped up in the streets and everything was sold out by mid morning. At Swayambhunath there were no cars not even seen in the ring Road. Marijuana plants were all around. It was part of the system. I have very fond memories of that place. I remember at the temple seeing amazing holly man all dressed in red with long pure white hair. I wonder how disappointed I will be if I go now. But I did promise myself to return.

Pretty views. We walked to this temple from Thamel in Kathmandu, and it was a nice brisk walk, plus you walk up to the top of the temple and so it's a great exercise. The view of Kathmandu and surrounding area is great!! Very pretty. The temple charges I think 200 Rs to get in, but no one was checking tickets so we managed to just walk right in. Definitely check it out if you have nothing else planned.

Monkey Temple. When we left from hotel our tour guide sait "today we are going to Monkey Temple" i was confuse about what he said "Monkey temple"...... after 30 minutes of bus ride, we arrived and I understood why he said Monkey temple.It is a stupa, one of the oldest temple in Nepal located on the top of the hill. You can see the kathmandu city from the top...... do not forget to visit this place one you are in Nepal.

A peace filled experience. The best thing about the place was that no guides were present here to harrass you with foul history lessons.Its a place above the city ground level and has a magnificient city view. It all started with us trying to put the coins in the mouth of some god on entarance. There were lot of coin vendors exchanging the coins. Then we went upstairs to visit all the temples and stupas which all were awesome. There is a real feeling of peace which somehow was missing in all temples in the city, Heard from lot of people and reviews here before going that there was monkey menace, but all this was flase. There were 1-2 monkeys but not menaceIt also houses some handicraft shops but beware of paying what they ask. Start with 50% and pay upto 60% is the right funda

I HATE MONKEYS. They are nasty, vicious, and will bite you. Rabies shots are not my vacation plans and should not be on yours. Sadly, the monkeys rule so if you go, and you will because every tour includes it, don't carry food and don't offer any to a monkey because "they look so cute" - especially babies because older more aggressive monkeys will attack the baby and then you'll feel really bad. As for the temple, it is ok - nothing to write home about and if it is the view you are going for - go in Oct/Nov - otherwise, the pollution of KTM will block everything else out. HOWEVER - do spend time going down the large staircase and walk the circle at the bottom, it is beautiful and has many side sights that are worth the walk.
Magical, serene...welcoming. This place has something special about it that can only be experienced and not described. A great view of the city though.

Amazing spirits!. The power and history of Swayambhu is incredible and unlike any other energy I have experienced, other than perhaps the most powerful spiritual cleanse I felt during the transmission in June 21, 2011 in the Negev, Israel.

Auspicious Tour. They say that if you visit all three major stupas in Kathmandu that the blessings are multiplied. I started at the Boudhanath Stupa and hopped a taxi with a few friends for 700 rupees. The "monkey temple" and other holy structures and statues made for a great way to spend an afternoon. If you only have a day and want to collect some merit, I would highly recommend visiting Swayambhunath Temple complex.

A Great Buddhis Temple. The Swayambhunath complex consists of a stupa, a variety of shrines and temples, some dating back to the Licchavi period. A Tibetan monastery, museum and library are more recent additions. The stupa has Buddha's eyes and eyebrows painted on. Between them, there is something painted which looks like the nose - but is the Nepali symbol of 'unity', in the main Nepali language dialect[citation needed]. There are also shops, restaurants and hostels. The site has two access points: a long stairway, claimed to have 365 steps, leading directly to the main platform of the temple, which is from the top of the hill to the east; and a car road around the hill from the south leading to the southwest entrance. The first sight on reaching the top of the stairway is the Vajra. Tsultrim Allione describes the experience:
good temple. It was a nice temple. Great view of Kathmandu from here.

The real Paradise on the Earth.. I saw this temple on web and post card, once i've been there found that it is a real paradise on earth. As it has a nice stupas and shrines around the temple. Nest to the temple there is a monastery where number of monks are praying. If you are going to Kathmandu please visit this temple.
Souvenir City. I didn't expect so much souvenirs on the top :)Hahaha...but nice to go and see Kathmandu from the top

Personal favorite of all stupas around Kathmandu. Even if all the other UNESCO sites and stupas around Kathmandu had monkey residents, still 'Swayambu' would be my favorite based on location and relative tranquility as compared to all the other heavily commercialized stupa spots around town.There is a cool upstairs cafe, Nirvana, serving the usual cold drinks at street level prices, so that has to be respected. This was featured in Baraka, however, I wonder why Fricke didn't video the macaques swinging around. Do be aware of their intrepid nature towards humans with any sort of tangible food in hand. Simply put, if you could only visit one stupa, make it this one. It is close enough to the city center, yet towers high above the valley making for a perfect sunset retreat.

Monkey Temple. We were driven to the top so did not have to climb the steep stairs. This holy place is well worth your visit. The view of the city is breathtaking as it sits high on a hill. The monkeys are entertaining as long as you don't show them food. People were friendly and helpful. Having a guide was very helpful to get the full experience.

One of the Holy Place in Nepal. The locals called it the Monkey Temple because of the many monkeys living there. It is a holy place in Nepal and a must-see place for all pilgrims. Lots of stairs to climb, but not wheelchair-friendly. Fantastic view from the top of the temple.Beware of the monkeys. Do not expose any fruits or peanuts. The monkeys will observe from the trees and descend upon you to snatch them from your hands. You can sustain serious scratch marks or injuries from their nails.

I hope you like monkeys. This is a working Buddhist monastery complete with 6 year old monks. The monkeys are startling at first, but then you stop noticing them. The view of Kathmandu is not to be missed. Warning, you need to be able to walk up stairs.

Beautifull place. you should go this place early in the morning and its beautiful .perfect place for getting peace of mind and calm . you need to climb the place where after car drops you .must say a must place to visit if visiting kathmandu

Temple for Buddhists and Hindus. It was fascinating. There were so many things to see. The stupas, the prayer wheels and the temples. It is located up high so you can get wonderful views of Kathmandu. It was beautifully bright and sunny on the day we were there. I was a little disappointed because we didn't see that many of the sacred monkeys. I was also interested in seeing both Buddhists and Hindu worshippers there. I loved the idea that this holy place was one where two religions could come and worship. The only thing that was a little hard was the warm, humid day. I'm afraid I'm a bit of a wimp when it comes to warm, humid weather. Other than that I was very pleased to be able to visit this wonderful site.
Excellent. We enjoyed it all the time. Be aware of the monkeys...if you carry any fruit
The monkey temple. There are some 365 steps up to the temple and as many dogs as monkeys but its worth the walk. Both for the temple itself and the views across Kathmandu

Views of the Valley. The view from Swayambhunath (Monkey) Temple is reason enough to make the 350-odd stair climb to the top. Despite having to negotiation your way through the maze of hawkers selling the usual tourist treats, and pass the occasional group of stray dogs, the temple itself is worth the visit.Walk clock-wise around the main stupah, spinning the prayer wheels, before taking in the breathtaking views of the city. Best on a smog-free day, early or late in the afternoon, it will leave you breathless.Definitely worth the 200rp price tag, be sure to take the rear exit when departing so you get a chance to pass the monkey pool, where the primates gather.

Temple of mystery. All people will tell you that Swayambhuntath, or Swayamba, - this is a magic place. What I dislike - there are a lot of monkeys, and it is not something you can avoid. Be prepared. But, on the other hand, thereWhat I dislike - there is an enormous stairs, just like in all those movies, when you almost have to die to be able to reach the place on the top of the mountain. But, on the other hand, there is a way for the cars, so you can forget about the rules, and just drive there to the top.When you are there, everything is perfect. You just feel free to make your own mind about this place, and do not forget to formulate the request - what do you really want? It is the place to ask for it. It has this power. Two of Stupas in Kathmandyu have. This one is famous on its healing abilities. I was there late in the evening and I still feel like I am there. Somehow.

Monkey Tempel. It is very touristic and the entrance fee is a little bit too much. When you arrive a the bottom of the hill, you see the monkeys who aren't scared of humans. It's more the other way around. You start climbing the stairs and very soon you are passing different buddha statues. When you finally reach the top (the last part is pretty steep and don't forget the altitude of Kathmandu), you are just happy you made it. Just go left onto the terrace and admire the beautiful view of Kathmandu and the Himalaya's. In the middle of the complex there is the stupa. The dome can be full with monkey's. There are different tempels there, Hindu and buddist. There are also little chörten and not a lot of room to walk. Despite of this all and the fact that you can also buy souvenirs at a not so very good price, I strongly recommend a visit. Especially late in the afternoon, when the sunlight isn't that strong anymore. Afterwards walking down again, just walk back to Thamel if you stay there. Otherwise walk till Thamel and take a riksja back to ypur hotel.
Also heritage site. It,s great, heritage site and still lots of work going on inside the place. Need more cleanliness and well signposted

Steep hike!. Get ready for a steep hike! You can walk there from Thamel, the tourist district. The site is very nice, although very crowded. There is food at the top, severl monks, good views, and lots of prayer wheels.

Heritage monument. Good place to see. If the govt. makes this site clean it would attract more visitors. Except cleanliness everything was good. One can see rare art work at this place. One can oversee the Kathmandu city from this place. World peace sign is also part of this monument

excellent. Its a religious place, nice structure. It is in the middle of the town and surrounded with the shops. If you are really interested in Budha culture, you will get many things to buy and understand the culture.

There really are monkeys here. I took the approximately 360 steps to the temple. Although you can take a taxi to the other side of the temple and avoid the steps, it is much more impressive approaching the temple from the steps. At first I saw a single monkey at the base of the steps. But there were many more monkeys near the temple entrance. Not being of the Hindu faith I did not fully appreciate the significance of the temple but seeing the faithful praying in and around the temple was spiritual.

Amazing!. This was one of the high lights of visiting this amazing country. My advise is do not have any food on you because the 'monkey temple' is excatally that, covered in monkeys, they wont bother you unless you have food on you. There was so much to do and see, great views of Kathmandu Valley from the top of the stairs. The cafe was great with friendly and helpful staff. I would highly recommend visiting Swayambhunath Temple!

Nice place for a visit with good views over the valley. At the top of a hill lays this stupa, with about 70 stairs and upward angled pathways leading to the site. There are many smaller religious buildings at the top, but the main one (Swayambhunath) is the largest and grandest. Probably allow about 1-2 hours for a visit (once there), with drinks/snacks and plenty of souvenirs on offer from many sellers - both at the summit and at the base. Some lovely photo opportunities on offer around this religious site, with monkeys freely roaming around.Definitely worth a visit in conjunction with other sites to make for a day trip - eg Bhaktapur town.

Tke your time and explore!. In such a chaotic city the temple offers a little calm. Lots of monkeys everywhere and just ignore the hawkers selling there wares. The steps are the only way to go to get the feel for the temple and the effort to have built it. Lots of things to see and wonder how they did that. Just remember before the last few steps an nice man comes out and tells you it is 200 rupees (2.50 USD or so) to go the rest of the way up. Bring your camera and take your time. At the top is the Stupa with dramatic views of Kathmandu. Be sure to check it out while in Kathmandu. If your trekking and staying in Thamel it is walking distance.
Fantastic. Stop, close your eyes and feel the Spirit that dwells within

Monkey temple. There are so many better places to go in and around Kathmandu literally just strike out (with a bottle of water) and go and explore and you will come across real gems. This place sadly is aimed at tourists with shops and people forcing you to go in them. Just get in and get out!
So much in a small space. A really facinating place with so much to see. Not that many monkeys when we were there though

A must see. Swayambhunath is probably the most popular place to visit in Kathmandyu, for it's immense vantage point over the valley, for the array of stupas and buildings and of course the monkey's. It's a great place to wander around. I went in the evening and it was very busy but there was space to manuoever, and sadly few (although enough) monkeys due to all the people. For someone not familiar with the odd mesh of buddhist/hindu culture it's an ideal place to witness the cultural melting pot. I actually had a driver that took me to the top so I kind of cheated (doing 4 sites in one day), but had the energy to enjoy it. I can also imagine that it is rewarding to reach the top of all those stairs! Although perhaps visit in the morning or evening when it's not so hot!

Time has taken it toll here. What a shame the Temple has been over run with locals selling their wares. We were harrassed going up the stairs, then it was very sad to see all the stalls in among the temples and stupor. Such a sad change to this very beautiful place that dates back to BC era. It seems these changes have only taken place in the past 10 years. Not right for such a sacred and peaceful place.

Amazing. if you are fit you can walk the 365 stairs and you will reach your Nirvana if not you can be driven to the top. If you dont like monkys then this is not the place for you.Tourists call it the Monky Temple. This Temple is steeped in history. Always go around the temple clockwise and be respectful of the people doing their puga.There are shop's for you to buy local artifacts. Places to have a drink and snax'sI recommend you go early in the morning or early evening to see the sun rise or the sunset which can be breathtaking

The best of Kathmandu!. I simply loved it! It's called the monkey temple as well, as there are so many monkeys around the temple. The way up, if you take the stairs on a very hot day might be a bit difficult, but it's deffinitely worth the afford. Must see!
One Time Visit. Very Famous temple, lot of small temples in it. In one temple lot of fire lights seems extremly good. In museum reclining Budha is also availiable.

Swayambhunath. Amazing site -- worth seeing on your adventures! Very busy - beware of people begging and as always in busy areas, make sure you keep your valuable hidden and close to your body. Whenever monkeys are present, never get eye contact with them as they can be aggressive! And again, keep belongings close as they can be sneaky!

Monkey monkey everywhere. I could spend an entire day just wandering around this beautiful sacred place.Take time to make offerings of prayer flags while you're up there and then enjoy a cup of tea while you watch them flutter in the wind.Take a look around the shops that you'll find filled with interesting things mainly from Tibet.

Too crowded. From Thamel it is 20 mins walk to the temple. The walk shows a lot about Kathmandu so we recommend you to walk there. There are a lot of stairs to get to the temple and once you arrive, it's difficult to appreciate the temple because it's too crowded by tourists and also by people using it for prayer. There are many souvenir shops around the temple if you want to buy buddhist souvenirs.
Interesting. A must see in Katmandu but very commercial. Tradition to walk up the steps but at age 70 I was pleased to be able to take taxi up the back way !!!

A beautiful place with lots of monkeys. After the initial climb to the top(there are a lot of stairs), the view of Kathmandu is spectacular from the top.Take your time ambling around the temple and looking through some of the shops nearby, it's a very beautiful, rather tranquil place. Alas when we went over there weren't all that many monkeys as I had expected, just one angry one who snarled when I tried to take his picture.Once you are done with the temple, walk through the village and if you have time to kill head to the National Museum to look at some moon rocks and the skin of a two headed deer.
A mus see. A great place to stroll around and take in the local flavor
Well worth a visit!. Monkey temple is well worth a visit. The views of the Kathmandu Valley from the top - if it's a clear day - are great.
A nice place to see KTM. Nice View, nice temples and good atmosphere.Take care the stairs are step, but it's worthwile.

Haven't you always wanted a monkey?. I was here ~10 years ago and made a return visit in April 2012. My only question is - where are the monkeys? The place was full of monkeys before, there are far fewer now. Still beautiful, definitely a memorable site, but I'm left wondering what happened to all of the little primates.
Worth visiting. has great views of kathmandu, as well as impressive stupas and temples. It was quiet when we went which made for easy viewing.

Head at Sunset!. The best time to visit "monkey temple" is sunset. You'll see monks and monks in training doing nightly prayers. Incense is burning, calming music can be heard in the distance, as well as Buddhist chanting. Make sure to check out the small pool where the monkeys play as well! They're amazingly human like!

One of the highlights of Kathmandu. Swayambhunath stupa is located in the west of Kathmandu. We went there at the end of the afternoon. A great decision. Although the entrance is not attractive, not indicating a sight worth seeing, once you climbed the steep stairs amid the dirt and chaos, you will reach the top of the hill with a very beautiful stupa and surroundings. We shot very nice pictures and wandered around for more than an hour. Really one of the highlights of Kathmandu and also great to escape the noise and chaos of the city.

My least favorite. The temple is impressive, monkeys, snakes encounter on the way up. Great view of KTM, very old temple. Many hawkers selling and people begging. It is very different that other temples. It was very poor and the food offerings started to smell. I am glad I went but happy to leave.

Our favourite stupa in Nepal. Apart from the stupa itself being exceptionally beautiful and having all the naughtly rhesus monkeys running around, the views of Kathmandu from up here is good enough reason to climb the several hundred stairs to get there (you can also drive if you wish but the staircase side is much more beautiful)
Nice place, good view over Kathmandu city. Definitely worth a visit. Great place to have a view over Kathmandu. Many tourists, but also monks and locals, and many interesting things to see.
