Great views. The Monkey temple is a located on a gorgeous hill overlooking the city of Kathmandu. There a plenty of sports and houses on the hill, which you climb to the top on broad stairs. Plenty of tourist trinkets to buy, but also great culture and beautiful picture opportunities.

Well worth the hundreds of steps up to the stupa. I have seen the Buddha eyes of this stupa in pictures for years, but the hike up to the actual stupa and just sitting there in the presence of a truly holy shrine was magnificant. Much to my surprise, there is a small Hindu temple next to the Buddhist stupa and I found both exhilerating to walk around and just sit and enjoy the "vibes." Unless you are a mountain climber or serious trekker, you might select the walkway up on the right side facing the stupa entrance rather than the left where there are only hundreds of steps straight up without shade. The right side has steps, walking space, and a few really good tradesmen working on the sides making beautiful objects. I especially recommend taking a look at the fellow who does really intricate embroidery work at extremely reasonable prices.

Awesome to go before sunrise!. I went up there around 5am and it's the most rewarding experience. The spiritual energy up there is so strong that I feel my heart beating so fast. It's wonderful to see all the locals wake up early to pray and chant together in front of the stupa too. Amazing.
interesting mixture of buddism and hinduism. This is very special place due to mixture of buddism and hinduism. Worth staying for a while.

Nice experience at the top. Its just an ok experience, not very happy to see it but indeed its in a much better situation then other places. Restoration of the heritages is the big time problem in kathmandu1. Must visit place2. Go till the top3. some 300 steep stairs may scare you.4.very divine, amazing feeling to be on the top.5. you can have a look on full kathmandu, and you will realize its not that small town as the impression you had in the town.6. Lot of monkeys and one will be surprised to see that they actually poze in front of camera. I saw first time camera friendly monkeys.7. shops till the top are spoiling the beauty of the heritage big time.8. 50 NPR is the entrance fee for SAARC nationals and 200 NPR for non SAARC.Overall very nice experience must visit place.Over All nice experience.
Interesting. We got a feel of the site's importance visiting it during some big festival.. super-crowded but interesting!

Impressive, though not a lot of monkeys. Many steps to climb (you can come through the back, but then you will not meet monkeys at all!), and in the end - a nice panoramic view over the not-too-clean city of Kathmandu, and an impressive place to walk around for 15-20 minutes. Can be easily reached from the Thamel for R200 ($2.5), 7 minutes taxi drive.

good hike &view. its really good hike to swayambhunath tmple.many stairs to go up.There are so many monkies arround you looking for foods.some times they grave your bag.becarefull with carrying foods.The view from the top is excellent.worth hiking up.so many buddhist temples.

Well worth a visit. Be prepared for a steep climb up over 100 steps and you may need a rest half way up. But it's worth it. At the top there are lots of interesting things to see and a wonderful view over the Kathmandu valley. This is not as peaceful a site as Bodnath, but is still worth a visit all the same.Also be prepared for many salesmen offering you goods at highly inflated prices on the way up and down. My advice is to bargain hard and be prepared to walk away - most of what they are selling can be bought much cheaper in Kathmandu itself.If you have the time and want to see some local life, it is possible to walk to Swayambu from Thamel - takes about 40 minutes, through Dhalko.
Nice and quiet complex. You can spend hours working around, walking distance to the main tourist attractions in Kathmandu
good view of the city. good city view. The ambience was very nice. Especially in the morning you see many locals local people coming to pray .
Very interesting. Also this excursion is very interesting in this old city.Everytime it is amazing what nice parts Kathmandu had

Don't be scared of the monkeys!. I visited Swayambhunath about 3 times a week when I lived in KTM! I'll never get sick of feeding the monkeys here - the trick is to put biscuits in a daypack, and only pull them out one at a time, when not too many monkeys are around. They gently take them out of your hand, or a few who are a little more curious may climb onto your shoulders and try to get into your bag! If they get a little too rough, just move to another area, they're quite territorial so won't follow you too far!There's a great, tiny gallery just behind the stupa as well - the artist is only around 25yrs old, is taught by his father, and does amazing stuff. Bought several water colours from him and he gave me a very fair price as well.Stunning views, great for panoramic shots, especially at sunset.

Monkeys!. So many monkeys roaming around and taking the offering food left behind from the worshipers. The grounds were actually larger than I expected and you can get a great view of Kathmandu at the top. There are a few shops selling art and trinkets. I even spun every prayer wheel we walked past. I would recommend putting this temple on your list of things to see while in Kathmandu.
Many monkeys. Great place to view the City from the top. If you are realy fit you can climb about 300 steps. We took the short cut with about 50

Great Views!. This temple is very iconic of Nepal so its awesome to check out. There are beautiful prayer flags everywhere, you can do some shopping, but the best part is seeing the views of the city. Great spot for photos!

MONKEYS AND A GREAT VIEW. The famous Monkey Temple of Swayambhunath sits on a hill overlooking the city of Kathmandu. The history of this place is awesome, the stories and significance surrounding the various architectural and sculptural works are spellbinding, and the monkeys are to be avoided. Don't miss it whatever you do!
Definite highlight. Early morning to beat the crowds but evening is really nice too.
Swayambu. Worth the climb up many many steps, ward of the dogs and the monkeys and 'guides' and wander among the stupas

nice place. A good view over the whole Kathmandu from the top of the hill. Stupa looks attractive =) but the Vajra bound to a big stone impressed me more. Beware of the monkeys; they can be unexpectedly strong & a little aggressive while trying to steal your friuts & drinks.

wander in a picture perfect cultural capsule. No visit to Kathmandu would be complete without seeing Swaymbhunath. There's a luring, mysterious halo about it. I like those places where roaming aimlessly is the only purpose.

Peace on top of a hill. It was a climb of about 300 stairs but was worth it at the end. If you have been to the Bodnath stupa, its very similar, the only difference is that you get real nice views of the valley since it is located at a height. Worth visiting!!
If you go to one temple in Kathmandu, I suggest this. Mixing great views with an amazing temple, this is a vibrant place to visit in the already lively Kathmandu
Temple visit. Interesting site, great view over the city. Take time and relax with a beer on one of the rooftop restaurants. Negative: all the people who offer to guide you.
Great stop, sweeping views. Climb the 300 steep steps through the wave of worshippers to great views, some trinket shopping.

Great Impression. I loved visiting the Swayambhunath, or Monkey Temple, on my recent trip to Nepal. It was my first temple in the country and it was interesting and visually stunning. The only bummer was that I was really looking forward to seeing hundreds of monkeys, however because I visited right in the middle of the day, most monkeys retrieved to the jungle due to the heat. So...I recommend visiting either in the morning or later afternoon.

The Monkey Temple.. Tourists and taxi drivers know this place as the "monkey temple". Apart from the poverty stricken individuals at the bottom of the stairs, the temple at the top, and the views (if you are blessed with a smog-free day) are very, very good. Don't miss the 'back-side' of the temple, or the western half. There is a working monastery there, huge old growth trees, much more shade, and of course - monkeys. Speaking of monkeys - once you get to the top of the incredibly long stone staircase (which is also patrolled by monkeys looking through trash or just lazing about) you will notice them everywhere. Some of the tourists try to feed them, to lure them in for better pictures - but if you don't want to be doing a midnight trade of $500 USD, over a fence, for the first dose of rabies immunoglobulin, then please do not feed them. They can become aggressive very quickly, and your finger may just look like a snack. They also seem to be irritated when starred at while you are wearing sunglasses. I'm not sure how this works, only that they seem to prefer being able to know what you are looking at.A taxi will always deposit you at the bottom of the main stairs, but it is best to exit the other side and walk a block or two before hailing a taxi - it will be cheaper.

Hey Hey it's the monkey temple. Known locally as the Monkey Temple, not surprisingly given all the monkeys and monks come to think of it. More prayer wheels than you can turn too if you walk around the base of the hill on a morning with the large number of people who get up at around 6 to do just that (clockwise). If you are here in the early morning you will hear laughing yoga and Buddhist trumpets. 200 rupees to get in at the top but the views are great and in the evening you can even see snow-capped mountains to the north of Kathmandu. Well worth a visit.

Buddhist temple. Lots of monkeys all around. Fun for the kids to see. Interesting atmosphere around. They are working on the stairs near the top but just keeping going on up. The temple is past the construction. We have seen many temples over the last few months so can't say this one really stands out above any of them. It's just another temple. Many vendors trying to sell you things.
monkey business. A wonderful view over Kathmandu City and the whole holy life around the Temple is totally mesmerising. Amust see.
Worth a visit. lots of stairs but very moving when you get to top.
excellent view. to go on the top we need to climb more than 300 stairs and we can take the best view of kathmandu valley from there.

Monkey Temple Trip. This is worth the haul up the steep steps (there are other ways up but this is the true way, the Pilgrim's Steps) to be able to expereince the stunning temples and surrounds, as wellas the excllent views over the city of Kathmandu and the valley, to hills and mountains beyond. 200 NRP for tourists. There are shops and stall as well as worhsipeprs and sight seers, and of course, lots of monkeys!
Must see. We have visited there and its on the top of a the city from where u can see the kathmandu city
Monkey temple. My fav temple, you can see th emonkeys living with humans, and ktm valley if the sky is clear

Monkey Temple. The Buddhist temple Swayambhunath is one of Kathmandu’s most populart tourist attractions.
This temple stands on a hilltop (lots of steps) with great views over the city.
Swayambhunath is also known as Monkey Temple due to the resident monkeys.
A very worhtwhile place to visit
Morning glory. Went early morning and enjoyed the beautiful view. Beware the monkey they go after your plastic bags!

amazing place!!!. ...if you can climb up the 395 steps!!!! it's a beautiful temple with a couple of restaurants, one of them with a nice view all over Kathmandu so you can spend some time there. Also a few souvenir shops and some monkeys that don't try to steal your staff like in other places...but too many beggars make the atmasphere rather heavy...

spectacular views. There is a steep climb to the summit (called the Monkey Temple) and the views are lovely. The stupa was busy with people praying but was quite dirty due to the birds and monkeys around the site. There were hawkers and touts everywhere, which made the place less spiritual.
so beautiful place to visit.. As like view natural view tower of Kathmandu city.

Interesting but there are better buddhist places worth visiting. Entrance is fine, what bothers me is that the Buddhist places on the hill top is somewhat too commercialized for my taste. Overall, if you decide to visit you will get great view of the city and don't forget to go inside the monastery at the top.
Buddha. Again a similar place like Boudhanath but it is on height. amazing view of Kathmandu from the hill top.
over-hyped. Too many tourists and vendors although they are not persistent into selling. The view from the top is great but over-crowding takes away the charm.
Amazing. The history is everywhere, well worth a visit and easy to get to

Ready for a 400 steps climb? Well worth it!!. We visited this during a valunteer mission. Our cab dropped us off at the base of the mountain, 400 steps up to the top. But not too onerous and certainly well worth it.Only one problem... This is also called the Monkey temple; but (alas) not a monkey in sight.But, all the same, a very worth while visit with stunning vistas of Kathmandu and temples.
don't forget to to for sunset!. had really nice sunset from this place, becareful with monkeys try to give any food!
Disappointing. Too many people, venders and monkeys! You have a choice to walk up 365 steps or have the driver bring you in closer. The mass of people and venders seemed overwhelming!
Monkey temple of Nepal. Another Buddhist destination of nepal full of Monkeys and its on top of a hill. Another favorite tourist destination.

A must for the tourist's visit.. Swayambhunath can be walked to from Thamel if it isn't too hot, or it is a short ride by taxi. There are wonderful views of the city below, and the temples are alive with devotees. The monkeys are entertaining as well.
Swayambhunath Temple. Another great temple to watch life go by especially in the evenings. It's also has a nice view over the Kathmandu valley.
the best symbol of Nepal. plenty of great view from the top, plenty temples to vist, also posibilty free entrance, if you go from back side.the best

Beautiful place!. If you can manage the steep climb to the top.....you'll get a lovely view of Kathmandu....and there are several tiny shops even though I wouldn't recommend shopping from those because they sell things at three times the price as they would on any ordinary street shop. The temple itself is very peaceful and the monastery next to it is worth a visit. Even from the bottom you can circle the temple with their prayer wheels and take pictures at the entrance where supposedly, Buddha left his footprints.
One of the best. I always come hear at sunrise... Main reason to come is always the same: real feel of the local spiritual life in the early rays of a sun

Holy pick of the world! MUST SEE!. I would call Swayambhunath Temple top sight to visit in Nepal. Just must see - no other option. It is worth to visit it few times during your trip, experience different weather, light, smell, sound, people... Great place to relax even with thousands people around you.Swayambhunath Hill is located approximately 2 km from Thamel and taxi price shouldn't exceed 350 NPR. Entry fee for foreigners is 200 NPR. You can choose steep stairs or other way from the right. Both interesting, but quite demanding. Don't forget to take bottle of water with you.From the top you can experience amazing views over Kathmandu and incredible temple complex with different types of shrines, Swayambhunath Stupa, monasteries, temples, souvenir shops and of course monkeys. They are everywhere and you have to be careful not to lose any of your belongings. I really liked just sit down and watch people around me. It is peaceful oasis in crazy Kathmandu. Do not miss birds (eagles) hunting above the hill.

Great views. We have been here with our guide and very good place to see the view of Kathmandu. If you are taking a tour to Kathmandu, make sure to visit this place on the evening time to see the great sunset view.
Spectacular. Well worth the climb up the long steep staircase. We especially liked the views.

The Monkey Temple. Seated on the highest point in Kathmandu, the Monkey Temple is well worth seeing - I think a trip to Kathmandu would be incomplete without it. I took a cab and paid a few extra rupees to have him take me to the top of the hill and wait for us to finish. We were there about an hour or two. There are many steep steps if you get dropped off at te bottom. There is a fee to enter. There are bathrooms that are marked as free for tourists, but people will try to tell you you have to pay - don't do it! It was crowded when I was there and even at the top, you will have to climb some stairs, but it is worth it. There are tons of shops and peddlers around the Stupa - some with unique items. The most fascinating thing is seeing the monkeys. They are all over the place! You do have to be a little careful because they will try to steal things you are carrying and I heard that if you look them in the eye they could attack - but I didn't see that.

swayambhunath temple. classic piece of buddist culture that is a must see in Kathmandu, can be reached from the main tourist zone by walking but its quite far so renting a bike is a great way to get there and you get to see other bits of the city on the way.

Great views of Kathmandu!. Take the stairs to go up the hill and once you reach the summit the first thing that hits you are the eyes of the buddha! It is an amazing feeling. Rotate the prayer wheels while taking the circle round the temple, play with singing bowls in the trinket stores around, soak in the beautiful views of kathmandu, avoid the monkeys and come back feeling good about the day well spent!

Swayambhunath at aglance.. Swayambhunath is Located on a hill west of the city, this is one of the most important pilgrim centers for the Buddhists who visit this place from far and wide. As one climbs up the 350 odd stairs, one is watched by the watchful eyes of the Buddha. which have been painted on all the four sides of the tower.While some say that these eyes are part of complex Tantric symbolism, others say that they are there to keep a benign eye on the faithful so that no harm comes to them.whatever be the reason, the fact remains that these eyes leave a lasting impression on the visitors. There are some 211 prayer mills surrounding the stupa. One striking features of the Swayambhunath Stupa is that it is surrounded by five Tathagathas, who are also referred to as Dhyanbuddhas, representing the five elements - earth, water, fire, wind and ether-of the cosmos. They are shown riding different animals.Akshobhya is shown on the elephant, Vajrocana on lion, Ratnasambhav on a horse, Amytabha riding peacock and Amoghasiddhi is seated on heavenly bird Garud.

Spiritual place. The moment we reached the top of the hill, it started to rain like crazy, so we had to spend there 2 hours we like it or not... And I could feel that atmosphere there, like all that rain was on purpose - to make us stay there and understand the spirit of this place. I had opportunity to check every detail... beautiful curving, colourful clothes, rituals, architecture... Don't be in a hurry, visit small buddhist temple and also budhist school for boys.
Must see!. A true world treasure. Dont miss this one if you travel to Nepal!
Monkey Temple. Don't go in the way of those monkeys at Swayambhu!!Keep your bananas in your backpack.

Interesting. We visited Swayambhunath Temple towards the end of our stay in Kathmandu and maybe our expectations were high and I must confess to being a little disappointed if I compare it to Bodnath or Pashupatinath. There are just far to many souvenir stalls all over the place that detract from the temple itself. The views I am sure were spectacular many years ago but as Kathmandu has developed you mostly see a sprawling city which in itself is quite interesting.There are two ways to get there, the first is up the longest steepest steps I have encountered in many years and my legs were like jelly when I had completed the trek. I would recommend driving up and the shortish walk to the top which still has plenty of steps.We went at around 11am, I am told it is much better to visit at dusk or early evening when the bulk of the street sellers have departed and the temple returns to it's sacred self. When we return to Kathmandu we will revisit in the evening and hope we have a more enjoyable experience.
Monkeys are great!. The monkeys are just great to see and feel them by heart. It is the real place to see the view of Kathmandu..
The Eye's Have It.. You must see the Swayambhunath Temple. It appears as though Buddah was looking into your very soul

Not to be missed!. A beautiful view on a hilltop overlooking Kathmandu. Beautiful temple plus entertaining monkeys roaming around. It doesn't take too long to explore the area if you arrive by car, but if you decide to walk up the hill to the temple you are in for a true workout!!

Best Sunset View over Kathmandu. If you're staying in Thamel area it's a bit of a walk (30mins) to get to the base of the hill and I believe it costs approx 200 rupees. Its a very popular spot so there will be lots of tourists, also keep an eye out for pickpocketers. There are many monkeys which make part of the experience but don't bring out snacks, they're brave! Its a very nice view over the city at sunset with great light and colours that come over the valley. Must see if you're in Kathmandu.

Interesting!. We climbed to the top passing monkeys as we went. At the top we had a great view of the city as we walked around the stupa with the spinning prayer wheels. There is one special shrine where mothers make special requests for the health of their children. Vendors sell everything needed for your visit as monkeys frolic all over the site.
Monkey!. I never see monkey in my life, so it was an amazing experience. Hike up to the temple from eastern part of the temple is very tough even it is short walk. really enjoyed it a lot.

Beautiful at sunset. Such a beautiful, spiritual place. I went at sunset and it was so peaceful yet there was this pulse that just can't be described. Swayambhunath offers the most wonderful tours over Kathmandu. The Tibetan prayer flags float in the breeze and the monkeys give you a real laugh. There is even a monkey swimming pool where you can watch them do Tarzan-esque tricks!

Quite possibly my favourite Kathmandu attraction. I lived in Kathmandu for 6 months and visited this place three times during my stay. I really appreciated the area as it was quieter compared to most of the city, and there are many trees as you walk up the pathway toward the Stupa. That being said, there is a bit of a climb, so wear comfortable footwear. If you enter through the main entrance, the cost is 200 NPR per person (that is less than $3.00 Canadian). There are also some restaurants that are open until 6 pm or later. I went here for dinner after dark with two friends and it was by far the best time to go in my opinion. There were very few people there and a group of monks was chanting and with the burning incense it felt like we had gone back in time. The Stupa was lit up, as you can see in the photo. Dinner was good and well-priced (I wish I could remember the name of the restaurant), and we had a view of the city.I would definitely recommend visiting Swayambhunath either in the early morning (6-8 am), or later in the evening (5-7 pm). That way you are more likely to avoid crowds and the heat. Also, there are two entrances, one of which takes longer to hike from, but is a pleasant walk. Allot a minimum of 2.5-3 hours of your day to visit, keeping in mind that the climb up the stairs may take extra time. From personal experience, be careful around the monkeys, if you are eating a snack they will not hesitate to grab it out of your hands!

Still a 5-star attraction. Still a 5-star attraction for its historical/cultural and religious signficance. Beautiful architecture and interesting activities going on a the temple grounds, however tourists should be careful about the sensibilities of the locals. Many stalls in the surrounding area atop the hill selling paintings, memorabilia, etc. Some items maybe interesting so be a good cheerful haggler. However, I think the management should be careful that commercialization will not spoil this place. A must see for every tourist visiting Kathmandu. Be careful though about the monkeys that roam freely in the area, do not go too near and avoid feeding them.

Astonishing Stupa. I can not believe I could see this place! It is really astonishing place that when I reached the Stupa after passing too many stairs, I cried about 15 mins!!! The atmosphere is calm and full of ring sound that people praying there.I bought one Tibet music CD from there- that can hear all over the Swayambhunath - for remain and bring all that good feeling.

feel the pristine touch of all seeing eyes. Swayambhunath as the name suggests , self originated god who appeared in a lotus amidst a lake , which later converted to Kathmandu valley , when Manjushree a monk drained out the lake water with his sword at Choubar gorge and made it habitable . The temple is situated in a hillock with steps leading to different temples in the premises . We can see a large Bajra in front of the temple , mini wheels surrounding every stupa , Rudrakhya trees ,a sacred tank with crystal clear water and monkeys everywhere . The top of the temple offers a great scenery of whole Kathmandu city .The steps are steep ,and we can feel the pristine touch of all seeing eyes as we proceed through these steps .We can also visit Choubar gorge (Choubar Ganesh) , Sesha Narayan along the way from Kathmandu to Dakhin kali . They are in the same route .

Swayambhunath:- the Self-originated God. This stupa is considered to be one of the most sacred stupa for the buddhists and is among the greatest stupas in the world. According to the legend, kathmandu valley was a big lake and there was a lotus in the middle from which the beam of lights were coming out...later, the water drained off and the lotus was found on a hilltop which is supposed to be the swayambhunath.....both hindus and buddhists consider this temple very sacred. You can see temple and stupa in the same premises. The Vajra (thunderbolt) offered by the hindu king Pratap Malla hundreds of years before can be seen still. We climbed up hill through the road and climbing the flights of stairs....no sooner we were there we felt a kind of peace and holiness.....there were two white temples each side of the stupa but one was destroyed by the ;lightening last year...these temple was also built by Pratap malla with the tantric methods. The temple is being renovated now......the view of the valley from here looks very beautiful.....there is a small museum regarding to Buddha....the monkeys are one of the major 'attractions' for tourists but beware DO NOT HOLD BAGS IN YOUR HANDS otherwise they can snatch it for food....there are plenty of souvenir shops but I think it is wise to buy outside unless you get good bargain....A must while in Kathmandu

Monkey Temple. Swyambhunath temple is also known as monkey temple among the tourists. I guess it is because of the bunch of monkeys surrounding the stupa. Situated at the top at the edge of Kathmandu valley is best spot to see Kathmandu valley. You only realize the ugly part of Kathmandu while you are in Monkey temple.If you are not physically fit you can reach there by vehicle using the road on the other side. Don't forget to bring some biscuits for monkeys, it is worth seeing monkeys eating/playing/crawling.

Monkey Heaven or Hell--You Decide.. Swayambhunath is really impressive, but not for the reasons you may think. The devoted come here to give puja (offerings) to Buddha and various Hindu gods, most likely Shiva or Ganesh. It's very humbling to see devout and elderly Nepalis climbing the 300+ stairs to be a good Hindu or Buddhist at the top. It's interesting how Swayambhunath, like Nepal, mixes the two major religions. For me, the most enjoyable aspect of the temple was the horde of macaque monkeys running around and creating havoc. It's true; there's an entire gang of at least 50 of them that roam the top, usually feasting on trash people throw over the side. You can see them stealing french fries or marigolds, grooming each other, or getting into a blur of a nasty fight. Respect their power as they are not afraid of people and if provoked can and will bite. Monkey teeth are very sharp!! I could sit for hours watching their behavior, but I settled on 20 minutes.

Never explored the temple. Mesmerized by monkeys!. I could have spent hours just watching the monkeys. It didn't occur to me that I would be so CLOSE to them. Just sitting on a bench watching them sitting next to me, grooming each other, interacting with each other. I felt like I was in a NatGeo documentary. THEY WILL STEAL FOOD FROM YOUR HANDS, so be careful. Knowing this, my friend tried to eat her granola bar before passing the ticket booth. Too late. A monkey snuck up and "mugged" her, running off with her food! Rather than try to feed them where they were grouped (which gives you a close up view of the hierarchical fighting over food) we walked down the steps through the park and fed some monkeys (with healthy snacks!). They were not at all aggressive. We sat and hung out with them for quite some time until they bored of us. We must have taken the wrong turn to go out as we ended up at the Three Buddhas temple, which was amazing...

An essence of Rich Mythological history of Nepal. Swayambhunath Temple or Stupa is an ancient religious complex atop a hill in the Kathmandu Valley. This Temple serves as a pilgrimage and tourism option for both Hindus and Buddhists from all over the world.The Stupa sits atop a hillock which is fabled to have sprung up all by itself thus giving it the name of Swayambhunath. For the mythological details please do a more elaborate search on the same and sure would be enlightened. There are two entry points. One goes up through some 365 stairs, and the other is a car lane which leads straight up to one of the gates of the temple. You can enjoy 360 degree view of the Kathmandu valley from this hilltop temple. There are various other old architectural relics at this site, some are libraries and others are scattered temples. If you are a photography enthusiast this place gives you plenty of options for good clicks. There are shops selling very good items / souvenirs and breathtaking paintings.The main stupa with its prayer flags fluttering in the air and chants of 'Om Mani Padme hum' being slowly played via hidden speakers add to the serenity and divinity of this enchanting place.

They don't call it the Monkey Temple for nothing.. World Heritage site. 'Nuff said, really. Just be prepared for the steep climb up the 360 stairs! Otherwise, there is a 'back' way up.Needless to say, the monkeys are everywhere, as are the dogs.Ignore all the little tourist shops that ring the stupa.

very nice place. If ever you get to Kathmandu, never pass this place. Although it is hard to climb all the 500 steps to the temple, it is worth it. You woll find a very impressive stupa and I recommend a kora around it. It is a fine spiritual experience. And please, give something to the holy monkeys.

Must see- have been twice. I have been here twice and the experiences have been slightly different each time. The first time the monkey's must've been hiding in the shade because of the heat, but the second time they were out in droves and decided to get into a nasty fight while we were there. We did have kids in our group and had to pick up the kids for fear of the monkeys coming out way.Aside from the monkey's this is definitely an important cultural experience if you want to learn more about Nepalese and Tibetans. You will see a mix of both Tibetan and Hindu religious practices as they exist right next to each other at the top. On clear days, you have a beautiful view of the city. I suspect it's not uncommon for taxis and tour guides to take you to the top parking lot of the area, but if you have the physical stamina I recommend walking from the bottom or down from the top so you get to see the whole place.

The oldest Buddhist temple in Nepal. This was our first visit in Nepal and on a clear beautiful day it was just as beautiful. Our guide took us right up to the entrance where there were just a few steps to walk. I would have preferred to walk up all the way from the bottom - about 400 steps- and wished I had done that. By the time we arrived it was late evening and the plentiful monkeys that were supposed to be there were not around. However, you get great views from the top. I enjoyed the ambiance here more than at Boudinath, which is supposed te be the largest stupa....

A must visit for religious people as well as nature lovers. Me, my wife and a couple of friends recently visited this place on 9th August 2011. It is said to be about 2000 years old and considered as one of the holiest place for Buddhists who visit in large numbers on major festivals like Buddha Purnima. It is one of the most visited tourist attraction in Kathmandu. It is located on a very high hill from where breathtaking views of Kathmandu are visible. The temple has two entrances. Best is that vehicle drops you on the backside of hill at a height. From there you reach the top of temple after covering steps. On downward journey one can go by steps as it seemed much easier.Entrance fee for Indians is 50 Nepali rupees, it is more for foreigners.There are lots of monkeys but normally they don't snatch your belongings and are comparatively of peaceful nature .Once u reach the top, you are greeted by fresh air and colorful prayer flags. You find impressive stupa with golden dome, lot of small temples, museum and lot of prayer wheels (always rotate them clockwise). Beware of fake handicrafts. There are lot of small shops.In nutshell, if you have not seen SWAYAMBHUNATH TEMPLE in Kathmandu, you have really missed a beautiful religious place. It is a must visit site.

GREAT views of the Kathmandu Valley. We visited the Swayambhunath Temple on our first morning in Kathmandu. Though the temple is certainly interesting, if you have been to Tibet previously you will be disappointed. It was a lovely day when we visited, and the location of the temple offers a fantastic view over the Kathmandu Valley. The Swayambhunath Temple is not called the ‘monkey temple’ for nothing, with monkeys competing with humans for the best vantage point. The taxi dropped us at the main entrance – in hindsight we would have preferred to walk the long flight of stairs from the bottom – so bear this in mind. There are many vendors offering all sorts of Nepalese handicrafts, and some can be quite insistent – one even followed us when we expressed initial interest in a painting and then decided against it.Upon making your way up the stairs, in a clockwise manner of course, you are greeted by fresh air, numerous prayer flags and a most interesting historical site. The temple is worth the Rs 200 (around USD 2.70) per person to enter, as a fascinating introduction to the culture of Nepal. You should expect to spend around two to three hours at the Swayambhunath Temple to gain a full appreciation of the site.

Watch out for the monkeys!. Large temple complex with shrines to both Hindu & Buddist sects. Good views over Kathmandu as it's on one of the highest accesable points in the area. Many shrines/temples, all very colourfull. This is known as the monkey temple for the large numbers of them that surround and swarm over everything here. They are very accoustomed to humans and don't have any hesitation in running up to someone to take any kind of food directly from peoples hands, usually when they are least expecting it! Either don't be tempted to eat here or be very carefull, they can be dangerous and there are over a thousand. Entrance fee 200 Rupees

Really nice recreational attraction in Kathmandu. The Swaybhunath stupa located atop the hill in Kathmandu offers really good view of Kathmandu valley. I really enjoy it going out of hustle and bustle of Kathmandu city and pollution, really superb place. I avoid the stairs and use the road on backside. Looking forward to visit again on my second visit.

Swayambunath Stupa, Kathmandu, Nepal, is AMAZING!. Swayambhunath Stupa is the most ancient and enigmatic of all the holy shrines in Kathmandu valley. A must see if you are ever in Kathmandu. Arriving at the foot of the Swayambhunath, there is a long flights of stairs leading. Take your time to climb and enjoy some old statues of Buddhas and Sanskrit words, motifs, carvings that line along the side of the stairs. Just don't feed the monkeys that make this place their home.Don't give up on climbing the stairs. Many more elderly Nepalis people consider climbing the stairs as a form of pilgrimage. After the 365 steps that lead up the hill, you will pass the gilded Vajra (Tibetan: Dorje) and two lions guarding the entrance. The Swayambunath Stupa is impressive as you look at it. On each of the four sides of thestupa there are a pair of big eyes. These eyes are symbolic of God's all-seeing perspective to the four corners of the world. There is no nose between the eyes but rather a representation of the number one in the Nepali alphabet. This represent the single way to enlightenment is through the Buddhist path. Above each pair of eyes is another eye, the third eye, signifying the wisdom of looking within. No ears are shown because it is said the Buddha is not interested in hearing prayers in praise of him.The area surrounding the stupa is filled with chaityas, temples, painted images of deities and numerous other religious objects. There are many small shrines with statues of Tantric and shamanistic deities, prayer wheels. We were lucky to be there during the Nepali National Day, a public holiday. The place was crowded with people worshiping and making offerings, a photographer's treasure trove.We spent approximately 2-3 hours photographing and enjoying the view. Unfortunately, the view of Kathmandu valley, from the top of Swayambunath, was not the best on the day were were day.Enjoy my sample photos.PS. You will need a good pair of comfortable walking shoes and bring some water along

Don' t miss it !!!. I visited SwayambhunathStupa , in late September 2010, with my wife. The whole scenery was absolutely great . The sound of the colourful praying flags , waving in the air , made the atmosphere even more astonishing. This Stupa was more impressive than Buddhanath , and the way to the top was full of little shopsand small temples, yet everything was so relaxing . The view all over Kathmandu was breathtaking and if you are lucky enough, you can have a good view of the mountains which surround the capitail city of Nepal. The monkeys , if you pay attention, are not a problem . there is also a small monastery by the Stupa , where we were lucky enough to watch a couple of monks praying with a traditional drum .If your programme doesn't include a visit to Swayambhunath Temple, you' ll have missed the most beautiful temple of Kathmandu .

Swayambunath Stupa 'Monkey Temple' near Kathmandu. In my opinion one of the highlights of any visit to Kathmandu, this is a must-do half day trip. Lying to the north-west of the city, high on a hill overlooking the city, the Swayambunath complex is an ancient, sacred Buddhist pilgrimage site. The entrance stairway of 365 steps flutters with colourful prayer flags and the famous temple monkeys can be seen running around all over. The complex consists of a central stupa, several temples, shrines and a more modern tibetan monastery. Huge, mysterious buddhas eyes on top of the dome stare out knowingly over the Kathmandu valley and above this thirteen golden pinnacles symbolise the thirteen stages of enlightenment sensient beings have to go to reach Buddhahood.Swayambunath is not just an ancient religious site but an active, living one with pilgrims performing clockwise circumambulations around the stupas. The continual soft chanting of 'om mani padme hum' and the smell of incense and yak butter lamps create a magical atmosphere in the early morning. There is plenty to walk round and you may like some time to soak up the views so a half day is probably about the right amount of time. A rich cultural experience not to be missed.
